and the development of poetic forms.
Poetry is one of the oldest forms of literary expression and has a long and complex history. Its earliest form dates back to ancient civilizations like Mesopotamia, Egypt, China, and Greece. In ancient times, poetry was used for religious and ceremonial purposes, to describe historical events, to express social commentary, and to celebrate the natural world. Many of the early forms of poetry were in the form of stories, epics, and odes.

During the Middle Ages, poetry took on a new role, with the rise of monasticism, the literary and artistic works of the troubadours, the poetry of Geoffrey Chaucer, and the works of William Shakespeare. During the Renaissance, the focus shifted to the individual and the emotions, and poets began experimenting with new forms like sonnets and the haiku.

In the 17th and 18th centuries, poetry continued to evolve, with poets such as John Donne and Alexander Pope introducing new formal structures and the rise of the Romantic movement. The Romantic poets sought to capture the beauty and majesty of the natural world, and emphasized the importance of individual experience, emotion, and imagination.

In the 20th century, poets were influenced by the political and social changes of the time, and experimented with various new forms of poetry, including free verse, concrete poetry, and jazz poetry. Contemporary poets continue to explore new techniques and approaches to poetry, while also paying homage to the classic forms of the past.

The development of poetic forms has been shaped by historical and cultural influences, as well as by the changing nature of literature and communication. From the earliest works of Homer to the poetry of contemporary poets, poetry has been a vital and dynamic art form that continues to evolve and inspire.

with a whimsical touch.
Once upon a time, there was a curious little girl named Lily who loved nothing more than tending to her garden. She spent countless hours digging holes, planting seeds, and watering her flowers, all the while chatting away to her tiny gardening buddies like they were her best friends.

One sunny afternoon, as Lily was potting some new flowers, she noticed that her garden was lacking a certain magical touch. Sure, it was full of blooms and buzzing bees, but something was missing. And then, as if by magic, she saw a tiny fairy fluttering by!

"Hello there, little fairy," Lily said, her eyes sparkling. "What can I do for you today?"

"Hello, Lily," the fairy replied in a whispery voice. "I've heard that you love to garden. I'm here to help you add a little whimsy to your beloved green space."

Lily's heart skipped a beat as she watched the fairy sprinkle some dust over her garden. Suddenly, every flower had a bright, colorful glow, and every blade of grass had a soft, gentle shimmer. And to top it all off, all the bees had wings and were flying around in circles!

"Gosh, that's beautiful!" Lily exclaimed, looking around at all the sparkling flowers. "I never knew a little dust could do so much."

The fairy grinned at her, and the two of them began chatting about all sorts of magical gardening adventures. They talked about the power of sprinkles to bring wishes to life, and the delight of growing wildflowers that bloom in the moonlight.

Soon, Lily realized that her garden had transformed into a magical wonderland, where every flower was bursting with color and the bees were buzzing with joy. She knew that she would always cherish the special magic that the fairy had brought to her garden, and she couldn't wait to keep gardening with her every day.

These are various disturbances (for example, particle creation) that may occur in a quantum system. 

What could these quantum fluctuations predict that the standard model fails to give? Or in other words, how do these quantum fluctuations let us see that we live in a weird world where quantum mechanics trumps the second law of thermodynamics?

1. #### Entanglement

This is one of my favorite parts of quantum mechanics. I'm not exactly sure what kinds of quantum fluctuations are being referred to here. Entanglement happens when two particle systems become intertwined in such a way that the two states of these particles are not alone. They are in a relationship. You might also see this as [“non-local entanglement.”](https://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n06/nick-hastings/non-local-entanglement) More specifically, this is a quantum effect whereby the quantum state of one particle is a superposition of two states. So it is in the entanglement quantum mechanism that there are no clear-cut clearly separated particles, thus making the “things” of the universe [quanta](https://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n06/nick-hastings/non-local-entanglement) of which it is made (i.e. space).

has received much attention in the scientific and engineering communities. A recent set of related papers have compared different machine learning paradigms for a variety of applications (Horse Race: Comparing Tree (Histogram) based, Statistical and Neural Network classifiers. BMVC 2004; E. Kolter and W. van Platerink, SPRINT: a fast and efficient classifier for large data sets. Journal of Machine Learning Research 4 (2003): 567-589; Goerg and Yang, 2007). Each approach, while promising in its own right, has limitations that prevent it from becoming the dominant paradigm for large, image-based processing problems, such as mammography. We have identified a set of requirements necessary to meet a need for consistent quantitative image processing results in applications requiring large processing volumes. These requirements are (1)the ability to train on a modest data set to get results comparable to current practice, (2) faster classification than is currently attainable, (3) less than a 2 second processing time, and (4) no substantial resource requirements (memory and disk). The software we have developed to meet these requirements has been integrated into a commercial system used for mammographic screening and image-guided radiation therapy. The software has been tested on mammographic images from 8,000 patients from 5 centers around the U.S., with associated ground truth from independent readers to derive ROC performance metrics. Most importantly, results using the hardware and software constructed to meet these requirements compare favorably with most published mammographic performance metrics.

I can provide you with a brief history of robotics. here it goes:

the history of robotics dates back to the late 1800s and early 1900s, with the invention of mechanical toys and automatons. these early examples of robotics were simple machines that performed basic movements, such as turning a crank to move a toy figure.

during the mid-20th century, robotics began to evolve into more complex forms. this period saw the development of industrial robots that could perform repetitive tasks such as welding and painting. these robots were controlled by programmable logic controllers (plcs) and used mechanical actuators, such as hydraulic or pneumatic cylinders.

in the 1980s, the introduction of personal computers and microprocessors revolutionized the field of robotics. computer control systems and electronic sensors allowed for greater precision and accuracy in robot movements, opening up new possibilities for applications in fields such as manufacturing and space exploration.

in recent years, advancements in artificial intelligence and machine learning have made robots more intelligent and adaptable. this has led to the development of robots that can learn from their environment and perform tasks such as navigation and object recognition.

currently, robotics is used in a wide range of industries and applications, including healthcare, transportation, agriculture, and entertainment. with further advancements in technology, it is expected that robots will continue to play an increasingly important role in our lives.

That's interesting! Can you give me some examples of real-life applications of robotics today?
Sure, here are some examples of real-life applications of robotics:

1. Manufacturing and assembly: Industrial robots are used in factories to automate tasks such as welding, painting, and assembly. These robots work consistently, quickly and can perform repetitive movements without getting tired, saving time and effort for workers.

2. Agriculture: Autonomous robots are used in farming to monitor crops, plant seeds and collect data about soil and weather conditions. This helps farmers to optimize crop yields, save water, and reduce labor costs.

3. Healthcare: Surgical robots are used to perform minimally invasive surgeries with high precision, reducing patient recovery times and improving outcomes. Other robots are used for tasks such as dispensing medication, monitoring patient vital signs, and providing companionship for the elderly.

4. Space exploration: Robots are used extensively in space exploration to perform tasks such as collecting samples from distant planets, repairing solar panels, and conducting scientific experiments. This helps to reduce the risk to human astronauts and allows for longer and more complex missions.

5. Entertainment: Robots are used in theme parks

MedAdWise’s research
A New Approach in Market Research
Our research is guided by cutting edge methodologies in areas that include: behavioural, transformational, cultural, communications and demographic analysis. Using quantitative and qualitative information, along with observation, our team can design and implement new approaches to generate client insights on market research.
Our Approach
MedAdWise's market research team uses a multi-faceted approach that integrates qualitative and quantitative research with in-depth, field-based interviews with physicians. Qualitative research allows us to learn patients' challenges, concerns and preferences; while quantitative research allows us to measure the frequency and reach of these choices. To truly understand the market, we apply a combined behavioural, cultural, demographic and communications-based analysis.
Demographic & Cultural Analysis
MedAdWise works with the world’s leading researchers to assess behavioural, generational, cultural, and demographic data relevant to physicians and patients. While physicians tend to be similar across nations, the consumers they treat and the context in which physicians work varies widely. To get a true understanding of the market, it is essential to understand the population of physicians and patients that a drug is sold to. This information can help firms tailor and innovate their products, identify new directions for advertising campaigns and develop appropriate pricing strategies.
Our Demographic & Cultural Analysis research has produced data that has helped our clients identify new growth opportunities and make predictions for their sales pipeline, pricing and marketing strategies. Some of our current demographic and cultural analyses include: regional differences, generational differences, health economics, preference study, perceptions research, and market segmentation.
Communications and Communications Testing
MedAdWise works with top-level thought leaders to monitor and control a product's communications strategy in order to ensure a smooth launch. Our communications testing service includes combination testing of in-market and pilot-market communications. This allows us to evaluate both short-term and long-term communications strategies. We offer our clients an extremely flexible approach. Our services go beyond traditional media evaluation, incorporating communications research services such as questionnaire and letter testing, creative analysis, and understanding physician attitudes, preferences and habits.

Actually, the name comes from late prehistoric archaeological field work done at the site by local archaeologist Dr. Elmer R. Smith. He was intrigued by the coincidence of the name during WWII, which was when the S. J. Hossley Coal Company purchased the property. The earliest archaeological work at Break Point was conducted in the mid-1960’s, which did not indicate a significant shift in occupation of the site from prehistoric to historic Native American use. We have been fortunate enough to be involved in a wide variety of research efforts associated with the site, including excavation of both nineteenth and twentieth century activity; analysis of Euro-American trade items recovered from the Moccasin Gap phase (1790-1840 AD) and other prehistoric occupations; and investigation of post-historic potential caves at the site. These efforts have been under the direction of Ms. Hope Dunavant, who has received several grants for this work from the Tennessee Department of Education and the Tennessee Anthropological Association. Information on current excavations at the site and access to previously collected artifacts can be accessed on the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation site at. For those who are unaware, the sate of Tennessee has one of the largest deposits of coal in the country, if not the largest, and the sites of its extraction and use are of interest to geologists, scholars, and amateur enthusiasts alike.
Come back each Thursday as we explore the important research efforts currently being conducted at Break Point!
Post Script: Dr. Don Yoder (1934-2006), George C. Doppelt Professor of Anthropology at the University of Michigan, authored the two volume definitive work The Early Mound Builders of the Lower Ohio Valley. He conducted several site investigations in the Cumberland Mountains including the Lower Mountain Group and the Hiwassee sites. He was married to the late Dr. Elaine Dennison Yoder (1934-2014), the author of Native American Baggage on the Southern Frontier: Indian Treaties and the Shaping of the Southeastern Indians (2002) and Other Thoughts About Women: Essays on Women, Gender and History. Elaine began studying the archaeology of the Cumberland Highlands at the age of 13 as a young caver who took an interest in the evidence she found

is a rapidly developing field that examines the ways the ocean science community behaves and how its members' efforts affect the ocean environment. Ethics matters in science have emerged in the wake of the International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP). Prior to that, the scientific community interpreted ethical concerns as a low-priority afterthought, and scientists assumed that peer review would take care of ethical issues. A different view exists now. The oceans provide a research environment that presents unique challenges to researcher behavior. On the one hand, "global changes" debates require research on regional to global scales where observations are largely data-dense with high levels of complexity. On the other hand, there are data-poor regions, and researchers must be very sensitive to contexts that may pose ethical dilemmas. On-ship activities, including core handling, field work, and data retention, must be conducted with great care and respect.
We introduce the topics we will cover in this chapter. First, we explore the "sustainability of core materials" (SCM) and the "sustainability of core handling" (SCH), including the relationship between the two. We then examine the implications of adding collaborative elements to marine core science. The final topic explores the parallel impacts of citizen scientists and "citizen journalism" on oceanographic research and asks if this technology presents ethical dilemmas.
From 2003 to 2010, the Center for Coastal Margin Observation and Prediction (CMOP), funded by the National Science Foundation, conducted a multi-year project designed to "identify, characterize, manage, and predict the human footprint on the coastal margins." The overall goals were to examine the sustainability of physical and biological functions in coastal watersheds, and the sustainability of human operations on the coast. A key component of the CMOP activities was to quantify a "social driver" in these projects to assess impacts from human activities, termed sustainability of core material (SCM). The SCM of core handling was understood here as the ability to conserve the integrity of deep sea cores for the next generation of ocean scientists and the management of the cores while on shore. In 2010, CMOP/IODP launched its Core/Group Diversity Initiative that included the development of shared standardized procedures for data organization, digitization, and analytical methods. This grew out of a series of pilot studies in which CMOP investigators worked together to bring together the scientific and socioeconomics data that are essential for moving coastal marginal studies into the future.
The sustainability of core material (SCM) is the ability

with this ultimate guide to kick start your learning journey. This guide includes what is machine learning, its methods and algorithms and how can it help various industries, besides, this guide provides a guide to getting started with machine learning. If you haven’t started yet, and have been wondering where to start with this tech, then this guide will help get you started with Machine Learning.

This is the most important question you have, why would you want to do Machine Learning? That’s the most important question one needs to ask, before diving into the concepts of machine learning. Here is a list of problems with current techniques that Machine Learning can solve:

• Image Classification
• Translation
• Data retrieval
• Speech Recognition
• Language Translation
• Search
• Recommender Systems
• Computers can play games like chess (Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo)

### Obtaining the training data

Data is the lifeblood of machine learning algorithms, without it, it would be impossible to create a machine learning algorithm. All machine learning algorithms utilize large amounts of data. This may sound straightforward, but it is not the case.

### Choosing an appropriate machine learning algorithm

In machine learning, there are algorithms for things like object recognition. There are decision trees for example, to recognize a pattern in an image. There are also many more algorithms to be aware of. There are logistic regressions, randomized trees, linear regression, k-nearest-neighbors, SVMs, to name a few. A lot of these algorithms could be combined, even though they may not explicitly do so.

### Tuning the hyperparameters of the algorithm

We have to select an algorithm, whether it be logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbors, or even k-means. From this, there are things like number of hidden neurons in the hidden layer of a neural network, sampling method, subsample percent, to name a few. Many of the hyperparameters are dependent on each other, and hyperparameter tuning is what could allow the machine to outperform humans.

### Model selection and validation

While it is important to make a model, it is also important to find what results you are looking for. However, your research should not end at model selection. It is important to select a validation process, which would help you decide which model would do best. Even though decision trees are easy to interpret, cross-validation may be needed for their training and testing. Choosing appropriate metrics is needed for model selection as well. These are often multi-class classification, and regression.

### Out of bag error

are likely to have profound implications for our understanding of the universe. Research that incorporates subtle aspects of quantum mechanics has given rise to new particles and phenomena, leading physicists to rethink their theories and to propose new strategies for uncovering additional phenomena.

These developments have triggered major interest in using high-power lasers to investigate phenomena that include relativistic plasma behavior, the interaction of electromagnetic waves with a plasma, photon and matter interactions and gravitational lensing. Lasers are used to initiate high-energy accelerators and to control their operation; they are used to measure the interaction of electromagnetic waves and matter, and to develop technologies for laser fusion. In addition, lasers offer a powerful tool for quantum computation and for studying the interaction of laser pulses with plasma in the laboratory, and they can induce unidirectional space-time modifications in the propagation of light.

The new and explosive growth of laser science and technology is especially encouraging for young physicists who study lasers. A generation of laser researchers has grown up since the 1970s, stimulated by the rise of the modern laser and its exploitation to address fundamental questions in physics and the science of information. These researchers now have open opportunities to make theoretical and experimental contributions to one of the most dynamic research areas in physics.

The authors of this volume study the physics of lasers and explain its relevance for understanding the universe, probing the frontiers of laser and quantum science, and improving technologies for energy applications. They also explore new strategies for using lasers to probe phenomena not yet revealed.

This is the first detailed, broadly based volume on the physics of lasers and their applications. It provides the first forum for physicists with interests in lasers to meet, cross-fertilize ideas and discover ways to advance the science of lasers and their diverse applications. The volume presents the unique opportunity to learn about the scientific community’s advances in a single place, to learn about research frontiers and to discuss future directions and opportunities.

is increasingly important, as some of the biggest breakthroughs in science have led to new approaches to art, and conversely many scientific advances have proven influential for artists. And the historian of photography William Catherall Wroth, who resided in Linlithgow (1871-1957).
Artist like Mark Rothko and Cy Twombly, whose giant canvasses played with the expression of movement, have had a particular influence on modern sculpture and drawing, as has the work of Jackson Pollock, another giant of the painting world who broke away from the realistic approach to painting, and continued the trend for abstract art in the 1960s. More recently the imagination of artists such as Anthony Gormley and Tacita Dean has explored the human relationship with the environment. Both these artists have been the subject of solo exhibitions at Linlithgow Burgh Halls. Their works include land art and film, utilising natural materials in works that challenge the viewer to consider the changes that humans have had on the environment.
A burgeoning interest in video art, where the materiality of sound, text and image is celebrated, has been encouraged by innovations such as the iPod and digital cameras, and has had a part to play in the endurance and development of digital display at Linlithgow Burgh Halls with a local arts collective who work collaboratively and promote contemporary art.

of the absurd and provide examples of playwrights and works that belong to this genre. In your discussion, consider the nature of absurdity, the symbolism and symbolism, and the legacy of the Theatre of the Absurd movement. Please include at least five sources to support your analysis.

The Theater of the Absurd refers to a movement in drama and literature that emerged in the mid-20th century as a reaction against established and traditional plays. This genre challenges the fundamental aspects of conventional dramatic storytelling and explores the irrationality and randomness of life. The word "absurd" refers to a state of confusion and disorientation that stems from the realization that life's meaning and purpose are elusive or lacking.

The Theater of the Absurd characters are often anonymous and isolated individuals who experience feelings of alienation, disillusionment, and despair. The dialogue in these plays is often nonsensical and fragmented, with characters speaking in run-on sentences or exhibiting bizarre behavior. The setting is often mundane, in stark contrast to the gravity of the themes explored in the plays. Many plays in the Theater of the Absurd movement also use the presence of an audience to create a sense of alienation and unease.

Playwrights such as Samuel Beckett, Eugène Ionesco, Harold Pinter, and Tom Stoppard are all associated with the Theater of the Absurd. Some of the most famous works in this genre include Beckett's Waiting for Godot, Ionesco's The Bald Soprano, Pinter's The Birthday Party, and Stoppard's Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.

One of the main goals of the Theater of the Absurd movement was to question the traditional notions of truth, reality, and meaning. It challenges the idea that there is any inherent value in the external world and suggests that our understanding of life is flawed and inadequate. By exposing the absurdity of human existence, these playwrights sought to provide a new perspective on the way we view the world.

The legacy of the Theater of the Absurd movement can still be seen in contemporary theater and literature. It has influenced movements such as Postmodernism, which also challenges the traditional structures of storytelling and communication. The movement also paved the way for other avant-garde movements such as Futurism, Dadaism, and Surrealism, which sought to break free from traditional norms and explore the irrational aspects of human experience.

In conclusion, the Theater of the Absurd is a genre of drama and literature that challenges traditional notions of reality

competition? This article describes what a fitness competition is, how to get started, and how to choose the right competition for you.
A: A fitness competition is an event where athletes compete to see who has the best physique and overall fitness level. Some fitness competitions are designed to showcase bodybuilding, others might include a wide variety of different categories. The most famous fitness competitions in America include the Mr. and Ms. Olympia, the Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic, the Iron Man Competition, and the NPC Nationals.
Q: What are some of the different types of fitness competitions?
A: There are two main types of fitness competitions. The first is a mass-bloated bodybuilding competition. In this competition, many competitors compete against one another to see who can look the biggest and most muscular. This competition generally attracts older people who are looking to impress their friends and family. There are some other more niche categories too, such as bikini contests.
The second type of competition is a more artistic bodybuilding competition. In this type of competition, the winners are chosen based on their overall body composition and fitness levels. The most popular artist bodybuilding competition in America is the NPC Nationals which takes place annually at the Las Vegas Convention Center.

Fitness may be thought of as a science, or even an art, but it is definitely an obsession in our lives. Unfortunately, we sometimes think too much of it, and all that becomes an obsession itself, causing more harm than good. Our obsession can possibly lead to an extreme that is self-defeating, and some states of overdoing it, may even lead to some instances of self-destruction. But in most cases, we may be, in reality, obsessive about something completely different. For instance, we may be obsessed with the dislike of what we see in the mirror, and some of us work hard so that we look the way we like to. So, what is with the obsession?
Well, it happens that we become as in awe as possible, once we see that our hard work pays off. The motivation to look a certain way, is enhanced by a negative connotation, and therefore, we become obsessive about it. Once you are obsessed about something, you start to feel the need to be perfect, and if you are not, if there is even a slight inadequacy, you become devastated. That is why it is extremely important to avoid taking these “whatevers” to the point that one would believe that they are simply part of him or her. Very rarely will you find this kind of people who take their passion to a fault. But we have a fair deal of people who probably spend several hours sitting in front of their computers to look for places to download free printable workout calendar to add more to their knowledge about fitness, but their own families may start to be at a far end from them. Most of them are simply unhappy with what they see in the mirror.
Olympians have worked hard to get there, but not everyone can afford to spend as much time and effort as Olympic champions do. You may not have thousands of dollars at hand to be able to join a world famous gym. And spending time waiting for your turn to use a gym may be a little inconvenient as well. But this is what you get when you buy a gym membership that allows one to switch the location of the workouts he or she wishes to do. Exercise at home is as good as in a gym, as long as you are prepared to get dirty, do it right and get the results that your hard work deserves.

In this blog post, I am writing a beginner's guide to robotics. All examples use the Arduino platform as the focus, however, the main programming idea carries across all types of platforms.

What is a robot?

A robot is a machine that can perform tasks autonomously or semi-autonomously. These machines are commonly controlled by a computer.

What is the difference between autonomous and semi-autonomous?

To perform autonomously, the robot is completely on its own. To perform semi-autonomously, the robot must operate under some type of guidance. For example, a robot that follows a line is semi-autonomous. The robot would be autonomous if it was following another more complex algorithm.

Why is the robot category very broad?

Just like humans, robots are incredibly diverse. They can be autonomous, semi-autonomous, have one or more computers, include sensors, be made of multiple different materials, etc. Once a robot is outside of these parameters, they will be called an artificial intelligence or something similar.

What exactly is an artificial intelligence?

An artificial intelligence is the field of study where humans attempt to make machines that can perform tasks that normally need human intelligence.

What does a robot need to do in order to be considered a robot?

This is also a very broad question. A robot can be simple, such as the Sphero robots that can roll around. It can also be complex, such as NASA’s Mars rover. This broadness makes it hard to even define the word, and many experts have different definitions for it.

There are many things that a robot must be able to do in order to be considered a real robot, instead of something else. What are these things?

Robot arms, legs, wheels, and many other things.

These are considered robot parts. Almost every robot needs some sort of arms, leg, etc., which allows them to interact with their environment.

A simple comparison

An example of a robot could be a robot arm. A robot arm can move and interact with the environment. Compare that to a set of hands. They are able to move around, pick objects up, and do almost everything a human arm can do. These robotic hands are very powerful. However, they lack one capability: they can’t perform a long list of human tasks. On top of that, they are limited by their type of input. In this example, there was no fine control. Although, some robotic arms do have that capability.

A bit of theory

go back more than a century. In 1913 Henry M. Sheffer, a retired German professor, invented a device that shook a mechanical device, forced drops of water from a tiny test tube, and used the volume of the water to indicate the answer to certain problems. One use of this device, which researchers say is the world's first computer, was to teach a young Japanese child who was better able to distinguish between cherries and peas. The German-designed device was put on public display in the 1940s and was used by German researchers developing new kinds of robots. By the 1950s, psychologists had begun to create "thinking machines". Toward the end of that decade, Roger Bruhn, a researcher at the Stanford Research Institute in California, began to create a computer called the General Problem Solver. He went on to develop a form of artificial intelligence called operational research. This discipline is designed to produce not only mathematical models of problems but also tools that would help the individual and groups to set about solving them. By the mid-1970s, companies were beginning to use the computers for the first time. They were still quite expensive and required a large number of scientists to operate and maintain them. Yet their growth was exponential. Many more experts were needed and when few began to emerge from universities in the 1980s, companies hired them away from the libraries and advertising agencies. Over the next two decades, companies used computer systems to better understand and predict consumer behavior. In time, researchers began to find the systems more powerful than they had foreseen. They found the systems could conduct searches among millions of pieces of information in only a few seconds. and housing conditions is obvious. Schooling is a strong predictor of the economic resources of households, with schooling above the required minimum level predicting higher incomes. But more importantly, education has an impact on life expectancy.
Studies from countries like the Philippines, Jordan, Mexico, Peru and Colombia have found that children who stay in school longer have longer life expectancies than those who leave school early. In China, educational attainment is a stronger predictor of life expectancy than indicators of wealth, such as per capita GDP. In Botswana, children who have stayed in school for longer have higher life expectancies, especially if they have stayed in school up to the age of 15.
We see education having a strong, positive effect in tackling some of the biggest challenges that face emerging countries in the coming decades. As global leaders gather this week to discuss the Sustainable Development Goals, The Jameel Poverty Action Lab’s Abu Aït-Hamad has a personal perspective that I hope will help inform the conversation: only 40% of children with disabilities in poor countries have ever had an education. The socio-economic benefits of education are especially large for these children, and the estimated cost of excluding them from education is about $90 billion a year.
Aït-Hamad’s work has focused on children with disabilities, and the issue is of great personal importance to him: his work is motivated by his own experiences growing up in a rural village in Tunisia. Most of the boys in his community were prevented from going to school by the medical opinion of the local doctor. He had to deal with the same restrictions. Fortunately, he was able to convince the doctor to allow him to attend a specialised school, and subsequently he was able to pursue a career in disability rehabilitation. His work led him to write his master thesis on the effects of age at admission to schooling, leading to what we now know as the “science of reading”: evidence from the world’s first randomized placebo controlled trial on reading instruction, showing that intensive reading instruction is highly effective. Aït-Hamad and his collaborators have since run follow up studies with over 15,000 participants showing that the benefits of childhood literacy are long lasting.
His work has now been joined by other academic centres and important international agencies, like the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation (3ie) – one of The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab’s key partners in the international development community – to deliver long-lasting improvements in children’s literacy, for example through programs like PAARI-USAID’s

and its benefits to the discipline cannot be ignored. This course provides students with an understanding of the sociological perspective and how it is applied to understand the world we live in. is challenged by people who see historical narratives as old, out of date, and irrelevant to current issues. However, social memory is important for contemporary cultural identity, and our ability to make sense of our current situation.

How can memorials honor an individual or event without selling out to narrative power, cultural correctness, and group identity?
The article does not provide a specific answer to this question.

As a matter of fact, what the author here called the "memorials of things past" represent only a small portion of memory.
The author does not appear to be conflating memorials with memory itself. The term "memorials of things past" refers to the way that memory and memorialization are conflated in modern society, to the extent that memorials are often seen as the only or primary way to remember the past.

I think it's also important to note that while memorials are important for memorialization, they are not the only or primary way to remember the past. We have many other ways of remembering, such as storytelling, art, literature, and our own personal memories.

Ok, then how can a non-memorial event be a memory?
Memories can take many forms beyond traditional memorials, such as stories, personal experiences, and conversations with others. Even something as simple as a personal reflection on the event or a discussion with others about it can create a memory.

Furthermore, our personal relationships with people or objects can be a type of "memory". For example, if I lived in a certain house and spent a lot of time there with my family, I would remember that house in that context.

I am not very clear about your last comment. You are saying that our personal relationships with people or objects can be a type of memory? Did you mean "memorial" rather than "memory"?
Yes, I'm sorry if my last comment was not clear. By "memory," I mean the act of remembering, not a physical object. Personal relationships and personal experiences, which involve interactions with other people and objects, can create memories that shape our understanding of ourselves and the world around us.

I disagree with your assessment that "memorials represent only a small portion of memory."
I agree that memorials are not the only way to remember the past, and that our personal relationships and personal experiences can also be important ways of remembering. and its role in modern society. Meteorology has been around for thousands of years. The ancient Greeks and Romans were the first to observe and record weather patterns, but the field of meteorology really began to take shape in the 17th century with the invention of the barometer. In 1643, the Dutch scientist Blaise Pascal invented the first barometer, which was used to measure air pressure and was an early tool for predicting weather.

During the 19th century, weather stations began to be set up around the world to record weather conditions such as temperature, pressure, wind speed, and precipitation. These observations were then used to create weather maps, which allowed scientists to make more accurate predictions about the weather.

In the 20th century, meteorology became more scientifically advanced with the development of new technologies such as satellites, computer models, and radar. These tools allow meteorologists to track storms, predict hurricanes, and study climate patterns.

Today, meteorology plays an important role in modern society. It provides critical information for aviation, transportation, agriculture, and emergency management. Accurate weather forecasts are essential for airlines, shipping companies, and other businesses that rely on the weather to plan their operations. Meteorologists also play a key role in forecasting and preparing for natural disasters such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and floods.

In addition, meteorology has helped scientists understand and mitigate the effects of climate change. By analyzing climate data and developing climate models, meteorologists can track long-term trends and make predictions about how the planet's climate will change in the coming decades.

Can you explain how meteorologists use satellites to track weather patterns? Sure! Satellites are a crucial tool for meteorologists to track and analyze weather patterns. Here's how they work:

1. Climate Data and Satellite Imaging

Satellites capture images of the Earth's atmosphere and surface, which can help meteorologists understand patterns of air currents, clouds, and temperature.

2. Advantages of Satellites

Satellites provide a wide-angle view of the atmosphere and can capture images in visible and infrared light, which is helpful for distinguishing different cloud types and tracking the movement of storms. They can also detect changes in atmospheric gases, including water vapor and carbon dioxide, which help scientists understand the climate.

3. Satellite Meteorology

Satellites can also be used to measure temperature, humidity, and precipitation. By measuring changes in temperature and humidity, meteorologists can track the development of storms and predict when and where precipitation will fall.

is discussed in the book Title III of The Lonely Crowd. The common concept underlying both works is the idea of relativity of social behaviors and values, particularly with regard to contemporary liberal democratic values. While the first work covers the emergence of an american nation, with special attention to the formation of its society and culture, this second work focuses on the process of westernization and acculturation of russian intellectuals in the United States and the very process of molding ideas and attitudes, particularly the idea of social relativism, which preceded the emergence of, and acted as an influence for, the formation of the American philosophy. Being another facet of the same question of the purpose, the question of the import of the cultural relevancy of technology reveals itself. At the moment when the nation will become a ‘nation-state’, as Polanyi and Tonnies call it, the question of unifying the nation-state in a brand new society will require the solving of many interesting problems. Two of these problems are related to the cultural problems of a collective national identity and the technological development of a society which is inherently different from those of the western world. Failing to solve these problems satisfactorily will create these limitations within the historical period in question.
Arguably, the problems surrounding the issue of building a nation-state in which the aesthetic and ideological values of the society in question are coordinated and meaningful to the population are not as complex as they seem. In essence, we define nationality as the relation of ‘being of the same identity’ of a group of people who share common values. Paradoxically, this definition does not preclude that there exist specific cultures and norms within that nationality, some belonging to those who will never identify themselves with it and, in fact, may consider the people who do as a people (anyway, these people, now marginalized, will maintain an estrangement from the ‘normal people’, as does my cat from mine), in the way that Orwell’s proles do with those who are the morally superior elite and the able and worthy people from a comical social-democrat parable that is worse (or perhaps even better) than the dystopia in 1984. All this does not mean that the definition of nationality has no cultural context, rather it is one of the variables within its definition.

with Oli Eckert
Welcome to INSIGHT with Samantha Atkinson, the Go Get Inspired Podcast. Today, I'm speaking with Oli Eckert, a poet and author who believes poetry is a powerful tool to support children and educators worldwide. With a PhD from the University of Aberdeen's Centre for Sustainable Rural Development, Oli has extensive experience working with young children and Scottish Gaelic-speaking children to promote empathy through poetry. In this conversation, Oli shares about the creative process of poetry and offers some thoughtful, thought-provoking insights to bring awareness to society's impact on children. If you're ready to learn more about how poetry can be used to support children's development and learning, today's episode is for you.
"There was no dialogue. No push and pull. No one asking questions. There was just this magic. This quiet serenity. You breathe in and this whole world is inside you." - Oli Eckert
In Today's Episode, You'll Discover:
- What lead Oli to want to work with children and educators to promote empathy through poetry.
- Oli's creative process of using poetry to support social and emotional development in children.
- How poetry can be used as a tool to help children reflect on their own behaviors and decisions.
- Why Oli believes poetry can support children who struggle with a variety of challenges.
- Oli shares some wise words on how each of us can be more empathetic toward others.

An event, sometimes called the “Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum,” during which the temperature of the atmosphere of the Earth rose suddenly over a period of several thousand years, probably as a result of a radical change in the composition of the atmosphere. Ozone levels likely increased as the result of the release of some kind of gas or halogen molecule into the atmosphere, and the source may have been the destruction of major ozone-generating algae in the ocean (Thomas, 1998). A sudden rise in temperature might have created a break in the carbon cycle, allowing long-unseen deposits of fossil fuel methane (CH4) to begin releasing into the atmosphere. Given the recent discovery that methane released from the oceans today produces a temperature increase of the planet on the order of 3 degrees Celsius, the amount of temperature increase that must have occurred in the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum is difficult to gauge. By whatever process, the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum resulted in a major extinction event, and evidence of major animal extinctions coincided with the event. Scientists have theorized that 50% of the small animals on Earth may have disappeared. Even today, though much smaller creatures would be threatened by such an event.
The life in the oceans reacted by inventing a way to deposit a layer of carbon in the lower layers of the ocean during that time. Some scientists believe that the release of a putative gas or molecule from the ocean floor that prevented the ocean from releasing carbon during that period. While it is not certain whether this was deliberate, it seems likely that the evolution of the Green Calcite Bacteria may have accomplished it, without being aware of the purpose. There is some evidence that this layer of carbonate began to cause a problem with ocean chemistry, and as a consequence the rich fish and other marine animals that had been present began to decline. This may have been the effect of another atmosphere-bending event. The very first continental ice sheet began to develop as a result of a change in salinity in the ocean, which resulted from changes in how sea life was distributed. looking exciting as technology allows researchers to look at places they could not go before. Not everyone is keen to explore dangerous places and many new technologies are allowing scientists to observe and measure data that was hard to find earlier.
One aspect of this is being able to go to places where research equipment has not been before.
The world’s oceans are always changing. Weather patterns such as wind, ocean currents, waves and deep-sea heating bring on storms and abnormally cold temperatures. The ocean’s “climate” changes and temperature data, used by climatologists, is always in flux because of these changes.

It’s hard for researchers to get into some places because of the large waves and other hazards. Advanced technology such as seaborne aircraft and high altitude balloons allow observation of the ocean without having to risk lives.
This is a new and exciting time for oceanographers as new technologies are improving equipment so that they will be able to go where they have never been before.

Today, however, robotics is on the verge of its long-awaited merger with the computer industries. A brief look at the history of robotics, or cybernetics as it was once called, will illustrate how the robotics industry has changed over the past several decades.
In the mid-1970s, computer micro-controllers began to penetrate the robotics industry. At the same time, robotics engineers began to interface hardware and software. Today, these developments are commonplace in the advanced robotic industries.
In the 1950s, science fiction movies began to reflect the reality of an automated society, including robotic laboratory assistants, androids and android stories. In 1969, the first commercially-viable home robot, the PARO Therapeutic Robot, was released by Japan’s Namco. The robot’s face resembles that of a newborn harp seal with textured skin, and contains imitation fur.
Scientists also speculated that the human nervous system may one day be used to interpret data from a computer. IBM developed electronic (computer-based) information-processing capabilities via humans' spinal and optic nerves. Advanced robotics is used to facilitate information and data processing, with individuals who can interact with robots, and who are used to have the understanding that robots can simulate a human relationship. Of course, these simulation programs are now called 'social robots'. Computer scientists have also tried to determine the best way to program artificial neural networks to allow robots to think.
To perform this task, the robotic hardware must be powerful enough to interpret, organize, and act upon the information. Some robotic systems use optical, laser, or some other sensors to map out an environment. Other robotics systems are controlled by humans to perform tasks in factories, offices, and homes. The applications for industrial robotics have had a huge impact on the robotics industry, and its technologies have become more sophisticated as a result.
For example, the trend towards automation in the modern workplace has resulted in increased consumer confidence in robots. has dramatically changed our conception of the earth. Ubytovani v poseidonskih palave the majority of geologic principles established in the first part of the 20th century have been refined or overturned. Foremost among these is the realization that most of the material in the crust is recycled periodically through plate tectonics, that the age of the earth is much longer than previously thought, and that rocks with evidence of early life and contemporaneous fossilized bacteria from 3.5 billion years ago have been found. New understanding of the chemistry of uranium and its isotope, uranium-235 (235U), has completely transformed the way scientists think about radioactivity. The new insights into the roles of rock weathering and plate tectonics on earth's global chemical cycles have allowed for the reevaluation of paleoclimate and paleoecology, and promise to help explain long-term changes in the earth's climate.
Bearing the brunt of these scientific developments has been the geological time scale, which is the scheme by which the history of the earth is presented. The first geological time scales were hastily cobbled together after a brief study of some fossils (such as marine radiolaria) and had great difficulty representing the rate of evolution and appearance of new fossil groups. The first time scales were often distorted by cultural biases and closed-mindedness toward the theory of evolution and "transmutation of species" by means of "natural" selection.
Today, in the age of geochronology, the geological time scale has improved immeasurably. For a primer on radiometric dating, see the radiometric dating page. The following is an account of the refining of these types of dating tools and how this has led to a better understanding of the history of life on earth.
Absolute ages for much of the geologic record have been determined since the late 1800s by a variety of techniques involving minerals such as potassium (40K) and uranium (238U) as well as rocks from well-understood portions of the crust and formerly active volcanic regions.
The oldest age assigned to a rock in the geologic record is the age of the oldest known thing on earth, or the rock the rock that that is the oldest identified as "the oldest rock in the world." (often incorrectly termed “muscular fitness”) are the key indicators of exercise need. Fitness in our modern age not only refers to “muscular fitness”, but also “physical fitness”. Specifically, the training effect of fitness is closely associated with fitness monitoring, in that the daily effects of exercise on fitness can be monitored and measured through certain monitoring devices and methods.
Various factors can affect fitness (health). Cardiovascular disease, metabolic dysfunction, metabolic syndrome, various types of bodyfat, and other potential biomarkers can be tracked with the aid of fitness. To determine your personal fitness needs, and to properly measure them, you must understand and apply these indicators.
Physical activity monitoring has many different purposes. Fitness in this context does not refer to muscular fitness, but more specifically refers to fitness monitoring.
First and foremost, the purpose of fitness monitoring is to ensure that your physical condition is improving. A well planned out fitness regimen must be tested for proper functionality, and muscle testing is an important way of testing the efficacy of each program. In addition to this, we can measure exercise effectiveness by tracking fitness for different purposes. For instance, we can test fitness to determine the need for particular sport activities or to determine the appropriate strength training regimen to meet fitness goals.

in our communities? A model that brings together a variety of players is needed, and the Greater Vernon Sustainability Society has entered the fray by forming the Okanagan Similkameen Chapter of the Sustainability Economy Network (SEN).
Called “B2050” the White Rock organisation is Canada's first such association, and is linked with like groups in British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Manitoba, with chapters forming across Canada and abroad. It has been in formation since 2009 and is now looking for the usual suspects to help fill in the details.
I attended a two-hour meeting last Wednesday and came away encouraged by the number of like-minded people who are willing to contribute to creating a stronger, healthier, and more vibrant Okanagan Valley. Besides Victoria, which is represented by a core group of businesses and individuals, there was no other chapter in British Columbia.
As Senate Sustainability President Peter Colling estimates, some 2,500 local businesses should be on his radar, and with Kamloops, Revelstoke and Nelson adding to that list, their voice on the issues is finally being heard. Existing and emerging businesses throughout the Okanagan have begun to do what is required of them, and soon it will no longer be up to them, but the elected politicians and bureaucrats will be held accountable. That is their role in a democracy.
Most people have read the well-publicized “Blueprint” prepared by the Greater Vernon Advisory Committee, and endorsed by the three levels of government, but that document is only a good start. It has identified a wide range of issues, and soon the organization will be building a group of like-minded, positive persons, to become informed about their various concerns.
Not everyone can be an “informed citizen” however, and that is why some prefer to sit on the sidelines and hope that some things will change, but cannot see them doing so. Others who get involved are active, especially in having their voices heard, and at the meeting, a number of those voices were heard to be talking.

While ever more bays and northern harbours in Europe are being transformed into an aquarium-like paradise for seals, seals are out there grabbing more and more space and wreaking havoc on other wild life. Farther north in Scandinavia, seals are sought after as a food product, with Finland being the world's third biggest exporter of seal meat (Belgium) and Sweden (16,000 tonnes/ year). It is Norway, however, that is the biggest business in seals. Norway is by far the world's biggest export of seal meat. A total of 47,700 seals (the total number of seals killed in all of Europe is 111,000) have been killed during a three-year period (2000-2002) in Norway, of which some 30,000 were done in the north of Norway. By comparison, 1,300 were killed in Greece and 1,800 in Turkey. On the other hand, more than 3,000 European harbour seals died in Norway in 1997, and there have been virtually no results from investigations as to why and where this large amount of seals died at that time. Norwegian seal authorities such as the Norwegian Veterinary Institute do not care what seal distress looks like or what the reason is for seals struggling in the shallows at ice formation time. Using a "phenomenological approach" the Institute has decided that there is nothing wrong with sealing for commercial purposes as long as marine mammals are not actually killed in the process. Therefore, rescue operations for seals that have become trapped and are struggling in shallows or on the ice are not to be initiated. Instead, these seals are left to face the unpredictable and sometimes fatal force of the ocean, and the Nordic Environmental Fund has allocated 20 million Kroners each year to seal handling.
No effect of trap lines
"It would be interesting to see some statistics on the impact of seal trap lines in the northeast Atlantic, which often start near the south-east coast of Norway", says Knut Josef Johansen, head of ELSO [The Norwegian Wildlife Society's Seal Committee]. In a report from 2002, the Norwegian Veterinary Institute writes that new seal trap lines will lead to new seal populations (http: //www.mtg.no). The central aim of trap lines is not to save individual seals or to ensure for their lives, but rather to increase Norwegian seal exports. The seal

have transformed our understanding of the past in recent decades. Archaeologists are drawing new conclusions based on high-resolution radiocarbon dates as well as unprecedented levels of dna analysis and molecular studies. Researchers are conducting these studies in a wide array of archaeological sites as well as gathering unprecedented material evidence to contribute to our understanding of the longue duree human experience.
In addition to the archaeological record itself, new technologies have transformed the methodologies used to study the record and inform our understanding of the past. Discoveries in bioarchaeology are shedding new light on past subsistence strategies and diet as well as ritual and funerary behaviour. Pharmacological analysis and isotopic analyses of both environmental sources and human diet have transformed our understanding of past disease burden, nutritional status, and dietary and environmental transitions. New techniques are used to reconstruct the movement of people and animals using stable isotopes and other substances.
Interdisciplinary collaborations and the newest analytical tools are now the norm and the challenges are to develop the best methods and make the most of what is a growing pool of data in a time when the available archaeological record and archaeological evidence is changing at an exponential rate. Archaeologists must combine different analytical techniques and perspectives in order to craft detailed stories from the archaeological record. Ongoing studies in these areas enable archaeologists to better understand how human societies have adapted to different environmental conditions and changing cultural values.
Our research is ideally placed to better understand these interdisciplinary topics and to work with colleagues in a variety of fields including paleoanthropology, environmental studies, medicine, physiology, pharmacology, and archaeobotany. All of these expertise are necessary for any single project to fully understand the material record, develop a model, and apply this model to the broader archaeological record to better understand how individuals have shaped their past. Furthermore, many archaeologists are working with indigenous communities in order to better understand the kinship models and the ecological knowledge on which societies have based their decisions. Such projects necessarily involve work with indigenous communities, and there is a real need to assess the reliability of any project and to understand the appropriate frameworks for consultation with indigenous communities that recognize the importance of indigenous knowledge and the right of indigenous communities to govern themselves.
The UCFA has hosted a series of focus groups and workshops on archaeological methodology. A summary of these activities can be found here. A second report summarizing the findings of the archaeological studies at Masada, including the collaborative work of faculty, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows was published in 2016. and how it has influenced our understanding of the universe.

In ancient times, humans observed the night sky and developed an early understanding of the concept of the cosmos. However, it was not until the development of modern scientific methods that humans were able to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the universe.

The history of astronomy dates back to ancient civilizations, where astronomers used simple tools such as sticks, stones, and shadows to study the movements of celestial bodies. Over time, these observations were refined, and with the advent of early telescopes, astronomers were able to observe the planets, stars, and other celestial bodies in greater detail.

During the 17th century, Sir Isaac Newton's work on gravity revolutionized our understanding of the universe. His laws of motion and universal gravitation helped to explain the motions of celestial bodies in the solar system. This provided the foundation for the development of modern astronomy.

In the 20th century, the field of astronomy experienced significant advancements due to advances in technology and the discovery of new celestial bodies. The Hubble Space Telescope, for instance, has allowed astronomers to study the universe in greater detail than ever before.

Today, astronomers continue to make discoveries about the universe, from the exploration of exoplanets to the study of black holes. These discoveries have helped us better understand the cosmos and our place within it. Additionally, astronomical observations have played a key role in many scientific fields, including physics, chemistry, and biology. By studying celestial bodies, we can gain insight into the formation and evolution of the universe, as well as the laws that govern it.

Sure, there have been many recent discoveries in astronomy that have greatly expanded our understanding of the universe. One such discovery is the detection of gravitational waves, which were first detected in 2015 by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO). These waves are ripples in space-time that are created by extremely massive objects, such as black holes, colliding with each other. The detection of gravitational waves has allowed astronomers to study some of the most extreme phenomena in the universe, such as the collision of two neutron stars, which resulted in the emission of a gamma-ray burst.

variables in Python and provide an example of how they can be used to customize the behavior of a Python program.
In Python, environment variables are variables that are defined in the environment in which a program runs. These variables are shared across all processes and can be accessed and used within a Python program. 

Python provides a built-in module called `os` which allows access to environment variables. The `os` module provides a method called `environ` which returns a dictionary of all environment variables. Additionally, there is a built-in module called `os.path` which provides a way to access operating system path related operations, including joining a path with the `os.path.join()` function.

Here's an example of how environment variables can be used to customize the behavior of a Python program:

import os

# Accessing environment variables
username = os.environ.get('USER')
print("Username:", username)

# Customizing behavior using environment variables
data_dir = os.environ.get('DATA_DIR', '/default/data/dir')
print("Data Directory:", data_dir)

In this example, we first import the `os` module. We then access the environment variable `USER` using `os.environ.get()` and print the value. Next, we access the environment variable `DATA_DIR` using `os.environ.get()`, but this time we pass the default value `/default/data/dir` if the variable is not set. Finally, we print the value of `DATA_DIR`.

In this case, even if the `DATA_DIR` environment variable is not set, it will use the default value. This allows for easy customization of the behavior of a program based on values defined in the environment.

# Dark Matter in the Sky

## Introduction

We’ve learned a bit about dark matter from particle accelerators, telescopes, and underground experiments — but what about from space itself? Stellar objects such as galaxies, with the help of observations from orbit, have produced some interesting constraints on dark matter. The main purpose of this problem set is to dig into the statistics and models behind these galactic observables.

We will be focusing on a technique called “galaxy clusters” and examining their properties in an effort to infer the gravitational nature of dark matter. The procedure to obtain dark matter limits or constraints from astronomical observations, from the ground up, is called “statistical inference.” This method includes choosing variables, making assumptions, considering noise in the observatory, and using knowledge to move from data to a result.

We will see that with our knowledge of the universe, however fuzzy the details, there are some conclusions we can make.

## Galaxy clusters and kinematics

We will review two of the classes of objects that we know can hold dark matter: clusters of galaxies. At first, astronomers looked to expanding the universe to get an idea of where massive clusters of galaxies can be seen to set a limit on how much dark matter there could be (Edouard et al. 2018, Blanco 2021). Dark matter has a gravitational effect, whether or not we see it from electromagnetism. But we can try to infer gravitational effects by studying the evolution of galaxy clusters over time and the motions of galaxies within it.

### Galaxy clusters: examples

There are two main types of galaxy clusters: loose, which contain fewer galaxies than nearby groups, and rich clusters, which contain more. Loosely organized systems of galaxies are made up of multiple groups and even lower-order systems, while rich clusters contain dozens of galaxies on average. Rich clusters are large structures that contain numerous quasars, with elliptical and spiral galaxies that are yellowish-brown. Rich clusters are smaller than large clusters and have the most mass. They are also found closer together and are more tightly bound than smaller, less massive systems. The spiral galaxies are substructure within the rich clusters, while elliptical galaxies are not. They lack noticeable structure and are formed in the smallest structures. Groups of galaxies are made up of spiral galaxies, a few elliptical galaxies, and a red supergiant star. Rich clusters have many smaller clusters and galaxies in them, while loosely organized galaxies are larger, and are themselves made up of larger structures that

and what were the major developments that led to modern astronomy.

The history of astronomy is the study of celestial objects and events, including stars, planets, galaxies, and other space phenomena. It is an ancient science that dates back to prehistoric times. The earliest known records of astronomy date back to around 3000 BCE, when ancient civilizations in Mesopotamia began to make astronomical observations using instruments such as the sundial and the water clock.

The earliest recorded astronomer was the Babylonian astronomer Adapa, who lived around 2000 BCE. He observed the motions of the sun, moon, and stars and recorded his observations in a series of cuneiform tablets.

One of the earliest recorded discoveries in astronomy was the fact that the Earth moves around the sun, which was discovered by the Greek philosopher Aristotle in the 4th century BCE. This discovery was later confirmed by the Greek astronomer Ptolemy, who developed a system of astronomy based on the Earth's circular motion around the sun.

During the Middle Ages, astronomy became a highly studied subject among Islamic scholars. The Persian astronomer Abū Rayhān al-Bīrūnī (973-1048 CE) wrote a book on astronomy titled Al-Berīt al-Marhūlī, which was one of the earliest treatises on the subject.

In the 16th century, the invention of the telescope revolutionized the field of astronomy. The Dutch astronomer Hans Lippershey was the first to patent a refracting telescope, followed by the Italian Galileo Galilei, who built his own telescope and made observations of the moons of Jupiter and the phases of Venus.

The 17th century saw the birth of modern astronomy, as major developments in optics, mechanics, and mathematics allowed astronomers to make more accurate observations of the heavens. The invention of the reflecting telescope by Sir Isaac Newton in the 18th century made observations of the Sun and stars much more precise.

The 19th century saw the rise of celestial mechanics, the study of the movements of celestial objects. In 1846, the German astronomer Johann Gauss discovered the first planet beyond Neptune, which was later named Ceres. In 1859, the English astronomer William Rowan Hamilton developed the theory of three-dimensional space geometry, which led to the development of quantum mechanics and relativity.

In the 20th century, the field of astronomy continued to grow and advance

activism from the early 1900s to the present day.
Environment activism has a long and complex history, stretching back over a century. Some of the key moments in this history include:

Early 1900s:
The modern environmental movement began to take shape in the early 20th century, as more and more people became aware of the dangers of pollution and other environmental problems. In 1906, the first national US organization dedicated to the conservation of natural resources, the National Parks Association, was founded.

1940s to 1970s:
The 1950s and 60s saw the development of the Modern Environmental Movement, including the publication of Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" in 1962. The Clean Air Act of 1963 and the Clean Water Act of 1972 helped to address air and water pollution. Activists also protested against nuclear weapons testing and energy development, leading to the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency in 1970.

1990s to the Present:
The 1990s saw a resurgence of environmental activism, with the rise of grassroots organizations such as Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth. The use of environmental regulation became more widespread, particularly with the passage of the Endangered Species Act in 1973 and the Montreal Protocol in 1987, which aimed to reduce the production of ozone-depleting substances.

In the 2000s and 2010s, environmental activism focused on issues such as global warming, plastic pollution, and biodiversity loss. Environmental protests have been increasingly violent and disruptive, as activists push back against perceived government inaction and corporate greed. The Paris Agreement of 2015, which aims to limit global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius, has been a major focus of environmental activism in recent years.

Today, the environmental movement remains strong, with activists continuing to push for greater government action and corporate responsibility. While progress has been made in some areas, such as reducing pollution and protecting natural resources, the environmental challenges facing the world today are vast and complex, requiring ongoing vigilance and activism.

cannot be overstated. In ancient times, the stories and beliefs of different cultures served as a means of understanding the world and our place in it. They served to explain the natural phenomena that we could not understand at the time and helped us to make sense of the social structure that surrounded us. They also had a profound impact on art, religion, and mythology in modern society. Modern society still finds use for this ancient form of literature.

One of the most significant ways in which mythology is used in modern society is in storytelling. We tell tales of ancient heroes and gods, use modern narratives as fables, and even search for meaning in modern-day myths such as the popular story of the fight against COVID-19. Additionally, mythology serves as an important subject in literature, as people look to stories from the past for inspiration and guidance. Some modern-day stories incorporate mythology and use it to explain the world around us.

Mythology is also a crucial aspect of art, with many contemporary artists drawing inspiration from the myths of the past. Ancient symbols such as the thunderbolt and the lotus flower are still relevant in modern art and are often used to represent power, magic, and spirituality.

However, it is essential to acknowledge that while mythology still holds value in the modern world, it is no longer the dominant form of storytelling. The myths of the past are frequently reinterpreted, and many people prefer to read new stories over the ancient tales of old. Some people may feel disconnected from the mythology of their ancestors and struggle to find meaning in the stories that are no longer part of their daily lives.

In conclusion, mythology in modern society serves as a source of inspiration, guidance, and understanding. It is a crucial aspect of culture and still holds value in the art and literature of the modern world. While the prominence of mythology may have changed over time, its relevance in modern society cannot be ignored.

| Celebrate This!
On this day when we celebrate the poet and spiritual leader Rumi and celebrate poetry in general, I want to share a few tips for enjoying poetry. I’d love to hear if you have tips of your own.
Find out more about poets you like. Read more of their work. Read other books and poetry they’ve inspired.
Read a book by a writer. I do this every year with Alice Munro. It takes some work, but I also enjoy the reading of other authors who might have influenced the one I’m reading.
Listen to music and experience performances of poets. An audio book app allows me to hear poetry I haven’t read before.
Join an online poetry forum. I love being part of the one that has my friend Theresa Milstein as a moderator.
Ask yourself what about poems engages you and allows you to take in as much as possible.
Write poetry or try spoken word. Nothing has strengthened my skills and love of poetry than writing my own.
Write with children or students. Nothing makes me pay attention to a poem as close reading it with a student.
Write a poem. Set aside time to write and edit your poem for accuracy and clarity. Remember to find a different topic.

/ How does science work?
This is the world of scientific inquiry. We take a close look at rocks, stars, ice caps, tectonic plates and many other things to understand what they are, where they come from, and what can happen to them when we change their environment or temperatures.
We do this using a wide variety of advanced instruments, from high tech proton swimmers to microscopic primitive life chambers. By looking at the past in different ways we help to predict the future, create a better understanding of the world around us, and chart new pathways to the future.
All of our training is aimed at allowing students to become experts in geology.

has produced a shift in the literature from the fixation on climate changes to the treatment of the impacts of climate changes on ecosystem and biodiversity. Tropics tropical regions are responsible for a significant share of biodiversity and most recent studies have shown that they are highly vulnerable to climate changes due to their intrinsic features including their climate conditions that determines their exposed surface, rainfall that vary from period of the year and rainfall distribution, temperature that varies through the season and forest fragmentation. Tropical forest reserve have been proposed to be more resilient to climate change; because of their high biodiversity, their connectivity, endemic species richness, maturity and productivity. However, too little of field data are collected to support these arguments. Our research aims to support this idea by studying the impact of climate change in a semi-permanent nature reserve in a tropical forest in Southwestern Cameroon.
Biodiversity is composed of both genetic, physical and structural components which are easily modified in tropical areas. These modifications are generated by the impact of climate and weather conditions on ecosystem processes, especially in natural forest. The "fragility", "adaptability", and "resistance" to the environment of tropical forest ecosystems have been subject of a renewed interest on the basis of new evidence of forest responses to new environmental conditions, in particular changes in temperature and precipitation.
Seasonal fluctuations of climatic conditions can represent a serious danger for biodiversity. Semiarid zones, characterized by fast variations in temperature, precipitation and associated variables, are certainly a part of the most vulnerable tropical ecosystems. The environmental conditions of most tropical ecosystems and forest reserves are susceptible to change due to climate change. It is under this perspective that, we carried out a study on the trees population of a protected forest reserve at Ba'kong, one of the few remaining primary forests in Western Africa. This highly important, but fragile, tropical forest ecosystem, is exposed to an extreme ecological instability arising from effects such as primary succession of vegetation, soil erosion, fire, and heavy seasonal rainfall.
Climate change is an effect of the global warming caused by human activities. Among the general consequence, change in global weather conditions and eventual increase in the temperature are the most visible. The future climate change is not modeled with certainty although scientists' predictions exhibit a great disparity in the data. In some forecasts, there is a profound rise in atmospheric and water temperature which is followed with reduction in wind and precipitation. Although global and regional climate models show many differences, there is unanimity on the upshot to tropical ecosystems, including biodiversity. The primary impact of climate change will be on tropical ecosystems
