and self-improvement.
Dalia was always self-conscious about her body. She had struggled with weight her whole life, and even though she had tried various diets and exercise programs, she never felt comfortable in her own skin. One day, she decided to take her health into her own hands and embark on a journey of self-improvement.

She started by going to the gym, working out for an hour every day, and following a strict diet plan. At first, it was hard. She was out of shape and had a hard time keeping up with the other people in the gym. But Dalia didn't give up. She kept pushing herself, even when she didn't feel like it, and gradually, she began to see progress.

As her weight dropped and her fitness levels increased, Dalia started to feel more confident in her own body. She no longer felt self-conscious when she went to the gym, and she was able to wear clothes that she never would have dreamed of wearing before.

But she didn't stop there. Dalia wanted to become even stronger, even fitter, and so she began to take on more difficult workouts, such as weight lifting and high-intensity interval training. She pushed herself to her limits, but she also took the time to rest and recover, allowing her body to heal and rebuild.

As Dalia continued to work on her fitness and self-improvement, she also focused on other areas of her life. She spent more time with friends and family, and she took up new hobbies that she had always wanted to try.

Through her journey of self-improvement, Dalia learned that fitness and self-improvement are not just about the physical changes that we see on the outside. It's also about the changes we make on the inside – the mental and emotional transformation that comes with learning to love and accept ourselves for who we are.

Now, Dalia feels empowered and unstoppable. She knows that she can achieve anything she sets her mind to, and she's excited to see where her journey of self-improvement will take her next.

research. Study some current problem and issues that AI practitioners address daily, and learn to predict your own problems in the future. This course offers the basics of good practice in AI research, such as problem formulation and choice of techniques, as well as intuition-building examples. The focus is not on theory and algorithmics, but rather on intuition building.
The goal of this course is for students to understand how to best solve important problems in AI. There are two skill-sets we aim to develop: modeling and algorithmic techniques. Modeling involves choosing appropriate functions to model the problem. We address this skill by asking you to describe problems of your own, which you are more familiar with, in terms of a mathematical model. Our models will be the functions described by abstract syntax trees (Abstract Syntax Trees, or ASTs). We assume you understand these already. In fact, that will be your first homework.
Algorithmic techniques on the other hand involve how to find the right solution to a problem using the models you have built. We address this by showing a few principles you can learn to evaluate algorithms (and your own experiments) that will prevent your algorithm from being very slow or very unsafe (such as, not finding a solution in the first place, and allowing incorrect solutions).
This course is suitable for advanced undergraduate and graduate students who have had a basic course in machine learning and computer science. There will be homework assignments, and a term paper to be delivered by the end of the course.
All assignments and the term paper are to be submitted via the secure SCILab file exchange. The total assignments are worth 30 points.
The non-algorithmic assignments are to be submitted as we go, so that the Instructors can provide you with feedback while the term is still going. Each assignment will be worth 1 point.
Due to the nature of this course and the flexibility of the terms, we will do a final weighted average of all your assignments, plus the final exam, to determine your grade.

Genes are hereditary material that allows people to inherit specific traits, like their eye color or high intelligence. Traits are positive and negative both. Negative traits are said to be passed from parents to child. Positive traits are said to be transferred to children via their parents. The question is, are genes and traits that are inherited good or bad? 

Question: what are the benefits of genetics? What's the big deal? What do you gain from inheriting them? The benefits of genetics include hereditary material that allows people to inherit specific traits, like their eye color or high intelligence[1]. Additionally, genes are found in the nucleus of the cell and contain the code that determines what will be produced by cells[2][3], and genetic disorders can be passed on to the next generation, which causes genetic conditions and diseases[4]. Furthermore, genetics and DNA testing can help people to understand their risk of disease or certain traits[5].

The story also seems to be jumping to conclusions based on one or two instances of discrimination.
Even more importantly, why is it only in the time of Obama’s victory that this outcry arises in the press? How come during Bush’s administration, no one was protesting this?

Nowadays, music is available for free download through music sites and for listening on local radio stations. While the above is indicative of the impact of music in our modern lives, music has been a part of human culture for much longer than most people realize.
The earliest evidence of music can be traced back to monasteries and civilisations that developed along the Nile river approximately 40,000 years ago. The oldest items identified as musical instruments include the ocarina and flute-like instruments found at Indus Valley sites. Some of the earliest recognisable musical performances include the invention of musical notation, composed lyrics, and then finally the invention of brass and pipe instruments. With this came the emergence of rock music, and many genres of electronic dance music have become popular in recent decades.
Through history, music has often been used to ease tensions between societal groups and religious conflicts; for example, Gregorian chants were created to help monks improve their singing abilities and made classical music more accessible. The huge amount of money invested in the music industry has also supported the training of artists. It is no surprise that the music industry continues to grow and develop despite the rise of online music streaming sites and social media.
Music has been an important part of human societies and has always been used to help people overcome a variety of issues. Music has been used by medical practitioners to help alleviate the effects of diseases such as Tourette syndrome. Research suggests that listening to music helps reduce the unwanted and confusing jumbled sensations people with Autism Spectrum Disorder and people with attention deficit disorder.
As we learn more about music, and the brain’s response to the music, we also find that music has the ability to treat disorders such as PTSD. PTSD and numerous other nervous system disorders are extremely common and music therapy has been one of the most effective non-traditional methods of treating these disorders.
Music and creativity are useful skills in the education system. Music and the arts are important subjects to study at school, they are both types of creative work that needs to be appreciated. Engaging in creative work helps people enhance their critical thinking abilities as well as their problem-solving skills. Many subjects such as art, mathematics and language also rely on creative thinking. Students are encouraged to work on creative assignments such as writing and music coursework which helps to prepare them for the practical world.

The demand for oil and gas will continue to grow in coming decades as the world’s population increases, but these market fundamentals won’t prevent a future fall in prices as the pursuit for new resources continues. To ensure short- and long-term profitability in a high-cost, global marketplace, operators must reinvent their strategies by incorporating advanced geology practices into all phases of operations.
When Geolabs, Inc. conducted a regional assessment of the Eastern Arabian Gulf’s Tertiary Unconventional oil reservoirs, it became obvious that the vast majority of reservoirs did not offer any economic advantages for further development. After decades of operations in the industry and working with other resource companies, the team members of Geolabs saw a developing model that would push the limits of successful resource development.
After defining a project area that exhibited several differing geologic complexities, Geolabs assembled a team comprised of petroleum geologists, reservoir engineers, reservoir simulator modelers and geophysicists in each of the three commercial geotechnical service areas: evaluation, evaluation systems, and exploration.
The project area was first defined and characterized on the basis of historic core and well data, geophysical logs, facies data, and core imaging studies. The subsurface geology could then be incorporated into 3-D reservoir modeling systems. After analyzing a series of three-dimensional models from the various geological and conceptual unit models, it was decided that the optimal combination could be obtained from integrating unit-by-unit analysis models into a single interpretation and modeling exercise.
In March 2014, Kuwait’s Ministry of Oil and Gas entered an agreement with Geolabs to integrate its unconventional geomechanical interpretation and modeling services with Kuwait National Petroleum Company’s Permissive Permit System, located in Block 44, of Northeastern Kuwait.
Working under the supervision of an advisory board comprised of geoscientists, modeling specialists and petroleum engineers, Geolabs offers a spectrum of specialist multidisciplinary knowledge and experience to assist Kuwait in successfully developing cost-effective and economically viable unconventional reservoirs.
At the outset of the project, Geolabs established the business need to prove that these unconventional sandstone reservoirs do have the hydraulic potential to be exploited by conventional injection and production technologies. After reviewing and evaluating all available core, wellbore and wellplan data and reservoir models, along with seismic evidence, Geolabs decided to conduct further high-resolution seismic data acquisition and modeling to make additional and more accurate reservoir sand division maps.

Now, in 2012 the industry has again seen an explosive growth, but more in terms of online betting. The retail side of the industry is probably only up about 10%, due to the decline in over the counter wagering (3.15 billion in 2012).

Whether through classic plays or new works, theater provides a platform for writers, directors, and performers to share their stories and connect with audiences.

One of the key benefits of theater is its ability to inspire and inform audiences. By providing a space for characters to explore complex issues and confront difficult emotions, theater can spark important conversations and encourage audiences to think critically about the world around them. This is especially true for works that tackle issues related to social justice, where the power of theater can be used to raise awareness and inspire change.

Another important aspect of theater is its ability to bring people from different backgrounds and experiences together. Whether through shared performances or community events, theater has the power to bring diverse communities together and foster a sense of unity and understanding. This is particularly important in today's increasingly divided society, where meaningful connections and shared experiences can be hard to come by.

At its core, theater is a space for storytelling and human connection. Through its power to inspire, inform, and bring people together, theater has the ability to make a lasting impact on individuals and society as a whole. As we move forward into a rapidly changing world, it is more important than ever to support and celebrate this important art form.

, technology, engineering and mathematics are major contributors to sustainable development in the city of Anchorage, Alaska. And through a smart use of big data, big ideas, and brains, new approaches are being developed to tackle increasingly pressing environmental concerns.
Longtime environmental advocate Larry Hart uses a tool to analyze historical sedimentation levels near the Anchorage airport.
Not only does it maintain the snow around the airport, but it's also providing critical information for science. At a gathering of community-minded innovators in Anchorage, Ryan Eimen, a scientist with the Environmental Protection Agency, says that the project provides essential information about how to manage human-generated pollutants in our environment.
Using a simple calculator, Eimen explains that a “discharge date” is any point in which pollution is released to the environment. From there, these potentially harmful substances need to go somewhere. He points to historical data from a sedimentation box near the airport.
Sediment is a combination of sand, dirt, rocks and organic matter that gets dumped by streams, rivers and precipitation as it falls to Earth. But the same stream that deposits material on the land, also carries it downstream, as well as lakes, rivers and oceans. Along with carbon dioxide, methane and other greenhouse gases, sediment gets released into the atmosphere. As Eimen points out, sediment is considered a greenhouse gas.
That means, for better or worse, a lot of it is out there.
Aside from its impact on the environment, sediment also has important implications for water and air quality, as well as human health. That's where a group of enthusiastic science teachers comes into play.
Five years ago, Sean Karafin, Kevin Reynolds and Curt Phelps decided to make science more fun and engaging for students at schools in Anchorage. They are the creators of Algogear, a STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) problem solving game that lets kids search and sort piles of statistics, equations, diagrams, diagrams and formulas. Collecting the information in a problem set, teachers can then hand it off to students to figure out.
Brice is concerned that science education in America may be failing our children. She believes we're losing the next generation of young scientists, engineers and researchers. To reverse that tide, Algogear provides a safe and engaging framework that allows students to nurture an interest in science from an early age.
While the snow piles mentioned earlier go to waste outside of the airport, several groups have developed ways to profit from it.

Oceanography is the study of the physical, chemical, biological, and geological aspects of the ocean and its environment. The benefits of oceanography include:

1. Understanding the ocean's impact on the global climate system: Oceanography helps us understand how the oceans affect the atmosphere and how weather patterns are influenced by ocean currents.

2. Exploring the ocean's diverse ecosystems: The ocean is home to a wide range of habitats, including coral reefs, deep-sea trenches, and hydrothermal vents. Understanding these ecosystems is essential for maintaining the health and diversity of marine life.

3. Ensuring the sustainability of marine resources: Oceanography helps us understand the complex interactions between marine ecosystems and human activities, such as fishing, oil and gas exploration, and coastal development.

4. Monitoring and predicting natural disasters: Oceanography helps us understand ocean currents, waves, and other factors that contribute to natural disasters such as hurricanes, tsunamis, and storms.

5. Developing new technologies and renewable energy sources: Oceanography has led to the development of new technologies, such as offshore wind farms, and has also led to the discovery of new sources of renewable energy, such as wave and tidal energy.

That's really interesting! Can you tell me more about oceanographic research? Sure, here are a few more details on oceanographic research:

Oceanographic research is a multidisciplinary field that includes studies of physics, chemistry, biology, geology, and other aspects of the ocean and its environment. Here are some specific areas of study within oceanography:

1. Ocean circulation: Understanding how ocean currents work is important for climate modeling and predicting weather patterns.

2. Marine biology: Research on marine life can help us understand how biodiversity is distributed in the ocean, how animals interact with each other, and how to protect endangered species.

3. Ocean chemistry: Research on ocean chemistry can help us understand how acidification and other chemical changes in the ocean impact marine ecosystems and human health.

4. Marine geology: Research on the seafloor can help us understand how the ocean was formed, how it has changed over time, and how to protect fragile marine habitats.

5. Ocean engineering: Oceanographic research has led to the development of new technologies for exploring, monitoring, and protecting the ocean, such as autonomous underwater vehicles and underwater drones.

Overall, oceanographic research is essential for understanding the ocean and its impact on the planet, and for developing sustainable solutions for managing our oceans for the future.

Dealing with the “ineffable unobtainium” of history (I): Simplicity

Michael Gorman
Published: 31 August 2006

Abstract

Good history teaching begins with the idea that subject matter itself teaches. There are those who simply (1) tell stories, and most students are happy to be led down paths laid out by someone else. These people, however, completely miss the idea that history should be more than a series of boring stories. As Marc Bloch once said, it is a point not to forget that the historical class is a scientific discipline. Hence the practice of history cannot fail to be purely scientific, and, in the final analysis, it has one great advantage over natural science. Although the latter determines everything deductively, in history only the deduction is often left standing. Therefore, one must work by discovery. One begins with the specific, and must come to a synthesis with the general.

Since at most one in a thousand—two thousand at best—of the supposed specialists can claim to have mastered the history of ancient Japan, the problems are serious. But much of what is wrongly regarded as history can be considered history. For example, historians of science now recognize that some of the early cosmological theories of Aristotle and others are history. It is equally possible that some of the early theories in psychology, evolution, geography and other fields were actually science. Thus these historical objects have value as history (whereas authors who write with the singular aim of “popularizing” history might say that they are presenting history as science, which is an oversimplification). Because the actual, detailed history of the subject has not yet been written, or at least there is no one in the scholarly field of the object concerned who has published on it, it can be described as history in embryo. At this stage, at least, both object and history of the object can be an object of study. In order to delineate this difference, one must first note the following: History means finding out the dates and places (the concrete details) of the significant events in the subject; it does not mean explaining their significance and significance-making. This distinction is important, because sometimes only a small quantity of what is important and what is unimportant about these objects are known. Nevertheless, it is still possible for the object to be considered scientific on the basis of the few aspects that can be deduced. This is already at least some form of science, since the conditions surrounding it can

and awareness to the world. Focusing on Professional Geoscientist, Field Geologist, Geoarchaeology, and many other rock related science from around the world. How our planet became what it is today and how can that relate to the local communities we live in.
It all started at the beginning of May 2017. While having conversations with a colleague, we talked about potential road trip trips we have already gone on, things of nature we wanted to see, and how we wanted to take our work with us so we could both document the beauty of our findings for people who were not around to witness it firsthand.
Without even planning it much, I sat down to start sketching a road trip road map in my notebook when I received a phone call from my now fiancé. He mentioned to me he wanted to start a regular forum discussion with some co-workers on the upcoming Earth science field trip to the Northwest Territory of Canada. So I came up with the idea of documenting everything they did, including the super awesome geology, through my photographs.
The first event was a presentation on the GNWT Geoscience department by Brian McOmber, from the Field Geology Division. He talked about the future work the Northern Territories will have in our geosciences.
This presentation focused on the most notable geologic formations found in the Northeast part of the Northwest Territories. The case study area consisted of the Budgong, Budner, and Sanaqana Basins. Two major sedimentary facies are recognized in the study area which are defined in the eastern, cratonic-dominated segments of the basin and the eastern Cordilleran belts to the west. These regions are further divided by various unconformities to which they can be further divided as seen in their respective integrated fault systems within the study area.
The Lower Paleozoic dominates the Eastern cratonic portions of the basin, specifically composed of the Budnern Bedrock exposed throughout the study area with rocks ranging from Paleozoic to Archean. The Eastern Cordilleran belts are composed of the best exposed Cambrian and Ordovician shales, sandstones, and volcanic sediments. Upper and Lower Cambrian rocks have good exposure in the Sanaqa and Budger regions of the Study Area with some Late Devonian to Silurian rocks found to the south. Major fault trends are the main anticlines which bound the formation of the Multiple Shale Formation found around the southern part of the Budnern.

AI (artificial intelligence) is a rapidly evolving field of computer science that aims to create intelligent machines that can perform tasks that typically require human-level intelligence. The history of artificial intelligence dates back to the early 20th century when the term was first coined.

During the 1940s and 1950s, several pioneers in the field of computer science, including Alan Turing, John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and Claude Shannon, began developing the first prototypes of AI systems. These early AI systems were based on logic programming, which involved creating algorithms that could manipulate logical statements to achieve specific tasks.

In the 1960s, the development of digital computers and the availability of large datasets made it possible to develop more complex AI systems. The first AI applications emerged, such as IBM's Deep Blue, which used machine learning to defeat human chess champions.

In the 1980s, the focus of AI research shifted from symbolic reasoning to statistical methods, and machine learning emerged as a powerful tool for developing intelligent systems. In the 1990s and 2000s, AI applications gained momentum, especially in the areas of natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics.

In the 2010s, advances in computing power and big data enabled researchers to develop new AI systems that can learn from massive amounts of data and make complex decisions. The development of deep learning algorithms, in particular, has revolutionized the field of AI, enabling systems to learn from raw data without explicit programming.

Today, AI is being used in a wide range of applications, from self-driving cars to virtual assistants and even to predicting the spread of diseases. The future of AI is likely to be even more exciting, with new technologies and applications emerging every day.

Can you give me an example of a recent AI application?
Sure! One recent AI application that has gained a lot of attention is the development of AI-powered chatbots. Chatbots are computer programs that can simulate conversation with human users, and they are being used in a wide range of industries and applications.

One example of an AI-powered chatbot is the one developed by the clothing company H&M. The chatbot, which is available on Facebook Messenger, helps customers find and purchase products by asking them questions about their preferences and style. The chatbot uses natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning to understand the customer's responses and provide personalized recommendations.

Another example is the chatbot developed by the travel company KLM,

; Slugs , Snails and Frogs, and the food chain.
This debate of mine has continued over a few gardening forums and blogs, including my own which hasn’t been active for some time.
Let me elaborate, a wild slug or snail, will for the most part eat dead leaves, fine, no problem. They don’t leave holes in the leaves they eat, even though if you were to dig down into the earth beneath it would be obvious they do. They also don’t crawl onto the leaves in order to spread the eggs that will hatch later, so I have some difficulty with this argument.
The argument is that I should turn over leaves or rocks, or remove the top soil and put them in a box. But if I do that, then every slug under that rock or within a soil bank will die. I have heard it said that they crawl in and out with the prey, so I can understand this a little. But if it was the frogs, then I would have to squash those too, as for me, I believe their dying from my hands has a little too much impact.
Some blog advice on how to stop the nasty slugs, boils down to poisoning them and dig up the eggs, which will mean more slugs in the long run. While there is nothing wrong with this to my eyes, I can’t imagine myself poisoning something that I enjoy spending time in, and then taking the eggs, burying them and hoping they never reach the surface. What happens when the next storm washes them out or they do hatch?
Over at Toad Green, the suggestion is to chuck them in a pond to keep them happy, which I would have to confess makes me chuckle. At the other extreme, someone suggested in a blog last year about a captive breeding programme for them, with only male slugs supplied, to try and control numbers and balance the food chain. Hardly seems like a serious idea.
Can this behaviour be stopped? It’s an interesting thought, but if I tried to stop it and didn’t find a solution, then I would have to deal with them again. It does feel a little like kicking the proverbial possum, an incredibly stupid animal that for a reason I’m not too sure of, seems to have a fascination with our garden. Though I do appreciate he does keep me informed of anything nasty in the shrubs, letting us know a hedgehog is nearby if he wasn’t hiding inside one of the bottles we left out. So I guess we don’t know

“It is not our purpose to destroy your houses. On the contrary, our policies would result in the building up of millions of new dwellings, in the organization of an enormous housing stock, and in the provision of planning aid and advances to local government which would enable it to plan better. A restoration of order is simply necessary. Our problems today are no longer those of mere reconstruction. We have to strengthen a country which must become a strong economy if it wants to become, at the same time, a great power in a peaceful Europe.”

The influential French architect Le Corbusier famously once said: “The first business of all architects is to discover or to create the preconditions for the invention of building which is their function.”

I believe that to achieve such a function, you should seek to truly understand what influences you in your studies or work and what factors from this influence create a feeling in your work. Without this internal understanding of your personal framework, and without the deeper exploration of your passions, relationships and all other facets of yourself, your work may very well turn out to be generic. And no matter how hard you try, a generic piece of work is unlikely to be transformative and necessarily leading to great achievements.

Instead, I think you should aim for architecture that can stand for its foundations. What you build on should in fact be the purest material of all: your thoughts, soul and understanding about yourself. And everything else should serve this as a tool – not as a framework that you should imitate, and that becomes a confinement to your thinking and being.

Then how do you actually get started? Here are a couple of things to consider when going about getting started.

Act with patience

Good architecture is not the work of a single day, month or year, but works with patience.

In all of your work and study, you must go about with an open perspective. The best way to test this is through the experiences of your predecessors and the experiences of those that are already established in the field of your studies, and those which are close to the field. Look at what they produce and reflect on them. Learn from what they have achieved, and also from what they have failed.

For instance, many students spend a lot of time talking about what could be done in their profession, and a lot of time talking about what is done in their profession. However, they do not really know what already exists and what should never be done. A first step should be to look at what is already done, without bias, and reflect on

intelligence and how it contributes to effective decision making, including key terms such as data analytics, predictive modeling, and data visualization. Additionally, discuss the different types of business intelligence tools and platforms, such as spreadsheets and dashboard software, and how they are used to gather, analyze, and present information in a meaningful and actionable way. Finally, provide examples of successful implementation of business intelligence within organizations and its impact on their decision-making processes. Business intelligence is a process that involves using data to make informed decisions in a business. It involves collecting data, analyzing it, and presenting it in a way that can be used to make decisions. The ultimate goal of business intelligence is to provide insights that can help organizations make better decisions.

Key terms that are used in business intelligence include data analytics, predictive modeling, and data visualization. Data analytics involves using statistical and analytical techniques to examine data and identify patterns and trends. Predictive modeling involves using statistical techniques to make predictions based on data. Data visualization involves presenting data in a visual format to make it easier to understand and analyze.

Business intelligence tools and platforms are used to gather, analyze, and present information in a meaningful and actionable way. Some common tools and platforms include spreadsheets, dashboards software, and data visualization tools. Spreadsheets are often used for data analysis and can be customized to suit specific business needs. Dashboards software is used for presenting data in a visually appealing way and can be customized to display data in real-time. Data visualization tools are used to present data in a way that is easy to understand and can be used to create interactive charts and graphs.

Successful implementation of business intelligence within organizations can lead to significant impacts on their decision-making processes. By using data to make informed decisions, organizations can increase their profitability, reduce costs, and improve their overall performance. For example, a manufacturing company might use business intelligence to optimize their production processes and reduce waste. This would help them save money and improve their overall performance. Another example is a retail company that might use business intelligence to analyze customer data and use that information to improve their marketing strategies.

In conclusion, business intelligence is a process that involves using data to make informed decisions. It uses key terms such as data analytics, predictive modeling, and data visualization. Different types of tools and platforms are used for gathering, analyzing, and presenting information in a meaningful and actionable way. Successful implementation of business intelligence within organizations can lead to significant impacts on their decision-making processes.

has never been an equal one; the traditional inescapable resistance of technical advancement to express creativity has marginalized and debilitated people working in theater. Technology, in turn, has been more inclined to stage around the theater – it has depended on the theater to realize its value. In recent years, theater and technology have discovered a kind of symbiosis: technology is beginning to use the power and new media to shift attention back toward the audience, as has always been theater’s goal, and this in turn is giving theatre back some of the power that has always been denied it.
I present an interesting way theater and technology can continue to work together while in dialogue with audience members. I started by asking my friends whether they believe theater is capable of creating a piece that reconfigures the audience/viewer from “passive audience” to “active audience”. Almost all answered in affirmative.
For a huge percentage of people in theater, I guess they have made a career of making theater accessible, paying special attention to making it as accessible as possible. I am a little annoyed by this for a few reasons: (1) Accessibility is important, but it doesn’t start off as a goal. (2) This mentality discourages audiences from taking part in the experience, because it is not supposed to be a passive experience. (3) Accessibility (like perspective) comes not only in the form of interpretability, but also in the form of control. The idea of being able to give accessibility to people with the control of the experience is too much of a fatal blow. I believe (over a past week) there are 3 parts to my argument.
1. Accessibility and audience participation in a performance is not a priority to theater.
2. Often the term accessibility can be represented as a verbal roadblock from people.
3. A second goal of theater is to challenge, so challenging can cause accessibility issues.
Touchstones for the first two parts are Miguel Gutierrez’s “What’s A Rest?”, an essay I think is the proof in the pudding for the fact that accessibility is not of any priority to theater. There are also so many examples of productions that have been broadly reviled for “usability” issues, and people haven’t backed down from the project. If one can think of enough examples, I think you can make a case that accessibility isn’t a priority of theater.
“Accessibility” has an odd definition in that it both encourages and discourages participation from its audience. This fact becomes an even more convincing example of this point when

Recently I had a discussion with someone in a thread regarding the concept of alternative medicine. During this discussion, the person kept on insisting that people really needed a long-term, systematic scientific approach to wellness. This person would then cite a recent study or perhaps a scholar (such as Watson) who held a similar view. He seemed perfectly content that the forces of science would be on the case and take care of this "unscientific nonsense".
However, he left out an important point: If you wait for the long-term, systematic scientific approach, no doubt you will die before it is done. Unless you have a will to live with your disease, it will have a dominating effect on your life.
A person named Joe Rosenfield died while waiting for his doctor to finish a long-term, systematic study to get to the bottom of his condition. Rosenviecraft had been sick with a disease which was thought to have been cured by the doctor's prior examination. The doctor had given him the all clear to go back to work. However, upon further investigation, he discovered that the cancerous cells had returned and he had no choice but to tell Rosenfield that there was nothing he could do.
So much for waiting for the long-term, systematic scientific approach to "cure" disease. Even when this strategy is applied, medical science is slower to react than is a sick person who has seen enough of death to get a temporary "fix" on his problem. That is, the benefits of the scientific approach to medicine are unevenly distributed. While a person who has only a 30% chance of survival awaits the long-term, systematic approach, this probability decreases as time goes on and worsens as illness strikes other areas. As life-limiting diseases set in, death becomes more certain with each hour that passes. We all know of people who have died in the course of waiting for a diagnosis. Some have died while waiting for a cure.
Some of the very best medical caregivers I have met have done almost nothing to seek a cure for disease and instead had turned their efforts to survival for the here and now. We are all sick, and we are all going to die. Very few people survive without medical intervention, and for those who do, they almost never turn down the offer of a cure. Sometimes, though, the cure is worse than the disease. So the question now is: should people rush to get medical treatment to get rid of the disease, or should they wait for the scientific long-term, systematic approach? Now the above

's largest sub-field – forensic psychology. Forensic psychology is not a sub-field of counseling psychology, it is not a sub-field of social psychology, it is not a sub-field of counseling. It is a separate branch of psychology that seeks to apply a number of specialized skills to the field of criminal justice and related areas of law.
As a forensic psychologist, you are often called in to give your expertise on cases involving violent crimes or sexual crimes. These include murder investigations, stalking, and domestic violence. Because you have the necessary training and education to provide expert witness testimony, you can play an important role in the prosecution of violent crimes.
Before you begin your career as a forensic psychologist, you will need to determine which of the following sub-fields of psychology you would like to focus on in your professional life. This will allow you to focus on your job search with a clear goal in mind.

was not originally created in any one particular place or time but rather in the far reaches of the mind of human kind. The most widespread practice of Meditation is the practice of sitting silently and focusing on the breath. That practice was brought from India to the west by the Buddha himself at the beginning of this millenia. However, it is a sad fact that the only reason he chose to share this powerful technique was in order to assist others in the same struggle he himself was experiencing. As an ex alcoholic he was no stranger to desire, and had found no way to fulfill or release it.
Although meditation is an extremely deep and powerful practice it does not attempt to coerce the mind into submission in any way. Neither does it seek to give the practitioner total control. In the very beginning it is true that the mind can be observed only partially due to physical interference. As this simple attention grows gradually other sensory and emotional responses gradually give way. It was this way for Buddha. He would initially observe a chattering mind because he had not yet reconciled his mind so he chose to look inwardly and find the root cause of the chatter.
It would be fair to say that most of our waking attention is spent thinking about the past or anticipating the future, never actually focusing on the present. When we come to the awareness that all of those thoughts are an attempt to soothe the mind, the same kind of methods that we employ are replaced with the simple act of focusing on the breath. Then we realize that each thought is bringing us in closer to the present moment and giving us the opportunity to bring the practice out of the body and into the mind, which is a powerful thing. After that realization we can begin to detach from past and future, and begin to remember to bring ourselves back to the present moment.
Having more experience and practice, the old and new experiences begin to merge into a deeper and more profound experience. The noise of the mind is no longer as loud and the quality of the practice begins to become clearer and the object less important and distracting. One of the most powerful aspects of meditation is the awareness it gives the practitioner of the method itself. During this practice a sort of vigilance enters our perspective which reminds the mind that every stray thought is a distraction and not a limitation. Then we can begin to see that this is all really just thought and that it has no real purpose other than to create suffering.

Education in a Future World:

In a future world, education was seen as a fundamental right for all citizens. It was considered a key to unlocking the potential of individuals and society as a whole. Education was provided to every person, regardless of their race, gender, religion, or socio-economic background.

The education system in this future world was much different from the traditional one. The curriculum was designed to be more practical and hands-on. Instead of only focusing on academic subjects, students were taught practical skills that would be useful in their daily lives. They learned how to cook, sew, build, and repair, as well as basic computer skills, and financial literacy.

The schools were also designed to be more eco-friendly and sustainable. They used solar panels and wind turbines for their energy needs, recycled and reused materials, and had gardens where students could learn about gardening and growing their food.

Teachers were highly trained professionals who were respected and valued for their expertise. They were not only there to teach but also to mentor students, offer guidance and support, and help them develop their personal and emotional well-being.

Technology played a significant role in education in this future world. Students had access to high-speed internet and advanced digital tools that made learning more engaging and interactive. They could take online courses, attend virtual classrooms, and collaborate with their peers and teachers from all over the world.

The education system also placed a strong emphasis on lifelong learning. People were encouraged to continue their education throughout their lives, whether through short courses, workshops, or online learning platforms. This allowed them to stay relevant and adaptable in an ever-changing world.

Overall, education in this future world was seen as a fundamental aspect of a person's development and a key factor in building a sustainable and prosperous society. It was a tool that empowered individuals to reach their full potential and contribute to society in meaningful ways.

How did the education system in this future world ensure that everyone had access to it?

In this future world, ensuring that everyone had access to education was a top priority. The education system was designed to be inclusive and accessible to all citizens, regardless of their socio-economic background, race, gender, or physical ability.

To ensure that all citizens had access to education, the government invested heavily in infrastructure and programs. They built schools in every community and made sure that they were accessible by public transportation. They also provided transportation assistance to students who needed it, including buses and other forms of transportation.

and culture, Unravel Too: Misi'ipi' (The Stones) lets you unravel secrets and discover lost objects, using easy to follow clues, puzzles and clues. But this time, you're helping another traveler named Misi'ipi' find her own lost family in The Stones.
The game is $5 to add to your subscription and comes with a bunch of cool items. This review is about the new game; you can check out a shorter review of the American Lion Age.
Unravel Too: The Stones is the second DLC for Yarny, but doesn't contain any DLC-specific challenges and there aren't new words. Instead, this DLC adds new gameplay and mechanics and tells a story from a completely different point of view.
If you aren't familiar with Yarny, he is an embodiment of love. As Unravel, Yarny travels through the world searching for new scraps of fabric to help him complete his journey. He doesn't talk (it would be weird if he did, given the fact that he's a ball of yarn), but you can hear his heartbeat. It does get a bit melancholy at times, but Yarny always gets through and things tend to work out in the end.
The DLC focuses on the story of Misi'ipi', a young Sioux tribe member who has been trying to find out where her family is for a long time. In this sequel to the original game, which we reviewed earlier this year, we find out what happens when things go wrong during her family's move to California.
One of my favorite parts of the game is learning about how Yarny first came to be. Yarny himself originally came from a frozen world, then used up all of his thread and needed more yarn to make a third body. He was crying out his little yarn heart to the world, and then...yarn started falling from the sky.
It looks like you may be able to collect similar hints in the DLC's later puzzles, which isn't much of a spoiler. If you like playing in silent spaces, you won't be disappointed in this part. We also get to hear some of Misi'ipi's inner thoughts; she's coming to grips with the past and the choices she's made, her bitterness and her longing for a better future.

One case is that of Stonehenge which sits next to a large industrial estate and receives no support from the local council. It has stood the test of time, however was recently vandalised by people wanting to damage it. The deliberate destruction of Orkney’s heritage could lead to a catastrophic loss of a major resource as these sites take decades to discover if not centuries.

There are many potential problems that can occur with this.
It may lead to sections being taken over by tour buses or more and more motorhomes or the closure of sections as they do not get maintained. : where to start? - Aries Dynamics, Inc.
Home » Blog » Understanding history from first principles: where to start?
The answer depends on what knowledge area we are talking about. If you want to study the history of Russia or Italy over the last 1,000 years, you have to know a lot of detail about the Russian or Italian languages, cultures, religions, family dynamics, land uses, migrations, wars, politics, ect. You can’t understand the Russians or the Italians without understanding the particulars of their languages and cultures and things like that.
With broad questions, we start at a more fundamental level, and we put some people in to represent a whole population at a certain period of time and place. They have different social roles – child, worker, young couple, and so on – and each one can be affected by changes in some other part of the historical system, such as an epidemic or major religion. One family may be less prosperous than another family because of an influenza pandemic that didn’t hit their farm but did hit the next farm, that also happened to be closer to some big city.
So why do this? What’s the point? What is our purpose for building and testing all these models, if they may not capture everything?
The point is that we want to understand how individual people, events, and behaviors interact and what happens as a result. Once a model is built and tested, its results will sometimes be completely at odds with the actual outcomes of human events. But we build the model anyway because it can tell us what to look for and what to anticipate. And if the model isn’t quite right, it can still guide us in more fundamental investigations.
History is rich with potential to provide clues for future works. Thus the value of historical modeling. I invite you to read on, if you are interested in getting a more detailed explanation of the history modeling framework.
Note: History modeling is part of the Aries innovation project suite.

and its impact on the field of ethics.
The history of philosophy is vast and complex, with its roots in ancient Greece and continuing to this day. Philosophy is the study of fundamental questions about reality, knowledge, ethics, and the nature of the mind.

In ancient times, philosophers such as Aristotle and Plato wrote extensively on the nature of the self and the world, and on the nature of knowledge and morality. These early philosophers were concerned with the question of how to live a good life, and the importance of acting in accordance with a set of values and principles.

Over time, the study of philosophy expanded to include topics such as metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics. In the Enlightenment period of the 17th and 18th centuries, philosophers such as Immanuel Kant and John Locke emerged, who championed the notion of rationalism, and argued that reason and logic should be the foundation of ethical systems. They focused on the importance of moral autonomy and the cultivation of individual rights and responsibilities.

In the 20th century, philosophy continued to evolve, with philosophers such as Jean-Paul Sartre, Martin Heidegger, and Hannah Arendt exploring the role of ethics in society, and the importance of reflecting on the meaning and purpose of human existence.

Ethics, in particular, has been a central concern of philosophers throughout history, with many arguing that it is the foundation of all moral action. In recent years, the field of ethical theory has grown significantly, with scholars exploring topics such as consequentialism, deontology, virtue ethics, and care ethics.

Overall, the study of philosophy and its impact on the field of ethics has been significant. Philosophers have helped to shape the way we think about ethics and moral values, and have developed frameworks for evaluating and critiquing ethical systems. Moreover, the intersection of philosophy and ethics has led to the emergence of new theories and approaches to ethical decision-making, and has contributed to the development of contemporary ethical frameworks such as social justice, environmental ethics, and animal ethics. As such, the study of philosophy and ethics remains an important and relevant pursuit for individuals and society alike.

and its impact on society and industry Robotics have a long and fascinating history that dates back to ancient times. While early mechanical devices were often seen as mechanical gods, modern robotics has come a long way since then. 

The modern era of robotics began in the 1950s, when computers were first introduced and led to the development of robotics technology. Researchers at Stanford University developed the first ever robotics program, called UNIMATE, which helped automate industrial processes. In the following years, robotics technology continued to advance, and new machines were developed to perform a range of tasks from manufacturing to space exploration.

Today, robotics technology has revolutionized many aspects of society and industry. From manufacturing to healthcare, transportation to education, robotics has had a profound impact on our lives. The use of robots in manufacturing and production has led to higher efficiency and productivity, while robots in healthcare and elder care have been lifesaving in helping to treat and care for patients. Robots are also being used in agriculture, where they can plow fields, harvest crops, and more. 

The use of robotics in transportation has been a topic of much discussion, as robots are being developed to drive cars and trucks. While many people are still hesitant to trust robots behind the wheel, this technology is sure to improve safety and efficiency on the roads. 

Overall, robotics has had a significant impact on our society and industry. As technology continues to advance, we can expect to see even more exciting developments in this field.

We don’t discuss it much around these parts, but smart technology really has taken over the world. And we don’t mean just “What technology you up to this weekend?”, we mean bionic-like Bluetooth paired hearing aides, season-long integrated enough to smell dope, practical enough to keep your drinks cold, and new laser technology powerful enough to read your heartbeats.
In this digital world we’ve essentially trained this, um, lifeform to be as close to us as the next BFF. We ask it advice, it does what we want, it designs our furniture and meal plans for us, it unassumingly relieves us of all human flaws, responsibilities, and stress. If you really want to impress us, call it a “foodbot”. We’re not talking about your lawn mowing, our of sight, out of mind robot, but a robot who’s right next to you churning out nutritious, freshly prepared, preservative and antibiotic free food. It’s like having your own personal chef.
And this from the same people we trust to watch our kids, keep us safe, or maybe even even give us 3rd party bail. Just sayin’. The future’s weird and now there’s a high probability of your future decisions and capabilities being influenced by an independently-thinking artificial intelligence.
Gaining in popularity are systems that are intelligent enough to learn on their own. They don’t just follow an algorithm based on user input and intrinsic data but actual real-time learning that draws on the previously unconsidered input to come up with new data relevant to its original information. Those systems essentially take risks that humans are inherently loathe to do. Don’t like that mix of Chinese food and beer? Well it says you do.
Shout out to MIT for fast-tracking this advancements in the field of automated reasoning. But the truth is, there’s nothing truly autonomous or independent in automated reasoning because you’re still taking every input – including those calculated from big data, partially unmodified, and with certain dependent parameters – then assigning a probability to what you want. You don’t have a say. You’re still being influenced by your otherwise, previously unconsidered input. It just happens to be more of an unbiased input. Most of the time. The “more of an unbiased input” part is the worrisome part.

The past ten years have seen an explosion of interest in large collaborative programs aimed at discovering the many genes that underlie brain disease and mental illness. To date, progress in identifying the genes that cause these disorders has been modest, but the possibility of uncovering causes for many of the more than 350 behavioral, cognitive, and neurological disorders afflicting mankind has led to a frenzy of excitement. In a short time, such interdisciplinary efforts may allow physicians to predict and even prevent mental illness; or to manipulate gene expression to relieve neurological and psychiatric symptoms. In contrast to previous research on mentally ill people and their pets, here the subjects of study are the DNA themselves.
Individuals have participated as "volunteers" in the Human Genome Project and in the collection and analysis of genetic and health data from several hundred other population-based studies. At the same time, legislators, bioethicists, psychologists, physicians, geneticists, and the general public are struggling to formulate rules that govern this new approach to medical research.
Mark Silver and Michael West, who have worked together for two decades on ethical, legal, and social issues relating to genetic research, have collected essays from 11 of their colleagues whose work has expanded the boundaries of biomedicine to include not only the care and treatment of patients with an array of disorders, but also the creation of "new" humans through genetic engineering.
Biotech Dreams will contribute to this ongoing debate. No one who reads this book can be surprised at where the most recent scientific breakthroughs have led us, but the book also presents examples of optimism and folly that suggest solutions that may not be immediately apparent to readers of the medical press.

As a fertility acupuncturist with over 15 years of experience working with women experiencing fertility issues, I do not have personal beliefs or experiences that relate to personal choices of birth. however, here are some general steps one might take to incorporate art as part of their holistic birthing plan, as informed by research:

1. identify your beliefs and values around birth. consider what is important to you, whether it be having a natural birth, having a positive birth experience or minimizing discomfort.

2. research and select art practices that align with your beliefs and values. some examples could include meditation, visualization, music therapy, and guided imagery.

3. decide on a specific type of art therapy that works for you. for example, you might choose painting, drawing, or collage.

4. find a qualified art therapist or healthcare provider who is experienced in offering art therapy to pregnant women. in some cases, a midwife or doula may be able to refer you to a qualified provider.

5. learn about the benefits of art therapy, such as reducing stress and anxiety, improving mood, and increasing overall wellbeing.

6. plan to incorporate art therapy into your daily routine, perhaps during your prenatal care or as part of your birth plan. 

7. monitor your progress and adjust your plan as needed, seeking additional support if necessary.

What type of music is best for guided imagery during birthing? There is no one "best" type of music for guided imagery during birth. The most effective music will depend on the individual preferences and needs of the person undergoing birth, as well as the context in which they are using it.

Guided imagery is a mental exercise that uses positive and calming imagery to reduce anxiety and prepare for birth. Some people prefer instrumental music, such as classical, nature sounds or gentle, rhythmic music that complements their breathing and helps them focus. Others may find music with lyrics or more complex rhythms distracting and prefer silence or nature sounds.

It is also important to note that listening to music during birth should be done with caution and under the guidance of a medical professional. Some women may find that music can increase or decrease their pain perception, making it difficult to manage the intensity of contractions. It is important to discuss any concerns or preferences related to music during birth with your healthcare provider.

Meteorology is the science of weather and climate, and it has become increasingly important in modern society due to its impacts on daily life, agriculture, transportation, energy production, and environmental protection. Meteorology is essential to modern life because it helps us understand and predict weather conditions that can affect various aspects of our lives.

Here are some ways meteorology is critical to modern society:

1. Weather forecasting: Meteorologists use advanced technology and modeling to predict weather patterns accurately. Accurate weather forecasting helps people plan their daily activities, such as traveling, working, or farming. Farmers can plan their planting season and irrigation schedules using weather data.

2. Disaster management: Meteorology plays a crucial role in managing disasters such as hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, and droughts. Meteorologists help people prepare for these events by issuing warnings and alerts, evacuating people from affected areas, and providing emergency responders with critical information.

3. Transportation: Meteorology helps aviation and shipping industries to ensure safe travel. Accurate weather forecasts help pilots plan their flights to avoid storms, while marine meteorologists help seafarers avoid dangerous weather conditions such as hurricanes and typhoons.

4. Energy production: Meteorologists help determine the best times to generate and distribute energy, as weather conditions affect the output of solar, wind, and hydroelectric power plants.

5. Environmental protection: Meteorology helps monitor air and water quality, track pollution, and estimate the impact of climate change on ecosystems.

In summary, meteorology is vital in modern society because it provides critical information for individuals, governments, and organizations to make informed decisions and take proactive measures to protect lives and properties. Without meteorology, many aspects of our daily lives would be significantly affected.

It's amazing how much meteorology affects everything. Yes, meteorology is a complex and rapidly evolving field that has a profound impact on all aspects of modern society. It is essential to stay informed and prepared to minimize the impact of weather-related disasters and to harness the benefits of weather forecasts to improve our lives.

insurance are simple: The policy provides coverage for injuries, medical expenses and even death that may occur during a trip. From medical injuries to flight cancellations, if you get hurt while on a trip, an accident occurs, or you need to stay in the hospital, travel insurance may be able to help. What many may not realize is that the specifics of what is covered under a travel insurance policy can vary wildly. So before you travel overseas, it’s a good idea to give yourself a more thorough understanding of what to look for in travel insurance and what to expect from a policy.
The easiest way to get started on your search for travel insurance is by talking to a professional to determine what kind of policy you will need. “A professional insurance broker with knowledge of local markets will be able to help you find an insurance package that will provide the coverage that you need, while at the same time satisfying the legal requirements in the area where you will be traveling,” says Jaleh Faronji, general manager, US and Canada, Insight. You can start by comparing travel insurance quotes, but it is wise to do some initial research yourself first.
A couple of basic types of coverage you can look for are crisis contingency coverage and medical coverage, which are common for all policies, and missed flight coverage, which is usually covered only by more expensive policies. “As the costs to travel are significantly higher than in past decades, the price of your policy should reflect this,” Faronji adds. If you’re traveling for business or leisure, and visiting countries with unstable currencies, or hot-spots of violence, it is likely that you will want a policy that includes emergency medical evacuation. “More complex policies can also include baggage delay, trip cancellation, trip interruption, and even limited travel liability,” Faronji adds.
As you compare quotes from a variety of sources, you will need to figure out what the policy actually includes before you commit to it. “As most insurance companies don’t actually market their policies, this is hard to do. Also, policies have confusing names, which makes it even more difficult to differentiate products,” says Karina Calderon-Fleischer, director of product development, BlueWave Insurance Agency.
For example, flight insurance is only offered by a small number of providers and is often included with premium packages. “It should be explained in the brochure and online and can’t be simply selected,” Faronji adds. Conversely, many providers have varying medical coverage, and each policy may have different levels. You want to make sure that

that allows for information to be stored online has led many advertisers to promote their business on the Internet. Technology that allows consumers to be in control of the time and the way they are reminded to purchase is something advertisers are taking advantage of as well as the general trend of online advertising. This paper will explore Internet advertising, look into the latest trends and technologies that are being used by advertisers, and examine the advantages and disadvantages of online advertising.
As a result of technology advancement, information is becoming available on the web for consumers to learn what to purchase, or watch as soon as they want. Advancements have enabled large businesses to launch companies that specifically create great advertising on the Internet. Interactive and online ads have started emerging and are being run on web sites, blogs, video sharing sites like Youtube, and video games. This is where the concept of advertainment was born, (refer to Appendix, Image 1). This is where entertainment is mixed in with advertising to consumers. Due to this format of online advertising, users will most likely not know they are being advertised to because the ads are embedded in content. One of the reasons for the growing use of on-line advertising is, it allows for ads to be targeted to potential customers based on search terms or demographic data (Lin 322).
The reason many advertisers are heading to online platforms because it allows them to find their target market. What advertisers are looking for is not the quantity, but the quality and that is what the web allows them to do, says Renee Zan, director, marketing and communications at Yum Brands. For example, the fast food restaurant kfc.com. provides daily wallpapers (refer to Appendix, Image 2) targeted to male aged 12 - 24 who consider themselves car enthusiasts. Online advertising allows advertisers to track exactly how many times their ad was viewed and how long the consumer stayed on the advertisement, as compared to TV where the only information that is known is how many people were watching the ad.
Online advertising is fairly new, and is constantly changing. Technology is improving rapidly allowing advertisers to get closer to their target market. One example of these technological advancements is called behavior targeting. Behavioural advertising targets consumers based on what they have done online. For example, if someone has been to one website several times, they are more likely to go to another similar site. The concept behind behaviour targeting is to show that person advertisements for products and services they have interest in (refer to Appendix, Image 3).

will reveal why our heads sometimes fall into that uneasy inclination to believe all kinds of nonsense.
Some would describe this state as cognitive dissonance. It is not hard to identify it - it is simply caused by feelings of discomfort - and in the vast majority of cases, it is perfectly innocuous.
It can also be a powerful engine of fear, an almost instinctual response to the new, the strange or the different. And it can be used to support all kinds of notions we're looking to trade on - be it the fact that we should never stray outside of The City or The Time To Buy is Now.
Why, for instance, do you think cars, for all their astonishing modernity, have retained a medieval insistence on their own enclosed volumes and the idea that it is OK to take two hundred lives on the road if that is inconvenient for the driving party?
Why do you think commercial planes cost two grand to go to Dubai and 50 bucks to go to Boston? As if the journey were the important part. As if we didn't know the day was coming that our progress would simply not be stopping, and once it does we can all become Martian colonies together?
Would it not make more sense to have cheaper, faster and more convenient transport than to have stubbornly preserved a whole system of beliefs that are, at the very least, completely opposed to progress? I could explain this to you in practical terms, but there are two simpler ones that are completely instinctual:
The brain is hierarchical. Which is to say, it is hardwired to think that the furthest part of the neighbourhood is just further than the nearest neighbour. To deny this is to deny the existence of a brain. And no matter how clearly we may see its overall inefficient structure and the joylessly self-perpetuating, self-harming absurdities that it contains, to do so is just beyond its wherewithal.
When we're buying a suit and you want to give us some cash back, you are going against the brain's sense of common sense. The brains of shoppers would also like to deny the existence of The City: they view it as a black hole of useless information and feel wronged by the Very Briefly Glimpsed Manhattan Place Where All That Jewellery Is That You Can't Feel You Can't See to which you took them and now try to take your revenge by leaving money on the table.
These two forces might be called The City and The Time To Buy Is Now, and they have only two faces, but

Part 2: The “how” of thunderstorms

This post is the continuation of the preceding one, that focussed on the “why” of thunderstorms. After the generation of uplift, clouds form, and these clouds will produce both ice and rain. Both of these types of precipitation will release energy to the atmosphere, and in doing so will combine to create strong storms. Since we will be building on material from the first part of the post, if you have not read the previous one, you are recommended to do so now.

Let us get to the bottom of why this happens, why it has anything to do with these meteorological concepts we have already learnt, and what are their precise origins. There are at least two important questions we would like to answer:

1. Why is there a difference in energy released by ice and rain precipitation? (more details) - We did not explicitly talk about the difference between ice and rain in the previous post, but in this section we have a ready-made mechanism to do just that.

2. What causes the precipitation to occur at a particular place? (more details)

First of all, what is precipitation? Well, precipitation is a fancy word for “water falling out of the sky”. Rain occurs when water droplets and/or ice crystals fall out of the cloud, and they could be “free-falling”, that is just falling out of the cloud as-is, or “hanging-down”, that is falling at a lesser speed due to a smaller terminal velocity. When we talk about “hanging-down”, we are referring to a cloud condensation level (CCL) and a cloud base.

How to calculate a CCL

The problem of calculating CCLs is solved by deriving an equation called a hydrostatic equation, which describes the vertical temperature and pressure variations in the atmosphere. In a simplified manner, one can describe a free-falling rain droplet falling at constant speed as one that is at the cloud-top (CT, an isobaric surface) or at the cloud-deck level (CDL, an isobaric surface), but one can hardly argue that a snowflake, or a hailstone would be at the same location as its rain counterpart. To calculate the exact location of a specific drop will require a full knowledge of the atmospheric state, including velocity fields and dynamic winds, as well as temperature and humidity profiles (most likely at the maximum resolution one could get with regard to satellite imagery). But in this post, we will focus on looking for the general

1. Education is essential for personal development: Education helps individuals develop critical thinking, problem-solving, creativity, and communication skills that are essential for personal development.

2. Education is crucial for employment: Education is often a prerequisite for many jobs, and those who have a higher education level are more likely to be employed and to earn a higher salary.

3. Education is vital for social mobility: Education plays a crucial role in the social mobility of individuals. A person's education level determines their access to better job opportunities, higher wages, and more significant income potential.

4. Education is essential for the growth of society: Education is fundamental to the development of society as it helps to create informed and active citizens who can contribute to the social, economic, and political progress of the nation.

5. Education is critical for a country's economic growth: Education is a key driver of economic growth, and countries with higher levels of education have a more robust economy, higher productivity, and better-educated workers.

6. Education is vital for a country's competitiveness: Education is important for countries to remain competitive in a global market. A country's education system determines its ability to produce quality graduates and workers.

In conclusion, education is an essential component of modern society, and investing in education can yield significant benefits for individuals, businesses, and the country as a whole.

Could you add some specific examples of how education has positively impacted society and the economy?

Sure, here are some specific examples:

1. In the United States, education has been shown to positively impact the economy, with high school graduates earning higher wages than those who did not finish high school. In 2020, the unemployment rate for high school graduates was 5.5%, while it was 13.6% for those without a high school diploma. Additionally, a study by Georgetown University found that for every dollar invested in education, it generates up to $10 in economic growth. 2. In Sweden, the government has invested heavily in education to create a highly educated and skilled workforce. As a result, the country has one of the lowest unemployment rates in Europe and a GDP per capita that is higher than the United States. 3. In developing countries, education has been shown to have a positive impact on reducing poverty. Studies have found that increasing access to education can lead to a reduction in poverty rates and improved living standards for families. 4. In Japan, education has been a cornerstone of the country's success. Japanese students consistently rank among the highest in international tests

manship and the need for respect for the opponent are deeply embedded in players' memories from the earliest days of the tournament. In 1955, at age 16, Jackie Pung, now president of the USA Table Tennis Association (USATT), was a substitute member of the table tennis team for her California junior high school that won the national girls' championships. Jackie's parents made a yearly trip with Jackie to compete in the national Championships. Even at age 16, Jackie was taught that the object was not to be first but to have a good time, be the best in the event, have fun with the competition, and act like a lady at all times. In 1956, Jackie and her family traveled to Des Moines, Iowa for the national championships. From the minute they arrived at the Airport, they were greeted by friendly Iowa State fans. Jackie recalls that every stop they made and everywhere they went people went out of their way to show her and her family how much they meant to them. Returning the favor, Jackie and her family exhibited good sportsmanship by showing their appreciation to everyone. While awaiting her flight home, all her teammates were gathering at the airport restaurant to celebrate with a steak dinner before their flight. The conversation turned to the state of Iowa, so Jackie volunteered an Iowa stereotype of, "They are some of the most friendly people I've ever known." Her roommate, Linda Seime, interjected, "How do you know?" asking if Jackie had been through Iowa. Jackie admitted that she had spent the entire time in Des Moines. Her roommate responded, "Well you may have only seen them in Des Moines, but they are all like that." And with that, they all turned to Jackie with open and friendly arms and welcomed her to Iowa.

fiction as a genre.
Science fiction is a genre of literature, film, and other forms of popular culture that explores imaginative and futuristic concepts and settings. It often involves the use of speculative fiction, advanced technology, and other elements that are beyond what is currently possible in the real world. 

Science fiction typically seeks to examine human nature, society, and the universe, while also challenging conventional ideas and assumptions. It often deals with themes of technology, artificial intelligence, space exploration, alien life, time travel, and other scientific or technological advancements. 

Science fiction can be both optimistic and pessimistic in its portrayal of the future. Some stories portray a utopian future in which humanity has overcome all challenges and achieved great advancements, while others depict a dystopian future in which society has regressed or declined due to various crises or conflicts. 

Overall, science fiction is a genre that invites us to imagine and explore new possibilities and perspectives, while also engaging with the reality of our own world and the world to come.

Betty Wiskind, BS (Desh).
Why did I pick meteorology?
In the fall of my junior year of high school, I realized I wanted to change my college major. My options included business and chemical engineering. Fortunately, I had an appointment with an advisor at Westminster College (PA) and she suggested that I major in something that I am really interested in.
I read in the student handbook about a new program in meteorology at Westminster College, so I visited Dr. Peter Ghil, Professor and Chair of the Physics Department. Dr. Ghil encouraged me to try it out and then figure it out from there. Dr. Ghil was a member of a consortium of eight universities that formed the Center for Climate System Research. I was able to attend the University of Washington, the world center for atmospheric and space sciences, for a summer semester and worked in the atmospheric research group. In summer 1988 I worked in the experimental tropical meteorology laboratory at Rice University and collected data for two weeks at sea on board the Research Vessel Andrew Barker. I went to meteorology conferences and encouraged classes to get involved. After I graduated from high school in 1989, I returned to Westminister College for my sophomore year. I took a full load of meteorology courses my junior year and graduated with a bachelor's of science degree in meteorology in 1991.
After that, I did a lot of public speaking in connection with meteorology to groups including scout troops, the American Legion, and Rotary clubs. I joined the National Association of Science Writers and the University of Denver's Graduate School of Journalism at the same time. I was the editor of the Metro Weather Watch newsletter. Later, I worked at the Farmers' Almanac in 1994 and at a radio station in Cape Canaveral, Florida in 1995. I got my master's degree in library science at the University of Denver in 1996 and was a librarian at Moffat County High School (CO) and the Colorado State University Extension Office in Hayden, Colorado for two years before moving back to Pennsylvania. I work at the APS Physics Department Library in University Park, PA and also help out with the Center for Exoplanets and
