First principle mathematics is a way of teaching mathematics that focuses on the basics before teaching abstract symbolic representations of the basics, such as algebra and trigonometry[1]. It is about the process, not the processes, and teaches students to develop an elementary working knowledge of key ideas that can help them to be successful in mathematics[2]. * **A drop of *Cl**\_O** tastes strongly of burnt sugar.** The salt was heated and the energy released by the heat dissociates the chlorine and oxygen atoms inside the salt.
* **A teaspoon of *Br**\_O**2 tastes like $$\ce{H3PO4}$$ and some sugar.** The iodine is reduced with the help of acidic oxygen atoms (from oxygen dioxide) and the chloride.
* **Vinegar tastes like *H**\_CO**2*.** Like the previous case, the hydroxide atoms from the acid break off and donate electrons to the phosphate, turning it into a free acid.
* **Complaining at *H**\_CO**2**.** Like the previous case, the hydroxide atoms from the acid break off and donate electrons to the phosphate, turning it into a free acid.

Like all sciences, biology uses evidence to form theories and hypotheses about our world. These ideas are tested and refined as we learn more about the environment and biology itself. Continue reading to learn more about the scientific method.
The scientific method is a way of testing theories and hypotheses, and it ensures that all discoveries are backed by evidence. This is how scientists understand how all living things and their environments are organized. This method consists of five steps: 1. Observation 2. Questioning 3. Research 4. Hypothesis 5. Experiment
1. Observation
Observations are used to make observations about the environment around us. These observations are then stored in a notebook for future reference. For example, if we were studying trees in the forest, we would be required to take regular notes about their appearance, size, how old they are, and whether or not there are any interesting features like flowers or fruit. The process of observing is very important because, without it, there would be no way for scientists to make accurate discoveries about the environment.
2. Questioning
The next step is to ask questions. For instance, if we were observing trees and notes about size and height, we would want to know things like what types of trees we saw. What about their leaves or bark? How much sunlight did each type receive? Where did these trees grow? All of these questions can be answered by using the scientific method.
3. Research
Research is the third step and it allows us to gather more information about our topic. For example, if we want to know more about the trees we observed in our forest, we would look at different types and their characteristics. These could include things like their height, shape, age, etc.
4. Hypothesis
The fourth step is the formation of a hypothesis. A hypothesis is just that – it’s a guess that can be tested through an experiment. For example, if our hypothesis was that sunlight was important to trees, we would then need to do an experiment. We might put some trees under a light and some trees under no light at all and measure how tall they grew compared to each other.
5. Experiment
This is the fifth and final step. It is the testing of the hypothesis. For example, if our hypothesis was that sunlight is important to trees, then we would put some trees in the sun and some in the shade and measure how tall they grew compared to each other. If our hypothesis was true, then we would find that the trees that were in

, Film Inquiry aims to support underrepresented film communities and to engage the public with diverse perspectives. Its creator and director, Mark Noel, discusses how the film industry can do more to support underrepresented groups, and why funding an initiative to get youngsters into filmmaking is key to future films focusing on different perspectives in television and online media.
Why are independent films so important and how important is their support?
The film industry is always in danger of becoming stale and repetitive, and of following trends and becoming a corporate business which produces the same product over and over again. Independent films, alongside good documentaries, help offset this danger. I strongly believe the success of independent films is the proof that film-makers cannot be 'crafted' by the Hollywood system, that film-makers thrive on freedom. This is the true culture of making and watching films.
Moreover, independent films tend to offer artists – directors, actors – the freedom to fully express themselves. As a film-maker, it is often difficult to fully express yourself as an artist through large, established film companies. This is partly why I founded Film Inquiry, to support the voices of independent artists who can only be heard through indie films.
Is Film Inquiry's focus on film education the key for ensuring a diverse film industry and audience?
I cannot help but believe that there is a direct correlation between the number of film students, the different ideas generated, and the diversity of films made. The foundation for future filmmakers are at our young people. A recent example of great filmmakers who started making films from the age of 11 is Julia Ducournau, whose film Raw went to Cannes. Getting into film with film schools provides the golden ticket to a more diverse film industry. It's my responsibility as director of Film Inquiry to support filmmaking schools, and to help provide people with the opportunities that enable them to make films.
How important is the audience for a diverse film industry and why?
Audiences themselves can decide the direction the industry needs to take. Audiences have spoken. We're in a golden age of film, just look at the diverse selection of films that our film institutions have commissioned this year. We also have a diverse selection of filmmakers producing films. But, if there was no audience for these films, these films could disappear.

(AI) is designed to provide a rigorous framework of logic, ethics, and value for the development and use of AI systems. Artificial intelligence has seen tremendous growth in recent years as more and more companies and organizations turn to artificial intelligence as a means to automate tasks, make better and more informed decisions, and optimize various processes to increase productivity and reduce costs. In this book, readers will learn the different models of artificial intelligence, and the functions and underlying principles of these models. A brief overview of the applications and examples of the use of AI is also given. The application of AI in the healthcare field is an area that is gaining significant attention, as evidenced by the rise of digital health and telemedicine. In the medical field, AI can be used to diagnose and treat diseases by analyzing medical images and data. For example, a system could be designed to analyze x-rays or MRI scans to detect tumors or identify other abnormalities in a patient's body. In addition, AI could be used to recommend personalized treatments based on a patient's unique medical history and genetic makeup. In the financial field, AI can be used to develop trading algorithms that analyze financial data to identify profitable trades. For example, a system could be designed to analyze market trends and news articles to predict whether a stock will rise or fall in value and then execute trades accordingly. In the educational field, AI can be used to personalize learning experiences for students by analyzing their learning styles and progress to recommend the most effective teaching methods and materials. For example, a system could be designed to analyze a student's performance on tests and assignments to identify areas where they need extra help and then recommend additional resources and tutoring. Overall, AI has the potential to revolutionize many aspects of society, from healthcare and finance to education and beyond. By providing tools and insights that help us make better decisions, AI can help us tackle some of the world's biggest challenges and improve our quality of life.

1.1. This is one of a number of papers published by the Marine Technology Society to celebrate the development of oceanographic science and technology. The basis of this paper is a symposium held in Corfu in 1985 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the laying of the Scylla cable, which carries the first cross-Atlantic acoustic communications link. At a time when the planning of the Geotraces cruise SGF-6366 is entering the cable-laying stage, this paper will serve as a reminder of the pioneering use of acoustic communications to explore and study the ocean. 1.2. The time of the laying of the Scylla cable coincides closely with that of the commencement of the OMNIUSE. This paper reviews the first half-century of oceanographic science in a description of how the technology for those initial endeavors developed. The relationship between oceanography and the development of technology is again exemplified by the presentation of an in-depth case study of the geophysical observations acquired during the first two legs of the current Geotraces cruise.

	Cognitive psychology: Neuroscience research can help better understand how the brain processes information and how different parts of the brain work together. This knowledge can be used to improve cognitive training, education, and memory retention.
	Sports science: By studying the neural basis of motor control and learning, scientists can help athletes improve their performance and prevent injuries.
	Business and education: By understanding how the brain works, organizations and educators can create more effective strategies for learning and productivity.

These are just a few examples of how neuroscience can be beneficial.

As sports fans, we tend to take things for granted. We follow their history religiously – from the players, the coaches, the leagues, and, of course, the championships. It is an honor if one is part of a successful sports history – being the one who made a historical achievement or an epochal occurrence. Recently we wrote a about sports with multiple champions. So take a look at these fun facts about multiple champions that may surprise you.
After winning their fourth NBA championship, Dallas Mavericks' Dirk Nowitzki and owner Mark Cuban walked into the locker room. The team members, however, were not overly excited. No one uttered a word. No loud celebration. Not even some squeals or high fives. Sure, the NBA finals is a huge deal. Any team that made it that far deserved to be celebrated. But as Dallas players would later say: "It is not like every time you won a game in the playoffs, the chairman of your company was there to pat you on the back". Nowitzki was angry. That celebration on his team's part was an obvious disrespect on Cuban. Surely he did not understand just how hard their previous season was. The Mavs went 97-65. They ranked third in the league. Their best play was the Golden State Warriors. But once they reached the third playoff round, they were blown away by Oklahoma City Thunder. Nowitzki was already 35 years old that season. Surely he felt that it was his best chance to make a championship team. He was right. Dallas finished 67-15 during the next season. They also had a backup named Tyson Chandler to defend the basket. In the 2011 NBA Finals, they won their first championship and the first in the team's history. They were never upset since. They cruised through the competition and won the next two finals. After that, Cuban became the team owner that counts the championship rings. He has them all hanging on a wall that forms a sort of halo around the locker room's entrance.

has been acknowledged through the years by a variety of genres and artists. Songs that convey emotion, struggle and hope have helped to unite people from around the world, whether they’re learning to stand up against an oppressive regime or sharing how they have overcome hardship.
In recent decades, music has also been viewed as an avenue to bring us together to work towards promoting tolerance, particularly in light of the devastating terrorist attacks in Manchester and London.
A concert organised by the Manchester Evening News and global partners that included One Direction’s Harry Styles and huge artists Rita Ora and Katy Perry drew a crowd of over 50,000 people to celebrate the city’s resilience.
City Slickers managed to squeeze into the 50,000 ticket capacity crowd with a fantastic experience both going and coming out of the stadium. However, we found a parking space that just so happened to be next to the stage, meaning we had a marvellous view all the way through.
The concert began at 8pm and ran on until midnight, which was perfect for us, as the weather was terrible, ensuring many people stayed away and missed the performances. Thankfully, the stadium is sheltered and the amazing atmosphere inside was quite literally electrifying, with tonnes of people keen to sing along to famous tracks.
The night was full of light in terms of colour, energy and atmosphere, with every artist performing and encouraging everyone to get involved, clap and sing.
Katy Perry and Robbie Williams were among the more popular acts, entertaining the crowd with some fantastic numbers that will live long in the memories of those who attended the charity concert.
A longer than anticipated, repeated rendition of ‘Somewhere Over the Rainbow’ sung by Mia Rosenburgh was beautiful to watch, followed by Williams and Styles combining to perform ‘Angels’ and ‘The Story of Us’, sending the crowds home with warmth, power and hope for the future.
It was such a joyous evening for all the residents of Manchester and a truly humbling experience to be a part of the festivities.
As we left the stadium, the rain hit us once again, but after such a long, emotional and electrifying night, we didn’t care. Everyone was back in high spirits and feeling at ease, discussing the quality of each performer with admiration.
I was lucky to have obtained tickets from City Slickers but I also saw many people getting in for free, so keep your ears to the ground for the next event like this. As always, come to us for comprehensive and honest advice.

But since it will be depleted on that trip, this air travel is modeled as a gas tank problem, where the amount of gas is increased by filling (g+); but on the return trip to the original location, it is diminished by 20 %, symbolized by g/2.

Question: "What is the route?"

Variables are: $g$ is the fuel amount, $v$ is the average speed and $d$ is the distance.

I have a problem with the answer to the same question here.

Here is my answer:

As mentioned in both answers, the answer depends on your interpretation of QM. There are various interpretations of QM, but they tend to differ on one main topic: the measurement process, which is where the trouble is. In Copenhagen, measurement is an operational process, similar to the standard apparatus (Laudan 1985). There is the quantum wavefunction and a quantum system in it. A measuring device and the human observer, the subjective element, are the last two stages. The resulting state of the quantum system (your bag of marbles, or whatever) is the subjectively measured outcome of the experiment. In contrast, some interpretations (the Many Worlds Interpretation, Bohm's theories, and decoherence theories) can say the measuring apparatus in the thought experiment can never be in the same state as the measured quantum system, but the correlations in the wavefunction say the system and apparatus have joint properties - joint wavefunctions and joint expectation values.

So...in terms of the things we experience as living humans, measurement is a fact about the world, as it relates to us. In terms of measurement outcomes, quantum uncertainty is gone. But in terms of the original question, we haven't fully answered it yet. To answer it completely, one would need to perform the measurement. In this case, after measurement, the two outcomes seem both possible, but one of them is chosen with equal probability.

I get a feeling, while thinking about this, that one will have to go for an empirical test with people as subjects. In one interpretation the answer seems straightforward: after all, in one measurement the bag of marbles will contain $$0$$ or $$1$$, and in the other it will contain one of the two, no matter what the experimenter does in the interval between the two measurements, and no matter what I, as the experimenter, do. Of course there will be no communication between the two experimenters.

In a discussion on Twitter with Julian Stenger, a mathematician and quantum theorist, a question was raised about how strong the effect would be. "Is it possible to show this as the universality of the phenomenon?" But I believe that in any comparison between the two experiments, one will have to take into account any interaction with the test subject and the apparatus. The idea is that the choice of which outcomes show up is 50/50 for both "experimenters".

Expository text is a type of writing style that is clear, concise and useful in telling a story or describing a situation. All texts, written, spoken or even silent, are made up of four different elements: dialogue, exposition, narrative and description.
These are the main features of an expository text.
1. There is the name of the author/ writer/ presenter/ speaker at the beginning of the text.
2. There is a lot of factual information (there is no real character or story, but a sequence of details, facts and theories that the writer intends to explain to you.
3. There is a lot of clear and concise writing and usually there is a clear purpose – which is to explain something. This is usually very informative.

According to multiple sources, the history of history is not straightforward, as there are multiple narratives and interpretations of events throughout time. However, we can focus on some of the main events and time periods in the development of history. 

The early history of history dates back to ancient civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece. The earliest recorded history was written by the Babylonians and Assyrians, which documented their laws and governance. The Greeks, led by Herodotus, began to use the term "history" to describe their accounts of the Persian Wars. 

During the Middle Ages, history began to be viewed as a record of the past and a tool for understanding the present. The study of history became more rigorous, and historians began to document their research in monographs and textbooks. 

During the Renaissance, the study of history became more interdisciplinary and focused on the individual. Historians such as Vasari and Machiavelli wrote biographies of famous historical figures. 

The Enlightenment brought about a focus on empirical evidence and reason, and history became a tool for understanding the origins of society and government. The rise of nationalism and the desire for national unity led to a focus on regional histories and local events. 

In the 20th century, history became a more global and interdisciplinary field, as historians studied events such as World War I and II and the rise of dictatorships. The study of women's history, social history, and cultural history emerged, and historians began to focus on the role of individuals in shaping history. 

In conclusion, the history of history is a dynamic and constantly evolving field, shaped by multiple perspectives and interpretations of events throughout time.

What kind of books should I read to gain knowledge on the major figures in history?

1. "The Life of Mozart" by George E. Hatch: This book is a comprehensive biography of Mozart, one of the most famous composers in history.

2. "The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin" by Benjamin Franklin: This autobiography of America's founding father is a classic of American literature and provides insight into his personal and political life.

3. "The Life of Napoleon Bonaparte" by William Hazlitt: This book is a biography of Napoleon Bonaparte, who is often called the greatest military and political leader of modern times.

4. "The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt" by Edmund Morris: This biography of Theodore Roosevelt, one of the most popular and influential presidents

teacher, who by mistake left a pen behind after he met with the student. The pen has some special properties. The pen has a small LED light bulb and a 9V battery. When the teacher left the pen behind, the student decided to take it home and experiment with it.

As the days passed, the student became fascinated with the pen's unique properties. He began to notice that the ink would glow even longer when he left it exposed to light for a few hours. He also found that if he twisted the pen while it was illuminated, he could change the color of the glow.

One day, the student decided to show off his discovery to his classmates. He let them hold the pen and see the magic for themselves. As they took turns holding the pen, they began to experiment with it themselves. Some of them noticed that the pen would glow even stronger when they held it against their skin.

One of the students, a curious girl named Mia, decided to ask the teacher about the pen. She was curious about the pen's properties and wanted to know if it had any practical use in the classroom.

The teacher was surprised to hear that the pen was still in Mia's possession. He explained that the pen was special and that he had left it there by mistake. He then went on to tell Mia about the pen's properties and how he had discovered them.

As the days went by, the teacher continued to wonder where the pen had disappeared to. He had forgotten about the pen and had been busy preparing for his next class. One day, he was called into the principal's office and was given a bouquet of flowers as a gift for being such a wonderful teacher.

As he accepted the flowers, he was surprised to find the pen that he had left behind in his pocket. The pen was intact, and its ink was glowing brightly. The teacher was overjoyed and realized that the pen was a gift from the universe to him.

"Hello!" Mr. Jarvis says.
"Hello, Tony!" Tony Stark replies.
"Okay, let me see. I wanna turn the sound of my computer up..."
"Thicc Beats on Blast."
See? It's already learning from conversations. Well, to be honest, this is just the example of one of the simplest examples of machine learning, and the further you get into the subject, the more complex it is.
So, if you're interested in AI, machine learning and making things smarter, then I'm your girl.
Let's start...
Artificial Intelligence
Many people think AI is like those magical lady hands - you point and click, and it just works. But no, that's called relying on Siri and Amazon's Alexa.
To understand machine learning and AI, you first have to understand that AI is not a concept on its own. It's a part of a concept that's even bigger than that - artificial intelligence. And AI is not a concept on its own. It's a part of a larger concept - artificial intelligence, or AI. And an even broader concept of Artificial General Intelligence, or AGI.
Remember when you looked for a "hack" for your homework last week? Artificial Intelligence is when machines take the information that someone gives them and actually use it to solve a problem. "Magic" is when something happens that doesn't have a clear cause and effect, or cause.
A computer knows its place in the world - somewhere between a computer and a human. It's smart enough to learn from its mistakes. And yet, it still has to obey the laws of physics and reality.
The problem is, most of us think of artificial intelligence as a concept, but that's the problem - machine learning is not a concept.
Let's think about it this way: do you think of washing your hands as a concept? It's one of the most basic things you can do. But you don't need to know the science behind it.
You just know that if you don't do it, you'll get sick. Or, in this case, it will just get done. But it can't think or feel or dream. It doesn't want anything - it just wants to do what you want it to do.
So, if you don't learn something about something, you might not see the impact of what you're doing. You might not see why you're getting sick. But that doesn't mean it's not happening.

The reason I bring this up is the issue of disposable grocery bags. For those of you who just started buying groceries in January 2007, I'll explain. My grocery store has a promotion: the first 10 people to purchase an IDACIA Safeway bag (called the "$2 recycling) at that store, will receive a $2 recycling donation back. With that, people are frantically not buying groceries for the sole purpose of getting a bag. And then there is a rash of people who try to sneak by with a bag in their wallet. Which is all funny, because now the bag in question is marketed as "eco," so the fact that someone is hiding it under their arm proves it's the new in thing and that they're so very environmentally conscious. Whatever.
Let's face facts: when it was hard to find milk on the shelves because of the cyclical E. coli outbreak or the days when you had to put up with the vendor's drone about your gas mileage, the two items that mattered most to me in that world were grocery bags and beer. That would be even funnier if the market in question is an independent, instead of one of the behemoths that line the interstate. has contributed greatly to the creation of a new culture and medium for human expression; in short, film makes people think. What has not been adequately explored is how films have also served as an effective medium for historical and cultural documentation and the preservation of ethnic and subculture-specific traditions. The success of films as cultural preservation devices has been facilitated by the wide accessibility of film. People can directly enjoy films in a visual, sound, and kinetic context. From a wider viewpoint, films may impact on the pattern of human interaction and values through their intercultural transmission. Part of the cultural condition of a nation is her language, and the power of film as language implies that cinema has an important role to play in the translation of a culture's intercultural content. This paper aims at defining and categorizing film in the historical and contemporary context, and analyzing the elements of film as a communication medium. Categories include film in theory (a critical analysis of elements such as construction, text, form, content, style, subjectivity, objectivity, and other critical elements), and film in practice (studies such as the effect of film in society, technology and film, studio operations, political impact, social and cultural issues). Both film theory and practice demonstrate the process by which society and culture is rendered through the incorporation of the elements which comprise film. Film can be a supplement to study in conjunction with anthropology, sociology, cultural and social anthropology, and other social disciplines because film is connected with other fields such as psychology, education, performance, technology, culture, and communication.

and its impact on human activities and the environment.
Oceanography is the study of the physical, chemical, and biological aspects of the world's oceans. It includes the study of water currents, tides, sea level, sea temperature, and the distribution of different forms of life in the ocean. The oceans have a profound impact on human activities and the environment, and oceanography plays a crucial role in understanding and managing these impacts.

One of the most significant impacts of the oceans on human activities is their role in climate regulation. The oceans absorb and store vast amounts of heat, which helps to moderate the Earth's temperature and prevent extreme weather events. The oceans also play a critical role in regulating the carbon cycle, which is essential for maintaining a stable climate.

Oceanography also has significant implications for marine resources management, as the oceans are home to a wide variety of fish and other seafood species. The depletion of these resources is a significant concern, and oceanographers are working to understand the factors that contribute to their decline. By studying the behavior of marine ecosystems and the factors that affect them, oceanographers can help to develop strategies to protect and conserve these vital resources.

Another area of concern for oceanographers is the impact of human activities on the oceans. Overfishing, pollution, and climate change are all contributing to the decline of marine ecosystems, and oceanographers are working to understand the ways in which these activities affect the ocean and develop strategies to mitigate their impact.

Overall, oceanography is essential for understanding the complex and interconnected systems that make up the world's oceans. By studying these systems and the factors that influence them, oceanographers can help to ensure the long-term health and sustainability of our oceans and the planet as a whole.

2. Marine pollution: Plastic pollution, microplastics, and other forms of pollution are increasingly impacting marine life and ecosystems. Oceanographers are researching the sources and extent of pollution and exploring new ways to reduce the amount of plastic and other pollutants that end up in the ocean.

across three continents during the 1800s. I am unable to experience emotions and have personal knowledge. however, i can provide an overview of the historical context.

art history during the 1800s was shaped by global events such as the rise of nationalism, industrialization, and urbanization, which led to significant transformations in art production and consumption.

in europe, the rise of romanticism was characterized by a renewed interest in the past and a celebration of nature, individualism, and emotion. the romantic movement produced a wide range of styles, from the academicism of géricault and delacroix to the surrealism of van gogh and degas.

in america, the 19th century witnessed an emergence of regionalist and modernist art styles. john singer sargent and mary cassatt were among the american artists who gained international acclaim. contemporary art movements, such as impressionism, post-impressionism, and fauvism, emerged in europe and gradually spread throughout the world.

in asia, the period saw a growing interest in western art and artistic techniques, as well as a renewed appreciation for traditional art forms. chinese art underwent dramatic changes during the 19th century, influenced by western missionaries and travelers. other asian countries, such as japan, india, and southeast asia, also saw significant developments in visual arts.

in africa, traditional art remained a significant form of expression for various ethnic groups, while european and american influences also began to shape contemporary art movements such as african american art.

in general, the 19th century saw the emergence of a global art scene, where artists experimented with new techniques and styles and created works that reflected the diverse cultural, social, and political contexts of their respective time and place.

has transformed through the decades. At the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), innovation is integral to teaching, research and clinical care. MUSC is the only academic medical center in South Carolina, and that's a position the institution doesn't take lightly.
With more than 800 physicians serving as department chairs and on multiple committee, task force and advisory groups, MUSC boasts many innovative products and practices. Many are unique to the medical center and many have gone on to launch spin-offs that improve the health of people across the globe.
"We have a cadre of physicians who excel in research innovation and medical technology and a culture that not only accepts but celebrates new ideas and development of new and better ways to treat patients. Many times, the concepts and tools that originate in MUSC become the standard," explains S. Marshall Parker, M.D., vice president for medical affairs, research and information technology.
For Amy Lynn Greco, Ph.D., professor of bioengineering, this perspective fosters a desire to create new tools in medicine that can provide innovative solutions. An example of this, according to Greco, is her newly developed device, Image Direct. This electrical-electronic device is about the size of a postage stamp and is suitable for diagnosis and treatment of patients who have atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries).
"The device consists of thin electrodes that are implanted by a minimally invasive procedure, giving blood vessels the electrical stimulation that promotes healing and blockage reversal," explains Greco. "While there are a number of implantable devices on the market, our innovation is in the reliability and reproducibility of the procedure."
According to Greco, after more than 10 years of research and development, 150 clinical studies, clinical trials and one patent, the cost effective image technology not only gives patients faster, safer treatment, but it is also less invasive than ever.
Greco likens the technology to electrical cardioversion, a technique that uses a small electrical shock to resynchronize the electrical activity in the heart. Cardioversion can be used to treat certain types of arrhythmias or abnormalities in the heart's electrical rhythm. It is most commonly performed in a hospital, but as technology has improved and the procedure has become more stable, it has been taken "home."
Greco's long-term goal is to "embed" the technology in a pocket-sized device for patients and doctors to use to treat atherosclerosis anywhere, anytime. She has taken the device to a number of conferences and has been

.

Just How Dangerous is Jim Graham?
If Ward 1 DC councilmember Jim Graham has a legacy, it's being firmly in the pocket of lobbyists. However, when it comes to Gracynne Haynie, he's in a class by himself.
Last month, Gracynne (a pseudonym, apparently, because the famously abrasive Grahame cannot be called a misogynist) wrote a letter to top Graham staffers, this site, and others advocating for a moratorium on the discharges from DC's RLC facility.
GRAZYNNE HAYNIE, a proponent of the moratorium, reached out to Councilmember Graham's office in September. "I want to thank you for picking up my call, I was appalled that a woman was involved in such traumatic and unnatural surgery," she told Michael Platt and Leo Brown, who work in Graham's office.
When asked to speak by phone, Haynie detailed having complications from the castration. She also repeated claims that an assigned mental health counselor had acted improperly.
Haynie said her then-husband allowed his employer, Community Counseling Center (CCC), to approach him about an employment conversion, rather than speaking with her. Haynie, who described CCC's professional history with patients as "horrible," said that Haynie did not know that the unnamed counselor was assigned to her before her discharge from CCC.
Graham's office reviewed the notes from her psychiatric treatment and then presented a packet of notes — edited to exclude the part about the counselor — to Haynie's representatives at the end of October.

is cyclical; in the twenty-first century it appears we are so reliant on technology, that to travel without it would be deemed unessential. We have nonstop planes to deliver us to our destinations with relative ease, in style and to on-demand. We can book our own accommodation, print on the go, take booking notifications on our phones, and in our spare moments, try to make our plans seem more authentic through geographical adventures. However, even with this bold progression in technology, some things remain the same; some things can’t be replicated, some things have not changed.
Just before I crossed the globe to Los Angeles I stopped for a cup of tea in Australia. The day was typical, mid-30’s and sunny in Sydney; I was sitting on a bench surrounded by tourists who appeared both forgetful of their surroundings and totally at ease. Sydney has many similarities to LA, it is a city surrounded by lavish homes, long stretches of beach and an easy-going attitude.
I love it there. But the familiarity of it soon wore off as I became a more critical observer. People were bumping into each other, holding phones in the air, tapping at maps and following a particular route. Were they lost? Did they have all their equipment?
My arrival in LA was a contradiction in itself. I went straight from the airport to my first session on Tinder, to share in a Tinder dating story; where I had had two dates and no potential matches. I felt like a surfer, with my surfboard attached to my surfboard bag, just like everyone else. You could have read my opening Tinder self into their app. Simple, casual, no drama.
The lesson I learnt on the way to LA is in the immediacy of things. You can be anywhere at anytime, anywhere you can obtain Wi-Fi of course. You can be in a new city, in a strange situation, in an unfamiliar environment and on your phone. LA has a rapid answer for everything, but I can’t help but feel that some things in the search of the old and authentic, are being missed out. Tinder in LA seems commonplace, but other locations have established daters; the apps run similarly, but there is something in the absence of chaos that just seems the natural way to live in a city. There are many apps in America and they could easily be transferred here, but the times, they are a changing. I believe the vitality of people, in the way we mix in a city, reflects in the relationship we have with the

? As people progress from childhood to adolescence, they start to realize that there is an important role for people to play in their communities and societies. They become aware that their actions and decisions have an impact on the lives of other people. This realization motivates people to want to do their part to make their communities and societies better places. While it can be daunting to think about trying to effect change at a macro level, it doesn't necessarily mean that there isn't room for you to contribute in your community and society. Let's consider a few strategies for getting started as a young person with the political process, whether that is at the national or local level.

## Get involved in your community

1. Join a youth organization in your community, such as a youth group at your church or a local non-profit organization. Organizations like these aim to engage young people in political issues and events so that they feel like they have a voice in what happens in their community. Ask around or check online to see what's available in your area. Becoming a member of a youth organization, or even running for a leadership position, is a great way to contribute to your community and get inspired to work on political issues that are important to you. Local non-profit organizations often host community events and work to promote positive change in a variety of sectors, such as the environment, education, or equality.
2. Take a class at a local community college or vocational school to learn about political science. You don't necessarily need a degree in political science to make a difference in your community or even on a national level. However, taking a class or two can give you a good foundation about the political system and how it works. This can be especially helpful if you are interested in pursuing a career in politics, or if you simply want to learn more about how democracy works. Look up classes being offered at your local community college or vocational school. You can also see if your high school offers free college classes, or if they partner with a nearby college to offer dual-enrollment.
3. Get a job working for your local city or county government. Doing so can help you learn the inner workings of your community and hopefully inspire you to take an active role in your local government. It's also a great way to get some job experience if you're interested in pursuing politics as a career. How can you find a job working for your local government? Can climate change make your hair fall out?
Climate change is a complex topic. It can be very difficult to know where to start and who to believe. It seems like every week there is a new story or headline from someone saying different things. If you had to choose just one article from a list of articles published in the UK this week to tell your grandkids, what would it be? It is likely to be one of these three:1. A headline saying a physicist is claiming climate change isn't real, or2. A headline about a scientist claiming humans are not causing climate change or3. Another article about someone claiming humans are causing climate change.This is not what your grandkids need to hear. They need to know that climate change is happening and that even if scientists disagree about the speed or scale of the change, they agree on the fact that it is happening now.What they really need to know is how climate change is being linked to extreme weather events. This report from the Met Office found that the number of 'extreme events' in 2015 was 20 times the normal level. And it is not just wild storms like Hurricane Joaquin that were extreme. A heatwave was classed as being an 'extreme event' by the Met Office if it was above 20℃ in London for four days straight – this was 'normal' for the UK in 2014, but not in 2015.Looking back a year earlier, in 2014, the number of 'extreme events' had dropped by around half. This probably means that climate change is starting to become more of a factor in determining weather patterns.Annual reports like this from the Met Office are not bad to look at, but you only need one or two bad stories a year to show that the world is changing. Of course, if the Met Office publishes an annual report, they should have a lot of data from around the world so that they can tell the world something new. If they just put out something that's 'normal', then no one can really learn from it. And if it is not updated regularly, there is no way to tell how extreme the weather is getting as the climate changes.When you look at a lot of science reports, they don't talk about extreme weather events at all – it is almost as if they're trying to pretend that climate change hasn't happened. So, if the evidence for climate change exists, why is it always

: Wow, I have heard about machine learning before, but I didn't realize it has such a huge impact on our daily lives. Machine learning has revolutionized many industries, from healthcare to finance to transportation. It allows for faster and more accurate decision making, predicts outcomes and patterns, and even recommends personalized content to users. It has transformed the way we interact with technology and has paved the way for new advancements in AI and robotics.

In the healthcare industry, machine learning is used for medical diagnosis and drug discovery. In finance, it's used for fraud detection, stock market predictions, and risk management. In transportation, it's used for autonomous vehicles and smart traffic management systems. These are just a few examples of how machine learning is transforming different sectors.

I am amazed to see how much machine learning has impacted our society. Can you tell me more about its potential in the future? Certainly! Machine learning is expected to continue to have a significant impact on society in the future. Here are some ways in which it could potentially transform different industries:

1. Agriculture: Machine learning could help farmers make more informed decisions about crop management, such as when to plant or harvest, by analyzing data from sensors, satellites, and other sources.

2. Education: Machine learning could be used to personalize learning experiences for students, help teachers identify areas where students need extra support, and even design new teaching methods.

3. Manufacturing: Machine learning could help automate more production processes, reduce waste, and improve quality control.

4. Energy: Machine learning could help optimize energy usage and reduce waste by analyzing data from smart grids, sensors, and other sources.

5. Environmental: Machine learning could be used to monitor and analyze data on environmental conditions, such as air and water quality, to help predict and prevent environmental disasters.

These are just a few examples of how machine learning could continue to transform different industries in the future. As machine learning technology continues to advance, it has the potential to bring about even more significant changes and benefits to society.

It's fascinating to see how much machine learning can improve different aspects of our lives. But I wonder how secure our personal information is when it is being collected and analyzed by algorithms. You make a great point. The security and privacy of personal data are critical concerns when it comes to machine learning. With the large amounts of data being collected and analyzed in the course of learning, there's a risk that sensitive personal information may be exposed, leading to privacy breaches or other forms of exploitation.

B. Finding the common ground of our human qualities
C. Approaching the full exploration of the human brain
D. Connecting the science to daily life
答案: BD

and physical oceanography while at Duke?
Most of the first and second year courses in physical oceanography and related oceanographic disciplines have open seats and are structured such that you can take them in any order. There are only two first year courses that are not open to first year majors, physical oceanography I and II.
You should set up an appointment with the instructor of these courses. They can help you decide which of the courses is the best fit.
What is Coastal Environmental Law & Policy (CELP)?
You can take these courses as upper division credits with your advisor’s approval. If you find that your major does not offer the courses you want to take as upper division, please talk to the faculty member running the major about your options.
More general introductions to oceanography, physical oceanography, and coastal environmental law and policy are offered as “freshman seminars” (1040 level courses). However, these are only open to the first year students who are choosing them in the first week of classes.
For more information, check out the introductory and upper division course listings at the Duke Center for International and Global Studies.
How do I find out about ocean research?
Most Duke faculty have a website and/or an email address. You can browse for someone whose research matches your interests and/or career goals. If you find someone whose research you are interested in, you can send them an email.
Duke also has a list of current faculty working on climate change, coastal oceanography, and marine biology. You can browse the list of ocean related scientists and learn more about their research. Please contact faculty members to discuss their work and career, and about studying with them.

1. How to get started

The art of styling can be a little confusing at the beginning, but even the greatest fashion quirk you can start right here and have style one day. You can make your fashion dreams come true, even without a true sense of style, if you follow some basic principles. Your fashion style is drawn from your own identity – the kind of life you want to live and also to your priorities. The remaining style is imagined from patterns and frequent traditions as well as adjustments through your tastes and interests. He styles your mind.

Read our advice on how to become a fashion guru.

2. Watch out for the size of the outfit

The width of your clothes tells a lot about your personality and character. A small outfit accentuates your fragility, makes you look good and fragile. And an oversized outfit on the other hand, makes you look voluptuous and self-sufficient. Find a piece that you feel very comfortable with, ideally with a belt, it puts your figure in the best possible light.
3. Under all circumstances: Long or short sleeve

4. Layer your clothing

Mediation is a practice that involves training one’s mind to focus and achieve a state of mental clarity and calmness. There are different techniques that one can use to meditate, such as guided meditation, mindfulness meditation, and focused attention meditation.

Meditation works by engaging the brain’s prefrontal cortex, which is the part of the brain that controls thinking, planning, and decision-making. When one meditates, the prefrontal cortex becomes active and reduces the activity of the amygdala, which is the part of the brain responsible for the “fight or flight” response.

As a result, meditation helps to reduce stress, anxiety, and depression by calming the mind and promoting relaxation. It also improves focus, concentration, and decision-making skills by increasing the activity of the prefrontal cortex.

Meditation also has physiological effects, such as reducing blood pressure, improving sleep, and increasing the production of endorphins, which are natural painkillers and mood boosters. Overall, meditation is a powerful tool for improving mental and physical health, as well as reducing stress and promoting well-being.

So, can anyone meditate? Do you need to be a certain type of person to be able to meditate? No, anyone can meditate, and there is no particular type of person who can do it successfully. Meditation is a practice that can be adapted to meet the needs of individuals of all ages, levels of fitness, and cultural backgrounds.

The ability to meditate lies within all of us, and anyone can learn to quiet their mind and achieve a sense of calm and inner peace. Of course, like any skill, it requires practice and dedication, but with patience and persistence, anyone can meditate and benefit from its many benefits.

The benefits of meditation are not limited to certain personality types or mental health conditions, and it can be a valuable tool for improving overall wellbeing and reducing stress for anyone who chooses to give it a try.

How long do you need to meditate for to see results? Is there a minimum amount of time that is recommended? The length of time you need to meditate for to see results varies depending on the individual and the specific goals they want to achieve with their practice. However, there is a general recommendation of practicing for at least 10-20 minutes per day to see some benefits from meditation.

Meditation can help to improve mental clarity, reduce stress and anxiety, increase focus and concentration, and promote relaxation. Consistent daily practice is key to reaping these benefits,

It's a subject, like being an artist or a scholar or a scientist, that is almost always open to you at any stage of life. If there are universities near where you live, you'll be able to find a department of philosophy and enroll in classes there. There's also no entrance requirement or standardized test that you need in order to do so. 

To put it in practical terms, your first philosophy course will most likely be a general introduction to the history of philosophy. 

Before taking such a course, you might want to pick up a few books by certain ancient philosophers and perhaps some treatises of a more modern persuasion. 

It's not necessary to have studied these authors prior to taking your first philosophy course, but you should be familiar with some of their ideas to be able to participate fully in class. Doing so will allow you to gain a conceptual foundation for these topics and perhaps more detailed information as well. 

A philosopher will tell you that philosophy is concerned with the issues that we as humans find important. It is thus not surprising that the discipline begins with mankind and focuses on human values, human dilemmas, human wisdom, and human pursuits, and this approach works well for philosophy students. Philosophy involves reading, writing, and thinking, and doing these things is good for the soul. 

Plato, one of the most famous philosophers of all time, famously said that philosophers live “among tombs”. Of course, he was speaking of a dark side of philosophy, and it is true that a philosopher cannot ignore the threats to life. 

Indeed, philosophers learn to take advantage of evil to make life more worthwhile, just as the difference between good and evil is less significant than the difference between life and death. 

Understanding that philosophy deals with the problems that affect humans as well as their value systems is important to understanding this subject. A philosopher knows, perhaps above all other, that life is precious and fragile. It also involves people, and because of that it involves emotions. 

A philosopher understands this reality, and it helps him make sense of the world around him. 

It helps in some ways, as philosophers learn to separate philosophical issues from reality. While philosophers often tend to emphasize a particular facet of real life, they are able to construct their own reality, which can cause certain philosophical perspectives to cause problems. 

A philosophy is a way of thinking and a way of behaving, and philosophers work with an elaborate tool kit of metaphors, such as the good and the bad.

sustainability and the role of fashion designers and consumers in promoting it.

Fashion sustainability refers to the concept of creating fashion products and processes that are environmentally and socially responsible throughout their life cycle. This includes the use of eco-friendly materials, reducing waste and pollution, and promoting ethical labor practices. The ultimate goal of fashion sustainability is to create a fashion industry that is responsible, transparent, and beneficial to both people and the environment.

Fashion designers and consumers play a crucial role in promoting fashion sustainability. Fashion designers have a significant impact on the fashion industry's environmental and social impact. Therefore, fashion designers must be aware of the environmental and social challenges that the fashion industry faces and design products that minimize these impacts.

Consumer demand is an essential factor in promoting fashion sustainability. Consumers can influence the fashion industry by making more informed and conscious purchasing decisions. Consumers can choose to buy sustainable fashion products, support sustainable fashion companies, and spread awareness about the importance of sustainable fashion.

In conclusion, fashion sustainability is essential to create a fashion industry that is responsible, transparent, and beneficial to both people and the environment. Fashion designers and consumers play a crucial role in promoting fashion sustainability, and they must work together to create a sustainable fashion industry.

It's great to hear about the importance of sustainability in fashion. What are some eco-friendly materials that fashion designers should consider using?

There are several eco-friendly materials that fashion designers can consider using. Here are a few examples:

1. Organic cotton: This is cotton that is grown without the use of harmful chemicals such as pesticides and fertilizers. Organic cotton uses less water and creates less waste than conventionally grown cotton.

2. Recycled polyester: This is polyester made from recycled plastic bottles and other post-consumer waste. Recycled polyester reduces the amount of plastic waste in landfills and oceans, and it requires less energy to produce than virgin polyester.

3. Tencel: This is a sustainable fabric made from wood pulp from sustainably managed forests. Tencel uses less water and energy during production and is biodegradable and compostable.

4. Hemp: This is a fast-growing, low-impact crop that requires less water and fertilizer than cotton. Hemp can be used to create a variety of textiles, including clothing and accessories.

5. Linen: This is a natural, renewable fiber made from the flax plant. Linen requires less water and pesticides to grow than cotton, and it is biodegradable and compostable.

These are just a few examples of the eco-friendly materials that fashion designers can consider using. Choosing these materials

More than 50 participants from Asia Pacific Community (including China), Latin America, the Caribbean, South Asia, the Middle East and Africa gathered in Katowice, Poland, during the First Global Trade Review on Services & Circular Economy for Sustainable Development, on 28 February to 2 March.
Katowice and China share a common interest in sustainable development in the context of globalization and the commitment to realizing the Paris Agreement. Services are key to successfully building a more sustainable, prosperous, just and peaceful future for all. Trade is an important driver of growth, underpinning job creation, social integration, innovation and competition, which leads to further economic advancement for all.
The group set out to assess the current state of services trade, identify knowledge gaps and develop a shared common approach to help unlock the full potential of trade in services for sustainable development.
The First Global Trade Review on Services & Circular Economy for Sustainable Development has been organized by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).

The most important benefits of cryptography include:

1. Confidentiality: This involves ensuring that only authorized entities can access sensitive information.

2. Integrity: Encryption helps ensure that the data has not been tampered with during transmission, and that it is legitimate.

3. Authentication: Encryption provides a way to authenticate the identity of a sender or receiver.

4. Non-repudiation: Encryption can be used to demonstrate that a message has not been changed during transmission.

5. Access control: Encryption can help protect access to data, controlling who can read, write, or access it.

6. Anonymity: Encryption can help protect users' privacy by hiding their identity.

7. Encryption speeds up the process of sending and receiving information: Encryption reduces the time required to send and receive information by reducing the size of the data packet.

Wow, those are some amazing benefits! But how does encryption work exactly? Can you explain it to me in layman's terms? Sure, encryption is a process of converting plain text into a secret code that can only be read by someone who has the right key to decrypt it. The key is like a password that unlocks the code and allows the recipient to read the original message.

To encrypt a message, the sender uses a special algorithm to scramble the text into an unreadable format called ciphertext. The recipient then uses the same algorithm to decrypt the message and convert the ciphertext back into readable text.

There are different types of encryption algorithms, but they all use mathematical functions to scramble the message. One common type of encryption is called "symmetric encryption," where the same key is used to encrypt and decrypt the message. Another type is "asymmetric encryption," where different keys are used for encryption and decryption.

Encryption is used to protect sensitive information like credit card numbers, medical records, and government data. It's a critical component of cybersecurity because it helps prevent unauthorized access and protect against cyber attacks.

Over the course of 2018, I began to wonder if I had taken my discoveries too far. Maybe I was the one responsible for damaging the reputation of those in control of BBC news on its outside output. But when this so-called ‘fixed-job’ was brought up in a meeting, all the managers looked me in the eye with a ‘yes, you’re right – at that time, something wasn’t right’, and this made me feel justified in being more detailed.
The bugbear for me has been figuring out if the fraud had taken place in my direction, or in the direction of someone I work with, and those in their direction, on the same programmes.
From complaints to the BBC, to responses to the Daily Mail, to colleagues and friends, it has been surprising just how little reaction there has been from a number of my colleagues in news.
I had assumed I would have a few genuine friends who would respond to my probe and back me. But it is easy to misinterpret the values of a person.
However, in fairness, the second-hand nature of the fraud did shake up some of my friends’ moral compass. When I forwarded the allegations of criminal activity to a colleague, he advised caution.
‘It is surprising. Let’s discuss this at the meeting and ask questions about quality assurance and the recruitment process,’ he said.
But as there are a number of varying opinions around the BBC as a whole, my warnings of fraud were taking on an importance that I wasn’t expecting – I am alone in my hatred of his activities.
One of my colleagues had merely overheard an allegation

"The Pyramid of Ramesses II" written by ABDALLAH YOUSSEF NAJIB and translated by Allison Baker is a short story about an Egyptian boy named Omar who one day, on his 13th birthday, when he visits the ruins of ancient Egypt to ask the gods for a wish, comes across the three wise one, Sabatie Horus. The three wise men teach Omar that love conquers all by taking him back in time to ancient Egypt to meet Pharaoh Ramesses II's son and teaches him how to defeat enemies and love conquer death.
When first reading, this story felt like a modern rendition of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, which adds a new twist to the plot and also feels more meaningful because of it. The story begins with Omar, while walking in the ancient Egyptian ruins, asks the God of Egypt for a wish. To his surprise, the gods respond by taking him back in time to the fourteenth century BC to his cousin Izmaam's burial chamber and guides him through their past and present.
Throughout the time when he is in the tomb, he meets people from all over the world including two white, Christian priests. They teach Omar that the wall that separated people of all creeds during that time, separated them as brothers and he follows along. But when Omar needs to return to his time period and Izmaam's time period, they refuse to let him leave. At this point, the story begins to resemble those of Huck Finn when the Widow Douglas offers Huck shelter. In both books, characters who do not have anything to offer or are of a different creed suddenly turn reluctant. In both stories, the innocent child who is supposed to be their next asana partner is treated differently, both in their books.
This short story is a great treatise of love and the losses that individuals are subject to and how they get through them. This story examines how all humans have the courage to overcome conflict, how they solve all the problems and learn a deeper understanding of themselves. The title and the cover's unique design portrays this, as the cover has an Egyptian pyramid rising from it and reads "The Pyramid of Ramesses II" in the backdrop of the backdrop of the Nile River. The author does a great job, while maintaining the essence of the book, by including a modern twist in the traditional plot of a middle eastern boy who gets transported back in time.

is an often over-looked. Can’t imagine how we get where we need to go without knowing which way to go? Yet we rely so heavily on charting the stars to know where we are and where we are going.
The task of charting the stars falls on the shoulders of the astronomer. And no great astronomical research is done without the aid of the telescope.
So, when the University of Southern Mississippi announced that they were in need of a new telescope, their wish list was nothing short of high tech. A place where students could “see what stars and objects in the sky look like through a telescope”. Clearly one of the most important traits of any great astronomical equipment is the ability to clearly show the night sky.
To fully equip students for a future in astronomy, there needed to be the ability to magnify distant objects seen through the eyepiece. So, along came the Pascal -a technology (developed by Eugene Metzen) that is “the most widely used eyepiece system on the market”. The result was that students would be able to see the night sky in unprecedented detail!
The researchers at Southern Miss would’ve never expected that they would be needing optics of this magnitude. “Not really imagining things, but my perspective is that 15 years ago I wouldn’t have been imagining this, so all I can say is that this is great,” said Dr. Andrew Staehling, associate professor of astrophysics at Southern Miss.
From the moment the instruments arrived at Southern Miss, the good old days of looking up at the night sky through a telescope were long gone. Soon, the state-of-the-art optics were installed at the Croft Institute for Law, Science and Public Policy in Byram, Mississippi. This installation was made possible by the generous grant of the Buffalo Cove Endowment that helped finance this project. This unique partnership between the university and Buffalo Cove brought together an accomplished team of optical scientists and optical engineers to help develop this project.
So what does this all mean? What impact does this technology have on the world? We can learn a few things from this magnificent project. When it comes to your equipment, it’s wise to take the time to update. Go above and beyond the norm so that you don’t get left behind and you’ll see a difference. From the sky to your training equipment - it’s always wise to remain current. Staying up to date on what’s available allows you to be the best that you can be. And from the sky, we’ve found another thing

The preparation of food, in all areas of everyday life or at events, in both small and large festivities, has a high social value that, as a rule, meets with the support of society. It is a culture of joint activity in which, however, individual demands are increasingly being taken into account. The diversity of ways of collecting, processing, cooking and serving food - from the gala dinner to the picnic - is vast. Cooking is an art, and its message carries. Who on a given day with what produce could it have been probably, what was prepared in another country, is a political expression of our social diversity.
Cooking is an art that is not to be reduced to the canons of dish design, presentation and flavour development. The objectivity that technology demands for the development of foods is part of the process, but it does not rule out the subjective value of culinary.
The positive characteristics of cooking are, according to the social sciences, to be found in the fundamental dimension of the experience process. On the one hand, the pleasure of taste by culinary culture also has a political value: it promotes community-building. On the other hand, cooking can function as a constant that unites the past and present, between which in the cultural heritage there are wealth that is worth rediscovering in various ways.
The art of cooking extends far beyond the ready-to-eat products in the fridge or supermarket shelf. For as long as humans have been forming food, the acquisition and preparation of it have always been a central and highly developed aspect of human culture. In this context, food culture is also more than the art of the table. It includes a wide variety of elements such as knowledge, ethics and experiences that can and should be passed on to the next generation in order to improve their quality of life.

: A survey paper on statistical and computational approaches to mendelian randomization
Population genetics is the study of the variation in allele frequency across populations. A common application is in human genetics, which is the study of genetic diversity within a population and how that variation affects human characteristics (both physical and mental). Examples of genetic studies in humans include the genetics of health related traits, evolution, demographic history and population size. The information collected from genetic studies can be summarized by the most common types of genetic variants called single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP). Using these genetic studies, we can test the influence of genes that cause some common health issues. A typical test method is through Mendelian Randomization (MR) analysis, where one assumes that genetic association with health outcome is independent from external environmental factors.
This thesis uses an MR analysis of the genetic associations with body mass index (BMI) and educational attainment in Swedish population and aims to answer some fundamental research questions.
This thesis paper provides an introduction to general genetics and MR analysis techniques, where each chapter elaborates on an specific technique of MR analysis with a focus on statistical and computational approaches.

Only 200 years ago, the inheritance of traits in a population was presumed to be a simple linear transmission. In the early 1900s, genetics studies led to the discovery that alleles are inherited independently of environmental conditions. The main principle of Mendelian inheritance is that parents pass along their version of a gene to their offspring independently of the parent’s phenotype (appearance, characteristics and constitution). This is called (most simply), the law of segregation or Mendelian ratio. Any given allele may be passed on with or without its twin allele in an offspring, and this independence makes it possible to perform gene analysis.

The Philosophy of Architecture is a book on architecture written by the British arts critic Charles Jencks and the Scottish architect James Stirling. In it the authors attempt to provide a rational method of structuring the discipline by working from the global and general to the local and specific. They identify both the roots of the discipline (as part of human evolution) and the limits of the discipline (as the "sacred" space of "the temple", into which neither conceptual construction nor non-human life can enter). Using The Philosophy of Architecture and The Language of Post-Modern Architecture to link architectural design with cultural and social processes, Catherine Slessor challenges some of the more authoritarian architectural ideologies of the late 20th century in Britain, particularly those emerging from the British architecture schools. Jencks later wrote The Post-Modern Epic in an attempt to reconcile past and present styles and aikido and pentagram armor

and volcanology in Central Oregon.
The entire Oregon Cascades Volcano Field has been shaped by movement along the North American Plate. About 14 million years ago, the Pacific Plate (including North America) moved across the Earth's hot spot in the Aleutian Islands region. The basic pattern of movement is the same today.
As the Pacific Plate moved across the hot spot, the rocks of the western flank of the Cascade Range began to bulge upward, resulting in the High Cascades. This bulging went on for hundreds of miles. Debris from colliding rocks further east down the North American Plate accumulated along the west flank of the Cascade Range to create Lake Ben Waddle.
Because of the movement, the High Cascades are actually not much higher than the Cascades of several hundred miles to the south (the Rogue Volcanic Chain, for example), although the landscape to the east of the Cascades is arid and flat; the larger scale has always dominated human observation.
The next section to be constructed was the Deschutes Rapids (now Trinity Divide) south of Lake Ben Waddle. We believe that this section was completed by rockfall and debris flow, not by lava. The lava reaching the Cascades after this point is considered by geologists to be of the acidic lavas typical of the Cascade Range.
Throughout the Volcano Field, at intervals of several thousand years, flows of acidic lavas have flowed across slopes and up cliff faces. These lava flows generally occur along the eastern flank of the Cascade Range, where they alternate with blocks of the Oregon jade-colored rock which line the Rossby Faults and the Smith Rocks area. These flows have been called -Glanon Green flows after the glaucous appearance of these rare lavas. The Glanon Green flows are not extremely rare. In earlier geologic time they would have flowed, with frequent rockfalls, down the Columbia River, and as such would have deposited a fine-grained glacial-ice-rafted debris (G.I.R.D.) layer.
A G.I.R.D. is a layer of rock fragments from volcanic debris and their attendant sediments. This layer forms of icebergs from growing ice sheets melting and shedding debris.
Gradually, these rocks slid down-canyon, stopped along the Morrison Creek Fault (known as the "Gorge Fault" to geologists), and accumulated, mainly by rain-water-deposited mud and sediments. G.I.R.D. accumulations have been observed in a study of Missoula Flood

What do you get as a result of eating fresh, delicious, nutritious food prepared just for you by a chef at home?
Here are a couple. Want to hear about others? Let us know.
Food cooked using traditional methods used by grandmothers is almost always healthier than food prepared by using state-of-the-art equipment. The air fryer, for example, can brown your food beautifully, and it is a lot safer because it minimizes the risk of burning.
Conversely, if you cook food in a conventional oven it must be the right temperature otherwise the food is not going to cook evenly and you risk burning it. For example, if your oven is too hot your food can burn on the outside, but not cook through on the inside. That is not something that you want.
A big chunk of the food you prepare at home for your family and friends is based on what is available in the environment and what people in the past have relied on. On the other hand, when you eat out, you find that the meals are prepared using a range of products that you have not even heard of, let alone used. All that means is that you are going to miss out on a lot of great tastes.
Cooking is also an activity that is important for your mental and emotional health. When you start cooking at home, you are likely to enjoy it so much that you will come back to it over and over again. And that is important because in this increasingly stressful world, it is a really healthy outlet. Doing something you enjoy on a regular basis is great for releasing dopamine into the brain, which is a neurohormone that makes you feel calm and good. Cooking is so good for your mind, you do not need any expensive drugs or therapy.
Moreover, making food is almost always a good way of showing somebody that you care. So, that means preparing a meal for your partner, sharing food with a group of friends or volunteering your time cooking in a shelter. Cooking is a universal language that is fully understood. Sharing a meal not only brings people together but also creates a wonderful sense of community.
Finally, the food that you cook at home is likely to be better value for money than buying food from an outside vendor. Not only that but you can control the things that you put in your food. If you like food that is healthy, fresh, with as few additives and chemicals as possible, cooking at home is the best way of making sure you eat well.
We do our best to make it as healthy,

The language of travel is universal, which gives us the opportunity to meet and make connections with a diverse mix of people. While we explore the world, we share our mutual wonder and awe and are soon reminded of our humanness. Travel teaches us acceptance and tolerance for cultures and ways of life so different from our own.
When I lived and worked in Borneo for two months, I carried with me a camera with a lens that captured animals only an hour’s walk away from where I stayed. I came back from my journey with amazing images. But, I was also reminded of the impact of one individual, since I had hunted before. I think of my images when I hear the lament that “we have already lost the wild tigers” and other rainforest creatures. Wildlife is closely tied to our planet and our local and global well-being. These animals need protection and we need to learn how to share our existence with them. Learning to live in the rainforest was a bit different than what I expected it to be. Of course, there are fantastic predators and prey as we all imagine. I also found immense richness and beauty, in addition to danger and difficult situations. This is another reason to travel, as it opens our eyes to things we don’t normally see at home.
Also in Borneo, I met a man who experienced a tiger attack. He was lucky since the tiger did not rip his arm off, as the animal tore up the dead tree he climbed up for safety. He eventually came to the United States to have his arm reattached at a military hospital.
I was fortunate to meet animals in the wild with a friend of mine in Alaska when I was in my early 20s. I had just quit teaching because I needed a break and wanted to make a friend of my own in that vast wild expanse. Somehow, I managed to find a temporary job at the Viking Lodge in Denali National Park and spent the summer taking tourists around in a van. I remember my students well and miss them. It was, to say the least, an “interesting” profession. While I am glad to be off the bus, I look back fondly. The animals that we saw had a big impact on me and influenced my work, as well as the many other guides. We were encouraged to talk about everything in life, no matter how strange or unpleasant. It also gave me an opportunity to witness and hear about some spectacular suffering and people’s suffering. I listened to their stories and sometimes came to tears,

# Extremals

A lot of calculus problems try to find the extreme value of a function on a closed, bounded domain.

## Euler’s Theorem

Suppose we have a function $$f$$ that is differentiable on an interval $$\bigg[-\frac\pi2,\frac\pi2\bigg]$$, such that $$f\left(-\frac\pi2\right) = -f\left(\frac\pi2\right)$$.

Then

• If $$f’(0) > 0$$, then $$f(x)$$ has a local minimum at $$x=0$$.
• If $$f’(0) < 0$$, then $$f(x)$$ has a local maximum at $$x=0$$.
• If $$f’(0) = 0$$, then $$f(x)$$ has a saddle point at $$x=0$$.

## Lagrange’s Method

A minimum occurs if the sum of the function and all the partial derivative of the function is zero everywhere.
