.
Nearly anyone who hears about the rapid rise of the robotics industry assumes that it somehow represents the death of human labor and productivity. Human beings, it seems, are on the outs. It just isn’t true.
Robotics is much more similar to the invention of the assembly line, which has had an on-again, off-again relationship with human labor. As complex assemblies, for example, move down the line, operators can come up with the best way to achieve the best results. Today, “merely intelligent robots” assist workers, but may never replace human labor, says Michael Orey, CEO of OriGen Robotics.
A more common misconception about robotics centers on the very name “robotics”. Robotics as a field or discipline started a couple of hundred years ago with the invention of the mechanical egg that cracked open and hatched baby chicks.
Since then, robots have come a long way, to be sure, and the field has evolved rapidly. A robotics engineer, therefore, creates robots that will do the things humans traditionally don’t want to do.
Orey says that most assembly lines today are far from being productive and this will become more apparent in the coming years. With the introduction of new robot lines and robots currently under development, the assembly line is likely to see rapid expansion.
OriGen is currently working on three assembly line technologies. One is a conveyor line that, without any human interaction, moves a steel machine to welding stations. The second is a laser-welding line that assembles systems in one step, reducing overhead. The final line is both of the above in one package with robotic arms assembling the structures. In the case of the last, the machine also carries the product where needed to be used.
Now, I don’t know about you, but one machine that cracks eggs and lets baby chicks hatch is a fine, fine thing indeed. As robots continue to evolve, we should expect to see a number of practical assembly line applications. In the process, human workers will move from the assembly line and more productive jobs.
Robots and human labor is not mutually exclusive. We’ll explore the latest tools for humans to use with robots to get more out of robots and out of human labor in the next issue.

Here's a simple guide on how to get started with gardening for beginners:

1. Decide on a space: Choose a place in your yard or balcony that receives good sunlight, and that is easily accessible for maintenance.

2. Get your tools: Start with basic gardening tools such as a trowel, gloves, watering can, pruning shears and a garden hoe.

3. Select your plants: Choose plants based on your climate zone, sunlight exposure, water requirements and soil type. Start with easy-to-grow plants such as herbs, tomatoes, lettuce and flowers like marigolds and petunias.

4. Prepare the soil: Improve the soil quality by adding compost, organic matter, and fertilizer. Mix them together and add water to make the soil moist.

5. Plant your seeds: Dig small holes in the soil and plant your seeds or seedlings, making sure they are spaced out properly. Water them gently to keep the soil moist but not waterlogged.

6. Maintain your garden: Regularly weed the garden, water plants, prune the growth as needed, and fertilize the soil to keep plants healthy.

7. Enjoy the fruits of your labor: Once your plants have grown, harvest your veggies, cut back the flowers and observe how your hard work has paid off. 

Remember, gardening is a wonderful way to relax, relieve stress, and spend time outdoors. Enjoy the process and have fun!

Can you give me some tips on how to deal with pests in my garden?

Yes, here are some tips on how to deal with pests in your garden:

1. Identify the pest: Before you start treating, identify the pest that is damaging your plants. Different pests require different treatments, so make sure you know what you're dealing with.

2. Use natural pest control methods: There are many natural pest control methods you can use, such as handpicking, companion planting, and using insecticidal soap or neem oil. These methods are safer for the environment and non-toxic to humans and animals.

3. Use physical barriers: Physical barriers can also be effective in deterring pests. For example, you can install row covers to protect your plants from pests like insects and birds.

4. Rotate your crops: Crop rotation is a natural method to manage pests. It helps to control the pests by breaking the pest-crop loop and reducing the populations of harmful insects.

5. Use natural pesticides: Natural pesticides like insecticidal soap, neem oil, and bacterial-based products can be effective in controlling pests

Then, after exhausting the literal and figurative benefits of prolonged texting ("What are you wearing?"), you must clumsily arrange to see one another in the flesh.
It is under these conditions that I bring to you love letters of the text-communication variety. Love letters to me, love letters to you.
Dear Dylan, Six months! A year! The dog! All love and lush puppy. A Venn diagram of dubious physics posited by St. Christopher's College freshman year and warmly reverberating one beautiful and harrowing trip to Grenada for a public gathering. I imagine an adoring black and white dog below, and I repeat it to myself, like some kind of incantation. Dreams are hereditary, which I think leads to the question, where is the dog? I don't think it's here. Is it lost? Were you ever more interested? Or can I find it again through your retelling?

Meaning sustains itself through an inscriptive velocity founded in the threat of newness. But the necessary first step must be emulation. To hold you in my arms, an offer which I find difficult to reject. An answer to Dylan-ectomy.

is one of the central topics of contemporary environmental concerns. In that respect, the writing of my PhD thesis has been influenced by the pursuit of updating Materia Medica as one way to step out of old-hegemonic vocabulary. I try to investigate in whose interest the ontological choice was made to report some objects as big, others as small, but, mostly, to refuse to distinguish colours of objects between healthy and deadly to transform them into medicines, in virtue of the produce of their origin in the mind.
Starting from Hesiod’s Theogony to Miguel Angel Lopez Ricon, through details from any pre-Columbian cosmos, the question is which ontological choices are historically socially constructed in the physical world. Have we evolved mythology? By going from Greek-Spartan mythological building to Ricon’s Chiapas construction, I claim, what might seem most worthy of mythological resources would appear to be in reality, a myth of human evolution.
To elaborate this idea, in my thesis, I perform a real anthropological process. I learned that Ricon’s organic understanding was inspired from a field-work from 1946-47. He observed ceremonies ritualised in the mangrove forest in Chiapas, in which ocelot is the main protagonist of a creation ritual. I consulted on this with Eilean Hooper-Greenhill, who invited me to meet him while he was in residence at the ZMBM. In 2017, he died. We travelled to Venezuela to visit my PhD and we filmed a deposition, from which we can extract the critical question of the existence of such wide-spread field-work by people like him. As Hofkapler-Greenhill put it, this is a general information we always wish for people to have, especially if we listen to their intellectual and spiritual stories. This also provided me with the opportunity to film Ricon in front of any autorectified tulipacu. Every time we used to meet, we observed the blue sky of the Andes reflected on this semi-transparent blue medicinal juice. I saw the landscape painting with which David Serrano painted Ricon’s cosmos. In London, he introduced me to Fulvio Melilli and Nicoletta Drago, working on Ricon’s frescoes. and hydrology research and operations enabled by high-performance computing (HPC) remain critically important for improving our understanding of ocean and coastal processes. In recent years, the Marine Hydrokinetics High Performance Computing Consortium (MH-HPC) has made several contributions to advancing innovative ocean and hydrologic applications and research with the guidance of a community-based steering committee. This presentation will highlight a few of these contributions, including (1) development of state-of-the-art Earth system models (ESMs) that have been used to study a range of topics, from model reduction to integrated model of coupled behavior in Earth’s mantle and ocean, as well as the use of these models in industry. ESM applications also include both airborne data assimilation and field observation efforts. (2) implementation of a 1D water column ‘Sediment Box’ model, combining both Eulerian and Lagrangian schemes, to better simulate multiple interacting marine processes. The model was successfully benchmarked against various open field and theoretical cases, and has already been used in a Coastal Modeling Symposium supported project. (3) Specialization of the MH-HPC HPC cluster to run the Eulerian/Lagrangian ‘Sediment Box’ model as well as coarse-resolution ESMs within the same suite of software, thereby enabling a comparison of model resolution. While the focus of this presentation will be on the work supported by MH-HPC, the substantial contributions of other projects which have been sponsored, including data assimilation, 3D Eulerian/Granular simulations of scouring and erosion and coastlines, boundary condition and simulated mixed layer studies will also be discussed.

are on display in a faculty showcase that promises to be a rare fusion of genres, including modern, jazz, tap, hip-hop, live music, Improv and more. The seven dance teachers in the College of the Arts will perform solo and group pieces as part of “Wild and Beautiful” on Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. at the Scarlett and Ralph Elliot Theater on Main Street in the Sprague Building.
Muriel Brown, chair of dance at UNCG, said this is the sixth “Wild and Beautiful” showcase in eight years. A goal, she said, has been to bring together a diversity of dance styles and choreographers.
“This year’s program includes faculty members who are very familiar with traditionals forms of dance, and who are always interested in stretching their creative boundaries,” said Brown.
Ellis Washington, the Tom and Mary Bradley professor of dance, said he is doing three dances this year. He performs with the Praise Dancers in “Please Not The Piano” and he is doing a trio “Sonnet” with two women. He also is appearing in “Sweet Home Alabama” with a cast of UNCG students, made up of 12 men and 16 women.
Washington said his dance, “Sweet Home Alabama,” is what he calls a “minor-minor” (minor in piano, minor in dance). In the music, in the spirit of Lionel Ritchie, he and the cast sing about how they came to love the school.
The 2015 inaugural showcase gave birth to the Splats Ensemble, an improvisational workshop led by Washington, James Thompson, Kerry Elliot and Mikell Tooms.
Washington said his piece that will be performed in the Feb. 24 event is designed to look at the spiritual and religious underpinnings of music and dancing. Washington said he does some practice African dancing, but he doesn’t use that in his piece. “The idea is: You can connect with God through dance,” he said.
Washington’s piece will be performed in an interpretation of black rock music from the 1970s. “We’re not going to do the actual music. We’re going to do what a black rock band would do, like Stevie Wonder, who I like. We’ll dress up in all black, shirtless, and use something like auto-harp or drum, with influences of other forms, such as Blues and the beatings of jazz and rock and roll,” he said. As for the splats,

Quantum mechanics is the study of nature at the smallest scales of energy levels of atoms and subatomic particles. Here are some interesting facts about quantum mechanics:
- The smallest unit of energy in an atom is called a quantum. This is where quantum mechanics gets its name.
- In quantum mechanics, particles can exist in multiple states at once until they are observed.
- Scientists use wave-particle duality to explain how particles can behave both like waves and particles.
- Quantum mechanics predicts the existence of particles called "superpositions" that can exist in multiple states at once until observed.
- The Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to know both the position and momentum of a particle with absolute certainty.
- Quantum mechanics has been used to explain phenomena such as quantum tunneling, where particles can pass through barriers that should be impossible.
- Scientists have used quantum mechanics to create quantum computers, which are much faster and more powerful than traditional computers.
- Quantum mechanics has also been used to develop quantum cryptography, which is used for secure communication.

Archaeology has influenced our lives in many ways that are invisible to us. In this article, we will look at some of the effects of archaeology on society.
Archaeology influences daily lives in subtle ways that are often unnoticed. The average person interacts with archaeological artifacts every single day without being aware of it. Archaeology can have a significant effect on society as well.
Archaeology can help us understand who we are
The study of the past helps us understand who we are, where we came from and why we are here. It can also help us to recognize similarities between different cultures and how they have influenced one another. Archaeology can provide a deep insight into human history, such as when we talk about ancient civilizations.
This makes it easier for us to appreciate the diversity in the world around us by putting things into perspective and realizing how long ago they were created. This knowledge also helps us understand what has happened since those times – from discovering fire through modern technology that we use every day.
It helps us to understand ourselves and our ancestors
Archaeology can help us understand ourselves and our ancestors. We can see how our ancestors were like when they were alive – their customs and way of life. By looking at the artifacts of different cultures from all over the world, we can see how they lived and how they developed over time.
We can also learn about the history of our own country, which is important for understanding what it means to be an American. Archaeology provides a lot of information on Native Americans in the United States. This includes details about their lives as well as what happened when they first came to America.
Why study ancient cultures
The study of ancient cultures can teach us how people lived in the past. This knowledge can help us learn about our own culture and understand how it has developed over time.
The study of ancient cultures can also help us understand modern society by showing us how certain events in history have influenced modern culture. For example, the Renaissance was a time when people from different parts of Europe became interested in classical literature and art from ancient civilizations like Greece and Rome. This led to many things being based on Greek and Roman ideas, like architecture (buildings with columns) or even stories like Romeo & Juliet or Othello.
The study of ancient cultures can also show us how much has changed since those times – what we do now was impossible then! We can see this by looking at the different languages used at different periods of time and seeing how they evolved into different forms over hundreds or even thousands of

.

Quantum mechanics plays an important role in modern society in a wide range of fields, including:

1. Electronics: The principles of quantum mechanics have been essential in the development of electronics, including the design of transistors, microchips, and other electronic devices.

2. Energy: Quantum mechanics is fundamental in understanding the behavior of atoms and molecules, which are crucial for the design and operation of various energy systems, such as solar cells and batteries.

3. Materials science: The properties of materials, such as their strength, conductivity, and optical properties, are often determined by their quantum structure, which is studied by quantum mechanics.

4. Medical science: Quantum mechanics is relevant in the study of molecular structures, which are important in drug discovery and design. It is also used to explain the behavior of electrons in the human body, which has implications for diagnosis and treatment of various diseases.

5. Computer science: Quantum mechanics is crucial in the development of quantum computers, which promise to revolutionize the field of computing.

Overall, quantum mechanics has had a profound impact on modern society, from the devices we use every day to the way we understand the world around us.

Wow, I had no idea that quantum mechanics had such a wide range of applications in modern society! It's amazing how much impact it has had on so many different fields.

Yes, it is amazing! Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory that has provided us with insights into the behavior of the subatomic world and has led to the development of technologies and inventions that we use in our daily lives. Quantum mechanics is an interdisciplinary field that brings together mathematics, physics, and computer science, and it continues to grow and evolve as we discover new applications for its principles. It has had an enormous impact on our understanding of the world, and we can expect to see many more exciting developments in the future as we continue to explore the possibilities of quantum mechanics.

It's crazy to think that something as small as a subatomic particle can have such a big impact on our daily lives. It really highlights the interconnectedness of everything in our universe.

Yes, it is truly fascinating and mind-boggling! The fact that the behavior of subatomic particles can have such a significant impact on our lives is a testament to the fact that everything in the universe is interconnected and interdependent. Quantum mechanics shows us the fundamental nature of the world around us and provides a new perspective on the universe. It opens up new areas of research and discovery, and it is certain that its insights will continue to shape our understanding

# Do students generally underestimate the significance of model investigations?

Students often complete model investigations as part of their studies, but they may not always fully appreciate the significance and usefulness of these types of investigations. This study looks at when, and how, 12-13 year-old students conceptualise the purpose of model investigations and identifies strengths and weaknesses in this understanding. The study includes student interviews and a self-concept inventory based on Stevens and Plucker's (2007) framework. The findings indicated that students generally under-estimated the use of model investigations in physics and that they mostly used the same approach to complete an investigation, regardless of its title. There were indications that students' understanding of the significance of model investigations may be dependent on their prior experiences of them, and that this understanding may change with increased exposure. There was also some evidence that a more abstract, global approach to conceptualising the purpose of model investigations than one based on Stevens and Plucker's framework, may be beneficial.

2 What Does it Mean to Conserve Energy?
4.1 What does it mean to conserve energy?
In general, the concept of energy conservation refers to the conservation of energy, or the idea that energy is conserved through interconversion. In many energy applications, particularly in power systems, there is a presence of energy demand, or specific devices, like electric power generators and motors, that produce energy.
Energy conservation can also refer to the concept of total available energy as well. In other words, in addition to conservation of energy in a conservation of energy in a power system, the concept of total energy conservation can refer to all usable sources and its related situations.
To further understand the general definition of energy conservation, we can look at the definition of energy, an essential concept in understanding how it is conserved. Energy is the capacity for doing work. In fact, energy itself is quite ubiquitous, as it is found in everyday occurrences and it is required to perform almost all basic actions. But what determines the difference between work being done or not, and why is energy conserved in some instances and not in others?
The answer to these questions is that energy is conserved through interconversion. In order for work to be performed, the potential and kinetic energy of an object have to change. And in other cases, the energy is stored in a form that can be converted from one form to another. To further understand these actions, let’s examine some examples of energy conservation in our everyday lives.
One of the easiest ways to understand energy conservation is that it provides us with a real-life reason to make energy efficiency in homes more appealing. can't be ignored or discounted. The facts in psychology are clear and cannot be disputed. The negative impact of these facts has created endless debates on how to handle certain situations. One of the main areas that psychology is involved in is what we call psychology's pain era. This article looks at the scientific aspects of pain and how it impacts society. It also looks at methods that can be used to help people with pain.
One of the main things that science has taught us about pain is that it is not an all-in-one experience. Many people experience pain, which is different than another person's pain. This is why studies show that pain suffers from delusions, excessive imagery and in extreme cases, hallucinations. Although there is no clear definition of pain, many people believe that it includes all kinds of sensations, even those that are completely non-existent or only temporary.
One of the big questions in psychology is the cause and effect relationship between pain and psychological disorders. One theory is that trauma and stress are the main causes of chronic pain. This would mean that certain types of mental health issues like anxiety and depression are also the result of trauma and stress. An alternative theory is that chronic pain is caused by traumatic and painful events, resulting in a build-up of stress and anxiety.
One area that has been widely studied is the relationship between pain and depression. There are many theories concerning the cause and effects of depression, including how it is the result of an overload of painful and negative feelings that end up being felt in the brain. The question of why depression is so prevalent among those who experience chronic pain is also important. One hypothesis is that those who are able to control their emotional pain through meditation or hypnosis may experience less pain overall. Those who have tried this method but don't seem to be able to reduce the severity of their pain may just need a little more time to develop the mental/emotional control techniques.
There is also a theory that it is possible to create pain without injury. Studies of brain function have found that an injury does not cause pain unless it is a real injury or a severe one. Some researchers suggest that some people can create a state of pain that feels like it is located outside of the body. Although this sounds odd, it does seem to be a very common occurrence with people who experience chronic pain.
It is important to remember that there are several forms of pain. Headache and earache are both considered painful symptoms of the body. In many cases, it is believed that the reason why someone may have this type of pain

in Kansas City are part of the reason Cal Poly Pomona alumnus Jacob Telfair has dedicated his career to the subject.
Telfair graduated from Cal Poly Pomona in 2005 with degrees in physics and English. He is now a professor at Blue Springs South High School in Blue Springs, Missouri, just outside Kansas City. As someone who has always been fascinated with physics, he wanted to take his passion to the classroom and get others excited about the subject.
Some students who might need help with physics in Kansas City decide not to take it because of bad experiences in the classroom. When asked if most of the students who enroll for physics at the high school don’t return for their junior year, Telfair said 30 to 40 percent of them transfer out. But when asked about why, he wasn’t sure.
“There’s a lot of misconceptions about the subject,” he said. Many students get a terrible first experience with physics. They might see it as homework problems with chalkboards and complicated equations.
Or, they might see people who are making fun of them as a child is falling through a trampoline and they miss the fact that they’re just joking.
“My first-year professors told me to approach the classroom with an open mind,” he said. And that is exactly what he did. He planned on being a physics teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District after his undergraduate years at Cal Poly Pomona. Since the district was too big, he asked to be placed at the smallest school he could. Although the move was initially planned to be a simple one-year stop, it ended up being his whole career.
Telfair said that he had some difficulties getting into teaching, even at the high school level. It took him a little over a year to find his footing in Kansas City and has been teaching there for four years now. He loves living in Blue Springs, where he has found the community supportive of his career choice.
“I wanted my students to know that learning physics has the potential to give them a greater understanding of the world and give them an advantage in a number of different fields of work,” he said. And, if that doesn’t work, he thinks knowing about physics will help them pass their MCATs or passing their driver’s tests, since many states require drivers to know about the quadratic function and car crash safety. After all, physics has applications in many different areas of life and Telfair wants to help his students see that.

in one sentence.
Geology is the study of the Earth's physical structure, processes, and materials, with a focus on understanding its formation, development, and composition over time.

That's a very broad and comprehensive sentence about geology. Can you provide more details about the specific processes and materials that geologists study?
Certainly, geologists study a wide range of physical processes and materials, such as plate tectonics, volcanic activity, rock formations, minerals, and fossils. They also investigate the distribution and movement of Earth's natural resources such as minerals, oil, and gas, as well as the impact of human activities on the environment.

Can you give an example of a recent geological discovery that has changed our understanding of the Earth's past?
One recent geological discovery that has changed our understanding of the Earth's past is the finding of fossils of advanced species of animals such as dinosaurs in unexpected places like China, and North America. These fossils provide evidence of dinosaur activity during a time when the Earth's climate and environmental conditions were quite different from what they are today. The discovery of these fossils has given geologists a more comprehensive understanding of Earth's geological history and how organisms adapted to changing environments over time.

Wow, I had no idea that geologists could uncover fossils of advanced species of animals like dinosaurs. Can you tell me more about how they were able to identify the fossils and what their characteristics are?
Sure, geologists use several techniques to identify fossils, including observing the structure of the fossilized bones or other remains, their composition, and the environment in which they were discovered. 

For example, the fossils of dinosaurs are typically identified based on the shape, size, and structure of their bones and teeth. Geologists can also determine the age of the fossil by comparing the degree of decay and other microscopic evidence to radiometric dating techniques. 

The characteristics of a dinosaur include a four-legged vertebrate with a long tail, which suggests an arboreal or quadrupedal lifestyle. Their diet was predominantly herbivorous, and their behavior involved movement through the landscape, most often through a mixture of slow-paced walking, running, and agile bursts of movement.

Dinosaurs lived on Earth approximately 230 million years ago and existed until around 65 million years ago. The most well-known and diverse group of dinosaurs was the Sauropods, which were the largest land animals to ever exist and had long necks and tails, and small heads.

Can you please explain how encryption works in Python code?
Furthermore, how can we use encryption to ensure the security of our sensitive data in the age of identity theft and data breaches? Could you provide us with a code example of how to properly encrypt and decrypt data using Python?

Cryptography is the process of converting ordinary data into a coded language that cannot be understood by anyone who does not have the key to decode it. Cryptography works by using a combination of mathematics, computer science, and cryptography to protect data.

In Python, encryption can be done using several built-in libraries like Cryptography, PyCrypto, etc. The most commonly used one is Cryptography. Below is a simple example of how encryption works in Python:

```
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet

# Generate a key to encrypt the data
key = Fernet.generate_key()

# Create an instance of Fernet to encrypt the data
cipher_suite = Fernet(key)

# Define the data to be encrypted
data = b"This is the data to be encrypted."

# Encrypt the data using the cipher suite
encrypted_data = cipher_suite.encrypt(data)

# Print the encrypted data
print(encrypted_data)
```

In the above code, we have imported the Fernet class from the Cryptography library and generated a key to encrypt the data. We have then created an instance of the Fernet class and used it to encrypt the data. Finally, we have printed the encrypted data.

To decrypt the data, we can use the same key used to encrypt the data:

```
# Define the key used to encrypt the data
key = Fernet.generate_key()

# Create an instance of Fernet to decrypt the data
cipher_suite = Fernet(key)

# Define the encrypted data to be decrypted
encrypted_data = b"This is the encrypted data."

# Decrypt the data using the cipher suite
decrypted_data = cipher_suite.decrypt(encrypted_data)

# Print the decrypted data
print(decrypted_data.decode())
```

In the above code, we have defined the key used to encrypt the data and created an instance of the Fernet class to decrypt the data. We have then defined the encrypted data to be decrypted and used the cipher suite to decrypt it.

What is a diet?
A diet is a shortened term for "eating habits", or you could say "how we eat". However, many people think that a diet is just what you eat. You may be surprised to know this is not entirely true.
When it comes to nutrition, a diet is the way in which you eat. It is your overall eating habits, whether you have three meals a day or four meals a day, have fruit or junk food and what you eat in them, along with all the other things you do when it comes to eating.
The most important thing is you need to have a food diary, which is a food list of all the food you eat, including snacks and drinks. If you are not sure what you eat, this tool can be very useful.

Calories in vs. calories out
Every diet is based on calories. In simple terms, they are the energy your body uses and they are the most important thing to know when it comes to food and weight loss.
Your body is in a constant state of caloric deficit or surplus. This means that it is always consuming energy from the food you eat. For example, when you have breakfast you consume calories for the food you eat. If you don't eat enough, your body will begin to store energy in the form of fat.

as an independent specialty system has been discussed for over a century, with a number of publication outlets such as the American Journal of Physics (AJP) and Physical Review Letters (PRL) in support of this evolution and its existence. Scientific research is completed through multiple steps, each of which is associated with specific topologies. An algorithmic framework is proposed to identify the high-dimensional patterns for characterizing a scientific research process. In this framework, current publications are formed into an overlapping classification network, which is dynamically structured and dynamically modified. A shared manifold metric is then used to identify how high-dimensional local patterns of publications co-evolve together, and how such patterns could be effectively used to describe and trace the complex research process. Statistical results of experimental results in comparing clustering with traditional spectral analysis demonstrate the effectiveness of the method. This approach can be easily applied to other distributed data that follows a community structure model, and can be used to serve as a generic method for dynamic network research in other interdisciplinary applications.

As long as there have been costumes, people have had opinion. The idea of a gown is to find one that makes the wearer appear chic and graceful, so if you're wearing it well then no one should notice if your top sleeve is a centimetre to the left. Fashion is very very subjective and personal and you may have many people in your life that don't like the same outfits as you, but you still should do what makes you comfortable. That's important and other than that the world is your oyster!
In any business you need to be confident. True, it's hard to have confidence if you haven't bought clothes you like – you feel naked because you don't have anything in your wardrobe to wear on nights out, but even if you don't like shopping you need to practice. Pick an outfit that is easy to wear or pick a favourite. Shopping can be time consuming and frustrating – the truth is not every shop has something for you, and it's easier to be apprehensive and stay home than to try on a pile of clothes and end up with nothing, but if you try everything on and make a list of what you like or don't like, it's easier for next time. If you don't go shopping then you may only have expensive and impractical things in your wardrobe and it's time consuming to make things work with what you have. Another way to find inspiration is in the press. Use the newspapers and internet fashion pages as well as your favourite magazines to see what kind of things you like – then just try to copy those designs or be inspired by them. Nobody will mind if you put in a few changes like take a pair of tights from a different shop and adding a flower from the hardware shop. (For a style lesson see the "how-to's" at the bottom of this article.) Have fun with your clothes, it's supposed to be a fashion adventure!
Tips on how to dress well:
It takes time to find your personal style – don't give up and try everything on that catches your eye! Wear colourful, interesting tops with navy bottoms – over-dressing should be about effort not colour. Try wearing off-beat accessories like a funky scarf and quirky shoes with plain clothes. Don't just wear heels with dresses – try tennis shoes on occasion as well. Don't be afraid of accessories or patterns, but just have fun!

# Congruence

## A family of equations

The congruence sign is used to describe that two mathematical expressions have the same values when we substitute one for the other.
$$12x \equiv 17x - 5 \pmod 2$$
This statement can also be written as
$$x \equiv 7 \pmod 2$$

How is the congruence defined? Let’s take a look at the values of both sides as we substitute the value of x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4… , in x when we substitute the expression.

$$0x \equiv 0x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 0x \equiv 2x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 0x \equiv 4x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 0x \equiv 6x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 0x \equiv 8x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 0x \equiv 10x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ \ldots$$
$$1x \equiv 1x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 1x \equiv 3x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 1x \equiv 5x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 1x \equiv 7x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 1x \equiv 9x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 1x \equiv 11x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ \ldots$$
$$2x \equiv 2x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 2x \equiv 4x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 2x \equiv 6x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 2x \equiv 8x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 2x \equiv 10x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 2x \equiv 12x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ \ldots$$
$$3x \equiv 3x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 3x \equiv 5x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 3x \equiv 7x - 5 \pmod 2 \\ 3x \equiv 9

and provide an example of a complex encryption algorithm.
Cryptography is the practice of securing communication and data by transforming it into a format that is unreadable to unauthorized parties. It involves the use of mathematical algorithms and encryption techniques to protect sensitive information from being intercepted, read, or altered during transmission. Cryptography is essential for maintaining privacy and security in today's digital age, where information is often transmitted over networks and stored in various devices.

A complex encryption algorithm is an advanced technique used to encrypt data securely. One example of such an algorithm is the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), which is widely adopted and considered to be one of the most secure encryption algorithms in use today. AES was introduced by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in 2001 and has since become the standard for various government and commercial applications.

AES uses a secret key to perform its encryption and decryption process. It operates on blocks of data, typically 128 bits in size, and applies a series of complex mathematical operations to transform the plaintext (unencrypted data) into ciphertext (encrypted data). The key plays a crucial role in determining the outcome of these operations, making it an essential component for ensuring the security of the encryption.

To decrypt the ciphertext, the receiving party uses the same secret key and applies the inverse operations of the encryption process to retrieve the original plaintext. This process ensures that only those with the correct key can access and understand the encrypted data.

AES provides a high level of security due to its complexity and wide range of key sizes (128-bit, 192-bit, and 256-bit). The larger the key size, the more difficult it is to crack the encryption using brute-force methods, as the number of possible combinations increases exponentially with the key length.

In summary, cryptography is a crucial concept for ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of data in today's digital world. AES is an example of a complex encryption algorithm that utilizes advanced mathematical operations to transform plaintext into ciphertext, providing a high level of security and protection against unauthorized access.

The Science Behind Artificial Intelligence
- What is artificial intelligence?
- What is predictive analytics?
- What is machine learning?
Artificial intelligence or “AI” can be described as the ability of a computer to think and act like a human, with the aid of algorithms and advanced information technology. For example, algorithms tell a computer system how to recognize information (storing and retrieving and sorting data).
AI can now be best utilized in various commercial markets, such as sales, where machine learning, a type of AI is used. Machine learning is generally developed using the algorithms that augment data processing. It means the data will be trained to learn from our responses to it and optimize at being able to predict what future outcomes may be.
What is predictive analytics?
Predictive analytics is the process of drawing inferences from past events, which leads to future actions that can be beneficial. It’s a field of big data analytics that uses advanced statistical techniques to predict future trends and events. It uses AI (in the form of machine learning) to sift through billions of data points, looking for patterns and correlations that can uncover insights.
A Predictive Approach to Analytics in Sales
Smart businesses recognize predictive analytics as a strategic competitive edge. In an environment where there’s a growing level of competition to match and exceed the needs of customers, executives know that an organization needs the tools to stay ahead of the curve. There are also many factors that can affect the sales process, like the economy, new legislation, public health issues, even natural disasters, meaning predicting future outcomes for an organization is paramount to growth, success, and maintaining growth in any field.
How Does Predictive Analytics Work in Sales?
Sales teams looking to implement analytics platforms into their sales strategy will benefit from having their sales process utilize predictive analytics to their benefit. In a nutshell, predictive analytics can help drive faster, smarter, and more consistent growth by helping sales leaders identify top prospects, streamline their sales pipeline, increase efficiency, and grow revenue.
Smart business use analytics to:
- Identify and close the right deals in the right order
- Create collaborative environments that increase productivity
- Measure business outcomes and easily optimize what works
- Become more proactive in identifying issues
- Enhance predictive accuracy through advanced predictive modeling and analytics
- Lower cost and improve margins
- Improve the customer experience with better relationship management
- Empower sales management and supervisors to lead the sales team to better performance

are demonstrating that there is an entirely new way of approaching the nature of life. It is becoming possible to observe actual processes of life at work in an experimental mode. A systematic, (although quite unsystematic) study of nature itself is leading to a novel perspective on the fundamental nature of life.
We shall be in a position to reveal, with a high degree of confidence, the actual nature of life. There is the possibility of knowing what life is like directly, and not merely on the basis of merely subjective and theoretical or hypothetical conjecture. Until now we have had to content ourselves with mere conjectures about life. We can now be making observations of life itself. It is of the greatest moment that we take seriously the philosophy of science and realize that there is a wonderful diversity of vital experience lying before us.
In retrospect, of course, we can reflect back upon life, recognize certain general laws of physics and "life experiences" and so forth, but this was only made possible in retrospect. What is most interesting is that we do not have to "invent the wheel" and reinvent the fact that there is a tremendous amount of material and immediate experience to be dealt with now. If we recognize this, we can utilize and develop this ready-made basis for new wisdom.
We can, for example, look at biology and see that it is, indeed, a great diversity and richness of empirical material, yet we can recognize that it is fundamentally incomplete. No description of life can be complete in terms of a particular ideological approach. Fundamental theory or approach -- such as the idea of "evolution" -- give an inadequate perspective and inadequately explain the basic nature of life.
The idea of "spontaneous order" also can be seen to be significantly flawed. Life is not simply order. It is disorder, it is variety, it is individual development and expression, it is cohesion, it is cooperation, and it is contribution. It is a totally unique and rich developmental experience, which is capable of being described, of being systematized, of being clarified, of revealing the actual nature of life. Yet all of this requires a totally new approach.
We are going to have to develop a whole new theory of life and, perhaps even more importantly, there will need to be a totally new social theory of the nature of life. This should be a new approach to philosophy, which is capable of serving as the most fundamental basis for social theory. and accounting, or accounting ethics, refers to the moral principles and values that guide corporate behavior, the choice of business strategy, and individual actions. The term is used in contrast with business and accounting issues and standards, which are principles of practice intended to facilitate correct and honest treatment of accounting data. Ethical behavior also conforms with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), however many non GAAP principles and practices often conflict with GAAP. 

Question: Accounting ethics Accounting ethics, or the ethics of business and accounting, refers to the moral principles and values that guide corporate behavior, the choice of business strategy, and individual actions[1]. It encompasses the discipline of accounting, and its bylaws and standards, and the selection of business strategies[1][2]. Accounting ethics is a subfield of ethics and a branch of philosophical ethics[2][3]. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and generally accepted auditing standards (GAAS) are widely used accounting standards[1][4]. Accountants often use the term “good ethics” to describe the five main accounting principles[5].

is fundamental to the practice’s success. As an in-depth approach to body-mind awareness, it is a vehicle for experiencing the potential of positive change in our lives. Simply put, this ancient practice works. Meditation has contributed to numerous scientific studies that have shown its many benefits to psychological and physical health. While research is at times conflicted on some of these subjects, other results have shown promising results in areas such as cardiovascular health, stress relief and reduction of pain.
While all people in general, regardless of lifestyle, seek to be happy and fulfilled, stress is a constant obstacle to overcome. That is one of the primary reasons so many people turn to meditation as a helpful method to balance the mind and reduce stress. Below are some of the many benefits of meditation.
Meditation is effective because it encourages positive thought and action. Regular practice helps us become more aware of our thoughts and learn to alter our emotions to more positive and constructive ones. Thinking good thoughts promotes well-being. Based on these more positive thoughts, the mental process generates calmness, which inevitably leads to happiness. Controlling your thoughts is an important part of positive thinking, and meditation is an excellent method for developing this skill.
Meditation not only helps you manage your stress, but it also alters your stress response. One of the most common conditions of the modern, fast-paced age is the stress-response, a sympathetic response to events of life, and an overreaction to minor problems. Meditation helps you notice what events trigger this “in-a-frenzy response” and helps you change it. When the sympathetic nervous system is activated, it sends hormones throughout the body. It also affects the autonomic nervous system, which controls heart rate and blood pressure. Prolonged stress causes both to shoot up.
One of the most powerful impacts of meditation is to learn how to relax. Relaxation does not mean sleep or to stop thinking. It means to let go of thoughts, in order to gain awareness of the present moment. Awareness is the key to understanding stress, which leads to the next benefit of meditation.
Stress becomes much more manageable, even after acute stress has been triggered, when your awareness informs you of your physical and emotional reactions to certain situations. The ability to recognize stress in the body and awareness of the thoughts behind it are two of the biggest benefits of meditation. Through meditation, you will learn what’s working in your body and mind. Not only do you learn to recognize problems, but you also learn how to alleviate problems when they arise.

补充资料： 戈尔兰油田
戈尔兰油田
伊拉克石油工业的心脏
戈尔兰油田位于北部城市迈苏拉的东南方约60公里处，是伊拉克主要油田之一，也是伊拉克最重要的油田，年产原油约1000万吨，占伊拉克石油总产量的三分之一。在此之外，该油田的天然气产量约占伊拉克天然气产量的80％，是波斯湾沿岸最大的天然气田之一，是伊拉克和周边国家天然气生产的主要基地。
伊拉克政府正在充分运用戈尔兰油田现有的天然气管道网，将天然气向离、科威特和沙特阿拉伯等周边国家，以及苏丹、阿富汗、巴基斯坦等中近东国家供电。这一计划中有一段将从巴格达到科威特、沙特阿拉伯的天然气管道。天然气管道中的装置采用世界最优的西方技术，工程师和技术员也均来自西方国家。工程的费用估计会达到30亿美元。如果通过这一计划，伊拉克每年的天然气利润就将达到10亿美元。
估计该油田目前仍蕴藏石油100亿桶。该油田曾于1974年进行过“试油”，当时测出的原油产气率为367立方千米/立方米，天然气比

programming with Python

Is Python a language for big projects?

If you intend to make something that requires lots of work hours, a decent amount of IO bound and backend computation, this might be the case. It can handle both graphical and more classic console interface applications.

There are different major frameworks one can use to build nice looking applications and other nice GUI interfaces (QApplication being the most common, pygame being the preferred for this). On the other side the use of sockets can be usefull for any networking purpose.

There is a pile of math engine libraries that you can use to perform any kind of computation you want, most of the times they contain more numerical accuracy than it is usually expected from mathematica, and are in general very reliable.

The answer can also be otherwise.

Python is a great language for prototyping very fast and it also perfectly adapted to data science. But if one is more interested in parsing large file amount of data from a database or else, using Python could be sometimes way slower than using other more specialized languages, like C or Java.

Which is the best IDE to use?

This is a subjective choice, some prefer to use very light editors like vim, others prefer to have the gui window all of it in emacs. However there is not a best IDE for Python, which is more like a task tool.

Installing Python and what are the supported operating systems and Python versions?

First of all one needs to have the correct Python environment and be able to properly interact with it.

Note: if you have an older installation you could have to reinstall it.

You can find links to download Python installation file on http://www.python.org/download/

Basically one can download executable packages and put it in the custom folder where one intends to run it, or install it through anaconda.

Anaconda is a set of libraries and packages from which one can start off and install new packages, so far it is more complete than the standard python, which might be very useful. Basically it creates conda environments, which are groups of libraries, so multiple uses of python can be done simultaneously without any interference.

The online interface for anaconda https://anaconda.org/ gives you the ability to build a specific package and to install it for all (not too complex to do).

Alternatively one can just install the libraries and packages manually. All of the frameworks can be downloaded from their official repository.

The official Python documentation lists all the modules that one can install from source. It also explain how one can build from scratch. There are lots of options, and

How Astronomy Impacts Our Daily Life: Traveling

Today, we can travel to those places, even though they might be hundreds or thousands of light-years away. Whether it be the auroras or the planets, we are finding these celestial bodies more accessible than ever before. How Astronomy Impacts Our Daily Life: Food

We know that many students view the night sky as a way of learning new things and gaining knowledge, and many of them would love to become astronomers someday. According to a study conducted by the American Museum of Natural History in New York, there has been a steady decline in enrollment in astronomy classes since the early 20th century. Even though the rate of enrollment has been slowing down, it is still higher than the rate of enrollment in other subjects.

The use of photography in a world that is increasingly out of control was not even imaginable in the 1920s when the world saw the last of the Black Sun Books. The most exciting image on the page (a photograph) was a small representation of a medium that consumed entire pages, and that that all art forms were preparing to devour. Now we have embraced photography as no other art form before it, and in turn, the photography changed daily life as it did not exist before.
With the ever expanding growth of the world’s population, the nature of its on hold markets are no longer confined by the nature of a geographic location, but by the nature of the world. The urbanization of our environment has increased the total number of people that live within an urban area by a third (Wilde 344). What this has done has made the world extremely global and has shaped the world image. With each passing day, the old national identity is being replaced with a new one that is aptly global, driven by the images, sounds, and phenomenon of a postmodern culture.
Even though humanity always was and always will be as one species, through the use of photography and the inclusion of the media, humanity is being transformed from a mere collection of individuals to a group of people with a common image that is shared and understood throughout the world. When it comes to photography, especially with the industry of nudes, this transformation has taken a turn to what was previously considered taboo. When looking at this side of image culture, we see that whatever will be accepted into society will be an evolution of that previously accepted. The penetration of photographs and images in consumer culture has shifted with that shift of culture. Early to mid-twentieth century photography created a debate on the contents of images that was long-ignored due to a stubborn insistence on the well-founded division between art and commercial purposes.
One such example of this was a widely-circulated erotic scene, which is a scandal in modern day life, but in the 1920s was perfectly acceptable to be published in photography. People were ashamed to view such images of their own sexuality. It was not until photography came into the picture that the idea was accepted within society.

: a menu designed to inspire a love of good food in children.
Cooking your own food isn’t just more fun, it also makes sense in terms of value and health. Nourishing our kids with a healthy diet isn’t just beneficial for their weight, energy levels, their appearance and their happiness; it’s also the best way to learn about food. Food is something we all take for granted, but by cooking it from scratch ourselves we learn not only about what we’re putting into our bodies, but also about what is involved in growing and producing it.
But food – and the vital role it plays in our lives – doesn’t come naturally. In the average day, we are programmed to reach for the most convenient foods that are available to us and given that these are often packed full of sugar, salt and fat and lacking in key nutrients, we are not only consuming foods that will cause us to pile on the pounds but also that are contributing to heart disease, diabetes and other chronic diseases.
Moreover, our children are being far less adventurous with food, too. Less than half of eight to 11-year-olds eat five portions of fruit and vegetables a day and more than 35% don’t eat enough calcium. Those who participate in the 5 A DAY programme eat fewer calories and make healthier food choices. They also consume more fibre, are more active and have fewer behavioural problems at school. In short, it’s all in the menu. But, to make these changes, first of all the role of cooking needs to be emphasised – our children need to get in the kitchen!
If your family isn’t cooking at all right now, what are you waiting for? It’s never too early to start – the earlier the better! If you have kids younger than five, start by involving them in preparing food – you might need help with the meal in the beginning, but you need to make it fun for them. If you can, get them involved in the picking of fruit and vegetables in the supermarket and encourage them to smell and get to know flavours. After that, just let them play! There will come a point when you need to start introducing ingredients that they are not familiar with and you may be quite tentative yourself; you need to give them time to get to know these new tastes, they’ll need to be introduced in small quantities. When trying new foods, offer them as part of a meal rather than alone. They need to get used to eating all the components together, then, in time, you can

is an effort to find value in the world. It makes individuals spend more time outdoors, like hiking, camping, or simply enjoying nature. It promotes individual responsibility toward the earth and any person that has the goal of preserving the ecosystem for future generations. 

Question: Why is 'nature' considered to be 'beautiful' when it doesn't serve any purpose on earth?
Nature is considered to be 'beautiful' because it is a reflection of the way humans perceive and interact with the earth. Nature promotes individual responsibility towards the earth and the preservation of the ecosystem for future generations[1], and has a calming and peaceful effect on people due to the positive association it has with nature as a whole, and familiarity with nature in general[2]. Nature is seen as something positive and rewarding because it gives life to ourselves and others and nourishes and enlivens us[3]. Human nature can also be described as a combination of the uniquely social aspects of our behaviour and the unique qualities that distinguish human beings from animals[4]. Ultimately, nature is important for everyone because it promotes care, healthy life, and high-quality societies[5].

Whereas expert systems reached a plateau some time ago, one of the most promising trends in AI is the rise of deep learning. Given an appropriate feature representation, for example, a large and consistent dataset, it allows machines to identify and respond to complex signals in the data.
Despite the many applications of deep learning, including image recognition and text analysis, researchers in the healthcare space are still trying to figure out how to use it to address the most pressing questions.
“It’s a very early field,” says Dr. Arvind Raghu, PhD candidate in Computer Science at the University of Toronto and the Head of the computer vision research team at the Vector Institute. “It’s both exciting and challenging. We are just at the start and I think the world needs a lot more expertise in this area if we want to make impactful use of it.”
Regulating Deep Learning in Healthcare
As the first true revolution in computing in the last few decades, deep learning is also happening to us and disrupting the markets we have grown to rely upon. Since it is a tool that was originally trained and created to best understand patterns, machine learning tools can easily spot potentially damaging patterns in medical data, and could therefore be used to identify a range of serious concerns.
Rather than identifying the existence of an anomaly or the potential presence of an illness, however, deep learning has the ability to spot patterns and detect groups of individuals who may be susceptible to a particular type of illness, and predict their likelihood of engaging in risky behaviours. Data on family history, for example, has been extensively studied and can be inferred.
“We don’t need a big dataset to show us how to predict what is going to happen in a thousand years,” explains Raghu. “We can use tools like big data and machine learning to make predictions about disease and death – to show us how many people will be affected in the next five to 10 years.”
Indeed, since deep learning is dependent on large, consistent, carefully-annotated datasets, the technology presents challenges for healthcare. Deep learning systems, for example, would be classified as proprietary if they used algorithms that could not be reproduced by third parties. In the healthcare space, this could spell trouble because, as other companies create models using the same data, patients might be treated differently, despite being in the same category.

and the impacts of climate change on traditional forms of architecture around the world. Climate change has already had an impact on traditional forms of architecture around the world. Rising sea levels, extreme weather events, and more frequent droughts and floods are forcing people to adapt to new ways of living and building. Climate change also challenges the values and aesthetics associated with traditional architecture, forcing architects and builders to consider new forms and materials that can withstand the changing climate.

For example, traditional Indonesian buildings are being modified to reduce their susceptibility to flooding and landslides. In coastal areas, architects and builders are using local materials like bamboo and coconut leaves to create houses that can withstand the force of the sea. In sub-Saharan Africa, drought-resistant building materials are being used in rural communities, while in Arctic communities, new forms of insulation are being developed to withstand the extreme cold.

The cultural significance of architecture has always been tied to its unique identity and the values that underpin it. The loss of traditional forms of architecture can have profound cultural and social impacts. For example, in parts of Asia, traditional temple architecture is an integral part of cultural heritage that defines local identity. Similarly, in South Africa, traditional thatched-roof structures are an important part of cultural heritage and tourism.

Climate change has already begun to challenge these cherished forms of architecture, and architects are responding with new strategies and materials to build structures that can withstand the changing climate. The preservation of traditional architecture and its unique identity is critical to maintaining cultural continuity and promoting environmental sustainability.

It's amazing how resilient and adaptable the traditional forms of architecture can be. Can you give more examples of how climate change is affecting different regions of the world? Sure, here are a few more examples of how climate change is affecting traditional architecture around the world:

1. The Middle East: In the Middle East, rising temperatures are causing desertification and increasing the frequency of heatwaves, which are leading to the decline of traditional earthen architecture. Local building materials are also becoming scarce due to overuse and illegal logging, forcing architects and builders to turn to more modern materials.

2. North America: In northern regions of North America, traditional log houses are being impacted by rising temperatures and melting permafrost. Log houses built on unstable soil are at risk of collapsing, and many are being rebuilt with modern materials that are better able to withstand the changing climate.

3. South America: In many parts of South America, traditional adobe houses are at risk due to melting glaciers and increasing rainfall. Adobe is a type of earthen building

I love borders. Of all the things I like to collect, be it stamps, postcards, coins or flags, borders seem to be the most fascinating and beautiful. But more than that, borders are the most representative feature of countries. Borders are the memory of the growing complexity of states and it is interesting to notice how these borders have changed over time. But what happens when borders change? When borders move or are moved? Of course, a lot. But, borders also influence people's decisions when they want to cross them. In the last few years I have read a lot about migrations. How they are often a result of political decisions, how many countries are still using specific migration laws, how migrants are sometimes pushed to flee their country. In 2016, before having been elected as Trump, there was the scary talk that was repeated ad nauseam on the news channels: Mexico would soon pay for the wall. I wonder what it would feel like to live in a country with a border constantly changing. I can imagine the fear, the stress and the paradox of being protected, but at the same time not being protected at all. Indeed, creating a border without reinforcing it with concrete walls or barbed wire does not mean keeping people out, in some cases it just means letting them through more easily, unbarred.
During my last holiday, I visited Budapest. A few years ago I had visited it, mainly because I wanted to see the Parliament, which I found really impressive. I then visited the City Park, where there is the aquarium and a planetarium. On one of the visits I got a little lost and instead of taking the usual way back to the area in which I had stayed I decided to take a different path. Crossing a bridge, following signs, I decided to take the street that runs along a river. It was 19:00, the sky was getting darker and, although the temperature was still pretty high, I was starting to feel the cold. As I got closer to the border I started wondering about people who, by chance, must cross it every day. While I was walking I saw two railway tracks crossing a road. They were very close to the river and above all they were wide and untended. I wondered what would happen if an angry Hungarian shepherd from the other bank crossed them by accident, causing the railway to collapse in a great avalanche and kill hundreds of people. , especially when it is called for, is the willingness of performers to embody the essence of a character and to do it in a way that makes the audience feel as if they were watching a real person. Some people are born with that ability. Others have to be coached and directed to learn and practice it to the highest level. In To Kill a Mockingbird, based on the Harper Lee book, director Brit Whitfield guides his cast of Auburn University students to portray this level of realism and to take the story to a level that reminded those who might not have heard of it that the story is the heart of why it is so important and why its message is still so vital today.
The story is set during the 1930s in a small town in Alabama. It focuses on two young children, Scout and Jem Finch, who are dealt the challenge of the racism and prejudice of their town when an integrated couple arrives in town. When they, an innocent white girl, is raped, the town’s white elite decide to put an innocent black man on trial for a crime he didn’t commit, despite the fact that there is physical evidence that he had nothing to do with it. Finch, who is a lawyer, finds himself pulled into the drama of it all, defending a man who does not deserve the accusation and damage that will be leveled against him. Meanwhile, Scout comes to a different understanding of the word “nigger” as she goes to court and becomes more cognizant of the fact that life is not black or white.
This is a wonderful story and is one of those stories, although not intentionally, about what makes us who we are and that the actions of others can change how we react. This is a story that is about fighting for justice, fighting for truth, and fighting to do what is right, no matter what the outcome. It is also a story about understanding, as Scout begins to come to grips with the fact that she can not see herself as superior to her black peers, and is that she is a racist because she has the wrong understanding of those people.
With those aspects of the story in mind, as well as the importance of such a story in our country’s past, it is interesting to note that Mr. Whitfield has asked the children’s grandfather to come on stage before the beginning of the play and make a statement to the audience about racism, about the importance of understanding our past, and about the potential of race relations in our country, especially with the election of our first

, which is the study of Earth's structure and composition and the processes that shape it.
Geology is the study of Earth's structure and composition, and the processes that shape it. It involves understanding the physical and chemical properties of rocks, minerals, and other materials found within the Earth's crust. Geologists use various techniques to study the Earth, including the study of natural landmarks such as mountains, valleys, rivers, and caves, and the analysis of geological data collected through fieldwork, such as GPS, remote sensing, and radar mapping.

Geology can be divided into three main branches:

1. Geophysics: This branch of geology studies the physical properties of the Earth, such as earthquakes, volcanoes, and the Earth's magnetic field.

2. Geology: This branch of geology studies the composition and structure of the Earth, including the Earth's layers, the composition of rocks and minerals, and the distribution of minerals and ores.

3. Petrology: This branch of geology studies the composition and properties of rocks, including igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks.

Geology plays a critical role in understanding the Earth's history, processes, and potential. It helps scientists understand natural disasters such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and tsunamis, and enables the development of strategies to mitigate their impact. Geologists also help us understand the Earth's climate, tectonic plates, and the geologic history of our planet. Moreover, geology is essential in determining the location of natural resources such as minerals and oil, and in predicting the potential impact of human activity on the environment.

, from prehistoric times to modern day.
The history of cooking is a vast and rich story that spans back tens of thousands of years. Here is a brief overview of the key developments and innovations in the art of cooking throughout history.

Prehistoric Times:

- The earliest known evidence of human cooking is carbonized plant and animal remains found in China that date back to around 29,000-30,000 years ago.
- Early humans likely used fire to cook their food, as shown by the discovery of heated stones used for cooking in Africa.
- During this time, humans also developed the ability to store food in caves, which protected it from spoilage and allowed for longer journeys.

Bronze Age (3000-1200 BC):

- The use of bronze tools for cooking emerged during this time, allowing for more efficient and precise cooking methods.
- Bronze cooking pots and skillets were used for roasting, stewing, and baking, as well as preparing fermented drinks.

Iron Age (800-400 BC):

- During this time, iron replaced bronze as the primary material for cooking tools.
- Skillet sizes increased significantly, and the development of specialized pots like the Chinese jadala and Dutch oven made cooking easier and more efficient.
- The use of ceramic pots and bowls became more common, and they were decorated with intricate designs and colorful glazes.

Ancient Rome:

- Roman cooking techniques included roasting, grilling, and baking, and Romans were known for their excellent preserved meat dishes.
- The concept of "boiling" was also developed during this time, as seen in recipes for fish in highly seasoned liquid.

Middle Ages:

- European cuisine was heavily influenced by the Islamic culture during this period, with many dishes originating from the Middle East.
- Recipes were often passed down through generations and included detailed instructions for seasoning, cooking, and preserving food.
- People also began to eat different meals at different times of day, with breakfast, lunch, and dinner becoming more common.

Renaissance:

- The Renaissance saw a renewed interest in elaborate culinary techniques, with wealthy families often hiring "cooks" (chef de cuisine) to create elaborate meals for their banquets.
- In addition, the first known cookbook, the Libro de Dieci Cucina ("Book of Ten Cooks"), was published in Spain in 1495.
- The development of glassblowing and glazing techniques allowed for the creation of intricate pottery for use in

is affected by several factors. Each factor is unique and operates differently. The factors affect the evolution of the genes and hence the organisms. They include mutations, natural selection, sexual reproduction, genetics drift and gene flow among others. Understanding these factors is key to the evolution of any gene and hence the organisms.
Mutation happens due to a random alteration in the genes of an organism. Mutations take place every minute and although some of them are harmless, others cause genetic defects in an organism. Several factors affect mutation including radiation, chemical reaction, cosmic rays and free radicals.
Natural selection occurs when there is a variation in the characteristics of organisms and is best described by the statement ‘Survival of the fittest’. During natural selection, the organism in the species with the most desirable characteristics survives as its different characteristics help them survive. These characteristics are passed on to the next generation in the form of genes (Molson, 2001).
Sexual reproduction is a very important concept. Here an individual produces offspring and these offspring then grow into adults. By the process, two parental organisms combine to produce offspring. Among the organisms like humans and flowers, only some genes can be expressed in both parents and are therefore passed to the offspring. This means that the offspring gets many desirable genes from the two parents (Johannes, 2001).
Genetics drift is an important evolutionary concept. Here it is noted that even though mutations are a rare occurrence, they cause significant changes in the genetic traits and hence results in evolution. This is because most of the organisms do not give rise to progeny and hence only a few leave the species as they are unable to produce offspring or as they are unable to change in order to give rise to progeny that are productive (Nussey, 2001).
All these factors contribute to evolution. Understanding the role of the factors in evolution is essential for the survival of the species. The factors play a major role and are very important for evolution.

budget cuts in Arizona
Common misconceptions about education budget cuts in Arizona#6932745
- By: Jeff Zink
- Published: Jan 3, 2016
Misconception 1: the Great Recession caused the largest school budget cuts in the history of Arizona
The numbers bear this out and they are well-documented and widely disseminated. The University of Arizona’s Economic and Business Research Center concluded that state K-12 funding levels today are lower, in terms of spending per pupil, than they were before the Great Recession. To be fair, public K-12 budgets in Arizona were under-funded prior to 2008. We were ranked 48th in the nation in K-12 per-pupil spending. The largest cuts came between 2008-2012. A collapse in the housing market and the resulting great recession did not help matters.
After plummeting to a low of 43rd in the nation in K-12 per-pupil spending in 2012, Arizona has recently returned to roughly where it was in 2003. This is above 43rd and back up to a respectable spot among U.S. states in education spending. What happened to these funds in the interim is important to understand for policymakers seeking to achieve and maintain top 10 education rankings for Arizona in the future. Rather than pursuing more money for education, the state spent a good portion of the windfall on an undoable Taxpayer Protection Act and then a deadly 2012 proposition — Proposition 204 — that put all those dollars into maintaining an unsustainable top 10 education system instead of using them as the central funding source for public K-12. The historic cuts of 2008 are best thought of as a plan for cutting way back, something to put the state on a sound footing for the future and, at the time, necessary as the $1.1 billion revenue windfall turned into a $1.3 billion revenue shortfall and property taxes were hobbled.
The additional $200 million in per-pupil funding provided by the legislature in 2015 only scratched the surface of the real gaps that exist in K-12 education budgets because those dollars were largely used for day-to-day operations as opposed to creating new programs. Those dollars are a one-time band aid that cannot be applied to the repair of a totally destroyed

and learn the fundamentals of planting, watering, and maintaining plants.
1. Research: Before you start gardening, take some time to learn about the plants you wish to grow and the local climate and soil conditions. Consider the space you have available, the type of plants you want to cultivate, and how much time and effort you are willing to invest in the process.

2. Get the right tools: A good quality gardening trowel, spade, watering can, and gloves can make all the difference in your success. Invest in quality tools that are durable and comfortable to use.

3. Plan your garden: Plan the layout of your garden before you start planting. Consider the sunlight, wind, and rainfall patterns of your location and choose plants that will thrive in those conditions. Also, consider any local zoning or building codes that may affect your garden.

4. Start with easy-to-grow plants: Start with easy-to-grow plants such as tomatoes, lettuce, and radishes. They don't require a lot of maintenance and are great for beginners.

5. Water regularly: Make sure to water your plants regularly, especially during dry spells. Different plants have different watering needs, so make sure to research the specific needs of each plant.

6. Fertilize regularly: Give your plants the nutrients they need to grow by fertilizing them regularly. Use a balanced fertilizer and follow the instructions on the packaging.

7. Prune and deadhead: Prune your plants to remove dead or diseased leaves, and deadhead flowers to encourage new growth.

8. Protect your plants: Protect your plants from pests and diseases by using natural remedies such as insecticidal soap or neem oil, or by introducing companion plants that repel pests.

9. Enjoy your garden: Finally, enjoy your garden! Plant what you love, and get outside to enjoy the benefits of gardening, such as fresh produce, beautiful flowers, and a sense of accomplishment.

When it comes to business communication, there are many interesting facts you should know. Here are 10 fun facts to get you started:
