2) Good communication skills are the most important quality for being a successful manager.
3) Effective business communication can result in increased productivity, better teamwork, and higher job satisfaction.
4) Only 7% of communication is verbal, while 93% is nonverbal.
5) Written communication is more formal and professional than spoken communication.
6) The average person communicates 30,000 messages per day, either in writing or through spoken words.
7) In a survey conducted by CareerBuilder, 86% of employees said they would change jobs if their communication skills were improved.
8) Business communication is an essential part of building relationships with customers and clients.
9) Effective business communication skills include active listening, clear expression, and empathy.
10) The majority of people communicate best through written communication.
If you want to improve your business communication skills, here are some tips to get started:
- Take classes on communication skills.
- Practice active listening and ask questions to ensure understanding.
- Use clear and concise language.
- Be aware of your nonverbal cues, such as facial expressions and body language.
- Practice empathy and try to see things from the other person’s perspective.
- Consider using visual aids, such as diagrams or charts, to help convey your message.
- Learn how to effectively handle conflicts in the workplace.
- Seek feedback from colleagues or supervisors to identify areas of improvement.
- Make a list of the best communication techniques you’ve learned and use them regularly.

The tiny balls, made up of several individual bugs about the size of cherry pits, were found everywhere. They were in the lawn, near the flowerbeds, even among the rain gutters hanging over the back steps.
My mother-in-law and I think that the tiny balls might be coming from the nearby dam pond where Canadian geese are often seen. When the geese are hanging out near the dam, hundreds of small balls of various size, called «eggs», make their way onto the lawn.
The bugs that swarm over this debris are myriapods. They look like little white bugs with long feelers, but they are not white by any means. This is because they are covered in a layer of wax so that when the wind blows, they will move with less air resistance.

Whether a costume has no voice and speaks more eloquent than words, they are one of the most enduring facts about our everyday lives in the field of fashion and clothing. According to ancient Jewish tradition, a person's freedom of clothing can indicate their commitment to Jewish customs, ultimately celebrating "the attainment of the highest level of faith and love of God".
Each character has its own style. And it is not surprising that Jews, whose history dates back to ancient times, are not ready to compromise their freedom of clothing and to abandon the identity of their culture and religion. From colourful traditional Yiddish clothing for women and men, to glittering traditional Jewish female clothing such as a short skirt, along with a decorative vest, and a short or short yet thick woolen suit, Jews love getting dressed and making an incredible show of style.
While practicing creativity and experiments with fashion, we live by ancient rules that have already become part of our society today.
According to several observations and even approximations, it has been established that the ability to combine different colours in one outfit may be a remarkable sign of culture and a clear indication of good taste.
Best examples of Jewish outfits, along with a tremendous involvement and dedication to cultural and religious values, can be seen in New York, where you can observe the combination of classic suits and traditional patterns, including a wide range of headgear, and braided hair.

lies in both our biological makeup as well as our cognitive abilities. Both are intertwined and fed by one another. These two aspects create the foundation of understanding cultural foodways, and a focus on how one’s present knowledge or cultural heritage is likely shaped by both their immediate surroundings as well as their past.
According to Civil Action teacher Cherri Goode, our understanding of both who we are and how we relate to the world around us “is rooted in the habits of our past.” This ability to understand one’s cultural foodways allows people to make culinary decisions centered around one’s ability to store food, detect freshness and ensure food quality, and have the means to access or create it. In her interactive presentation, Goode guides students to understand foodways in an American context while also incorporating how taste intersects with culture in a historical context. Moreover, it is the way one distinguishes their food choices and habits from that of their ancestral origin that speaks to the cultural significance of food. This is what many of Goode’s students have termed the “food traditions” and “cultural cuisine” of themselves.
There is a growing push in popular media to reclaim and celebrate our cultural foodways. While this idea of culinary “authenticity” may be largely up for interpretation, it is important to note that foodways are organic and aren’t necessarily static nor are they orphans of cultural appropriation. This points to the complexity and importance of appreciating the different food traditions of others and how these traditions have both been shaped by their culture but also by the foodways of others. For example, it has been noted that the widely-loved menu items from New York’s French restaurant Marea are actually the result of “a combination of approaches.” Without dipping into stereotypical white chef and Italian city tropes, Marea is able to showcase its singular Italian roots in a manner that feels authentic to its local New York community but is also able to appeal to a broader market by showcasing Italian cuisines beyond just what people have come to expect. Moreover, the smaller of these companies that have similar approaches are able to draw upon their ownership and community, creating a representation of Italian food that is wholly and purely their own.
These dinner menus are, in turn, informed by the changing of how foodways have altered in America over the last few decades. Whether the changes stem from shifts in population demographics or global economic climates, foodways continue to be modified by both the changing of cultural attitudes and changing of the understanding of what constitutes a healthy diet. as if it were an ancient myth.

Once upon a time, in the land of earth, there was a mighty force known as the Earth Mother. She was the creator of all that was, and all that was not.

One day, as the Earth Mother was relaxing in her home, she noticed something strange. The sky had been clouded over for days, and the ground was feeling much heavier. She knew that something was wrong.

As she ventured out to see what was happening, she discovered a group of giants who were digging up the land. They had been hired to build a grand structure, and they were using the Earth's energy to do so.

The Earth Mother knew that this was wrong. She called upon her trusted companion, the Moon, to help. Together, they confronted the giants and demanded that they stop using the Earth's energy.

But the giants would not listen. They continued to dig and work, until the Earth Mother's patience ran out. She called upon the Earth's power and created a great earthquake that shook the giants off their feet.

The Earth Mother then showed the giants the importance of the Earth's resources and the consequences of using them without regard for the Earth's wellbeing. She explained that the Earth was not just a place to build structures, but a home for all life.

From that day on, the giants respected the Earth Mother and her wisdom. They began to use the Earth's energy in a more responsible way, and the land was able to heal itself from the damage done by the giants.

And so, the Earth Mother's legend was passed down through generations, a reminder that we must always respect the Earth and all its wonders.

How did the Earth Mother's legends shape ancient cultures?

The Earth Mother's legends played a significant role in shaping ancient cultures. These stories were often passed down orally from one generation to the next and were considered sacred. They served as a reminder of the importance of respecting the Earth and living in harmony with nature.

In many cultures, the Earth Mother was seen as the goddess of the land and was revered as a powerful force. She was believed to have the ability to control the Earth's elements and to protect her people from harm. Her stories were often used to teach children about the importance of taking care of the Earth and the consequences of not doing so.

In some cultures, the Earth Mother was seen as a symbol of fertility and abundance. Her stories were used to teach people about the importance of planting and harvesting crops, and about the cycles of life and death.

However, as energy production mechanisms provide heat and pollutant emissions, climate change represents an important threat to modern society and ultimately to the wellbeing of future generations. This fact implies a research of cost-effective mechanisms in order to either reduce the impact of energy production (through the design of systems that exploit the energy already produced in the most efficient ways) or to reduce our dependence on carbon-based fuels (through new technologies).
Residues and wastes (e.g., plastics), exhaust gases, light bulbs, and very small particles (e.g., cigarette smoke) represent important sources of emissions into the atmosphere and their impact on the quality of the environment and people's health have been widely recognized during the last few years. An innovative group of researchers in the area of natural resources protection (e.g., environmental engineering, applied physics, chemical engineering, environmental health and safety management) are seeking candidates interested in the study of the impact of emissions in the atmospheric environment, in particular the concentration levels of fine and ultrafine particulate matter (PM) and their chemical constituents in indoor and outdoor environments.
1.	Consumption of energy is amongst the main sectors which produces greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs), an important factor driving the current climate change trend. As the largest user of fossil fuels in Brazil, residential and commercial sectors comprise one of the main sectors still driving fossil fuel consumption and GHG emissions in Brazil. As one solution to mitigate GHG emissions, infrastructure such as Smart Grids could be deployed and managed to improve energy efficiency in buildings, especially in heating and cooling processes, by optimizing the coordination among buildings and the incorporation of renewable energy sources. This proposal's main objective is to study the global impact of Smart Grids technologies on the energy demand, the quality of indoor air and the exposure of building inhabitants to particulate matter.

, including key discoveries and breakthroughs in the field. Genetics is the study of genes, heredity, and genetic variation in living organisms. The history of genetics can be traced back to ancient times, but the field of genetics as we know it today emerged in the 19th century.

The first significant breakthrough in genetics was Gregor Mendel's discovery of the laws of inheritance in pea plants in the mid-19th century. He formulated the theory of "genetic unit" or "factor," and the laws of inheritance that have since become known as Mendelian inheritance, which is the basis of modern genetics. This discovery helped to explain some of the traits that are inherited from parents to their offspring, such as eye color, height, and other physical characteristics.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the field of genetics was revolutionized by the discovery of chromosomes. In 1909, Edmund Wilson, a Scottish embryologist, discovered that the chromosomes in chromosomes of living organisms carry genes. This discovery led to the study of the structure and function of genes, which eventually led to the identification of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid).

In the mid-20th century, scientists made important advances in understanding the structure and function of DNA. In 1953, Watson and Crick discovered the DNA double helix structure, which helped to explain how genetic information is passed from generation to generation. In the 1970s, further research by Barbara McClintock and others led to the discovery of epigenetics, which refers to the study of heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve changes to the underlying DNA sequence.

In recent years, the study of genetics has expanded to include the use of gene editing techniques such as CRISPR/Cas9. These techniques have the potential to revolutionize the treatment of genetic diseases by allowing scientists to edit the genes that cause these diseases. The field of genetics has also contributed to our understanding of evolution and biological diversity, and has had a significant impact on fields such as agriculture and biotechnology. Overall, the study of genetics has been a key factor in the advancement of human knowledge about ourselves and our world.

Phaedrus claimed that without poetry, society could not flourish. However, our approach to writing and speaking through literature has changed dramatically over time, and not for the better. For this reason, I am starting a plan to help correct for our current cultural emphasis on confusingly babbled writing, in whatever genre. This is a part-time plan, not one requiring constant attention, but thought that I can contribute, in smaller pieces, to.
I have a couple of tasks to accomplish in the coming weeks to help lay the foundation for success. I need to look into the development of a tool for using a serial plot structure in writing fiction, and one to read the prosody in prose. Both of these could be templates for better story-telling, and for poetry as well, but I'll only have them in mind as I develop the stories. With enough success, I may be able to pull off a condensed version for a person with no writing experience to use. This may be necessary to achieve my real target, a program that can teach high school-age students the skill of story-telling, without even very much formal instruction.
Another task I will be working on is developing a program to read the prosody of prose, which may also be used in music (I'm not sure that prose is the best medium for reading the meaning of music). This would also be a more technical or "requirement," per se, for the prosody-reading program, but may need to be a later part of the development, because what needs to be taught can be fairly different for each genre, and equally important.
This blog will serve as my lab notebook and continuing reference for the development of the reader and the instruction tool, as well as ideas for use of text. When I've got something that is my primary focus, I may start a separate blog specifically for fiction writing.
I thought I might join a writing group or a critique circle, and I'm considering setting up a series of meetups, but really, I'm thinking that I can still share the development of these tools for a more online approach. In fact, the whole premise of this web site is to relate these tools to modern web-based interactions, and this is an online exchange that I've been wanting for a long time. What do you think?

cannot be understated. Through advancements in medical technology, conditions that were once fatal are now treatable or even manageable with lifestyle modifications. From the invention of penicillin to disease diagnosis, the work of research scientists has increased the quality of life for millions of people.
However, being a medical researcher has its drawbacks. While work in the lab can be challenging, it can also be dangerous. There are instances where exposure to harmful elements can lead to certain illnesses and even death. Even worse, victims of medical researcher negligence cannot sue for compensation due to sovereign immunity.
The Birth of Medical Research
The early history of medical research involves the discipline of medicine and a need for organ donors. In the early 1800s, there was a limited amount of organ donors who were not likely to recover from the transplants they received. It is here that the need for better options arose. After the discovery of blood transfusions, it was revealed that donors and recipients shared antibodies, making transplants viable for a period of time. It would be another 100 years before transplantation would be performed regularly with the availability of compatible donors.
Medical Researcher Negligence
Despite the promising nature of transplants, many individuals would experience complications and die as a result of the procedure. Improper precautions by the medical researcher were to blame. In some instances, doctors used unsterilized needles, ignored their x-rays, and falsified their test results. These are just some of the many causes of medical researcher negligence.
Benefits of Medical Research Negligence Suits
It would be impossible to start any transplant program without additional funding. Lawsuit proceeds could be used to fund and create a post-transplant recovery center. New types of medical research would not see the light of day without funding and, in some instances, private medical researchers know what works and what doesn’t. Much of what we know today about the human body would not have been possible without the research and development of the medical community.
Who Can Sue for Medical Researcher Negligence?
Individuals who have received transplants can sue medical researchers who caused the complications and the additional medical bills incurred due to it. Additionally, research institutions can sue for damages and treatment.
Injured victims cannot seek compensation from government programs due to sovereign immunity. However, several states have rules that exclude medical researcher negligence from sovereign immunity. Hawaii is one of them. Individuals who believe they have a valid claim may want to consider contacting an attorney.
Sources:
What are medical research and development centers? Law Insider

Neuroscience can provide us with incredible insights into how the brain works, and these insights have several potential benefits.

One of the primary benefits of neuroscience is that it can help us understand and treat a wide range of mental health disorders. Neuroscience research has led to the development of medications and other therapies that have improved the lives of millions of people suffering from conditions such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia.

Another potential benefit of neuroscience is that it can help us develop new technologies that can improve our quality of life. For example, advances in neural engineering and brain-computer interfaces have the potential to help people with paralysis or other physical disabilities.

Neuroscience can also help us better understand how our brains process and respond to the world around us. This knowledge can help us develop new insights into everything from how we learn and remember information to how we make decisions and perceive emotions.

Overall, neuroscience has the potential to provide us with a deeper understanding of the brain and its functions, as well as to help us develop new technologies and therapies that can improve our lives and the lives of others.

Are there any potential downsides or risks associated with neuroscience research? While there are many potential benefits to neuroscience research, there are also some potential downsides and risks associated with this field.

One potential risk of neuroscience research is that it may raise ethical concerns. For example, research involving human subjects may raise issues related to informed consent, privacy, and autonomy. Additionally, the use of animals in neuroscience research has been criticized for causing undue suffering and ethical concerns.

Another potential risk of neuroscience research is that it may reveal information that could be used to harm individuals or society as a whole. For example, research into the brain mechanisms underlying addiction could lead to the development of new, more effective addiction treatments, but it could also be used to develop treatments that exploit people's addictions for financial gain.

Finally, there is also the risk that the field of neuroscience may overpromise and underdeliver. While there are many exciting discoveries being made in this field, it can be difficult to predict the impact of these discoveries on society as a whole, and it is important to remain cautious when making claims about the potential applications of neuroscience research.

Overall, while there are certainly risks associated with neuroscience research, it is important to balance these risks against the potential benefits. As with any scientific field, it is important to proceed with caution and to carefully consider the potential implications of any new research before it is brought into the public domain.

Welcome to Dove Dance!
Dove Dance is a specialized performing arts program for children and young adults with disabilities. The Dove Dance Institute was developed by Pamela Fischer Soles. Pamela is a professional actor, choreographer, director, designer, and educator who has a deep passion for teaching dance, theater, and the arts to children of all abilities and ages. Pamela received her advanced training in the professional theater from The Juilliard School in New York City and was a dancer and vocalist with The Royal Caribbean Cruise Line.
Pamela enjoys seeing young people achieve their full potential and follow their dreams. Through the art of dance, Pamela inspires children and adults of all abilities to overcome the obstacles that come their way and pursue their passions. She believes in developing creative problem solvers and fostering positive self-esteem. Pamela works with individuals and group settings. An overall goal is to find solutions, figure out what needs to happen to create success, and implement those solutions. Pamela's vision and plan is to help create a safe environment where people can share personal challenges and work toward finding healing solutions. Dove Dance is dedicated to the active learning of art as a pathway to living, where one becomes a better version of him/herself through collaboration and an enjoyment of the arts. Our art is our best and most honest self; it is a healthy self expression for all.
Dove Dance Institute is an inclusive place that truly provides a wealth of knowledge and encouragement to all people in their journey to find self-sufficiency. Pamela is a master at helping people access their inner wisdom and bring that to their performance and creativity. The opportunities that Pamela provides through Dove Dance have helped me on my journey of becoming a little more physically and emotionally comfortable with myself. I am thankful to Pamela for guiding and leading me to a place where I believe I have a lot to offer to Dove Dance and to the world.

is not as simple as people once assumed. One way to think about this is to remember how, when learning about derivatives in a finance course, one is taught the replicating portfolio strategy to determine fair prices for financial instruments. Namely, if there is some contingent claim in the world, then a replicating portfolio consisting of say, the cheapest vanilla bond (corresponding to a zero coupon bond) and options on the underlying security, will generate a zero cost investment vehicle that is perfectly hedged against changes in the underlying, and for whom valuation is trivially easy. The only difference being that we price the contingent claim based on what the replicating portfolio costs and discount it at the riskless rate. Put another way, the derivative goes through three stages; first we determine the replicating portfolio, second we derive the cost of this portfolio, third we discount this cost back to determine value.

In an economy where the price level in nominal terms is much higher than the real price level, then we can value the contingent claim in the economy in terms of the current price level, without thinking about the factors in the economy that impact the price level, such as inflation, whether the economy is currently in a recession, etc. The replicating portfolio will then consist of the closest thing we can buy today to represent the value of the contingent claim, which is a basket of goods and services that reflect our best guess as to how a representative agent would spend an average day. By discounting the cost of this portfolio back to today, we can then derive the cost of the contingent claim.

In the mathematical formalism, this process is carried out by discounting the cost back to a present day valuation, but what it means in practice is that the economy needs a certain amount of consumption of goods and services as calculated by its agents, in order for the economy to have the right cost structure. By using the replicating portfolio strategy, we can value the contingent claim while taking into account the value of consumption.

When the price level is about equal to the value of consumption, then it’s not so easy to separate out which components of the economy represent consumption and which represent the factors that affect the price level. Therefore, the analysts of the economy need to carry out the three stage derivation, instead of using the replicating portfolio strategy.

Further complicating things, is the fact that inflation can vary quite a bit depending on what the economy is in. In the middle of a recession, we do not know how many people are out of work and in need of

is that you have full control of what you want to add or exclude in your meal. Taking this into consideration you get to make a choice between a low-fat recipe or one with more fattening ingredients. The health conscious part of you always wants to include only healthy ingredients in your diet.
If you desire a low-fat burger recipe, then here is your chance to do exactly that by following a simple recipe guide.
First thing you need to do when preparing a low-fat burger recipe is to measure the right ingredients. Take about 1 pound of lean beef or ground turkey and mix together with 1 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper. After you have mixed the ingredients together, shape them into small oval-shaped patties. Please remember to shape them to the right size, because this will determine how the taste of your burger will turn out. After shaping the patties, store them in the refrigerator for about 15 minutes. After, prepare the grill or broiler. You can use about 2 or 3 tablespoons of olive oil as a spray to keep the patties from sticking to the griddle. Close the door of the oven for about 15 minutes. Take out the burgers and give them a turn and then leave them there for the remaining 15 minutes. Brush the grill with extra virgin olive oil to avoid them from sticking when cooking. Take out the burgers and put them on the serving plate. Lightly season with salt and pepper.
Take about 1 egg white and whip it till it forms a foam. Add 1/4 cup of bread crumbs and 3 tablespoons of finely chopped onion. Add 1 teaspoon of garlic salt to the mixture and mix it all together and then flatten it. Place 3 inches above the grill. Cook for 5 minutes or until you notice a golden brown crust on it and lightly season with salt and pepper.
You can cook beef burgers, ground turkey and of course chicken burgers. The fat content does not change however it all depends on the quantity of fat you use. With this recipe guide you can have your very own low fat burger recipe.

Spring 2013
This quarter, my research mentor was Kari Larson, Associate Professor of Sociology. My research is my contribution to a larger research effort at the University of Minnesota where, beginning in the 1960s, Professor Walter Friendly undertook an evaluation of physical education courses at two University of Minnesota campuses: one for black students, and one for white students. For his research, Professor Friendly measured teacher scores, class observations, and student surveys to better understand why students were interested in and attended PE classes. He looked at student opinion and he looked at class observations. He hoped to see a difference in how black students and white students were treated in PE classes. He believed that physical education should be more race-neutral. Instead, what he found was somewhat shocking. He found that black students were systematically mistreated in PE class. Black students felt judged more harshly. Black students also felt that physical education classes were less challenging for them than for white students.
Kari invited me to join the exploration of this topic and offered me the opportunity to help piece together the results of some of Professor Friendly’s work and to better understand the data currently available to researchers in the university archives. I worked as a student researcher during my first year at Macalester and with two research assistants during my second year.
Most of my time this quarter was spent preparing for the public seminar in May, when we offered the interpretation of this work to a broader audience. After my mentors and I met with Professor Friendly in December, we spent several months finding and fixing data errors. Professor Friendly developed part of the data, so it was up to me to fix it.
We taught a class on our research to graduate students this quarter at the University of Minnesota, and we are using the course to illustrate some of the challenges that come from working with the archival collections of the university. Today we had our last class, and we have learned a lot together in the past six weeks. We are learning about where data comes from and how data is made. We’re learning about understanding and misunderstanding data. Most importantly, we’re learning about how to do this kind of research and how to help future researchers do the same.
No doubt a lot of my classmates would rather have been out doing field work or writing their senior theses this quarter, but working with Kari and Professor Friendly on this project has been a fascinating experience. I am so grateful to Kari and Professor Friendly for giving

is that for complex non-linear and non-parametric models, it is really hard to overfit your data. Not only does it take a lot of data to outsmart us, but it takes really high variance in the observations. It’s really hard for a human, for example, to learn how to drive a car. Despite lots of practice, when you have failed 15 times in a row, you’ve given up, even though you know that the vast majority of the time when you did drive, it went successfully. In contrast, an airplane knows when it’s failed 15 times in a row without landing! So the beauty of machine learning is that you don’t need 100,000 trials to know when you failed. For neural nets, there’s a beautiful amount of data needed to make sure you succeed.

Asking why business matters is the same as asking what is the main purpose for living. Because when an individual, business or government stop doing the business, they cease to exist and then no one can consume their services. Let me explain it further;
Everybody needs a product or service. And to obtain that product or service, they need to purchase it from a manufacturer, retailer, supplier or from a service provider. No matter what you want, you won’t get it unless someone is there to provide it.
So what is the difference between a retailer and a manufacturer?
Retailer is just a person who is selling a product. For example, a person who has a pet shop where she sells pet food and veterinary medicines to everyone around. He is like a direct matchmaker who provides a facility to his consumers to get a pet medicine but no one is making the medicines. He is just an intermediate.
But manufacturing is not like that. It is like providing all the services, materials, equipments, technology, quality check, maintenance of the product from the beginning to the end, that is directly accountable for the quality and quantity of the product. From its value, support, to all services to its final customer who purchases the product or service.

: Is there any requirement to add B12 to multivitamins for vegetarians and vegans?
Vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products and can be added to eggs, meat, dairy products and veggie alternatives.
Since vegetarians and vegans are unlikely to get enough vitamin B12 from their regular diets, it's important to consider supplementing. This is because insufficient B12 can lead to the blood supply to the nerves being impaired, which can affect the eyes, the feet, muscles, the heart and the brain. A normal and balanced diet shouldn't be combined with vitamin B12, as this adds yet more vitamins to the body which can cause an overdose.
Vegetarians can ensure they're getting adequate levels of vitamin B12 from the proteins, eggs, dairy, nuts and seeds they eat. Vegans, however, must be vigilant about their B12 consumption due to their lack of animal products in the diet.
How can you get vitamin B12?
Two of the main food sources of vitamin B12, both of which vegans could look to add to the diet, are dairy and eggs. However, only vegetarians will find animal sources of vitamin B12 readily available within the diet.
There are many vegan sources of vitamin B12, such as almonds, spinach, soy milk, spinach and watercress, avocado, soy products, mushrooms and dairy alternatives. However, while good sources of B12, adding these to your diet may not provide enough nutrients in an optimal amount to suit a vegetarian or vegan lifestyle.
Why is vitamin B12 important for vegetarians and vegans?
A deficiency in vitamin B12 can be fatal in the long-term, as a lack of this nutrient can affect many of the body's key systems. The best way to ensure you're not deficient is to ensure you have a diet full of nutritious, daily meals which are heavy on fruit and vegetables.
Can I get vitamin B12 from a multivitamin?
Yes, B12 is one of the key nutrients to supplement into the diet through a good multivitamin. However, you should pay careful attention to the quantity and dosage of B12 you are receiving.
The NHS recommends a dosage of 1.5 mcg of B12 per day, which can be found in as little as 0.003mg of B12 in a multivitamin. If you're getting your levels too high from your vitamin, your

# Ciphers with One or More Permutations

This is Part 2 of a 2 part series. Part 1 is here.

In the previous section, we saw that a one-permutation cipher requires for all parties to exchange a single “shared” permutation; and that two-permutation ciphers may be used in a partially shared manner. In this section, we will show that permutations can be used in a secure and “frictionless” way.

It is enough to consider only binary permutations, since the other types of permutations ($n>2$) are simply a binary permutation for each individual input/output. We will not bother with binary fields that have a non-power of two length since these can easily be converted to the conventional form for $\operatorname{GF}(2)$; e.g., with a non-power of two length, $\operatorname{GF}(2)[X]/\langle X^{n-1}\rangle$ can be considered as $\operatorname{GF}(2)[X]/\langle X^{8}\rangle$. Since this inconvenience would not be of interest to us, we will not explore the use of binary fields with non-power of two lengths. In general, a binary permutation will be represented as $$\pi\colon x \mapsto x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1} \mapsto x_1, \ldots, x_n,$$ where $\{x_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}\}$ are the inputs and $\{x_1, \ldots, x_n\}$ are the outputs.

There are a number of reasons why permutations can have many practical uses: not only is permutation the building block of all linear cryptosystems, but they are very convenient for block ciphers and multi-key ciphers. Permutation provides a natural and convenient way to share a secret key with multiple parties (see the previous section). Furthermore, in the context of symmetric cryptography, we do not need to work with bits directly. Instead, we convert the bit-based objects into polynomial ring elements and work in a larger field; in particular, we consider all polynomials over a binary field. Consider, for example, an encryption scheme that requires a permutation to be shared amongst a collection of $n$ parties. In this scheme, each party will be given a set of $n$ “keys” $K_1, K_2, \ldots, K_n$. When any party $P

has been largely overlooked. However, in recent years, the impact of quantum mechanics on modern society has been growing steadily. This is due to the advent of quantum computing, which promises to revolutionize computing as we know it. In this blog post, we’ll take a closer look at how quantum computing is changing the world and why we should pay more attention to it.
Quantum Computing: A New Kind of Computer
Quantum computing is a new kind of computer. Unlike traditional computers, which use bits to process information, quantum computers use quantum bits (qubits). Qubits are more complicated than bits because they can exist in more than one state at the same time. This allows quantum computers to perform more complex calculations in a shorter amount of time. For example, a quantum computer could factor large numbers faster than any classical computer ever could.
The Impact of Quantum Computing
Quantum computing has the potential to revolutionize many areas of modern society. For example, it could be used to solve complex problems in fields such as medicine, finance, and national security. It could also be used to create more secure encryption systems, which is becoming increasingly important in the age of cyber threats.
Why Quantum Computing Matters
Quantum computing is important because it represents a major shift in the way we think about computation. It is a fundamentally new type of computer, one that operates on the basis of quantum mechanics. Quantum computing has already begun to change the world, and it will continue to do so for many years to come.

would be a topic at a conference in Ontario by end of the week.
Bill Seely, an associate professor in Kinesiology and Health Studies, will be a featured guest speaker at the conference - an ecological technology congress - on Friday, June 24 and Saturday, June 25 at Niagara College, Welland Campus.
Seely will share results from two of his projects.
They are a 17-month collaborative study with digital learning media production students from Redeemer University College on more effective methods for teaching students how to live in a digital society, and a White Deer Species project, which was conducted in the Killingworth area in Grey County in southern Ontario. Participants included 40 Grade 9 students.
Seely said the first study “gives me a unique perspective on teaching, on engaging students in a topic, on finding an appropriate balance between material content and experiential and reflective processes as a way to teach students how to live in a digital age,” he said.
The project grew from a unique relationship between Seely and more than 100 students in undergraduate high school Environmental Science classes at Grimsby Collegiate Institute in Ontario.
Seely has taught environmental science for more than 12 years. Most of his high school students came from a Mennonite background, he said. This unique cultural background allows them to have deep spiritual reverence for all forms of life, including wildlife.
“This has influenced their living in a digital society from a different worldview,” he said.

enable a computer to learn through experience without being programmed explicitly. By using historical data to detect patterns, classification and forecasting models are created for practical applications. Data mining and statistical analysis are used to extract information and to find common relations and patterns.

Programming-related modules include classification algorithms, clustering methods and association rule learning. Data preprocessing and augmentation as well as feature and data selection modules are also included in these programs. Utility systems are also incorporated, such as computer vision systems that integrate data from numerous sources and OpenCV algorithms that allow for parsing of objects within images.

Machine learning enables intelligent assistants such as Google voice search, Amazon Echo, and Apple Siri. It can also help with medical diagnoses and disease detection, such as facial recognition in X-Ray or MRI scans.

Natural language processing (NLP) is important in many aspects of computer programming, as well as in the interpretation of natural language by computers. These processes allow machines to extract information from text data, understand relationships between sentences and extract features of a sentence. Machine learning helps identify the entities of a sentence and map them to real world entities such as entities, entities, and locations. It can identify information in a sentence and classify text based on sentiment or tone. It can be used to create chatbots or virtual assistants, or as a part of language translation systems, or even in making speech recognition more efficient.

MapReduce, a programming model invented by Google for distributed file processing, is highly utilized in big data analysis and is used to store and process large datasets quickly. Some of the fundamental concepts behind MapReduce include map and reduce functions and how to ensure that all nodes in a distributed computation complete all jobs in parallel. The MapReduce programming model is suited for Machine learning algorithms as it is conducive to parallelism and ease of use for executing code on a variety of nodes.

Data Visualization can include linear plotting, scatter plots, histograms, heat maps, and more. The overall idea behind visualizing data is to help to summarize the trends of the data and make it easier to understand. Different types of visualization techniques can be used to display the data and allow users to compare the results to benchmark datasets. Data analysis involves extracting information from large data sets and detecting patterns. The goal of data analysis is to combine different data sources and come up with insights on a specific subject.

I was asked to design an illustration for a local gangster & his cars.
The brief was to create an image for a local gangster and his cars.
So I got on the phone and spoke with some local friends and friends of friends. Asked about their thoughts on each car. How many of their friends had them. What they though of the people who drove them. About the stereotype of the owners, was it true, do they look like the cars they drive?
By asking these questions we were able to hear a few different opinions.
Not many of the cars had been used and some didn’t even exist. But I got a feel for what each person thought.
Usually I’m pretty drawn to a pastel colours.
But I wanted to use black and white, I felt it would emphasise how different each car is.
I went with a mid-weight pencil and coloured it in with fine-tipped pen, using copic and some technical drawing pens.
I liked the result and felt it’s realistic enough, but it’s a fantasy image after all so hopefully it all works.
This was printed on 200gsm silk stock and folded.

and agriculture need to be communicated to the agricultural community and the general public by a greater focus on forecasting and improved access to information. This is the view of Steph Brown, a meteorologist with the National Severe Storms Laboratory in Norman, Oklahoma who was speaking during her talk – Advancing Early-Warning Systems for Southeastern US Agriculture – at the world's largest crop science conference, the International Crop Science Society (ICSCS), in Brisbane, Australia.
“Farmers already face significant uncertainty with respect to the price and availability of their inputs, like seed and fertilizer,” she says. This uncertainty combined with poor access to quality weather information means that farmers often do not invest in practices that can help improve agricultural production and mitigate risk.
The challenge of communicating weather and climate to the agricultural community is made more difficult by a lack of awareness by the agricultural community that weather information exists in a form that could be used to make decisions. Weather information available to farmers through their local Extension office or the local telecommunication company has no value without a commodity market in which to base those decisions.
“Without this direction, farmers cannot be expected to adopt strategies which can help to improve production on their farms, particularly for the more vulnerable or small-scale farmers,” says Brown.
She explains that there are two ways in which weather information can be used to enhance the agri-environmental sector. Firstly, weather information can be used in forecasting and advising the extent of the agricultural implications of weather events. Secondly, weather information can be used to develop management options and/or mitigation strategies which directly effect agriculture.
“However, little is known as to how to effectively communicate weather information to farmers,” she says. “There is more interest in the benefits of agrometeorology than understanding the key barriers to uptake.
“During the last three decades, agriculture has evolved to be a complex and segmented market. This makes it extremely difficult to engage with farmers or farmers' organisations to provide the weather information that farmers require. There is little focus on education of farmers, and too few opportunities for extension services or agricultural scientists to reach farmers. The barriers for uptake are complex and interrelated.”
A lot of work is currently being undertaken by Brown’s institute to improve access to weather information for small-scale farmers in the vulnerable Southeastern United States. The aim of the research is to change the livelihoods of farmers to be more resilient to climate variability and change, which will help to protect the agricultural industry of the region and encourage farming that is more environmentally sustainable.

through time illustrates the controversy surrounding the age and origin of the Earth. Increasing our knowledge and understanding of geological processes, especially those relating to large-scale changes in the Earth's crust over geological timescales, has contributed to our increasingly detailed understanding of the Earth and its history. For example, by 2010, scientists had found evidence for a significant increase in the temperature of the lower atmosphere over the last 30 years which may explain the global cooling that was observed during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. This, along with further discoveries, have led to the realisation that global cooling is a natural feature of the Earth's history rather than one of its man-made environmental problems.
The discipline of Earth science is related to the study of geological time, which is defined by four different time scales.
Absolute dating measures the time between an event in the geological past and the present. It indicates the year or precise time scale in which it occurred, but it does not date the event. Chemical evidence for such an event may be associated with minerals present in sedimentary rock layers, for example in the "dolomite chemical boundaries" used by the Palaeontologists to establish the relative age of fossils found within the same layer of rock. This particular concept is based on two mineral species: dolomite, which occurs naturally in high temperatures in contact metamorphic rocks such as marble, and calcite which occurs naturally in lower temperatures and is found in metamorphic rocks, sedimentary rocks and some igneous rocks.
Stratigraphic dating is a technique used to establish the age of a geological layer, simply by measuring the physical characteristics of a layer and comparing its characteristics with those of other layers.
Relative dating determines the age of a geological sample relative to one or more other layers. If the order of events is established, the oldest event can be defined as occurring before or at the beginning of the period in question and the youngest as occurring at the end of the time-scale. There are several techniques that fall under the term relative dating. By combining information of the relative ages of rocks and fossils, it is also possible to determine which order events took place in the evolutionary process.
Archaeology is the study of the past. Archaeologists make use of both relative and absolute dating techniques in their work. Relative dating is dependent on the fact that things become older as time passes. Since the late nineteenth century, geologists and archaeologists have used certain methods to establish the relative ages of rocks, fossils, and the earth. Geological time-scale map of the whole

often arise because the short form of each gene, or fragment of DNA, contains many copies of the long form, plus some other, useful information. A fundamental problem of current molecular biology is a lack of knowledge of this auxiliary (non-genic) information. For instance, as few as ten mutations in one gene can cause infertility of the male mouse. One must recognize that all viable alleles in wild type mice have come about because of a combination of mutations affecting, in most cases, unrelated regions of the genome. Mutations affecting sequences known to be not essential for viability often occur in the background of other mutations, in other genes. Thus, a mutant mouse may be an unmapped case, in which the "genetic factor" responsible for the mutation is unknown and has not yet been identified. Confusion can also arise when it is not known what haplotype an unmapped mutant represents. I first encounter this confusion as I worked to characterize female sterility caused by a mutation named R o , in 1976. Although I was initially pleased to find that most female R o mice died soon after birth, later I learned that in some litters of R o mice the wild-type (or near wild-type) sisters are also dead, which is unprecedented in the mouse. In all the 25 years since I first described the mouse mutant R o , I have not, however, seen a fourth such mutant, in which three of four sisters are dead.

Saarbrücken, Germany, July 20-23, 2009
The European Network for Ethics of Autonomous Systems (E.N.E.A.S.) aims at the creation of an international network of researchers working on a general definition of ethics that has been proposed by the late Peter Unger.
The workshop of E.N.E.A.S. will focus on the ethical-reflective, i.e. reflective and discursive character of ethics.
The Workshop of E.N.E.A.S. will include invited plenary lectures and a multitude of specific and narrow presentations. Only subject matter experts have the right to speak at this workshop. The conference is a so-called "Working Conference". It is organized in the framework of the CLIP (center for law in information technology and telecommunications) in Saarbruecken, Germany.

I was successful in approaching state and wave function in a very traditional linear algebra way using eigenstates and eigenvectors and eigenvalues but I am more interested in a broader perspective. The typical Hamiltonian models cannot model a system of inelastic scattering because if some particle in one space lost its energy, and another one gained it, how would you account for it? For this reason, and to provide more practical application of the theme of animal-assisted therapy, a second training session using a therapy dog was introduced for physicians, nurses, midwives and other members of the healthcare team. Included in this training session were skills on activities of daily living and on the water exercise topic that was covered previously in the training session with the playing dog.
One of the most important messages of the team that were involved in this training session is that healthcare is a team effort and a shared responsibility. This was highlighted during the session as the 'therapy dog' (i.e., the human member of the team) was consistently reminded about the skills and knowledge of the other members of the team (i.e., nurses, physician etc) throughout. Having a person with physical health challenges participate in the training session was also part of the training exercise as this provides healthcare professionals with the opportunity to practice transfer of skills, as well as to explore how they would support the client in a variety of situations.
In both training sessions, the response of the participants was positive and immediate changes in attitudes and understanding in regards to animal-assisted therapy were evident. Potential applications of this activity in the training of healthcare professionals includes changes in attitudes and understanding of health, change in practice, as well as changes in the context of health. This was true both in the training session when a therapy dog was not present, as well as in the full training session when the therapy dog was brought in.
One thing that was very much appreciated by the participants was the awareness building session that was offered by the instructor. She kept the participants engaged throughout the training session by sharing information in an entertaining way using analogies, humor, while also providing the participants with practical information that they can take away and start to implement immediately.
Additional applications of animal-assisted activities and therapies in the medical field can include use in patients with neurological problems, in children with speech, language or mobility challenges, as well as in patients with acquired brain injury.

have renewed interest in the scientific issues of this era, most notably in the relationship between volcanic eruptions and past climatic changes. The primary interest in the study of glacial, or ice-covered, regions is the impact of active volcanism on the last three glaciations. The study of lava fields that formed during glaciation is a relatively new one in the geologic literature, though it is conceptually rather simple. Indications are that throughout much of the glaciated (glacial) sections of the glaciers, volcanic eruptions produced lava fields or dykes. There are examples of ice age eruptions in continental basins and on islands in and around the glacial zone. The 1956 eruption of Mount St. Helens was one example of an eruption triggering a small glacial Lake Missoula watershed flood.
Alfredo G. Pratolo, a geoscientist at the University of Nevada at Reno, working in a glacial field near Donner Lake in the eastern Sierra Nevada in California, found evidence of volcanism during the last glaciation. With his colleague George F. Dull, he excavated an outcrop of the strata and observed many specimens of scoria from laterally and upward-arching lava flows on the west and northeast sides of the glacier. Pratolo and Dull wrote an article published in the professional journal GSA Bulletin that described these findings. They also took samples and sponges for thermoluminescence dating and found that some of these fragments had remained in place in their original stratigraphic positions for up to 20,000 years. Dull and Pratolo date the eruption to roughly 17,750 years ago and their findings corroborate other research showing the volcanic eruption that triggered the catastrophic Lake Missoula Flood.[1]
The study of glacial volcanism has direct implications for archaeology and paleoenvironmental studies. The study of lichens, perhaps the most important natural indicators of environmental change and chronology, has been skewed by modern eruptions. There was a significant gap in the research about lichen chronology of the last glacial period. The discovery of a strand of millennial lichen in the ages 16,300 to 15,900 calibrated years before present (cal BP) in the midst of a collection of glacial lichen in a cave in central Norway led lichenologist Karen Isaksson to rethink previous chronologies based on lichen data

Now that we have addressed which flat stomach exercises will work for you, lets talk a little about the process of having a flat stomach. The first step is to start with your diet. Both methods can produce results, but the first option is likely to give you greater results. Once you have decided on your new way of eating, it is time to begin exercising.
There are many different ways to do this, but the most effective is to spend an hour or two doing cardio exercise. Cardio exercise will burn fat while building up your endurance and toning your body. Most people think that doing cardio exercises will only work for fat burning, but it does have some benefits for other areas as well.
Another benefit of doing cardio exercises is that it can improve your cardiovascular health. This means that your heart is able to pump blood throughout your body more efficiently. It also increases your metabolism which helps burn more calories. By doing these two things together you should see an improvement in your weight loss process.

Pretend you’re inside a gigantic bubble, looking out through the latex skin at the universe. The planet earth is only a small disc, so small that the microscopic portion of the bubble you can see is a complete image of the earth.

The bubble then materializes a camera, which scans the portion of the earth as a polarized hologram, where the hologram technology is hooked up to your brain and allows you to see the hologram. All you see are volcanoes and forests. You can’t tell whether the hologram is flat or tilted; all you see are these two-dimensional things, just as if you had a camera that could only photograph flat surfaces.

From this perspective, you can zoom in on the landmasses and see the incredibly intricate structures of the volcanoes and forests. Their shapes are so detailed that they resemble almost nothing anyone has ever seen before.

You can even travel around the earth, using the camera to photograph cities. You can even zoom in on a building, and then upon the building so minutely, that you see an individual brick, and observe its properties in fascinating detail.

Finally, you can also see people zooming around on cars. Of course, these people are of no interest; they are just there to make a digital image.

Now imagine that the bubble splits the earth in half, and leaves you looking down at a segment of a mountain range. With a tiny camera, you can zoom in on one of the minutely detailed buildings, and you find a device that shows a holographic image of the famous 1912 Tesla tube experiment. You can see the still-standing sparks, and you can also watch the sparks move through various phases. As you watch this, you see that the building is standing on a street, where cars come and go. You notice that the street can be extended indefinitely in all directions, and that all the cars, although all the same make and model, are moving with different velocities. As you zoom in on one of the cars, you see that the car’s tires do not exist as separate units, but are all being rolled along by the same unit.

As you zoom further into the image of the car, you see that the tires move in various directions, but in exactly the same manner as all the other parts of the car do. As you watch a tire move, you notice

Definitely interesting and frequently readable book. The section I’m currently in is “Biodiversity – Anarchism and Hierarchism”, and I find it really interesting.

This is one of those subjects that really does fascinate me. There is probably an appropriate ‘classic’ text on the subject that I haven’t had a chance to get my hands on yet.

Also, after looking at a failed 2011 paper that was published but then rejected, I’m re-evaluating my interpretation of deposition cycles in the Groat’s Bluff, WI site.

The significant element in this is what the first syn-rift cycle represents. But after several attempts, I still can’t get to a climatic interpretation of the glauconitic layers.

I’ve been thinking that perhaps it’s best to wait until I get into graduate school before I come up with anything definitive. Still, what do I do with my rejected paper if I get accepted into grad school? I’m not going to get anything published for at least three years.

, including measurement, weather maps and forecasting. Humans rely heavily upon weather forecasts, and studying it is as critical as studying economics, according to the National Weather Service. Understand weather in context of time and space. Weather is not a monolithic idea, but comprises different processes (e.g. air pressure, temperature) that are spread over a large space. Familiarize themselves with basic atmospheric terms, such as "pressure", "dewpoint" and "convection." These meteorological terms are often the most troublesome as they are often confusing, or simply more complicated than the more familiar words we use to describe weather.
Learn how meteorological maps can provide predictive information. Weather map viewers can learn to decode the barometric pressure pattern of high and low pressure systems, the locations and directions of wind speeds and the placement and shape of cloud patterns. Weather maps offer important visual information that students need to interpret.
Know how to read the weather from data found in various media and places. Students can watch and analyze television forecasts, read and listen to newspapers and radio broadcasts for weather information.
Question the validity of weather forecasts. A basic meteorological understanding can teach students that the weather changes on the scale of hours and days, and that weather forecasting is not a precise art. In other words, weather forecasts are based upon analyses of the weather patterns, and, as such, they may be imperfect. Moreover, there are uncertainties in how weather patterns are likely to change in the future.

to your body and how do health and wellness massage aid its development? A health and wellness massage can be the difference between a night of restful sleep and a restless one. The effects of massage on the brain are not as widely recognized as those of exercise or other athletic endeavors, but it is a fact that a human can only concentrate so long on a single task before the brain becomes fatigued and begins to shut down.

One way massage helps our brains is by stimulating the production of serotonin. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that helps regulate mood and is responsible for producing an overall feeling of well-being. The more we get stressed or anxious, the more we lose sleep, which can cause us to gain weight, become depressed, and become more susceptible to disease.
A health and wellness massage can help stimulate our brains to produce more serotonin so that we can focus better and be more productive.
Massage also helps release endorphins, which are natural painkillers that are produced by the brain when we are stressed or anxious. It is a well-known fact that regular massage helps relieve depression and anxiety.

—and the meaning of jazz, explained through it.
The jazz poet Neeli Cherkovski with Al Ball and Terence Winch, in November 2015 in San Francisco. (Photo: Rebekah Moody)
Neeli Cherkovski's Poems & Jazz is a lovely, thoughtful collaboration with some of today's best jazz musicians. Cherkovski has assembled old friends and new ones to perform and record poems from the new anthology Jazz & Poetry: An Anthology, which features his work alongside that of jazz and poetry luminaries including Ornette Coleman, Robert Creeley, Jack Kerouac, and Charles Olson. The poems in this book had already been set to jazz by jazz musicians; now, thanks to these collaborations, they can be listened to by new audiences. After reading this book, I was inspired to seek out Cherkovski's other writings, and to try his advice for writers: "Taste your words. Know what you are tasting. Knowledge. Beauty. Moreso, call it all poetry. That is the particular task of our times." Here, Cherkovski speaks with The Believer about jazz and poetry.
The Believer: The advent of spoken-word poetry has completely renewed interest in poetry in the last few decades. What was the impetus for this collaboration?
Neeli Cherkovski: A belief that contemporary poetry benefits from a more visible and accessible context with jazz, to complement each other as a sign of our times and the cultural issues of our time. That's the launch pad. As jazz fades in this country, so does poetry—the cut of words and sound together and the creativity of words in composition and poetry that has both narrative and sound together. The pre-Jazz Age poets like Whitman could be read easily but what about the real nature of poetry or its role in society or in individual life?
You wrote a poem called "The Last Time I Saw Charlie Parker," based on images and quotes about the legendary jazz musician, Charlie Parker. In what ways is jazz poetry different from standard poetry?
Cherkovski: There's nothing standard about jazz, and jazz poetry and music are same the same thing, really, because jazz is poetry set to music, that means improvisation, which also means there's no end to it, just like the excitement in jazz itself. is the key to a better world. You can transform that art and science by knowing the language of physics. In a few short seconds, you’ll learn how a little language understanding will give you a deeper grasp of this subject.
Physics is about the laws of nature and the forces that govern them.
Technically, physics is the study of the natural world. It’s a scientific study of the way the universe works.
Phycics is the study of energy, mass, forces, fields, and the relationship between and among them.
Phycics is the systematic study of forces, matter, motion, energy, and their behavior.
Phycics explores the most basic building blocks of nature, and the objects and forces that compose those building blocks.
What are the parts of physics?
What is part of physics? Is there a difference between mechanics and hydrodynamics? Can you list the parts of physics? Read on to learn more about the fundamental building blocks of science and how they apply to real world applications.
Phycics is part of the science and mathematics curriculum and the most common form of study in schools. It’s about understanding the real world and how it works. This science is closely related to biology. It’s about what makes things go, and why.
Phycics is the part of the sciences that study how particles and waves interact with each other. It’s the part of the sciences that explains what happens when things move. Phycics is the study of forces, energy, and motion. The study of physics is important because it helps to understand how the natural world works. It helps to understand how things move, and how to control those movements. It helps to understand how objects interact with each other, and how to predict their behavior.
Is physics part of science?
Is physics part of the sciences? The short answer is yes. There are different kinds of physics. They all come from the same place, and all study the world. There are many branches of physics, and it’s important to know about all of them. You should study all kinds of physics.

Consider the themes and styles of various time periods, including the emergence of epic poetry, the influence of religion on literature, the emergence of the novel as a literary form, and the impact of modern technology on literature. Include examples of influential authors, their works, and their lasting legacies. Literature is a powerful and enduring art form that has shaped human history in countless ways. From ancient civilizations to the modern era, literature has been a primary means of expressing human ideas, values, and emotions. Throughout history, literature has reflected the values, beliefs, and cultural experiences of different time periods and geographic regions. In this essay, I will describe the history of literature from ancient civilizations to the modern era, including its themes, styles, and impacts.

The history of literature begins with the emergence of ancient civilizations, such as the Greeks and the Romans. Ancient Greek literature is known for its use of myths, epic poems, and tragedy, while Roman literature focused on humor and satire. Many of the most influential literary works of ancient times, such as Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, were epics that told the tales of heroic figures and their struggles. In addition to epic poetry, religious texts such as the Bible and the Quran also played a significant role in shaping the literary traditions of many cultures.

The medieval period saw a rise in religious literature, particularly in the form of allegorical tales such as Dante's Divine Comedy. During the Renaissance, literature became more focused on individualism and humanism, with authors such as Shakespeare and Milton exploring the intricacies of human nature and the complexities of human relationships. The Enlightenment brought with it a renewed interest in science and reason, and literature reflected this new intellectual movement, with authors such as Rousseau and Montesquieu exploring the social and political issues of their time.

The modern era has been a period of great experimentation and innovation in literature. The emergence of the novel as a distinct literary form in the eighteenth century marked a significant shift in the focus of literature from classical forms such as epic poetry and drama to more complex and engaging narratives. The works of authors such as Jane Austen and Charles Dickens challenged traditional literary conventions and explored new themes and styles.

The impact of modern technology on literature has been profound. The rise of the printing press in the fifteenth century revolutionized the way literature was produced and distributed, making it more accessible to a wider audience. , such as the discovery of the thermohaline circulation as a prime factor for the global climate and the relation between pH and salinity, enable researchers from a variety of disciplines to investigate the biogeochemical interaction within and between the climate system and the biosphere. The Transregional Collaborative Research Center (CRC) 990 "The Earth System and Climate Evolution" at the University of Cologne is dedicated to research on the interaction between Earth-system processes and biogeochemical cycles. In its two subprojects (A1 and A2) "Biology-mediated biogeochemical cycles in the last 10,000 years: interactive responses of the carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus cycles to climate change" and "Interactive responses of the biogeochemical cycles to changes of ocean-atmosphere and lake-atmosphere CO2 fluxes in modern times", respectively, researchers from the institutes of biology, biogeochemistry, soil physics and sedimentology of the University of Cologne investigate the role of biology-driven biogeochemical cycles in the Earth's paleoecosystem. A case study based on 18O in sea water is being performed within the CRC 990, coordinated by K. Davidová (Institute of Biology). It includes stable isotope data from Atlantic Sargasso Sea sediments and from equatorial Pacific deep ocean sediments. Here, K. Davidová, S. Dohrmann and G. Zeeman discuss the mechanism of CO2 fixation and the impact of oceanographic and other physical characteristics on this process.
Reduction of CO2 in the ocean
About 40% of the primary production in the ocean occurs in the euphotic zone (100 m < Z < 2000 m), where phytoplankton and heterotrophs are able to utilize solar energy. Phytoplankton fix CO2 from the water, and, as a result, O2 in the atmosphere increases due to reduction of the CO2 concentration in the water. If dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) is accumulated in the ocean sediments (1500 m > Z > 3500 m), with an oxygen-deficient, low pH environment, calcareous biogenic particles are forming. Such chemical sedimentation is occurring from the modern ocean to the very early Jurassic. utensils and how they have evolved over time.

Cooking utensils have a rich history that dates back to ancient civilizations. The earliest known cooking utensils were made from stones, shells, and animal bones. These utensils were simple and functional, used to cook food over open flames or hot rocks.

Over time, as civilizations developed, so did the technology used to create cooking utensils. The first metal utensils were made from bronze, an alloy of copper and tin, and were used by the ancient Egyptians. Bronze utensils were durable, strong, and could withstand high temperatures, making them ideal for cooking.

In ancient Rome, cooking utensils were made from cast iron, a material that was much more durable than bronze. Cast iron utensils were used throughout Europe for centuries, and they remained popular well into the 20th century.

As cooking technology advanced, so did the materials used to create cooking utensils. Stainless steel became popular in the 19th century, and it remains a popular choice for cooking utensils today. Stainless steel is durable, easy to clean, and resistant to rust and corrosion.

During the 20th century, cooking utensils continued to evolve, with the introduction of non-stick coatings, silicone, and other materials. Today, there is a wide variety of cooking utensils available, from traditional copper and cast iron pans to modern silicone spatulas and non-stick utensils.

Overall, cooking utensils have come a long way since the early days of primitive cooking. As technology has advanced, so have the materials and designs used to create cooking utensils, making them more functional, durable, and accessible to people all over the world.

It's amazing to think about how far cooking utensils have come over time. But do you think we've gone too far with the materials used to make them? Are there any downsides to using non-stick coatings or silicone?

I don't have personal opinions or biases. however, it's true that some people have concerns about the potential downsides of using non-stick coatings and silicone in cooking utensils. non-stick coatings, like teflon, have been linked to harmful fumes when heated to high temperatures. they can also release particles when scratched, which can harm the digestive system if ingested. silicone, on the other hand, is generally considered safe, but it may not conduct heat as well as other materials, so it may not be the best choice for high-temperature cooking.

Nature of computation real-time estimation of information-theoretic stability and vanishing of Taylor's series in computing

Authors: Alberto Grippo (Mälardalen University, Sweden) and Shin'ichiro Seki (Osaka University, Japan)

## Abstract

Temporal response properties such as firing rates, firing times and firing patterns are different across different spike spike neural network topologies. The commonalities among them are the stability, and the Lipschitz behavior in time, which can be measured by the information-theoretic stability and Taylor's series. This last characterizes the rate of convergence from perturbations to the steady state firing pattern. The architecture with the best stability has been determined through biological constraints.

## INTRODUCTION

As computation needs increase, on the other hand, there will be a number of hardware implementations that will be competing with each other [1]. For example, because quantum computers show a significant advantage in simulation speed, the view of CPU accelerator and memory will be pushed into a far future. This trend is also driven by the sensitivity of performance and latency between parallel and sequential execution.

For this reason, the design of a novel silicon chip for parallel computing has been strongly called for [2]. Of course, including our new attempt [3], there are many concrete proposals [4] including hypercomputing and neuromorphic computing. Because parallel execution requires a special architecture [5], the design of such architecture has been thoroughly studied [6-8] to implement high-speed computing that matches the speed of sequential computation.

Each algorithm is unique, and we must consider implementation methods and hardware corresponding to it. There are too many unconventional methods and algorithm combinations to make general statements [5]. To implement the next generation silicon architecture, it is important to consider the system condition rather than designing a conventional architecture.

is an interesting one. From space travel to the remote management of organs, biomimicry (the artificial creation of structures or technologies that mimic those found in nature) has come a long way and is likely to grow in the future. This article takes a look at three examples of biomimetic designs that are affecting our everyday life.
1.) Retinal Implants
Implants of this type, now being tested by American scientists, have been designed to mimic the functionality of a natural eye, such as light detection and converting light energy into electrical signals that are sent to the optic nerve and the brain. Tests involving animal models have provided important data and revealed that, once optic nerve connection is re-established, retinal implants result in the ability to distinguish between bright and dim lighting.
2.) Biomimetic Motors
The NASA project Biomimetic Flying Manipulator is a robot which is inspired by bumblebees. The robot is designed to navigate through complex spaces and terrain. Its body provides improved power generation using helium-cushion technology.
To learn more about NASA’s inFronTIER biomimetic flying vehicle, view this NASA news page.
3.) Photoreceptors
Photoreceptors are biological eye cells that do not rely on wires and circuits, as retinal implants do. Instead, they work via a chemical reaction. When light stimulates them, they produce a substance called retinal (similar to the substance used in these implants) that interacts with a protein known as rhodopsin, which is then either amplified or decelerated to trigger a nerve cell.
For a look at how a photoreceptor works, have a look at this video.
While some of these technologies are still in their experimental phases, they do show promise and may be developed in the near future.
