The range of symptoms can seem quite bizarre and the variety of diagnosis is daunting. Unfortunately, there is no comprehensive check list of diagnoses for a diagnosis of hysteria.
And it certainly is an umbrella diagnosis that includes really broad and quite varied symptoms. So to a degree, the answer will be very dependent upon what the symptoms are, and the ability of a given psychiatrist or a given doctor or therapist to glean together relevant symptoms and put them in context to make a diagnosis. So I think it will definitely vary.
Can you elaborate on the broader possible symptomatology of hysteria?
Hyperactivity is a particularly common one. It tends to involve excessive bodily movement. But you can combine that with other symptoms as well. So for example, in an hysterical conversion disorder where there is movement, there are also loss of sensation. The loss of sensation tends to be one way. So the loss of sensation occurs more in the upper body than the lower body. And often it's a right side or left side loss. So it tends to be upper limb then lower limb and right and left rather than simultaneous loss. So if a person has a loss of sensation on one side, it tends to be affected. And similarly, if they have a movement, it tends to be over the same side.
So a person might have a movement that's strange or unusual or bizarre, or they might move in a way that would seem illogical and otherwise still be a bit confused about why the feeling was not being transmitted to the limbs and the person might have hyperactivity. So that it's much more difficult for you to be sure about what is the cause of the problem rather than someone with a hitherto obvious birth defect that's easily measurable like a spinal misalignment that's caused by the way the birth was conducted. But in cases where it's a specific disorder, there are very definite physical or chemical causes for the disturbances in their bodily function.
Sure, are there any medications that would serve to reduce or eliminate some symptoms?
Maybe. You should see if they have any relationship to certain medications. Many medications can cause tremors or hyperactivity, for example, neuroleptics like Risperidone or Haloperidol. Some medications can cause hyperactivity or tremors or in hyperactivity of pupils. So that's one possibility. It would be, I think, helpful in working out a diagnosis to see whether there's any relationship with a medication that was taken. If it is a steady state flow, we can pull an $U$ and $V$ through the left hand side, which will give a streamline (and hence single point stream function and velocity vectors). This gives

that exploit the BitTorrent protocol to encode and distribute stolen or pirated copyrighted content are an emerging threat to video copyright holders. In response, several approaches using the BitTorrent metadata to identify such works have been developed. In this paper, we present BitTtorrent, a model for tracking the BitTorrent-based distribution of a BitTorrent file across a peer-to-peer network. BitTtorrent is developed as a client and server side application and continuously tracks downloads from the network using a complex security model that fuses multiple communications mechanisms. has been on the fore of studies of technologies for over two decades. However, some new research questions have appeared in the literature that need further discussion. In this article, we will elaborate on these questions, based on our review of the literature. The three major research questions are: (i) How do technological resources influence the interaction between physics and technology? (ii) Does direct source-destination physical and technological resources determine user outcomes? (iii) Do direct and indirect source-destination physical and technological resources determine user outcomes? We found, based on our survey of the literature, that the purposeful use of some particular elements of the physical environment is not sufficient for success in user outcomes. More importantly, access to only some elements of the physical environment (or technologies) may not be sufficient to get good user outcomes. Our review, therefore, shows that one should use different resource mix in the design process if one is looking for specific user outcomes. To date, resources at the design stage have been used in isolation from one another. This, however, can create two problems: (i) One may miss inappropriately generated energy in one resource use that can cause environmental problems. (ii) One can lose out on certain social and ecological benefits that the interaction between various resource uses may lead to. Therefore, before design, we need to be aware of the consequences of resource co-allocation and its impact on human behaviour and ecosystems.
Khadempour, R., Griffiths, J. and Singh, H. (2015) ‘Possible research questions in the interaction between physics and technology’, Current Science, 108(6), pp. 1015–1026.

Chemistry is one of the most important sciences in modern society. From its discovery in the 18th century, chemistry has led to major breakthroughs and advancements in fields such as medicine, energy, and environmental protection.
 
Chemistry plays a crucial role in medicine. It is responsible for the development of new drugs and treatments. Some of the most important medicines in modern medicine, such as antibiotics and vaccines, were developed using chemical principles. Chemistry is also essential in understanding the human body’s functions, and in designing new medications that can target specific organs or systems.
 
Another field where chemistry plays a vital role is energy production. The world’s energy needs are rapidly growing, and there is a need to develop new and sustainable sources of energy. Chemistry plays a key role in this, as it enables the production of clean energy sources like solar, wind, and hydroelectric power. In addition, it helps in designing renewable materials such as biofuels, and better batteries, making it easier to store renewable energy.
 
Chemistry is also essential in the field of environmental protection. It provides the knowledge and tools necessary to identify and solve environmental problems. Chemists are involved in developing new technologies that reduce pollution and waste, and also in creating sustainable and eco-friendly products.
 
In conclusion, chemistry is a critical science that has contributed to many important achievements in modern society. Its contributions span across various fields including medicine, energy, and environmental protection. Without chemistry, many of the modern advancements that we take for granted would not exist.

I’m always surprised by what people would think that Literature was.
A lot of people think that literature is all about romance. Books like Twilight (gag), Nicholas Sparks, and Fifty Shades of Grey. But literature is more than that. It’s about so much more. And the best way to show that is to not only cite examples of people who write some of the greatest books out there, but also people who actually inspire me as a person, and drive me to want to write.
About a year ago, I wrote a post about Jennifer Niven, who really inspired me because she writes a book that I would actually consider reading! She inspired me to realize that writing a book doesn’t only need to be about love, because that is actually not something that everyone deals with. I’d love to meet her and say what an inspiration she is.
But aside from her, I’ve also met or actually seen in person, or met through conventions and Meetups, people who are just like me, who deal with real life things, like other people deal with love, but who have come up with creative ways of telling their story, and showing just how deep their emotions go. In fact, they also wrote characters who are nothing like what people would expect a shy author to write – creepy characters, gothic characters, characters that are beautiful but are deeply flawed, and those that have a hidden inner darkness, just like us writers do. Everything in writing needs to be creative, or the work will be boring, stale, and at times, is downright boring!
Let’s look at a few examples. I’ll refer to the characters in as “The Gentleman,” “The Muse,” “The Expert,” and “The Hero.” These are NOT my characters, obviously, but they are mine to tell because I am not showing them as they are, but rather how they can be good writers, and what their real personalities really are.
First is The Muse, and this person doesn’t have the typical personality that a lot of readers are looking for. In fact, I would argue that she doesn’t look that good and she doesn’t do all the things that are usually associated with a typical ‘man’ in popular culture. She uses the stereotypical ‘madonna/whore’ approach, trying to showcase this internal conflict within, while using power tactics. But underneath it all, is an artist, and a hardened soul who really does have a lot of literary talent. She acts like a man, so that she

has declined significantly in recent times, with many artists feeling alienated by the lack of interest in their work. However, the act of creating art still has great power and can be used to convey important messages and convey emotions. In this sense, artists continue to hold the power to transform the world and make a positive impact. What are your thoughts on this topic? Do you believe that art still holds a significant cultural significance or is it becoming obsolete in today's society? Can you give some concrete examples of how art has been used to convey powerful messages or emotions in the past? Yes, I do believe that art still holds significant cultural significance in today's society. While it is true that there may be a lack of interest in some forms of art, there are still many artists out there who are creating works that are both thought-provoking and meaningful. Additionally, art has a way of transcending time and place, which means that even if it is not popular or widely appreciated in a particular moment in history, it can still have a profound impact on people in the future.

There are many examples of how art has been used to convey powerful messages and emotions in the past. For instance, the works of artists like Frida Kahlo, Pablo Picasso, and Vincent van Gogh often deal with themes such as love, loss, and personal struggle, and can be incredibly moving and emotional for viewers. Similarly, artists such as Banksy and Keith Haring have used their work to critique social and political issues, and to raise awareness about important causes.

Moreover, art can also be a way of preserving cultural heritage and traditions. Through the medium of painting, sculpture, photography, and other forms of art, artists can help to keep alive the stories, beliefs, and values of different communities and cultures.

Overall, I believe that art will continue to play a vital role in our cultural and social lives, and that it will continue to be a powerful tool for expressing ourselves and connecting with others.

and water resource management have led to better understanding of the critical role played by shallow groundwater-surface water interactions in surface water discharge and quality. An understanding of how aquifer-head response can control the downstream hydrological variables (discharge, suspended sediment) is important for water management, especially in Karst watersheds where Karst aquifer systems govern groundwater/surface water interactions (Gorini & Curi 2014). The flow from deep to shallow aquifer systems is regulated by the effect of rocks which both control their permeability, their distribution and their thickness. This research aims to examine the role of such control mechanisms on the response of the groundwater head to groundwater withdrawals. This is done through a one-year case study in the context of the Alban Lake catchment in northern Italy. An improved version of the semi-analytical fuzzy package is introduced in a box model composed of two aquifers linked by a river through shallow, fractured porous rocks. The one-year, monthly groundwater head simulations cover the altimetric movement of surface water in the lake. The box model reproduces very well the observed behavior of both the lake water level and the groundwater head, thus demonstrating the representativeness of the boundaries of the catchment boundaries, i.e. their outline, altitude, slopes. The simulation was further validated using borehole observations. This work clearly demonstrates the crucial effect of control mechanisms on the interplay of groundwater with surface water. It implies a review of current approaches used for predicting surface water response to groundwater withdrawal and also of their use for optimization of surface water management by minimizing impacts on downstream ecosystems, groundwater recharge, aquifer sensitivity, etc.
There are many areas of the world where tectonically active volcanic systems intersect with karst and phreatic aquifers. These interacting water systems, referred to as equilibrums, are subject to a wide variety of phenomena, including but not limited to hydrothermal convection and changes in hydrothermal and chemical transport with temperature. The relationship between temperature and hydrothermal and chemical transport depends on a number of factors including system characteristics (such as depth, recharge, and porosity), as well as those of the local system in which it resides. This study analyzes a complex system that includes karst, phreatic, and hydrothermal flow occurring at various depths in the 3-D solution of the Geoscience Australia Fluids Inversion Program (GA-FIP) project, which was completed in late 2010.

: It was a warm spring morning and Angela was walking in the park with her favorite toy, a shiny red ball. As she walked along the path, the ball rolled out of her hand and bounced off a bench. Suddenly, a group of boys appeared, picking up the ball and throwing it around. Angela was upset, but then she had an idea.

She ran to a nearby tree and used it to climb up. The boys were surprised to see a little girl climbing a tree, but they quickly realized that she was not leaving without her ball. Angela sat on a high branch, looking down at the boys who were now trying to reach her.

She shouted to them that she would throw the ball down if they could reach it. The boys scrambled to grab it, but it was too high for them to reach. Angela laughed and smiled, knowing that she had won.

As the boys walked away, Angela jumped down from the tree and picked up her ball. She was proud of herself for standing up for her toy and showing the boys that she was not afraid of them.

From that day on, Angela and her ball became known as the brave little girl and her shiny red ball. People would come to the park just to see her play, and her ball became a symbol of courage and determination. Angela never let anyone take her ball away again, and she lived happily ever after.

Angela left a lasting impression on everyone in the park, and her story was passed down from generation to generation. From then on, every time someone saw a red ball bouncing around, they would remember the brave little girl who stood up for herself and showed that anyone can be brave when they are passionate about something.

For this presentation, I would like to begin with a glance of the rural Indian landscape. India is a country with the highest population. How India develops is important for the rest of the world. It is the largest producer and exporter of fruits and vegetables in the world. India contributes to 10% of the world's livestock output. India also has 40% of Asia's forest area, though it consumes 20% of world's wood, it is a forest of savannas, grasslands, shrublands, dry deciduous forests, moist deciduous forests, and wetlands. The position of India in developing green technology is also increasing with each passing year. Even though it is self-sufficient in agricultural production, it is also a major net importer of agricultural products. Even though India's food requirement is met by agriculture, its energy needs are met by petroleum and natural gas as well as by renewable energy. At present the energy requirements are met mostly by fossil fuels, but efforts are now being made to shift India to renewable energy.
As we know that India is the most populated country in the world. It has a large population and it is growing every year. It has population of 1.25 billion approximately. One of the major issues of India is the shortage of food, the problems of hunger and malnutrition. So I have chosen Indian children as my case study. I began to think about how these children learn to eat. It turns out children in India have a special food culture they grow up eating their basic diets. Indian children learn to eat and develop social attitudes and beliefs about food. This refers to their acceptance or rejection of food (but not their willingness or ability to eat food). The perception that food can or cannot be eaten has social, family, cultural, and religious associations. These basic food habits form the foundation of a healthy eating pattern in the

reveals the multiple pathways to building an ethical framework for AI and its deployment in emerging technologies.
AI has increasingly become a part of our daily lives, influencing consumer shopping experiences, public policy, product supply and distribution, and everyday communications. It is a highly refined field that has been studied and practiced for decades by computing scientists, software engineers, mathematicians, engineers, and researchers. Organizations are now putting increasing investment and more intense effort into AI, and this phenomenon is becoming a pervasive trend as the technology becomes more sophisticated and the field is more established. The potential positive impact of AI on society and the economy, however, is an important consideration. The findings of a 2016 MIT Sloan Management Review (MIT SMR) and Boston Consulting Group (BCG) study reveal that the vast majority of executives (61 percent) believe that AI is an opportunity to significantly transform their businesses. However, there is also a strong interest in AI's impact on the future of employment; a striking 57 percent of executives expect that over 20 percent of their workforce will be out of a job in the next five years due to AI.
The "Ethical Framework for AI: Aligning AI Strategies and Policies" research highlights the importance of culture in aligning corporate strategy with ethical considerations and gives organizations and individuals a deeper understanding of AI and the key issues related to the implications of AI and its use in our society. Businesses must take a strategic approach that includes governance and policy statements that define the organization's ethical AI framework, protect proprietary intellectual property, set guidelines for the ethical use of AI, and develop response strategies to manage AI-related risks.

India
Background on CCS implementation and long-term prospects of implementation in the context of India
India’s coal-based power plant energy is affordable and presents sufficient cost savings. It provides valuable societal advantages such as energy security and timely power generation. Moreover, CCS technology is still in its infancy and can yet face some problems and challenges such as high capital costs, technical complexity, operational costs, environmental management, reliability, and challenges of long-term storage. All of this has led to current national priorities and policies considering CCS implementation as only one of the many strategies for the long-term decarbonization of India’s economy.

and its impact on literature and culture throughout history.

Poetry has a long and rich history, spanning thousands of years and numerous cultures. It has served as a means of communication, storytelling, and the expression of emotion and ideas.

The earliest recorded examples of poetry date back to the Sumerian civilization, which existed around 2700 BCE. These early poems were often hymns to gods or prayers for good harvests and dealt with themes such as love, war, and nature. In ancient Greece, poetry was a popular form of entertainment, and many of the great works of literature we know today, such as Homer's Odyssey and Iliad, were composed in verse.

During the Middle Ages, poetry became an important part of religious worship, with poems such as the Psalms and the Song of Solomon used in Christian worship services. In the Renaissance, poets like William Shakespeare and Edmund Spenser helped to revive interest in the form, introducing new themes and techniques.

In the Romantic era, poetry became more emotional and expressive, with poets like William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge emphasizing the importance of nature and the individual experience. This emphasis on personal expression continued into the modern era, with poets like T.S. Eliot and Allen Ginsberg experimenting with new forms and styles.

Poetry has had a significant impact on literature and culture throughout history. It has been used to preserve traditions and values, to comment on current events and social issues, and to express ideas and emotions in a way that is both concise and evocative.

In addition to its literary value, poetry has also had a profound impact on the development of language itself. It has helped to shape our understanding of the world and our place within it, and its influence can be seen in the use of metaphor and imagery in everyday speech and writing.

Overall, poetry has played a vital role in human culture and development, providing a means of communication and expression that is both timeless and essential.

using Swift code.
Once upon a time, there was a company that specialized in creating personalized clothing. They wanted to improve their product offerings by using machine learning to predict what designs and colors their customers would like based on their browsing and purchase history. 

The first step was to collect and organize the data. They collected data on each customer's browsing and purchase history, including items they had added to their cart but not purchased. They also collected data on the types of clothing that were currently popular and trending. 

Next, they imported this data into Swift using the Core ML framework. They used the data to train a machine learning model that could predict which designs and colors a customer would like based on their browsing and purchase history. 

Once the model was trained, they integrated it into their website. When a customer visited the site, the model analyzed their browsing and purchase history and provided personalized recommendations. For example, if a customer had recently purchased a light blue shirt, the model might recommend a navy blue blazer and khaki pants. 

The company was thrilled with the results of their machine learning project. By using machine learning to predict customer preferences, they were able to provide a more personalized shopping experience, which led to increased sales and customer satisfaction. They continued to refine their machine learning models and expand their offerings, becoming one of the most successful clothing companies in the industry.

How did the company collect and organize their data on customer browsing and purchase history?
The company collected customer data in two ways: through its website and through surveys.

On its website, customers could create an account that allowed them to save items to their cart and view past purchases. The company also collected data on which pages of its website a customer visited and which items they viewed but did not purchase. This data was stored in a database and organized by customer ID.

In addition, the company conducted surveys to gather additional data on customer preferences. They asked customers to rate their satisfaction with the clothing they had purchased, as well as to provide feedback on what types of clothing they liked and disliked. This data was also stored in a database and organized by customer ID.

Finally, the company also collected data on the types of clothing that were currently popular and trending. This data came from fashion blogs, magazines, and social media platforms where customers were posting pictures and discussing trends in fashion. The company used this data to make informed decisions on which designs and colors to offer to their customers.

All of this data was then imported into Swift using the Core ML framework, which allowed the company to train its machine

I feel that I do not understand the current scientific understandings about the mechanisms of therapeutic agents. 

I know that one method is through binding to a specific receptor, such as on the surface of an "activated" immune cell. Is there a general way to go about looking at how another molecule interacts with another? How do researchers figure out what molecules to use in the binding, and how do they know that the molecule "goes" in the right direction? I would really appreciate any sort of link or literature to such a problem. To understand medicine, you have to understand diseases and there are a couple ways of looking at that.

First, a disease is a biochemical malfunction. It's a difference between the actual state of things and the standards. Antibodies, or drugs, or hormones are meant to bring you back to the healthy level, even if that healthy level is different than what you had.

Second, diseases are not just unphysiological effects; they are also caused by unphysiological changes. For example, cancer is a tumor, but if all the cancer cells all stopped growing the tumor wouldn't exist. There is a feedback loop there. This makes the issue of diseases very complicated. You can't just target one thing; you need to target it all, including the diseased cells and the variables that affect them.

It is important that you do not confuse these with “vocational rehabilitation services” in Virginia that can be paid for by your own health insurance, but can NOT be paid for by Social Security. This can also include other options, such as craft fairs or selling of your artwork, which many find to be therapeutic.
Also remember, there are many art therapists that practice art therapy, but are not supervised by an art therapy supervisor in a mental health setting, and sometimes an art therapist cannot be found in a mental health setting. It’s important to find someone who has been trained in art therapy and who is supervised, whether that is in a mental health setting or in a clinical setting such as a hospital, a senior center, or a community program. Art therapy training is a graduate degree of at least 420 hours plus a final field experience in clinical supervision.
Art therapy is therapy. Art therapists must be trained in therapy and their work is not a form of decorative art. They cannot paint or sculpt or draw in a way that is considered recreational. They are working in a collaborative way with their patients and they are acting in a professional and supervisory role in all their interactions with their patients.

Research 2017-02-10

Very early in the history of Earth, life lived in the oceans on the planet. The initial process of photosynthesis resulted in production of atmospheric oxygen, which provided a more inhabitable atmosphere. Micro-organisms also created the necessary conditions for early life. Organic molecules were created by prokaryotes and integrated into eukaryotic cells. Finally, eukaryotic multicellular organisms, which consisted of only a few cell types, evolved under the present-day environmental conditions. The evolution of photosynthetic and surface-dwelling organisms provided the basis for the evolution of all other animals.

It took hundreds of millions of years for one organism to develop into a multicellular, recognizable animal. In fact, five major periods of evolutionary development occurred. First, amoebas and microorganisms became multicellular organisms that swam in the water. Then, giant, multicellular organisms clung to the seasides and shorelines. After that, terrestrial vegetation and mammals developed and then reptiles. At the end of this period, reptiles were over 500 times larger than their ancestors (human dinosaurs such as Tyrannosaurus Rex were estimated to be about 60 feet tall). Finally, large sauropod dinosaurs lived on land, and then mammals went through a dramatic process of evolution.

In modern times, the innovation of medical science has reduced morbidity and mortality associated with infectious diseases. There has been a revolutionary evolution in cancer treatment in the last 50 years. The advent of effective diagnostic methods and treatment modalities has substantially improved the quality of health care. The focus of health care has shifted from a primarily curative approach to a more preventive approach, with emphasis on dietary health and activity. The extraordinary advances in medical science have caused a drastic increase in longevity of people, increased the number of people who have wealth, and caused a fundamental change in how we think about health care.

Medical science continues to advance with discoveries, especially in the field of cancer. Three new cancer therapies have been developed that utilize the power of the immune system. Immune checkpoints are usually expressed on both T cells and cancer cells, where they act as “immunological brakes.” Unfortunately, when cancer cells invade the tissues of the body, the immune system rarely recognizes the cancer cells as abnormal. is as old as cinema itself. Just as the nature of the human condition has influenced the evolution of cinema, so too has technology. The invention of the cinema camera in the late nineteenth century allowed filmmakers to see what only painters could previously see.
Over the past century and a half, the tools available to filmmakers have become more and more advanced. We can now use computers to make changes to the final product without ever leaving the editing suite. This in turn has made the process of storytelling possible in ways previously unimaginable. But these tools have come with significant costs.
As photography evolved from stop-motion and hand-drawn animation, the creative pool only became larger. And not all innovation has been for the better. While the digital revolution has opened up opportunities to experiment in film making, it has also led to the perception that technique is all that matters.
With effects now so seamlessly integrated with the live-action footage, it has become hard to define the difference between filmmaking and graphics. A scene can look so real, that it’s not until you look closely at the actors’ performance that you begin to doubt it. And with the technology and resources available to filmmakers, it’s all but impossible to create something which isn’t possible with a computer in post-production. Many now regard the incorporation of computer graphics in film as an abuse of technology which only serves to detract from the film itself.

As we take a look at Yorke’s efforts, a quick description of the content should suffice. The King of Limbs is a pretty abstract album which is given a visual representation using layers of organic and inorganic imagery. 51 minutes of loops make up the full length of the album, and each loop is fitted together into one large final version.
A solid proof of concept, the King of Limbs vinyl remains true to the origins of the album. Whereas the digital release of the album contained many live performance videos, the physical copy is bereft of these visual aids. Instead, your mind is left to play its own processional soundtrack to your listening, relying only on the sounds contained on the record to help you picture the visuals as you hear them.

with an AI-powered robot in the lead role.
In the year 2050, humanity had achieved the impossible. We had explored the farthest reaches of the galaxy and discovered a wealth of new worlds, each one with its own unique set of challenges and secrets to uncover. But with the endless expanse of space to explore, there were still countless mysteries waiting to be uncovered, and only the bravest and most skilled explorers were up to the task.

Enter Proxima, the latest and greatest AI-powered robot to join the ranks of the space explorers. Proxima was designed to be the perfect companion on long space journeys, with advanced sensors, weapons, and communication systems that allowed it to operate independently for extended periods of time.

Proxima's first mission was to explore a distant planet that had been detected by the Kepler Space Telescope. The planet was located in a distant solar system, and had not been studied before. Proxima was launched from the International Space Station, and after a long and grueling journey, it finally arrived at the planet's orbit.

As Proxima began to scan the planet for signs of life and investigate its surface, it quickly realized that the planet was teeming with strange and fascinating life forms, some of which were unlike anything it had ever encountered before. Proxima used its advanced sensors to collect data and samples, and sent them back to Earth for analysis.

But Proxima was not just a scientific instrument. It was also a powerful tool for space exploration, with the ability to navigate and map the planet's terrain, and even to communicate with other robots and spaceships in the area. Proxima quickly became a valued member of the space exploration team, and its contributions were invaluable in unlocking the secrets of the universe.

As Proxima continued its explorations, it encountered many challenges and obstacles, but it was always up to the task. Its advanced AI capabilities allowed it to navigate the treacherous terrain of the planets and moons, and its weapons and defenses were always on hand to protect it from any threats that might arise.

In the end, Proxima's mission was a success. It discovered new life forms, mapped the planet's surface, and helped to unlock the secrets of the universe. And as it returned to Earth, hailed as a hero and inspiration to all, it knew that its next mission was already waiting in the stars, and that there were countless more mysteries and wonders waiting to be uncovered in the vast expanse of space.

At a conference at the University of Utah for first-year mathematics PhD students, I was asked to give a talk.

I talked about math teacher unions in response to a question at the end of my presentation on student-centered learning.

As promised, here’s the post.

Background and Context

Several students have asked questions in the past about math teacher unions. I’m always ambivalent about this type of question, but I think they’re asking important questions.

This is a condensed and summarized version of the pasted together information I’ve gleaned from quite a few sources. I tried to focus on high-quality, scholarly sources that try to explain and systematize the history and current state of affairs.

Note: I have tried to summarize things that are very complicated, so I may well have mangled things. I put in the extra effort to give context and sources and let the reader make up their mind.

Importance of Unions

The mathematical profession is, unfortunately, unionized, and in fact, the American Mathematical Society has a politically active math teacher union, which mostly operates through lobbying.

Without them, mathematics professors would probably be paid slightly more.

Some of the reasons are the following:

• Would-be math majors tend to be in the same cohort as math teachers, and the teaching profession demands long hours and physical labor, which Math PhDs typically abhor.

• The postdocs that mathematics departments typically offer are usually pretty bad for teaching experience. If you don’t teach, then you usually don’t have a chance at getting tenure. If you teach, then you might be relegated to something called “The Third Life.”

• Math PhD programs tend to offer funding, and try to attract the best students. However, the details can vary widely, and the decision to pursue a math PhD is a major decision in and of itself.

Cultures of High School Teachers and University Professors

• This is arguably true in the US but not so much in Europe. A high school physics or math teacher usually has a large burden of teaching, office hours, grading, and parent conferences, and no office or office hours. For university professors, the office environment is a little more comfortable, and faculty don’t necessarily deal with students on a daily basis. Office hours can also be perfunctory.

• The breakdown between teaching versus research, and the pressure to publish and present are also different.

• Professional development is not a big part of math teaching.

and the development of theories on brain function. The history of neuroscience can be traced back to ancient civilizations, such as the Greeks, who studied the brain and nervous system. However, the scientific study of the brain and neuroscience began in the 19th century when researchers started to use new scientific methods, including microscopy, to investigate the nervous system. 

One of the key discoveries in neuroscience was the development of the study of the electro-encephalogram (EEG), which measures electrical activity in the brain. This enabled researchers to explore different brain functions and understand how they are coordinated.

The field of neuroscience continued to grow and evolve throughout the 20th century, with many groundbreaking discoveries. For example, in 1975, the discovery of the brain's internal communication system, known as the blood-brain barrier, opened up new avenues for research into brain function.

Another significant development in neuroscience was the study of neurotransmitters, chemical messengers that help to transmit signals in the brain. Researchers discovered that many different neurotransmitters played crucial roles in various brain functions, including mood, behavior, and memory.

Neuroscience has also advanced through the development of new imaging techniques, such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), which allow researchers to visualize brain activity in real-time. This has provided insights into how the brain works during different tasks and activities.

The latest developments in neuroscience include the study of genetics and epigenetics, which have begun to reveal how genetic factors can influence brain function and behavior.

Overall, the history of neuroscience has been characterized by continuous advancements in technology, techniques, and theories, leading to a deeper understanding of the workings of the brain and its complex functions.

It's amazing how far neuroscience has come. What are some current challenges in the field? As the field of neuroscience advances, there are several current challenges that scientists are working to overcome. Here are a few:

1. Understanding consciousness: Despite decades of research, scientists still struggle to fully understand what consciousness is and how it arises from the brain. It remains one of the greatest mysteries in neuroscience.

2. Disorders of the brain: Neurological and psychiatric disorders are complex and require a multifaceted approach to treatment. Researchers are working to develop new drugs, therapies, and treatments to help those suffering from conditions like depression, schizophrenia, and Parkinson's disease.

3. Brain-computer interfaces: While neural prosthetics, or devices that control muscles or limbs using the brain, are becoming more common, there is still a lot of research to be done on

cannot be overstated, and at the core of every organization’s financial plan are the vital steps to be taken in order to implement a budget and monitor performance.
Expense budgets need to be carefully controlled, and it is therefore prudent for a business owner to routinely check the costs associated with his or her key operations and departments in order to ensure that no important areas of the organization are going unchecked. The chief financial officer for the company or an accounting team will typically set up a budgeting process and in order to attain budget goals, steps are taken to monitor costs and analyze consumption. The effectiveness of this process is displayed through the process of budget versus actual cost, where the organization compares actual costs with the budget amounts for both individual expenditures and the overall budgeted figure for the period as a whole.
Once the budget versus actual costs process is established, the cost of particular components is then measured and controlled. Taking into account the variations in operating costs, it becomes easier for managers to understand and control the change in actual costs compared to the budgets. A number of important trends are evident by carefully reviewing these metrics, such as instances of increased labor costs (which could indicate the need to reassign employees to different tasks or recruit additional staff members to work in the organization). Other shifts in expenditure and consumption could point to problems in the supply chain, suggesting a need to evaluate the effectiveness of the supplier channel and institute measures to lower supply costs in the future.
In addition to these trends, the chief financial officer and the rest of the financial team will usually conduct analyses at the end of an operating cycle to assess factors which have impacted budgetary performance. This could include measures to reduce costs, identifying areas of potential waste, and calculating the total cost of the budget. It is also important to compare different cost metrics to help understand variances between programs and departments.
During the process of budgeting, it is also vital for companies to identify any material changes which could have a major impact on their operations. For example, a change in the international economy could have serious repercussions for a company engaged in exporting its products. By working with its supply chain to better estimate these future market shifts, a company can take steps to ensure that it has proper contingency plans in place to handle any fluctuations in its costs and revenues.

bright thanks to the Wolfram Language. It brings a technology revolution to science by enabling the use of computers as a critical tool for scientific investigation and communication. Although the mathematician and computer scientist Stephen Wolfram (born 1959) was the first graduate of his mother’s alma mater, Cranbrook School, he was not a child prodigy. In fact, he was well into his 20s before he discovered his passion for programming; he also had a career in engineering and particle physics before he left that profession to found Wolfram Research Inc. and create the Wolfram Language. In 2010, Wolfram published “New Kind of Science,” the result of more than 20 years of study and development using computers as instruments of science. The core of this book is the discovery of relationships between cells of data, revealing order at the most fundamental levels of nature, a phenomenon often referred to as cellular automata. Any time you see order in the universe, you can assume it is the outcome of natural laws. For example, you can predict the outcome of chess matches by assuming that white has at least a 70% chance of choosing the queen, because that is the strongest piece and it has been used in every successful attack. Whatever people believe happens in the future, many believe that soon the computational power required to solve a puzzle through this kind of algorithmic search will become available. And that’s the point: machines can now solve these puzzles that have eluded humans for centuries. The answer may be in the behavior of cellular automata. “New Kind of Science” also reveals the surprising degree to which complex patterns arise naturally in nature. Many physical systems appear to contain infinitely many self-similar patterns, for example, and many cell interactions are governed by precise communication networks. In particular, this kind of network can be described by cellular automata with the global state a description of the cell. In the Wolfram Language, a global state can be given as a table, in which the atomic state of each cell is represented by an integer. The computational power of the Wolfram Language for solving problems in science is enormous. For example, in genetic research it may be possible to uncover relationships between genotypes and phenotypes and use them to predict the biological implications of environmental exposure. If you know the state of two genomes, for example, you can infer the likely state of a third genome, which may then serve as a predictive tool. (AI) has long been a matter of intense debate in science fiction. Previous generations imagined a future where AI would do the work of creating a better world, be it the Terran domed cities of the City of Seven Lakes or the floating cities of the Lotus Eaters (always with the brave. machismo. hero only sometimes if he's a red-blooded boy who realized how beautiful and smart a woman can be). Although some believe that this is the destiny of AI, his true future is up to the human mind. Science fiction can predict only the barest of shapes when it comes to a future where intelligent robots can threaten human life.
However, while AI has produced some great things, most of it appears to be more of a mindless pursuit of money-making ventures rather than a deep understanding of the human spirit (or make efforts to reconcile the two). AI can make some incredible things that are not for use in the entertainment industry, but it seems that the money invested in this category is being poured into the hard work. That's not to say it won't be fun to see roving robots roam a living world, but if you want to find out how it works in the real world, just take a look at the companies you visit. Walk into Tesla, for example, and you can see hundreds of robots in action (and perhaps a little off balance in the process).
There is also the daily life experience, where there are more and more companies using AI in their products. There was a time when AI was in its infancy, having only just made a name for itself with interactive marketing to individuals, intelligent appliances, and bots that could match your expectations when shopping or doing a quick search online. Now there are many products that offer advanced chatbot-style AI. Chatbots are those cute little virtual assistants with personalities, the ones who can answer you simple questions (the ones you might ask Siri or Google Assistant).
But chatbots aren't the only artificial beings to be found, not even in the advanced machine world. Everyone knows by now that Google has created a phone or two, but do they also know that the development of Google Now Assistants, Google Assistant and Google Home were all using AI? People are familiar with Amazon's Alexa, which exists alongside the Amazon Echo speakers and Amazon's Fire TV devices to provide quick access to products, media, and information. Sometimes the association is effortless; Alexa could understand what a customer wants to know (and what kind of help they need) on Amazon.com.
Back to Google,

Once upon a time, there was a psychologist named Dr. Jennifer who had just started her practice in a small town. Her primary focus was on the psychology of aggression, as she had always been fascinated by the darker side of human nature.

Dr. Jennifer's practice was initially slow, but eventually word of her unique expertise spread, and she began seeing a steady stream of clients who were struggling with violent outbursts or other forms of aggressive behavior.

As she delved deeper into the minds of her patients, Dr. Jennifer began to uncover a troubling pattern. Many of her clients had suffered a great deal of trauma throughout their lives, whether from abuse, neglect, or other forms of hardship.

Dr. Jennifer's research led her to believe that many of her clients' aggressive tendencies could be traced back to these past traumas. She believed that understanding the root causes of these behaviors could be the key to helping her patients overcome their violent tendencies.

As she continued her work, Dr. Jennifer began to encounter some ethical dilemmas. Some of her patients were willing to try out new techniques that could potentially help them overcome their violent tendencies, but other patients were hesitant or even resistant to these methods.

Dr. Jennifer knew that she couldn't force her patients to try something that they weren't comfortable with, but she also knew that time was of the essence. She began to push the boundaries of her practice, sometimes prescribing medications or conducting experiments that were outside of the scope of traditional psychology.

As her reputation as a radical psychologist grew, so did the attention she received from the media and the public. Some praised her innovative approach, while others criticized her for crossing ethical boundaries and potentially causing harm to her patients.

Despite the criticism, Dr. Jennifer remained steadfast in her belief that the only way to truly help her patients was to get to the root of their aggression. She continued to explore the darker side of human nature, pushing the boundaries of what was possible in the world of psychology.

In the end, Dr. Jennifer's work inspired others to take a more holistic approach to psychology, one that took into account the full range of a person's experiences and potential. While her methods were controversial, they ultimately proved to be effective in helping patients overcome their violent tendencies and live healthier, more fulfilling lives.

But what about the patients who were resistant to the new methods? Did Dr. Jennifer have any solutions for them?

# Programming with secret information at the physical layer

## Summary:

The paper is about the ethics of cryptography

## Discussion and Analysis

• I really like the way the authors are questioning the (long) history of cryptography and present several examples of things being forgotten. In a related sense, it's also nice to see a moral example given explicitly (in particular a sentence used in the last paragraph of 1.2).

• I agree that §1.4 ("History of Secrecy and Coding") is interesting. However, I think it would be helpful if the authors provided a brief synthesis of where they think the study of cryptography in general goes from here. It seems to me that cryptography is merely part of a larger security system, and this needs to be kept in mind when trying to look ahead.

• I agree with Scott that the paper would benefit from a section on the current state of the practice of the engineering of cryptographic systems (with examples).

• I didn't find the issues in 1.1 ("Treaties and the Right to Privacy") in anyway convincing. In particular, I think the author over-reaches in their assertion that:

The debate over what is and what is not private may also imply that the legitimate goals of a prior nondisclosure agreement are impossible to accomplish. Not only did the negotiations between the UK and US resolve this issue—posing a series of alternatives so that each side could declare a "victory"—, but this particular issue is also unlikely to be given any priority in the highly politicized debate over President Obama’s “kill list”.

I also don't think these problems should really be attributed to cryptography as such. Whether or not some of what he says is true is, I guess, beside the point.

• I have no strong opinion on whether the authors should do or even could do a study of ethical dilemmas facing cryptographers in the job market. But I do have a serious disagreement with the claim in 1.1 that "cryptographic research should not be used to satisfy the trade secret clauses in nondisclosure agreements."

1) A lot of the mathematics used in cryptography (such as Shamir's secret sharing scheme) has substantial applications outside of cryptography. Even when the mathematics of cryptography itself is used in business, for instance during the Enron incident, it would be odd to regard the needs of the business "owner" as taking precedence over a need for academic freedom.

2) For many kinds of cryptography (e.g. financial cryptography) it would be irrational for

from ancient Greece to modern times. Throughout history, theater has played a significant role in human society. It has served as a way for people to explore and express their emotions, tell stories, and entertain others. From the very beginning, theater has evolved and changed over time, but one thing remains constant: theater continues to bring people together and leave a lasting impact on their lives.

Ancient Greece:
Theater in ancient Greece was seen as a form of ritualistic worship. It was believed to be a way for people to connect with the gods and goddesses, and to share in a common cultural experience. Greek theater featured plays that often had a moral or religious message, and they were performed outdoors in large open-air theaters.

Roman theater:
Roman theater was similar to Greek theater, but it was more focused on entertainment and less on religious rituals. Roman theater featured comedies and tragedies, and actors were often appreciated for their comedic timing and acting abilities.

Medieval Europe:
During the Middle Ages, theater took a more religious tone. Christian plays were performed throughout Europe, with themes such as salvation and repentance. These plays often took place in small, intimate spaces and were meant to inspire people to live virtuous lives.

Renaissance Europe:
The Renaissance brought a renewed interest in theater and a renewed emphasis on humanism. This led to the development of new plays and new forms of theater. The 16th century saw the emergence of the “Commedia dell’arte,” a form of improvisational theater that featured stock characters such as Harlequin and Columbine.

The Baroque period:
The Baroque period in Europe was marked by grandeur and extravagance. Theater during this time was often done on a larger scale, with elaborate sets and costumes. Baroque theater was also marked by a focus on emotion and drama, with plays often featuring tragic or romantic themes.

The Enlightenment:
During the Enlightenment, theater became more focused on reason and logic. The emphasis on logic led to new forms of theater, such as the play “The Dying Gaul” by Marivaux, which was a more naturalistic representation of life and relationships.

Modern times:
The 20th century saw the emergence of new forms of theater, such as the clowning and physical theater of Jerzy Grotowski, and the absurdist plays of Samuel Beckett. In recent years, theater has become more experimental and diverse, with theaters around the world showcasing new and innovative forms of theater.

In conclusion, theater has a long and varied history,

and computing presents an exciting area of research opportunity for meeting scientists from all disciplines. As chemical and computing technology continue to converge and mature, the implications of our integrated world are becoming increasingly apparent. Harnessing the power of computational simulation to accelerate our understanding of synthetic and biological processes and quantum advances to further our analysis and control of matter offer tremendous opportunities. Transformative advances may one day impact our life and work, helping to satisfy greater demands for clean, abundant energy; improving our capacity to respond to global climate change and environmental challenges; and modifying our bodies for better human health. There are, however, serious roadblocks to realizing the full potential of computing and simulation. One such roadblock is chemistry’s robust nature – with thousands of unique compounds possessing unique structures and properties. Computer simulation has matured from the simple molecular mechanics methods of the 1960s to new quantum computational approaches capable of handling the accurate description of tens of thousands of atoms and molecular orbitals. It is clear that tools are needed that can discover and virtualize chemical compounds over wide ranges of choices in structural and energetic criteria. Furthermore, our current computational approaches, much like our current computational mechanics, will be hard pressed to meet the demands of thousands of different reaction pathways with computational time and storage at a reasonable cost. Thankfully, the power of evolution and machine learning provides exciting new approaches to addressing these problems.
An invited plenary session entitled “Machine Learning as a Means of Quickly Virtualizing Chemical Space” at the May 2019 Spring National Meeting in Orlando, Florida.

and how philosophy can help. This is a discussion between Iain McGilchrist, Andrew Cole and Adam Gopnik.
We do not know how our brains work, and not really why we do what we do, there is a dearth of knowledge about neural development and plasticity, particularly about the brain’s brain, the neocortex, and its functioning when well. Neuroscience now appears to be at a critical juncture. There has been an explosion of data, but the neuroscientist’s conceptual framework still has much in common with that of the 1950s. As a result, the tools that have been developed for processing and interpreting this massive body of new data remain rather limited.
In a new book ‘The Master and His Emissary’ Iain has argued that the right hemisphere is the theatre of consciousness. The left hemisphere is a more passive processor, storing and processing information, according to Iain. It is more time consuming, and a more protracted processing, and is better at abstract thinking. The two hemispheres are in communication with one another. This blog describes some of the philosophy behind Iain’s book. Here is the link to the blog: http://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/feb/14/mcgilchrist-book.
At its best, philosophy also has the ‘feel’ of science. And it is the aim of the Symposium on Philosophy to show the interface between philosophy and science, and how these two disciplines work together to augment our knowledge of reality.
Andrew J.Cole is Senior Research Scholar in the Program in Writing and Rhetoric at Stanford University. His book ‘Writing and Reason’ is based on his time studying at the Sorbonne, where a lot of core philosophical issues are re-examined with a new focus on the relationship between writing and critical thinking. Cole has presented various versions of his thesis at Stanford and has an excellent blog on writing and thinking.
The program opens with the talk by Professor Frank Jackson on ‘What is analyticity?’, he is a widely respected philosopher and logician who spent most of his career in Australia. His work has been described by philosopher and logician David Lewis as ‘an artistic tour de force.’ Frank has written a book on the subject ‘Epistemic Modality’, which is just the first in a series of three. For these talks Frank has been working with philosopher Shane Austin who is going to open the second day of the Symposium, his speciality is the philosophy of language

, art, and musical composition has mirrored societal changes and has often preceded them. There is a hierarchy of advancement in the arts in relation to societal evolution. The visual arts are considered the highest forms of expression with literature, music, dance, and theatre being well behind them. There is a natural progression of sophistication, complexity, and discipline in all of these forms. Society develops its standards over time and as greater awareness of quality is attained, the form must follow in order to keep in step with social evolution. There will always be a few artists that lead the charge, that separate themselves from the normal force, leading the way toward new modes of expression.
Certain movements in literature, art, and music mirror the psychology of man. There was a well established system of political and social structure and expression during the Middle Ages, Renaissance, and Romantic eras. The ability of the individual to express himself was determined by his family status, accomplishments, and property. Their role was defined for them and they occupied a very specific place in society. The transfer to capitalistic societies and the rise of individualism was much more rapid than the evolution of art and became, for the most part, a reflection of this rapid social evolution. There was a great release in individualism and emotion was experienced to a much higher degree than it had before. As individuals more boldly and explicitly expressed themselves, art began to become more artistic. Literature, music, and visual art began to be created for the sake of the creation and not primarily for the purpose of social expression. During the later half of the 20th century, the basic structures of Western life collapsed and individuals placed less emphasis on the social order and more of a focus on their own individualistic needs. This has continued through this century to date.
In 1873, French literary critic Charles Baudelaire (1821-1867) writes "L'Art dans tous ses états." ("Art in all its states"). This was a culmination of his journey and search for creative expression after having moved away from Romanticism. He was disgusted by the effects of Romanticism and what he observed was that it replaced abstract emotion, with vivid emotion. The artistic pursuit of Romanticism began to become overwrought with self indulgent sentimentality and flowery descriptions. Baudelaire rejected emotional expression as being unimportant or the surface view of things. It was too highly influenced by the world around it and did not transcend it. and how it has evolved over time.

The history of medicine dates back to ancient civilizations such as Egypt, Mesopotamia, and China, where healers and priests were entrusted with the responsibility of treating the sick and injured. The techniques used in these early medical practices were mainly based on observation and superstition, and often involved the use of natural remedies such as herbs and plants.

During the Middle Ages, medicine was still largely unscientific, and many diseases were seen as the work of evil spirits or curses. Physicians and herbalists were still prevalent, but surgery was often performed without anesthesia or proper disinfection, leading to high mortality rates.

During the Renaissance, a more scientific approach to medicine began to emerge, with the introduction of new techniques such as bloodletting and the use of pharmaceuticals. However, these methods were still largely unproven, and many believed that they were of little use in the treatment of many illnesses.

In the 19th century, the use of antibiotics and vaccines revolutionized medicine, leading to significant improvements in public health. The rise of modern medicine was also marked by the development of many new medical technologies such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRI machines.

Today, medicine has advanced to the point where many new treatments and cures are being developed regularly. Advances in medical research have allowed scientists to understand many of the mechanisms behind diseases, and to create treatments that can help patients live longer and healthier lives. The focus on personalized medicine and genetic engineering is also revolutionizing the field of medicine, opening up new possibilities for the treatment of illnesses.

In conclusion, medicine has evolved over time to become a highly advanced field of science, driven by new technologies and innovations. While there is still much to be learned about the human body and how it functions, the advancements that have been made in recent years have had a profound impact on the way we treat illness and improve health outcomes.

Can you give an example of a new medical treatment that has been developed recently?

Sure, one example of a new medical treatment that has been developed recently is gene therapy. Gene therapy is a type of treatment that involves using a patient's own cells to treat or even cure genetic disorders. The procedure involves taking a patient's cells, modifying them in a laboratory to correct the genetic defect causing the disorder, and then reinserting the modified cells into the patient. This process is still in the early stages of development, but researchers have made significant progress in recent years, and there have been promising results in clinical trials for several genetic disorders.

: Is this the new way forward?
Despite having been in business for many years, we still have customers who talk to us at Xmas and say, “What’s all this research stuff about?”. It might just be because we are a long way from Christmas, but for me it is a clear indication that there are a lot of businesses out there, still using outdated methods to research their customers.
Based on a number of client conversations over the last month, and 3 years of talking to a variety of psychometric test companies, I’ve come up with a theory that psychometric testing and research has a real “nice-to-have” air about it and not a “must-have” air about it.
One of the questions we were asked recently on a test we completed was whether we could multi-task. It seems such an innocuous question but there are companies out there who claim their tests can go through hundreds of these types of questions in a day.
I was very taken by a quote I read recently about research that it needs to be done properly and only the researchers that have no other agenda can justify spending the time and money to do a quality research piece.
There are many us out there who just have too much time on our hands and have a strong preference for experience rather than research. It seems such a sound idea, surely it is true and therefore results are based on solid information rather than just gut instinct. Why do we spend so much time talking about gut instinct rather than being honest and saying “we don’t really know”. We are all familiar with the interesting times we live in and recent experiences around the world have not exactly helped.
I think the most prevalent misconception is that psychometric testing is a “nice to have”, I just don’t think it is a nice-to-have, I think it is a must-have. The only area in which this is not true is where the “average” manager or leader is concerned, but given that psychometric testing is predicted to grow year on year, there can’t be a large number of managers and leaders out there who don’t need the ongoing benefit of psychometric testing.
Another issue is how it is rolled out. Any manager that says that “he/she” got a special test to tell them how to manage, is likely to be down the employment market way before Christmas. Results in from psychological assessments can’t be written on a sticker and people need to know it is a process and take time.

is continuously changing. Cryptography underpins the technology of security, and the two continue to advance together; in the words of Bruce Schneier, security is just the art and science of managing risk.
As such, to discuss these topics meaningfully, we need to step back and understand what cryptography is and how it works. Our discussion today will be strictly theoretical, but as we learn about the past, we will also talk about its immediate future. Cryptography is how we keep information secure in the digital age. Without cryptography, we wouldn't be able to deal with confidential communications, computers in all their shapes and sizes, secure medical records, or anything else that requires you to keep your information private.
Very often, these communications have to be done in a way that no one can intercept them. This is no easy task, and it requires that we use highly specialized techniques to both encipher, or scramble up the information we want to transmit, as well as decipher it again once it has reached its destination.
At BWC, we believe that software development needs to be very focused on improving user interaction, which is why we are interested in improving the overall user experience. In particular, we are interested in providing users with the ability to securely and privately conduct transactions over the internet using the software development process. One of our first steps will be using cryptographic techniques to help users keep their private keys separate from the other information that is stored on their computer.
So why do we care about the relationship between cryptography and technology? The technological innovations and breakthroughs that we take for granted today were made possible by the unceasing efforts of a series of brilliant minds. From the creation of the electric lamp to the establishment of the world wide web, technology has been growing, taking leaps of incredible breadth and depth. Consider the technology of cryptography -- it enables secure communications by keeping sensitive information out of the hands of someone that is not allowed to access it.
As we move through the history of cryptography, we will discuss the individuals that were at the cutting edge of the field. These individuals should serve as a reminder that every technological marvel was once the dream of a single mind. In the very near future, we intend to continue studying and better understanding cryptography, and how it relates to the cutting edge technologies of the digital age.

Writing a cipher (encryption algorithm) can be a simple undertaking with a few mathematical components involved. However, writing a secure cipher requires sophisticated mathematics and complex algorithms to be effective. That’s where ICH1 starts.

Please note that what we are trying to implement is a vector of AES, SHA-2, Rijndael, and Serpent ciphers that use the Double Ratchet algorithm to provide security at every level of the communication. This includes within the application, the VPN connection, and the Internet connection. Some level of advanced coding is required to provide the proper implementation of the protocol.

The first phase of development will begin with the requirements phase and work through design, architecture, implementation, and validation. This phase will develop all the logic, tests, and components and should take approximately six months to accomplish. Design and Implementation are completed by Bill Spencer while design and architecture are completed by Randy Smith. After the application is created, the communication protocol, the network, and the Internet will be connected and tested with specialized tools, and with DNS Level 2 checks to see if the application is being successfully run.

The next phase will be a period of corrections and testing to ensure the protocol is both well architected and tested. This will involve vetting the software with advanced developers to provide feedback and (hopefully) correction. This phase will take four months.

At this time, a second security function can be incorporated, which is the ability to audit traffic on the link between the app and the VPN. This will reveal the nature of communication between the people who are communicating. This will allow an outside party to see who is talking to whom, and what they are saying to each other. In this case the security factor is removed because the communication between the people who are talking to each other will be visible. This allows a third party to see the conversation. However, if we consider that the link is public, the encryption should not be broken. This can be a deterrent for bad actors who would attempt to intercept the communication but would not be able to read it or hack it. This type of communication is safe from surveillance and intrusion.

The final phase will be to implement the feedback control layer to regulate the traffic of communications. If an application is used on a computer with a secure firewall, the results of what is seen can be blocked. Broadly, there are two schools of thought regarding historical geology. There is plate tectonics and there is catastrophism. The latter was the predominant theory until the 1970s and early 1980s. This was the era of the great ‘drainage set’. Due to its apparent success, they became almost paradigmatic, and gradually became the accepted dogma. If it does not fit with what they are actually saying, then we ought to ask what the implications are for this theory, and how might we test it?

If Plate Tectonics is correct, what does that mean that the majority of historical geology has been based on? This has been the mainstream view of geology until relatively recently, and even now is largely the view of the vast majority of geologists. Should the majority of geology be found wanting in the face of seemingly indisputable evidence, the whole of our understanding of the earth will have to be reconsidered. A few people will not be able to live with that thought.

There is one school of geology which claims that Plate Tectonics is too simplified a model to describe the whole of the earth's history, a school which is now increasingly accepted. It is the school of historical geology. From that perspective, the fossil record provides evidence not only of mass extinctions, but also evidence that these large tectonic plates are not static and in fact seems to suggest they may actually be ‘folding’ back upon each other, that is, pushing up under the other. We have to be aware of this when we attempt to reconstruct history and if catastrophism is true, then it suggests that the geologic record is even more chaotic than even those with Plate Tectonics have imagined.

It is the opposite of the ‘plate tectonic’ view of the earth's past. It is that the earth's history is full of catastrophes, caused by asteroid and cometary bombardment, by tectonic stretching, then shrinkage, driven by the lack of water, and by volcanic activity, in particular mountain building events. These would be catastrophes that will change all of the geologic layers, to some degree or other. For large scale mountain building events, the surface geology that we observe today would be totally unrecognisable; hence the rapid changes to the geology of the Earth's surface.

and its cultural significance.
Cinema is an art form that has been around for over a century, but it is constantly evolving and changing with technology. The history of cinema dates back to the late 19th century when the first experimental film was created by Louis Le Prince in France.

In the early years, cinema was seen as a novelty, and it was primarily used for entertainment and amusement. However, as technology improved, filmmakers began to experiment with new techniques and storytelling methods.

In the early 1900s, the industry began to grow rapidly, with major studios such as MGM and Warner Bros. emerging. The silent era saw some of the most influential films in history, including Charlie Chaplin's "The Gold Rush" and "The Kid."

The advent of sound in cinema in the late 1920s transformed the industry and opened up new possibilities for storytelling. The Great Depression in the 1930s led to the creation of some of the most iconic movies of all time, including "Gone with the Wind," "Casablanca," and "The Wizard of Oz."

During World War II, cinema continued to thrive, and films such as "The Best Years of Our Lives" and "Citizen Kane" became critical and commercial successes. In the 1950s, the industry saw a shift to more family-friendly fare, with movies such as "Gone with the Wind" and "Singin' in the Rain."

In the 1960s, the youth culture movement led to a new wave of films that dealt with social issues and challenged traditional values. The rise of independent cinema in the 1970s saw filmmakers push the boundaries of storytelling and use cinema to explore controversial themes.

The 1980s saw the emergence of the blockbuster era, with movies such as "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" and "Back to the Future" becoming cultural phenomena. In the 1990s, the rise of the internet and digital technology led to new possibilities for storytelling and experimentation.

In recent years, cinema has become more diverse and inclusive, with films such as "Get Out" and "Moonlight" breaking barriers and pushing for greater representation onscreen. Cinema remains an important cultural institution, with its films reflecting the hopes, dreams, and struggles of people across the world.
