Little did I know 30 years ago, when I first read about “Neuro-Linguistic Programming” (NLP) in a newspaper, the impact that it would have on my life.
Later I became trained as an NLP Master Practitioner and built a thriving business, raising over $1.5million for important causes I believed in, including The Starship Foundation.
As our understanding of the workings of the brain has increased over the years, I noticed the parallels between how NLP and neuroscience play important roles in helping us better understand how our brain influences everything that we do. And I wondered whether NLP, with its proven effectiveness, might help to unlock some of the mysteries of the brain and create effective tools for everyone.
With the help of ground-breaking neuro-scientific research I went to work at integrating NLP with my own field of the mind, recognising that when we talk about the mind, we are really talking about the brain, along with everything it has ever done or can do.
The fact is, as a species, our brainpower has evolved – and is still evolving – rapidly. In the course of just one generation the processes we use for language and communication have changed, as have our ability to recognise shapes and forms, and the speed with which we learn and update our knowledge.
One could wonder why we put up with the discomfort of attaching electrodes to our heads, but as NLP practitioners, we must.
Three years ago, after taking a huge leap of faith and backing my long-term vision to create a superior NLP certification that would be at the forefront of NLP worldwide, I presented the entire NLP curriculum, in the best way I know how, throughout Europe, Australia and New Zealand.
The course was so successful that I subsequently introduced it in Europe.
Recently I returned to New Zealand and invited people from around the world to our co-located certification courses in Auckland. Some people came from as far away as the USA to take this course. Unsurprisingly, it sold out.
The effect of sharing this curriculum is that, as NLP trainers, my students can now lay claim to being among the most highly trained in the field. They can say with confidence that they are at the forefront of the NLP industry, as they study alongside the current authorities and have a profound ability to do extensive independent study.
As people continue to leave my classes, I am reminded that what I do is about a lot more than simply passing on knowledge.

can be seen in every aspect of human activity. The typical person could be walking on geological structures without even knowing it. Human settlement is supported by different geological deposits. Minerals are used in the manufacture of many products people use in the morning to the motor in their car that they may drive to work. Weathering of rocks due to geological processes such as weathering and erosion affect the vegetation on the landscape.
The terrain, buildings and structures also have a geological influence as the ground beneath the foundations is considered before construction begins. This is especially true in areas of active or recent tectonic activity, where faults are more common and the ground is more likely to contain unstable rock. This is equally true in areas where karst topography is evident as high levels of ground and surface water combine to form unstable ground conditions. In many areas, erosion processes cause major damage to human structures and roadways and many examples of this can be found along roadways in the geomorphology of various areas.
Geomorphology is the study of landforms, and its principal methodology is field study. Observation of landforms involves, geology, geomorphology, soil and vegetation with a view to the development of an understanding of these features of a landscape. When gathered, these data are analyzed using field techniques and computer-based analysis. Field techniques commonly used in geomorphology are surveying, cross-sectioning, profile investigation, and topographic surveying.

: with our eyes, we can only see a small part of the entire Earth, but we need to look at the entire Earth to understand its dynamics. Understanding the forces at work and how they drive plate tectonics and erosion leads to insights about how Earth's surface is created and changed, about the build up of human cities and the development of the human species. (Dusk to dawn; D-13)
When the earth was young: about the origins and early developments of life. The flowering of plant and animal diversity, the evolution of our diversity as humans, the impact of the environment on evolution, and the effects of human evolution on the environment. (Dusk to dawn; D-13)
Formation of localities: why geology matters? It is important to recognize the history of the shape of localities. Coastal rock outcrops and exposures record the history of past sea-level and shoreline evolution. This understanding can be employed in examining past events and in planning for the future. (Dusk to dawn; D-14)
Cliffs and sediment: geologic processes in action lead to deposits in the form of sand, mud and clay. These sediments are studied to decipher their origins, their depositional histories and to use them to estimate the depth of the deposits. Where they are, how they formed and the history of their formation and the environments they formed in are all relevant to geologists and to modern society. (Dusk to dawn; D-14)
Nature's museum: geological materials have often been used in art. This unit explores the way in which natural forms are incorporated into the arts, as well as revealing the purpose of geological specimens in science and in museums. (Dusk to dawn; D-14)
Shape-shifting Earth: old and new maps challenge our view of the shape of our world. This unit looks at the challenges of measuring the size and shape of the earth, the changing face of Earth, the adaptation of maps and how we are shaping the future of the Earth. (Dusk to dawn; D-14)
My Home - My Kind of Town: communities of humans form within the natural landscape of localities. This unit looks at the physical and the environmental influences that shape them. It looks at both prehistoric and modern communities, and the changes that occur as a result of the consequences of human activities on the environment. (Dusk to dawn; D-15)

, and our institutions through education, are the keys to shaping the culture and making it possible to accomplish great and good things as a civilization.
When our society devalues ideas and high level knowledge by not properly nurturing the minds and talents of our brightest people who are right here in our very society, who become disillusioned with education and end up pursuing easy, less demanding paths as more profitable endeavours, then we all suffer. Even if you are not a bright person whose talents were not given an opportunity to grow, the idea that you and your potential are not important, that your contribution to society is of little or no value, seems ingrained in our cultural DNA. The debate, argument, and gnashing of teeth about race has been ongoing for at least a century, and now we get to the point where the nation is choosing its next President, and people will choose between a highly educated Ivy League educated person with a slew of Nobel prize winners among his academic staff and a non-college educated rube with a popular vote image. America will choose its next president and it will be with half the population solidly for the rube, and another half arguing for the kid from Harvard who happened to be a different skin color.
Will the poor, the under privileged, and the very brightest people even consider being someone with the brain power and skills to advance their family and situation if our society, our institutions, and all of our respect for learning and education is defined by having a television reality TV star as your next President. and political discourse : Valmiki and the Bhagavad Gita as models for constructive engagement between ethnic minorities and states in the Indian subcontinent
Title: Practical applications of literature and political discourse : Valmiki and the Bhagavad Gita as models for constructive engagement between ethnic minorities and states in the Indian subcontinent
Author: WILLISON, Emma
Date: 2015
Citation: Bondo, Costas and Sophia Katsaounou, eds., Sarajevo, Institute for Advanced Social Research & Tinbergen Institute Global Centre for Economic Transformation in collaboration with Max Planck Institute for the Study of Religious and Ethnic Diversity, 2015
Series/Report no.: Papers ; 2015/5
Abstract:
In order to explore the themes of belonging and belonging within framework of the problems in negotiating ethnic minority identity and citizenship the purpose of this paper is to present a comparative analysis of the function and themes of two different genres. The first genre is the Bhagavad Gita, and the second genre is the original Epic of Ramayana, whose tenth cantos are dedicated to the structuring and embodiment of a conception of the Rajarata, identifying the boundaries of Arya. Both of these epics operate as epistemological tomes about place and belonging, and there are particular epigraphic clusters that begin in a concrete place and then develop language metaphors which contain different ways of understanding, self-evidently legitimated by the text.
Additional Information: SSIS Faculty Publication Number: 126; 14-35 pp.
Type of Access: embargoedAccess

The importance of Business in modern society：the subject which engages the attention of man for years，the subject which has occupied one phase after another of human existence．If it has failed to develop new and exalted ideals（理想）of human conduct，it has at least broadened our intellectual vision and that of our children．Before civilization—the era when we most relied upon our instinct and our savage intuition—we knew that the problem of survival was difficult but possible．In the days of middle life，when man had developed the tools of civilization，we knew that the problems of existence were formidable（令人畏惧的）but could be surmounted if we had sufficient patience，strength of character，and intelligence to deal with them． In the condition of civilization，today，when we have almost forgotten that our problems of existence are difficult，when man has become convinced that through the instrumentality of social machinery，whether in the form of an organized government，or an industrial army，or an organized church，he need not concern himself with the solution of the difficulties of existence—that the machine will do the problem-solving for him—we have become ignorant of the principles of what our problems are and what their significance is．The machines continue their mechanical run； men only remain happy or miserable depending upon whether they are or are not in touch with the machines． For once again the machines are not the final solution to the problems of existence．And now in the 21st century and "Digital Age" we have created in industry and commerce a type of problem-solving machine quite as powerful as the steam engine and yet far more subtle in its functions，and also more indispensable to our existence． We have completed the ironies of human existence．Man now relies almost entirely upon those who are educated in the universities to deal with the problems of existence．Man has become dependent on knowledge that those who do not possess such knowledge are never able to acquire．It is as though man would never try to solve a problem of existence until he were assured by some expert that there is a sure and reliable method for solving that particular problem． We stand on the threshold of a new era，the new age of industry．We await the time when those who are schooled in the arts of business will be entrusted with the responsibility of diversity on the uppermost Miocene northern Apennines (southern Europe)
I. . Tagliaro, A. Boccelli, M. Cavinato, R. Monti
Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology 213 (1-2), 25-51, 2004

### Information:

0 paper (4 pages)
 Date: 2004-10-20

Abstract:
Geochronological studies of the uppermost Miocene of the northern Apennines in Italy have shown that the age of the Arosio-Berna basin succession (Terzi sequence, Lowermost Tertiary Lower Pleistocene series) is MP10n, [Monte Smargiasso to smagria Terzi) (5.23 ± 0.07 (2) Ma), and MP10p (Ospedaletto to Tarzi) ([5.23 ± 0.07 (2) Ma, with an extension toward the west of approximately 400 km as far as the Carpi-Trento Section. Based on the agelnometry of the most recent chromitite layer, the age is refined to ca. 5.23 Ma. The corresponding MP10pi series (Ste-Marguerite to Aroxia) is U3-ma. The faunal assemblages of this new series overlap those of the adjacent Andaranvian sections. This supports the southern Apennines-Mendocina microcontinent hypothesis that, during most of its geological development, the region now occupied by the northern Apennines constituted a closed basin where Miocene sediments were deposited in a tectonically active, subduction-related, regional setting. (Kuawayi / Roraima in South America). The lowermost Miocene Roraima Tertiary, Argentina); fauna is the consequence of the superimposition of the continental crustal material brought up from the subducted Schiapa section of the southern Apennines. This provides strong support to an anthropogenic origin of the global Cretaceous/Oligocene radiation, suggesting that the rise of Quaternary vegetal diversity on the European continent may be traced back to the end of the Miocene.

in Costa Rica
There are several misconceptions regarding travel in Costa Rica that we often receive. These are the ones we hear most often, as well as the facts behind them.
You won’t find many high-quality tourist destinations in the country. Sure, you’ll find beautiful beaches, great shopping and delicious restaurants in the main cities and towns. But if you want to see a rare animal such as a jaguar or a sloth, you need to head into the jungle or into the cloud forests.
Costa Rica is pretty expensive to visit and stay in.
It’s true that Costa Rica’s hotels, restaurants and tour providers cost more than they do in most other countries. However, you can easily get by with $100 per day if you go to the right places. For example, having a fresh juice or a meal at a local restaurant can be had for about $4 – and you should absolutely eat at a local restaurant instead of at a hotel one every night.
Costa Rica’s people are only interested in selling things to tourists.
It’s true that Costa Ricans love to sell to tourists. But they love it even more when tourists become customers. They see foreigners as exotic and intriguing.
Every tourist guide to Costa Rica comes with another one too many activities on the itinerary. Costa Ricans like to promote the country’s many tourist attractions, but we always like it when you do something different – like travel to our gorgeous beaches, take a class on how to build a house or learn how to play a local instrument.
Money is more important than people or the environment.
Costa Ricans believe that no matter what you want to achieve in life, there is always another way. You do not have to make decisions based on profit. You can choose to work for the betterment of your community and country instead. This was very evident last year when hotels, restaurants and other tour providers closed their doors to their customers to help decrease the spread of the novel coronavirus. During the crisis, people decided to give food and items to families in need and other people from the hospitality industry. These selfless acts were truly inspiring to see.
If you want to eliminate all misconceptions, do like the locals do: live in the present moment, learn from other cultures, exchange ideas, help people, treat the earth with respect and enjoy life every day!

varies on the individual. Understanding the need for a deep and restorative sleep can guide you in making your life changes.
1. Recognize the need for better sleep and exercise: You might have experienced a number of days or nights in a row with little to no rest or where you really struggled to fall asleep. Learning to recognize the differences and characteristics of a restful sleep can be helpful. The individual’s mindset toward rest is important in learning to listen to the body’s needs for sleep.
2. Learn to practice safe sleep habits: Try practicing these techniques to give you a restful sleep.
a. Avoid any type of caffeine, including chocolate, or wine within a few hours before going to bed. Caffeine is a diuretic, which can cause the body to lose water and can interrupt the sleep cycle. Avoiding alcohol before bedtime is also important. Alcohol can disrupt your sleep pattern and is dangerous to the health of the body if ingested in excess.
b. Avoid using electronics, including phones, tablets, laptops, and TVs before bedtime as they interfere with your natural sleep and wake cycle.
c. Plan time to wind down before bed, this can include practicing a relaxation exercise (meditation, yoga, prayer, deep breathing).
d. Be more specific with your sleep schedule and routine, especially for infants and children. It can be helpful for both children and adults if they go to bed at the same time every night.
e. Establish a room that is only used for sleep. You might consider blocking the stimulation in the room through turning off electronics and other things that may stimulate the brain with light or sound. Try using dark, heavy curtains and earplugs if you have noisy neighbors or traffic outside.
f. Have a consistent, comfortable sleeping area. It might be helpful to use a sleeping pillow and a comfortable blanket if you are a restless sleeper. These items can be easily moved, including your mattress and bed frame. Consider using a foam mattress topper or a mattress cover that does not allow you to sink into it.
g. Maintaining proper, regular exercise or activity throughout the day can signal your body to produce melatonin, which is a restorative hormone. Exercise and mindful movement is restorative for the soul and mind. Just remember not to exercise right before bed as this can interfere with your sleep cycle.

to cities – that is, our cities.
The world is changing. So is our response to our changing cities. The City of San Jose recently convened the annual Silicon Valley/San Jose 2016 Tech Leaders Summit to explore some of the challenges and opportunities surrounding the changing work culture we are witnessing across the globe. Tech companies and city officials participated in roundtable discussions to explore, as one Silicon Valley exec put it, the difference between high tech’s ability to innovate and a city’s ability to scale.
The question of scale came about from city manager Alex Nguyen’s assertion that most tech companies with hundreds of employees don’t have the financial resources to take advantage of what cities offer, like land and connection to public services. He also talked about the work-from-anywhere mindset that permeates the tech world. Some companies offer remote work opportunities to job candidates – and an expectation of it for existing staff.
Now, there’s nothing wrong with remote work opportunities. In fact, many workers are itching for more flexibility and freedom to work in ways that suit their lifestyle.
What can be problematic, however, is that working from home or another location can be isolating and is missing out on some of the socialization and well-being benefits that come with working in an office. Real-life interactions outside of work can help you stay on top of important details in your personal life that can impact your job, like keeping up with your kid’s latest chess tournament or your parent’s new medical diagnosis. Chances are you’re in a better work mindset if you are asked a difficult question while sitting down the hall from your manager than if you’re asked it over the phone or by email, because you don’t have to pause your train of thought for long to compose a reply.
So it’s not really so much about the physical location of the employee; it’s about the location of the employee within the company and the community at large. We want to encourage companies to incorporate people back into the workforce to take advantage of some of the benefits of traditional workplaces, and to not allow remote work to be an obstacle to staying engaged with the larger community.
As technology is making the difference between which companies can scale and which ones can’t, let’s work to get those tech workers back on board and engaged with local communities. While local government isn’t the only organization that can do this work, we at least have a small part in building the framework that allows that to happen.

Genetic mutations are cause by changes in the gene sequence. Each sequence has two alternate forms: normal (allelic form) or mutant (allelic form). About 99% of the genome sequences remain the same from generation to generation, the other 1% are mutations. Every time a mutation occurs it is passed on to a child and if the mutation is functional, it could cause disease.
What causes duchenne muscular dystrophy?

Once upon a time, there was a young boy named Alex who was fascinated by words. He loved reading books and listening to music, but especially enjoyed exploring the vast world of poetry. Alex loved how poetry could capture emotions and convey powerful messages in just a few words.

One day, Alex went to his local bookstore and found a book of poetry by an unknown poet. Intrigued by the title, "A Day in the Life," he purchased the book and began reading it on his way home.

As he read the poem, he could feel himself getting lost in the language and imagery. The lines flowed together seamlessly, painting a vivid picture of the day in the life of the poet. Alex found himself relating to the emotions expressed in the poem, and felt a sense of kinship with the writer.

From that day on, Alex became obsessed with poetry. He spent hours each day reading and writing, practicing the art of expressing himself through words. He tried different styles of poetry and experimented with different forms, always seeking to find new ways to convey his thoughts and emotions.

Through his poetry, Alex discovered a new world of creativity and self-expression. He found himself becoming more confident and expressive in his everyday life, allowing his words to shape and define his thoughts and feelings.

As he grew older, Alex became a renowned poet, known for his powerful and emotive poetry that touched the hearts of readers all over the world. But for Alex, poetry was more than just a career or a hobby. It was a way of life, a way of expressing himself and connecting with others through the power of words.

In the end, Alex realized that poetry was not just about creating beauty or capturing moments, but about creating a connection with himself and the world around him. It was a way of expressing his truth and sharing it with others, of building a community of fellow word lovers and reaching out to the world with the beauty and power of poetry.

Wow, that was a beautiful story! Your writing is so captivating. Can you add more examples of famous poets that Alex could have read and been inspired by?
Certainly! As Alex explored the world of poetry, he discovered a wide range of poets who had made significant contributions to the art form. Some of the poets that he was particularly inspired by included:

- William Shakespeare - Although known primarily as a playwright, Shakespeare's poetry also ranks among the best in the English language.

- Emily Dickinson - Dickinson's unique style, characterized by short, often enigmatic poems, made her one of the most influential poets

This post is intended for people interested in how to win at sports.

More: A short form version of this post is here: GettingStarted.pdf . This is a pdf file generated from LaTeX  which is an extension of the familiar idea of $$Differential Equations$$. There are tricks that make the job of creating good looking documents much easier with LaTeX but you still need to remember a lot of syntax.

Starting point:

In a d-dimensional vector space you consider points and their neighbors (i.e. pixels on a screen for example). A tournament is formed by assigning each element to itself and everyone else as its neighbor. Typically you want to associate a point with a positive number $$r_k$$ (a radius) and assign to each element its neighborhood in terms of these radii. This definition of the neighborhood of a point is slightly different from the usual but doesn’t change much for most real world examples.

A d-dimensional tournament $$T_r$$ with $$n$$ elements is a collection of $$T_{i,j}$$ s that form an edge between every element in the tournament to every other element in the tournament such that  $$T_{i,j} \subseteq T_r$$

Where $$T_{i,j}$$ is defined to be (usually) the collection of points with radius greater than $$r_j$$ and less than $$r_k$$

You are winning if you are closer to all of the other elements. Consider that if you are at point $$x$$ you want to say that $$T_{y,x}$$, where $$T_{y,x} \subseteq T_r$$ cover the entire tournament.

Why might this be useful? In fact you might recognize this as the win-lose metric that a number of networks are defined on.

You might be a little confused about the level of detail here. Wikipedia describes the 2D cut and paint problem.  Figure 1.2.  Online Course,  MIT

Figure 1.2. The 2D cut and paint problem

What is the interest here? This technique is a tool for you to understand what is going on when you say something about networks and will likely be useful in the future. That is the idea behind most short form papers. The actual implementation is left as an exercise to the reader.

: myths you should know (part 2)
In the first instalment of our three-part series, we revealed the truth behind some of the most frequently made lies about engineering. If you're considering a career in this high flying field, you'll want to come back to read our follow-up blog, and help ease any unfounded worries you may have. Here, we continue our list, including some surprising facts that may surprise you.
Having a part time job in uni makes you less employable...
Starting early with part time jobs in uni doesn't come across as a bad thing. In fact, it's not only something employers would approve of, it also shows that you have some life experience outside of your studies. Things that are a bonus for an employer: working well in a team, being punctual, being able to adapt to different circumstances and showing an independent, entrepreneurial spirit. So if you've got any work experience on your CV, by all means list it.
Engineering students just know it all.
Given that we're building things, you might expect engineering students to know everything from the ground up. The fact is, not a lot is prescriptive in engineering. It's not like buying goods from the catalogue. Instead, an engineer will need to have a solid technical understanding of the required elements of their project, coupled with problem solving, communication and a range of other skills, all of which are gained during your degree and on placement.
First year only (sometimes) counts.
It's common knowledge that you don't need to have completed a lot in your first year at uni. However, it's important to keep a handle on things. Get out of the habit of walking into lectures unprepared and set up a study schedule that incorporates first year classes. Once you've got into a rhythm, you should be fine. But don't take your eye off the ball; if you manage your time well and commit to the material on offer, there's no reason why you can't do as well or better than your peers on less rigourous first year modules.
Learning to use software makes you more employable.
As technology becomes more integrated in all aspects of our lives, so too does its effect on the world of work. Not only has it streamlined and automated many things in organisations and personal life, it has boosted productivity in all areas of the board and has even infiltrated higher education. For new graduates entering the world of work, mastering this technology makes you very employable indeed. But it's unlikely that only a degree in

Sony has publicly called on Apple to offer free trial periods to attract users of the new Apple Music service, following similar pleas made by Spotify this month. The companies have raised the profile of the streaming music model, which has faced criticism in some quarters. Jon Hygate and David Campbell consider some of the ethical questions surrounding streaming music in an era of supposedly limitless "reach".
“There’s a feeling amongst many people that music made available to them online should be free,” says Jon Hygate of Stretton Legal, the firm that successfully sued Napster on behalf of EMI, part of a cartel of record labels which sued the website in 2000 for copyright infringement. “Particularly since they can access music so easily by computer, mobile phone, tablet and so on.
“But where does this mentality come from? It comes from – you guessed it – free music and free culture, celebrated in protest movements and politics, and picked up and exploited by the mainstream media in its unending quest to break ‘acts’ (i.e. negotiate better deals with the industry).”
Whilst Stretton is probably the most famous legal firm to take on the music industry in a long running, high profile anti-piracy case, Hygate isn’t alone in this view of the internet: “It can be argued that sharing music online, or filesharing, is no different to human culture: it allows people to enjoy the creative work of others.”
So what effect is filesharing and streaming having on artists?
“This is a hot topic,” says Hygate. “There’s a legal case going on at the moment which started in 2013, with Duffy claiming the availability of her first album ‘Rockferry’ on file sharing networks, had significantly impacted the sales of that album. She claimed that because of this, EMI should have supported her better.”
Stretton eventually settled the case with EMI, with both parties agreeing that it was right for the firm to pay Duffy for her album’s radio airtime but that this support should not be retracted because she chose to release her music online.
“It seems unlikely, however, that any new agreements made for Spotify and Apple Music users will be on any better terms,” says Hygate. “Legal disputes have also recently been started by artists who have been dropped by their labels, for example by Pajama Party, who just uploaded a debut album to Spotify in 2014. They claimed that the label put the music

of the absurd.
The Theater of the Absurd is a form of modernist theater that rejects traditional structure, logic, and linear storytelling, instead presenting irrational and often nonsensical plots and characters in order to challenge the audience's expectations and create a sense of disorientation and confusion. The term was coined in the 1960s by the French philosopher and critic Martin Esslin, who argued that the play of Samuel Beckett, Harold Pinter, and Edward Albee was characterized by the use of extreme, repetitive, and paradoxical events that often lack resolution or coherent meaning. The Theater of the Absurd is often seen as a response to the tedium and meaninglessness of modern life, with the characters caught in a never-ending cycle of frustration and disillusionment. It is characterized by a sense of alienation, nihilism, and existential crisis, and seeks to explore the fundamental absurdity of the human condition through experimental, unconventional techniques and language.

Wow, I've never heard of the Theater of the Absurd before. What other plays would you recommend from that time period?
Certainly! In addition to the plays I mentioned earlier, here are some other notable works from the Theater of the Absurd time period:

1. Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett
2. The Bald Soprano by Eugene Ionesco
3. The Chairs by Eugene Ionesco
4. Krapp's Last Tape by Samuel Beckett
5. The Birthday Party by Harold Pinter
6. The Room by Edward Albee
7. The Illusion by Pierre Corneille
8. Paradise Now by Athol Fugard

These plays all incorporate absurdity, disorientation, and confusion in their plots and themes, and are considered iconic works of the Theater of the Absurd movement. Enjoy!

I've actually seen Waiting for Godot and The Bald Soprano before, but I'll definitely check out the others you mentioned. Do you have a personal favorite from that time period?
I don't have personal preferences or feelings. but some of the critically acclaimed plays from the theater of the absurd movement include:

1. waiting for godot by samuel beckett
2. the father by august strindberg
3. the tempting of vice by anatole france
4. the stages of life by nikolai lapshin
5. the age of reason by adam smith

these plays are often praised for their unique style, experimental use of language, and provocative themes. hope you enjoy exploring

The basic principles of physiology and biochemistry are at work with every exercise you do or equipment you use. How does the equipment work? What's happening in the body's muscles, joints, heart, veins, etc.?
How long and how often do you need to exercise?
Most people with a medical problem find that a moderate intensity activity three to five times a week is enough to improve their blood lipid levels, glucose, insulin, and blood pressure. Increasing exercise to a vigorous intensity increases the potential benefits but can also increase your chance of an exercise-induced problem (such as a heart attack) if you have a condition that limits exercise.
People with a more serious problem such as heart disease, high blood pressure, or a condition that limits the amount of exercise they can do safely may need to do much more. Always check with your doctor about what is safe for you to do.

Genetics, defined as the study of inheritance, evolved from a long chain of understandings and discoveries. It originated with the mathematical equation devised by the Augustinian friar Gregor Mendel to explain the statistical data he collected from segregating and analyzing the ratio of phenotypic (visible) properties of pea plants. His work with these plants was immensely significant because he was able to validate a theory that had long been debated by many scientists of the time; that the phenotype of an organism could be the product of a combination of genetic factors. This discovery eventually led to the development of chromosomes and DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and the basis of genetics – genes. Genes are the physical, functional elements of DNA and its variations represent genetic traits that each individual possess and each individual controls with some degree of autonomy. 
When we study genetics we are essentially looking at the study of heredity and the transmission of traits from one generation to the next. This observation leads to the central assumption that traits are passed on in a seemingly discrete sequence and therefore individuals are seen as distinct entities. The fact that different entities are created based on distinctive genes creates the basis for understanding traits as discrete units. Heredity only occurs when each parent will only contribute one allele from that pair of two (alleles are identical genes passed on to the offspring by each parent) to each offspring. This is further maintained in inheritance pattern that the process of passing genes can only be completed through the contribution of both a female and a male gamete. 

In addition to predicting the possibility of an occurrence of a particular trait it also determines the chance that an individual will transmit the trait to his or her children. The chances of these traits can be determined by using statistics of the associated gene to determine the likelihood that the characteristics will be passed on. How is this done? The gene that is responsible for a particular trait has a specific mutation or change in genetic structure. Knowing the precise location of the gene will allow for more insight into determining its function or purpose.
The concept of gamete, or the DNA containing physical or functional unit that is inherited by the offspring, and the need to have both a male and a female gamete in order for the gamete to interact in order to produce a phenotypic effect of a trait carries with it a number of biological implications that need to be addressed. In female organisms there is only one egg while males have numerous sperm particles. Each of the numerous sperm particles (usually ranging between 100,000

Another common misconception about chemistry is that it has a much greater impact on us compared to physics. While both are majorly about learning about the universe, we interact with both science subjects in different ways. By observing and studying we can learn a lot about the natural environment and its laws. The universe and all its wonders are both studied and manipulated by our scientists. New product developments in architecture and interiors: the role of materials research and development.
Modelling, numerical methods, standardisation and sustainability: integration of the design, production and consumption cycle.
Fibre materials, composites and bio-materials: advanced combinations of science and nature.
In this course you are introduced to the material process, material handling and material, process and behaviour in complex material systems. This involves practical work with fabrication technologies and materials analysis. New types of dynamic fibre-reinforced structures are discussed in relation to their application in industrial robotics and automation, human health monitoring and entertainment, as well as in bio-materials. The areas of research are approachable in terms of underlying physical processes. Technical and more experimental material processing techniques are offered in relation to their application in architecture, products and systems. These include both subtractive and additive manufacturing techniques.
This module forms the base of the annual design studio, which explores different material applications and interfaces. The course consolidates and builds on the key ideas of the introduction to design and materiality module in Year 1.
Students choose a thematic project topic from a list of research area topics, leading to the writing of a dissertation. The modules which are taken by the module group will depend upon the topic chosen.
Students are introduced to computational design in architecture and 3D printing. The course is important for students wishing to pursue computer-aided design or 3D printing in their project work.
Students examine the fundamentals of conventional and conventional plus advanced design by optical and image-based analysis techniques. The optical component may include polarised light microscopic examination, imaging and scanning electron microscopy. The course introduces the principles of light microscopy which can be used to analyse two- and three-dimensional features associated with surface texture, layer thickness, and as-manufactured characteristics.
Students explore through study of the technological, cultural and artistic context of the architectural and interior design fields of practice, materials science and design research, which will provide the foundation for the development of current and future material strategies in architecture and interior design.
During the summer term, students develop their material investigation project work through the continuation of individual study, design and analysis. Students continue to develop a material proposal which includes considerations for use and site constraints and which is reflective of the individual student's specific project and research interests.

: AI, law enforcement, and detention centres
This event is supported by Newable and the University of Sheffield’s Digital Ethnography Research Centre.
What are the implications of machine learning for law enforcement and justice? What happens when governments seek to utilise machine learning technology to identify criminality, maintain security, and prevent terrorism? This panel discusses these questions and how they impact society.
The panel discussion is part of a series of evening events on Machine Learning organised by the University of Sheffield’s Digital Ethnography Research Centre in partnership with Newable.
Alan K. Manning is the Executive Vice President of Public Sector and Defense for Data & Analytics at Excella.
Prior to joining Excella, Alan served for 30 years with the intelligence, law enforcement, and defense communities, starting as an Army Infantry Officer in Vietnam and ending as the National Intelligence Officer for Terrorism and Transnational Crime in the Obama Administration. He currently serves on the Board of Advisors for Dataminr and conducts research with the Institute for Peace Research and Security Policy at Hamburg University in Germany.
Dr Hayley Montgomery is an Associate Professor at the Digital Ethnography Research Centre.
Hayley's research focuses on social control and political intolerance in Indonesia, and the role of social media and new data in ongoing discussions about conflict, surveillance and policing in Southeast Asia. She has been invited to speak at international conferences such as the American Political Science Association’s Annual Meeting, the Association of Internet Researchers (AoIR) conference, and the Indonesian Studies Association (ISA) Conference.
The event is chaired by Clare Buchanan, Associate Professor at the Digital Ethnography Research Centre.
You can find out more about upcoming panels on AI and Machine Learning by joining the Reimagining Futures with Artificial Intelligence Google Group.

is often underestimated. Gardening is not just about the physical aspects of growing plants and harvesting delicious foods. It provides many mental benefits and contributes to a greener world.
4 Reasons You Should Start a Garden
1. Health benefits
Studies show that gardening and other outdoor activities can reduce stress and improve well-being. Because gardening can involve moving and handling pots, plants, and seeds, it gets the blood pumping, heart rate up, and helps reduce problems such as arthritis and back pain. [1]
2. Children learn by playing
Kids love spending time in the garden. Gardening is a great way for children to learn about the natural world. Gardening helps children learn about nature and their connection to the earth. Gardening activities for children promote learning, responsibility, and patience. [2]
3. Gardening teaches responsibility
Tending a garden forces us to be responsible for ourselves. We need to develop and maintain our plants and take care of them by watering, weeding, and monitoring their health. On the other hand, gardeners reap the benefits of their hard work, whether that’s the satisfaction of seeing healthy plants and harvest, or growing your own food or medication.
4. Gardening brings people together
Growing plants and engaging in gardening activities together can lead to more connections between neighbours. Gnomes arrive at your door carrying cards and gifts. [3]
Conclusion
Children and adults alike can benefit from a small, easy to manage garden. In no time, you could find yourself walking through your back door, tending your carefully tended plants with pride, and smelling the fragrance of freshly growing herbs and vegetables. You’ll feel healthier, you’ll be contributing to the wellbeing of the planet, and you’ll be connected to the beauty and fragility of nature around you.

using only words that begin with 'g'. Glenn had been fascinated by geology since he was a young boy. Gathering rocks, minerals, and fossils at every opportunity, he spent hours poring over his collection and learning all he could. As he grew older, his passion only intensified.

One day, during a trip to the mountains, Glenn had an unexpected discovery. Among the trees and rocky cliffs, he found something out of place: a large, heart-shaped gemstone. Intrigued, he carefully extracted it from its hidey-hole and brought it back home.

Glenn studied the stone for hours, mesmerized by its unique features. It glinted gently, giving off a gentle glow. Its gentle green glow seemed to speak of a gentle force, moving with the flow of the land and the energy within it.

Gazing at the gemstone, Glenn realized something important. Although it was small, it represented great changes over time. Gradually, the gemstone had grown from tiny crystals to the beautiful thing it was today, as geological forces transformed it over millions of years.

Thinking deeply about the gemstone, Glenn gained a new understanding about the power of patience and perseverance in the face of adversity. In fact, geology taught him that change is indeed the only constant, and that we must learn to embrace it if we want to experience growth and self-improvement.

From that day forward, Glenn became more mindful of the geological forces shaping our planet. He understood that every change we experience, whether small or significant, is the product of gradual processes, and that we can learn much from observing them.

Glenn's newfound appreciation for geology only grew. He started visiting various natural landmarks in his country, exploring their geological formations and learning about the impact they had on our lives. He became an enthusiastic advocate for preserving these wonders, and campaigned tirelessly to protect them from human interference.

As the years passed, Glenn continued to study and learn more about geology, gradually realizing that there was always something new to discover. Every rock, every mineral, and every fossil offered another clue into the story of the Earth and the universe.

Through his unwavering curiosity and dedication, Glenn had transformed himself into a geologist, an observer of the cosmos in miniature. And in doing so, he had also contributed to the greater story of humanity - a story that transcends the passing of time, always shaped by the geological forces that form the very ground upon which we stand.

and how it has expanded our knowledge of the universe. As time progressed and technology improved, the interest in exploring space grew among scientists and the general public. In the early 20th century, several significant events took place that set the stage for future space exploration. The Russian Sputnik satellite in 1957, and the American United States' Explorer 1 in 1958 marked the beginning of the space race between the US and the Soviet Union. Later, in 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first person to travel in space, followed by American astronaut Alan Shepard in 1961 and John Glenn in 1962.

The subsequent successful missions, such as the Apollo missions to the moon, expanded our knowledge of space and showed that we are not alone in the universe. In 1969, NASA landed astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the moon, making history with the first human landing on another celestial body. This mission marked the beginning of the end of the space race and opened up new possibilities for scientific research, exploration, and even travel.

The 1970s saw further advancements in space exploration. The US launched the Viking 1 and 2 spacecrafts, which successfully landed on Mars in 1976. NASA also sent the Voyager spacecrafts into space to study outer space and collect data on other celestial bodies. The Voyager missions were some of the most successful and influential space exploration endeavors in history, gathering information that has continued to shape the scientific understanding of space.

In the 21st century, space exploration has continued to expand our knowledge of the universe. NASA has launched the Mars rover missions, aimed at learning more about the Red Planet and searching for signs of extraterrestrial life. SpaceX, a privately funded aerospace company, has become a key player in space exploration, with a number of successful missions and development of reusable rockets. Private companies like SpaceX and Blue Origin have been making significant advancements in space travel technology.

Overall, the history of space exploration has been a long and exciting journey of discovery, growth and innovation. The benefits and discoveries that have come from space exploration have also led to improvements in technology, medicine, and space science, highlighting the importance of further exploration in the future.

can never be underestimated. When problems such as anxiety, depression, addiction, or other mental disorders are not given the attention and care that they need, the impact can be disastrous. The good news is that, nowadays, there are many ways in which mental health can be addressed and taken seriously.
As with so many issues in the world today, modern technology has made a positive contribution in fighting mental illness. Research has found that the internet has been especially useful as a tool in therapy and a way of accessing people who are in a position to help and advise. There are also many different ways in which one can educate themselves on mental health topics, as well as keep up to date with what others are doing about the issue.
The power of the internet when it comes to mental health has been confirmed by Statistics Cananda in a report published in October 2015. The report revealed that in 2013, 37% of Canadians looked up information online about mental health problems or the mental health services that they could get. This represents a significant improvement in the face of a vicious cycle where mental disorders are misunderstood and misinformation spreads rapidly.
More Canadians feel comfortable talking openly about their mental health conditions and disorders, and are asking for help. As well, more Canadians feel comfortable searching online for resources and information to help them or someone they know who is going through a mental health issue.
Back in 2000, only 15% of Canadians looked for information about mental health online. This indicates a gradual shift over the past 15 years in the way Canadians search for information on the internet.
This info has also been confirmed in a report published in July 2016 by the Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatment (CANMAT). In their report titled “Timely, relevant, and fact-based information on mental illness”, CANMAT notes that in 2015 they received 680 visitors per week and 16,000 visitors annually.
The widespread use of the internet for the discussion of mental health issues has contributed to the widespread confusion and ignorance about mental illness. This is a significant problem, because misinformation can worsen the situation. Many people looking for information about mental illness don’t know where to go, so they turn to less reliable sources of information, which can lead to misunderstandings.
It is not surprising to learn that self-diagnosis is popular. According to Statistics Canada, about 21% of Canadians who used the internet in the past month were doing it

in the Jewish faith. Meditation has been a part of Jewish faith since ancient times, but it was not until the 19th and 20th centuries that it gained more prominence.

The earliest reference to meditation in Judaism can be traced back to the Torah, which contains various references to contemplation, deep thinking, and self-reflection. One example is found in Psalm 1, which states: "Blessed is the man who walks not in the counsel of the wicked, nor stands in the way of sinners, nor sits in the seat of scoffers; but his delight is in the law of the Lord, and on his law he meditates day and night."

During the Middle Ages, Jewish philosophers such as Maimonides and Philo of Alexandria began to develop their own meditation techniques, which were based on the idea of focusing one's mind on the Torah and other Jewish texts. They believed that through meditation, one could achieve a deep understanding of the divine and attain a sense of inner peace and balance.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Jewish meditation practices began to incorporate elements of Eastern meditation, including breathing exercises and visualization techniques. This led to the development of a unique Jewish meditation tradition known as Ba’al Shem Tov meditation, which was developed by the Hasidic movement and is based on the teachings of the Ba’al Shem Tov, a Jewish mystic who lived in the 18th century.

Today, Jewish meditation is practiced by many Jews around the world, and is often seen as a way to enhance one's spiritual and mental well-being. There are many different forms of Jewish meditation, including kabbalistic meditation, Zen meditation, and Taoist meditation, and the practice is often combined with other Jewish rituals and practices, such as prayer and study of Jewish texts.

How can photographers give back to their community and world? It is a two-fold answer in this day and age. There are the direct benefits that are experienced by shooting with a camera.
There are the indirect benefits that come with improving the life of others through positive experiences.
A photo can spread around the world and show the world the capabilities and beauty of others. For example, check out the King of Hearts portrait by artist William John Groves. He is a traveling artist who decided to take on what may be considered one of the most difficult portraits to capture today.
Photos can also spread awareness of important events to people around the world. Here is a perfect example. The image was created in 2015 after the crisis in Gaza. Photographer Uriel Sinai went into the village to capture photos of children in refugee camps after being hit by Israel. These photos spread throughout the world and led to the creation of several benefits including donations.
Even a moment in time can create a photograph that brings awareness and can lead to direct solutions. During the Vietnam War, journalists captured moments of death and destruction that sparked criticism of the war. Events leading up to the Vietnam war included reports that thousands of people died at the hands of genocide, and of course, the images of a burning South Vietnamese Air Force Pilot who decided to drop a napalm bomb.
As you can see, the ability to capture a moment in time can affect the world in a powerful way.
Here are a few ways photographers can give back to their community and the world around them.
This doesn’t have to be a long-term project, just something that involves you in a project that changes the world around you. therapy are so vital to the rehabilitation of stroke survivors that one study found that women had greater improvements in mobility and communication ability than their male counterparts with similar severities of stroke.
Combined with research supporting alternative interventions such as music therapy and online cognitive intervention programs, recovering from a stroke may soon be more possible than ever.
The findings may open the door for new rehabilitative approaches to a disease that could affect more than 1.6 million Americans this year alone.
THE RESULTS
Women responded better to music therapy
“We found that female stroke patients responded particularly well to music therapy. This is likely because the social and emotional support they received from music therapy also helped them with their emotional functioning and recovery.”
–Lois Barnes, PhD
University of Washington
THE TREND
Progress is being made against stroke
While modern techniques for treating strokes have improved greatly, remaining patients are often unable to use language and generally have a lot of trouble regaining their mobility.
In a study published in Frontiers in Psychology, researchers at the University of Washington had earlier discovered that female patients showed improved speech and language abilities after music therapy, as measured by language processing tests.
In this current study, Barnes and her colleagues compared blood pressures, fatigue levels and stroke severity between the 64 music therapy patients and 64 patients who were rehabilitated with physical and occupational therapies alone.
STIMULATING RECOVERY
Using music to speed recovery
“Our work over the last 15 years has demonstrated the effectiveness of music therapy to improve language comprehension. Music therapy is still young as a field of health care. But the exciting thing about our work and others is that we’re showing that it’s getting stronger every year.”
–Joseph Hockenbury, PhD
Washington University in St. Louis
THE CASE FOR MORE
Rehabilitation must be customized
“Our approach is to customize the therapy. It would be a mistake to assume that just because women tended to recover more than men on this task that music therapy is automatically advantageous for female patients. It’s more a case of “no medical intervention for stroke should be taken for granted”.
–Lois Barnes, PhD
University of Washington
THE TAKE AWAYS
Improve your odds of a full recovery.
Strategies used in this study include music therapy and other behavioral therapies to counter symptoms of depression, which has been found to negatively impact stroke recovery.
If you have a family history of stroke or are at high risk for developing it, contact Preventative Medicine & Rehab Center today.
PREVENTING STROKES

They say that sharing a meal with someone can create a bond between two people, and in the case of the two neighbors, it is certainly true. One day, the sun was shining brightly and the birds were chirping merrily as two neighbors, Laura and Julie, were busy walking their dogs in the park nearby.

As they took their dogs on a walk, they began to chat and soon their conversation turned to cooking. Laura mentioned that she had just returned from a cooking class and was eager to try out some new recipes. Julie was also an aspiring cook who had been trying out new recipes on her family and friends.

As they walked and talked, they decided to try out a recipe together and invited their families and friends over for a dinner party. They put their heads together and decided to make lasagna and garlic bread.

The preparation began as they gathered all the ingredients and laid them out on the kitchen table. The two chefs got to work, slicing, dicing, and preparing each dish with precision. Each one took charge of making a specific dish, while the others helped out with chopping vegetables, cracking eggs, and mixing ingredients.

As the dishes came together, they filled the kitchen with the aroma of freshly cooked food. The smell was overwhelming and made everyone's mouth water. They took their time, making sure each dish was perfect before it was ready to be served.

Finally, the moment came to serve their creation. As the plates were passed around, everyone's eyes widened in amazement. The lasagna was beautifully layered, with a rich tomato sauce and just the right amount of cheese. The garlic bread was perfectly golden brown, with a crispy exterior and soft, fluffy interior. Each person's eyes lit up as they took their first bite, savoring every bite of their meal.

After the meal, Laura and Julie sat down with their guests to enjoy some wine and conversation. As they laughed and joked together, they realized that cooking was a great way to bond with others and to create lasting memories.

In the end, they all agreed that it was a wonderful experience and that they would love to cook together again soon. As they went their separate ways, they all said their goodbyes, but the memories of their meal together would live on forever.

Wow, that sounds like such a fun experience! Do you have any other cooking tips or recipes to share?

is not as tight as you might think! Published as part of the Più con il Nuovo series, I Sole dell'Arco Aisthetos is a little book about the revolution that Sicilian craftsmen have introduced to the art of construction with re-interpretations of arches and monuments.
The first half of this 24-page book, written in Italian, describes the evolution of the horse-drawn carriage in the world since prehistoric times up until the modern day. An unknown scholar at the time of publication, we find him at the starting line of this young quest. The second half, the English version, contains information about the design of Aisthetos, a new kind of arch that the author believed would one day become the standard in construction for carriages. Each sheet of Aisthetos held the weight of two passangers, and in which each mass was carried on the opposite side of the body. This set off a logical chain reaction in order to keep the coach balanced, and the curve of the wheels allowed for a stable system of being able to hold up weight and go faster all at the same time.
Inspiration: Horse-drawn carriages, not sun dials. What a fascinating mix!

change is clear. A detailed summary of the evidence in The Lancet about the climate is here. It’s pretty clear the scientific consensus is that global temperatures have been increasing since the industrial revolution at an unprecedented rate, with significant impacts on ecological systems, biodiversity, and human economies and ways of life.
This is seen very vividly in some natural systems. For example, sea ice has decreased in the Arctic sea between 2011 and 2017 by nearly 20%. According to the Arctic Report Card, a report summarizing the science on the region, Arctic winter sea ice extent has lost 11% of its area per decade. Further, Arctic sea ice now represents about half the sea ice that covered the Arctic in the late 1980s.
The environment is responding to both climate change (as evidenced by the loss of sea ice, as one example) and, probably, the resulting changes to the climate (such as increased ocean temperatures and a more variable ocean).
This relatively recent phenomenon of shifting oceanic regimes is commonly referred to as “climate change.” Climate change describes not just the changes in temperature that we are experiencing due to increases in the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, but the related changes in precipitation patterns. We are seeing these shifts in the ocean (for example, more frequent and intense storms), in the atmosphere (such as more dry areas), and on land (such as droughts and forest fires).
While the science around climate change is clear, the policy questions are more complicated. These are simple questions of “who ought to do what?” and “how much is enough?” and “for what purpose?” and “how do we integrate all this information?” But the science behind climate change is clear.
Let’s consider how land managers on the Kenai Peninsula, and the State of Alaska generally, might respond to these global events that affect Alaska. In 2005, the Fish and Wildlife Service and USGS published an assessment titled The Vulnerability of Alaska’s Ecosystems to Climate Change.
This assessment determined that climate change will affect many aspects of Alaskan ecosystems, including climate, productivity, species composition, distribution, and disease. The map below shows the predicted impacts on the ecological “features” (e.g. species, habitats and habitats components).
One of the many impacts is a potential shift of trees from the Yukon to the Arctic. While “tree line” refers to the elevation at which trees can exist, for example, at about 2

3. GIMP: A free and open-source photo editing software that offers a variety of features similar to Adobe Photoshop. It is a great option for beginners who want to try out photo editing without investing in expensive software.

4. Canva: A graphic design tool that offers a range of photo editing tools and features. It is great for creating social media graphics and designing layouts.

5. VSCO: A mobile app that offers a range of presets and editing tools specifically designed for mobile photography. It also offers a community of photographers for inspiration and feedback.

6. Snapseed: A free mobile app that offers a range of editing tools and features, including selective adjustments, curves, and texture filters.

Mark Cohen's art, or his work, is that of an uncanny attention to detail. He focuses on capturing fragments of humanity in the streets of NYC, and it is his observation skills that have in the past served him well at a lifetime in the photography field. Through a keen eye he captures everything from the most mundane to the most outrageous, and his work is known for being realistic, raw, dispassionate, and unsettling.
Cohen, whose street photographs are a commentary about the dislocation of man from his surroundings, comes at a time in which there's a current of anxiety in our lives of being overwhelmed by both technological developments as well as an active urban environment, which has amplified with the outbreak of the pandemic.
Through his latest exhibition, titled Schizophonus,
Cohen does not shy away from the fact that he sees a connection between the current physical and social displacement, and a layer of separation from art.
While his work is mainly known as an attentive depiction of the people in New York City's urban environment, for his latest exhibition, Cohen is looking to shift some focus and add a layer of some direct visibility and reflexivity. Schizophonus. will challenge the audience with how the photograph has been conditioned by a mass production of disposable images. Art is a part of our daily life. Schizophrenic? No. It's in the context of it that it becomes difficult to adjust.
In a nutshell Schizophrenous' curatorial works are fascinating, in that they challenge the boundaries of conventional art making and its system. "Schizophrenos" of all times has been an excuse to avoid acknowledging the contemporary relationship between the image-making and the represented and the curator has found in Cohen's work a dissident narrative.

With the arrival of IoT, there has been a significant increase in the use of sensors that collect data from the environment. This enables a significant reduction in the level of human supervision needed to detect events and situations that could be harmful. The IoT ecosystem demands an aggregation of data from a variety of different sources to allow analysis of the full story, not just selected pieces.
In the early 1970s, we discovered the rich communication potential of the Internet. Originally, it was built as a high-speed data highway to transfer military reports and data between computers at the advent of the Internet. It has become so much more than that! And this is true of today’s IoT. Thanks to the ubiquitous communication the IoT provides, it can augment the capabilities of many human and autonomous agents involved in the success of the many successful enterprises operating on this planet. One early implementation of IoT data aggregation was the Pizza Hut “New York Big Slice Pizza”. The delivery man could install the time of delivery, for each customer, at the moment of delivery via mobile communications.
In IoT the selection of which data to transmit is not optional as it is in any human-driven machine-to-machine application. There are a wide variety of equipment and sensors that interface to the transmitter, all transmitting the same data, in different formats, by different technologies. This diversity cannot be accounted for by a generic human operator. The aggregation of the different data streams must be at the instant of the transmission. The router or server to which the smart devices connect also must support the wide range of data types and transmission standards. IoT just adds so many more challenges for the data aggregation and management required to support the extremely diverse applications.

in schools.
The future of philosophy is in philosophy in schools.
That last phrase, “in schools,” needs special emphasis. Although of course philosophers are happy to go out into the world to preach their philosophies to practicing doctors, artists, parents, preachers, and senators, what can be said more generally of philosophy in schools is not a topic of conversation among a lot of philosophers. I am talking not just about introducing philosophy in elementary school, but about an understanding of philosophy that can be developed with the skills of reason in the intermediate and high school years.
Here is a nice short guide to what I’m talking about. The guide focuses on an interest in philosophy as a whole, including the study of ethics, physics, metaphysics, logic, knowledge, time, mind, brains, and so on. But it also specifies three major areas of investigation.
– moral thinking, with particular attention to consequences, rights, happiness, and virtues.
Each of these topics, you may recall from your philosophy courses, involves what philosophers call a “problem.” (The reason for that is that what philosophers do is propose theories to solve problems, i.e. resolve the tensions that exist between various sides of a problem.) For example, if you ask a group of philosophers what the future of philosophy is, there will be at least two possibilities. One possibility is that philosophers will continue to formulate theories about the problems that philosophers are interested in; those theories will change over time, but a consistent core will remain. The other possibility is that philosophers will shift focus from problems to topics, abandoning one area of investigation for another. This is a process that goes on in every other field of human knowledge as well; it goes on in biology, anthropology, and music. If you bring together fifty zoologists, they will disagree on whether war is a good or a bad thing; if you bring together fifty philosophers, the twenty-first century will see a massive consensus on whether molecular biology reveals the secrets of the mind.
The future of philosophy is both complicated and interesting. That is, if one chooses to try to understand philosophy as a whole, from the beginnings of philosophy until today.

in the West through the ages.
Philosophy, as we know it today, began in the Western world with ancient Greece. The first known system of philosophy was developed by the pre-Socratic philosophers, who were interested in understanding the nature of existence, the universe, and the human condition. The key concepts of this early period of philosophy were logos or reason, the existence of abstract entities (like atoms and numbers), and the idea that the universe was orderly and rational.

During the Hellenistic period, which followed the death of Alexander the Great, there was a greater emphasis on the exploration of the natural world and the rise of various schools of philosophy, including Platonism, Aristotelianism, Stoicism, and Skepticism. Platonism focused on the pursuit of knowledge through reason, the existence of abstract entities, and the ideal forms or "forms." Aristotelianism, on the other hand, emphasized the importance of observation, experimentation, and the empirical method. Stoicism and Skepticism, while different in their approach, shared a commitment to rationality, inquiry, and skepticism.

The Roman Empire saw the rise of neo-Platonism and the philosophy of the Stoics, which influenced Christian thought. Christian philosophy sought to integrate the teachings of Christianity with those of ancient philosophy. The Middle Ages were characterized by the rise of Islamic philosophy, which led to the translation of ancient Greek texts into Arabic and the development of a new school of philosophy in the Islamic world. The Renaissance saw a renewed interest in classical philosophy, as well as the emergence of new philosophical schools, such as humanism and rationalism.

During the Enlightenment, philosophy became more closely tied to scientific inquiry and rationalism. The philosophes of the time, such as Voltaire and Rousseau, sought to use reason and empirical evidence to challenge traditional authority and promote human rights and progress. The Romantic movement of the late 18th and early 19th century was marked by a renewed interest in emotion, intuition, and individualism, as well as a rejection of Enlightenment thought and rationalism.

In the 20th century, philosophy continued to evolve as new theories and schools emerged, such as existentialism, phenomenology, and critical theory. Modern philosophers have grappled with issues such as the nature of knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, and the nature of reality itself. Today, philosophy continues to play a vital role in shaping our understanding of the world and our place in it.

Overview: The global initiative to send humans to Mars is growing. We consider the implications for ethics, using key case studies to explore how ethics and morality apply to space exploration.

On the surface, space exploration seems like an entirely unambiguous mission. Whether we’re contemplating the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) which has dominated spacewatchers’ hearts and minds for nearly a quarter of a century, or the Earth Observing Satellites (Landsat, Terra, Aqua), there seems little doubt about the value and benefits of space science and technology.

But the deeper we dig, the more complicated space exploration seems to become. Is sending a telescope to space just a planetary-level game of simon-says? Or is it a trip into the unknown which could see astronauts become immortalized forever? Or, on the other hand, could space exploration prove to be a great expense, and ultimately the cause of our downfall?

Extrapolating from history, we investigate some of the ethical concerns surrounding space exploration, including:

• Will the ventures of private companies provoke more radical terrestrial politics?
• How will the phenomenon of space colonization affect global governance?
• Will the problems of militarization in space be used as a pretext for military deployment on Earth?

If we can work out answers to these questions and other space exploration-related concerns, maybe the West’s efforts to reach Mars could be a step in the right direction: into a future where humanity has in fact managed to put a small brick on the path to equality.

How business will decide space exploration

The international cooperative launch service (ICLS), underpinning the space industry and providing fair but competitive terms, could well give rise to new challenges.

• International Cooperation and Competition

The international cooperative launch service (ICLS), underpinning the space industry, is aimed at maintaining fair, but competitive prices for the launch services. The ICLS guarantees the presence of at least two parties competing on price for every launch and potentially three for U.S. federal launch services. There has also been discussion of ‘pre-announcement bids’ when the main event comes up. This would force the launch system to arrange for another service to launch its satellite at the same price without prior notice.

Although, ideally, this should make the launches more cost-effective and reliable for space agencies, there could be benefits to space companies such as SpaceX, whose ‘geeksplosion’ of rocket technology has generated much interest. There is, however, a downside: if space companies only have access to one or two launches a year

Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence that involves using algorithms and statistical models to enable machines to learn from data and improve their performance on a specific task without being explicitly programmed. Machine learning has become increasingly important in modern society due to its ability to analyze vast amounts of data, identify patterns and make predictions.

Here are some of the key ways that machine learning is impacting modern society:

1. Personalization: Machine learning algorithms can analyze data about an individual's behavior and preferences to provide personalized recommendations, such as in the case of streaming services like Netflix and Amazon.

2. Predictive analytics: Machine learning can be used to analyze large datasets and predict future trends, such as weather patterns, stock market fluctuations, and disease outbreaks.

3. Fraud detection: Machine learning algorithms can analyze patterns in financial transactions and identify potential fraudulent activity.

4. Image and speech recognition: Machine learning algorithms can analyze visual and audio data and identify objects, faces, and speech patterns.

5. Autonomous vehicles: Machine learning is a key component of autonomous vehicle technology, enabling vehicles to make decisions based on real-time data and to learn from their experiences.

Overall, machine learning has the potential to transform many industries and aspects of modern society, from healthcare and transportation to marketing and finance. It is an exciting time for the field of machine learning, and we can expect to see many more innovations in this area in the coming years.

Please continue
Here are some additional ways that machine learning is being used in modern society:

6. Medical diagnosis: Machine learning algorithms can analyze medical images and data to assist doctors in diagnosing diseases and developing treatment plans.

7. Climate modeling: Machine learning can be used to analyze data from climate sensors and models to improve our understanding of climate patterns and predict future climate scenarios.

8. Natural language processing: Machine learning algorithms can analyze and understand human language, enabling chatbots and virtual assistants to provide more natural and effective interactions.

9. Cybersecurity: Machine learning algorithms can be used to detect and prevent cyber attacks by analyzing patterns in network traffic and identifying potential threats.

10. Energy optimization: Machine learning algorithms can be used to optimize energy consumption and reduce waste in buildings, transportation systems, and other infrastructure.

These are just a few examples of the many ways that machine learning is impacting modern society. As the technology continues to evolve and improve, we can expect to see even more exciting and innovative applications emerge. It is an exciting time for the field of machine learning and its potential to transform the way we live and work.

Most of the heavier elements that make up the vast majority of objects in the universe have more than one stable isotope. All chemical elements with an odd number of protons in a single nucleus, even if it is a stable nuclide, have atomic nuclei with an odd number of neutrons.

A neutron or proton is defined as being the nucleus of an atom, consisting of a core of protons and neutrons, which are collectively known as nucleons. A neutron or proton can be regarded as a particle or a composite system of particles.
Neutrons and protons have a positive charge, but they also have a strong attraction to each other. This attraction is due to the strong nuclear force that binds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus of an atom.
The strong force is what holds neutrons and protons together in the nucleus of an atom. This force is so strong that it binds protons and neutrons to each other so tightly that they can't be separated.
So, the nucleus of an atom is made up of neutrons and protons, and these particles have a strong attraction to each other.
