and its impact on understanding the brain. Neuroscience is the scientific study of the nervous system, including the brain. It involves exploring how the brain functions, the mechanisms behind its operation, the structure of nerve cells and their interaction with one another, and how the nervous system communicates with other organs and systems. Neuroscience seeks to understand the brain's behavior, cognition, behavior, emotions, and diseases related to it.

Understanding the brain has been a long-standing goal of scientists, and with the development of new technologies such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), brain scans, and other imaging techniques, the field has progressed greatly. Neuroscience has played a crucial role in understanding a range of brain disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, depression, and schizophrenia. It has also provided insights into the structure and function of the brain and its impact on behavior and cognition.

One of the most significant impacts of neuroscience has been the development of new treatments for brain disorders. For example, the development of antidepressants and other drugs that target neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and dopamine, has revolutionized the treatment of depression. In addition, neurosurgery has been used to treat conditions such as epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, and severe mental disorders, saving millions of lives each year.

Overall, neuroscience has transformed our understanding of the brain and the nervous system. It has provided a detailed understanding of how the brain works, and how the brain can be manipulated to treat and manage neurological disorders. Neuroscience continues to provide new insights into how we think, feel, and act, paving the way for even greater discoveries in the future.

Can you provide some examples of how neuroscience has impacted the world of education? Certainly! Neuroscience has had a significant impact on the world of education. Here are some examples:

1. Understanding the brain's plasticity: Neuroscience has shed light on the brain's ability to adapt and change throughout life. This knowledge has been used to develop interventions aimed at improving cognitive skills and academic performance. 2. Enhancing memory: Neuroscience has helped researchers develop techniques to improve memory. One example is the use of mnemonic devices and strategies, which can be taught to students to help them remember information more effectively. 3. Improving learning and academic performance: Studies have shown that certain teaching methods, such as the use of multisensory learning, can enhance learning and academic performance. Neuroscience can help educators to design and implement effective educational practices. 4. Developing personalized education: Neuroscience can help educators identify the strengths and weaknesses of students, allowing for personalized education plans

is generally aimed at attempting to discover where in the mind cognitive processes such as perception, attention, memory, learning, and decision making take place. The subfields of cognitive psychology have been instrumental in the development of the cognitive theory, cognitive behavior therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy, psycho-cybernetics, and cognitive restructuring. The field is divided into areas of cognitive neuroscience and cognitive psychology. The field of neuropsychology is a cross-section of cognitive neuroscience and cognitive psychology. In addition to this divide, cognitive psychology has also included evolutionary psychology and cultural psychology. 

Question: What is Cognitive Psychology?
Cognitive Psychology is the study of mental processes such as perception, attention, memory, learning, and decision making[1][3]. It is a subfield of psychology that studies mental processes such as learning, thinking, and remembering[3][4][5], and it investigates questions such as the following: How does the mind work? How do mental processes help us think, remember, and learn?[4]. Cognitive psychology emerged from other movements such as behaviorism, but the majority of the problems under investigation in cognitive psychology have little to do with these foundations and follow instead from the growing interest in mental processes as concepts, perceptions, thoughts, ideas, memories, and so on[4].

It doesn't take long for a catastrophic event such as a natural disaster or terrorist attack to disrupt our way of life. While there are systems in place to prepare for such an event, sometimes the best remedy is actually having some outside-the-box solutions. That's exactly why a SAE student project was developed that could someday help relief workers treat victims of disaster. The treatment works by separating the red blood cells from the plasma, separating the hemoglobin from the plasma so that the plasma can be used for transfusion or for re-concentrating the plasma.
The team of nine students began work on this student project nearly three years ago. When disaster relief was needed in Haiti and Thailand following the 2010 earthquake and floods, respectively, the team was there ready to help treat victims. Their product, dubbed the LifeSaver, uses a chemical treatment to separate the plasma from the red blood cells. The design has several positive ramifications. First, it can be easily packed and transported anywhere in the world. Second, it uses pure water and local salts as a source of reagent, which means that it has a high recycle value. Lastly, it saves costly energy by not needing to be boiled in the process of separating the cells.
There is currently a team at the University of Rhode Island developing a larger-scale model that will replace the single-use plastic bags and can become a viable option for people in the developed world. The original plans to donate the LifeSaver to a non-profit was recently changed to a for-profit idea, allowing them to turn their product into a commercial reality.

change and the cost of fixing it
Doug Smith explores the impacts of global warming.
By Doug Smith
Was the price of ignoring climate change worth it? — Photo courtesy Stocksy United
Seven years ago a scientist, Amy Luers, presented a lecture to my fellow master’s candidates at the University of Washington’s School of Environmental and Forest Sciences (SEFS) entitled Climate Change: Is it a Significant Threat to Society and What Can Be Done About it? By the end of her well-researched and engaging talk, one question seemed to resonate with my peers.
Every university graduate and, for that matter, most university students of today and tomorrow will be impacted by the consequences of climate change. — Photo courtesy Seattle University
“What can we do about it?”
The closest I could come to answering that question was with research into how climate change has already affected each of our areas of expertise. I spent my year looking at the long-term, inter-related histories of human settlement of the Pacific Northwest, how Indigenous peoples settled the landscape of the Puget Sound region thousands of years ago and what the scientific legacy of the area reveals about this relationship. Two centuries ago, the Hudson Bay Company’s Portland Arm of the Columbia River was named for British explorer Sir Henry Hudson, who charted the river in 1608. Dozens of present-day Washington towns — Mt. Vernon, La Conner, Sammamish and Sequim, to name just a few — are straight-up translations of Aboriginal words. We as a society simply can’t ignore the question of what we have done and can do about climate change.
The good news is that, if we understand the benefits of the land — and recognize that the cultural and spiritual resources of Puget Sound indigenous communities are connected to our terrestrial and marine environments, just as their cultures, fishing, language and traditions are intertwined — we can come together to address climate change. Perhaps we can make a significant difference for future generations.
Bolstering your knowledge of climate change is a good way to offset the significant impacts of global warming. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory offers a series of articles, a glossary of terms, data visualizations and a comprehensive explanation of the carbon cycle. The Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center provides in-depth information on current and historical atmospheric greenhouse gas concentration and has a comprehensive set of global average temperature and sea level rise data. NASA, the U.S. Government’s National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has been tracking global atmospheric and

In Advanced Techniques in Sociology: A Research-Oriented Approach, well-known instructors provide 20 in-depth chapters on a wide range of topics in the design of innovative qualitative research. A wide variety of methods are explored as well as the process of data collection and analysis, presentation of findings, and ways to learn from mistakes. The chapters offer readers unique insight into the creative spirit of qualitative research, in which novel ideas for engaging participants and collecting data are often based on the careful analysis of problems and mistakes that researchers are prone to make.
The innovative theoretical perspectives and research approaches in the book allow readers to learn about and explore a diversity of topics including: new directions in in-depth interviewing; issues in observation; semantics and symbolic interactionism; contextualization of stories; analysis of mixed methods; applying rhetoric to interpretative analysis; various methods for interviewing and analyzing narrative data; the use of discussion groups; various approaches to analyzing interview transcripts; conducting ethnographies in long-term fieldwork; using ethnographic methods with life histories; and using interview data in participatory action research.

it guides us both with great enthusiasm as well as with a sense of apprehension. The excitement, of course, is the new experience that is about to unfold and the apprehension is due to fear of the unknown.
For someone who has never had a first aid training, the first aid courses are something to be apprehensive of. For a photographer, the apprehension is in the capturing of the first aid process. But just like it can be done with photography, it can also be done with the first aid course. Let us look at a few tips.
• Obtain an example of the work that you wish to capture. This may sound silly but it is what defines you. If you want to capture a first aid process that involves the first aid for cuts or a burn, you cannot get better examples if you do not sample the work.
• Jot down tips on how to capture the shots. Some of the tips you may have already memorized. However, when you start having a fear in your heart, you may need the practice tips that help you to be more focused.
• Be equipped with the right gear and accessories. It is a prudent thing to invest in good gear and accessories. Some of the tools include a first aid scissors and a first aid box. These may not come in handy all the time. However, your experience will always be greatly enhanced if you have the right things in your First Aid Kit.
• Try out some photography poses in a non-stressful environment. Avoid shooting at the emergency ward since you are not qualified to provide any medical attention to the patients. Instead, just walk around the hospital or a wide open space. Start practicing a few of the recommended shots to see how they are done. If it feels like something you are not quite able to pull off, move on and try it out with ease, with no pressure.

Question
Suppose you develop software for a major telecommunications company. You work with other developers to write the software and also manage a group of developers who work independently. Suppose you are having an argument with a coworker. She suggests that you should have the engineers spend a few hours working on personal projects. What steps would you take to evaluate the ethical implications of this suggestion?
Solution
- Ethical implications of using personal projects
- Preparatory steps
- A detailed response
- Steps taken to evaluate the recommendation
- Cited for sources
- Personal project options
1. Ethical implications of using personal projects
Suppose I decided to go ahead with this recommendation and my work week will be adjusted as necessary to provide two additional hours for my personal projects. That would be two hours per week for each engineer and would represent a nice bonus for them if this suggestion were agreed upon. However, this won’t be free. While I would offer the bonus to the developers, they would need to meet a certain standard. The standard would be that I don’t wish to negatively impact the quality of my work, and therefore, they must adhere to standards of excellence when developing their own software. In other words, their personal projects will need to pass the same level of quality as my own personal projects. They have two hours per week to develop their own work.
2. Preparatory steps
I would confer with the supervisor about this suggestion. I believe my plan could help reduce stress among the developers at work and therefore it could improve the quality of their work as well as their general happiness and life satisfaction. The supervisor would be very pleased if this was successful. I would also ensure that I am writing about this in a professional manner. It is very important that I do not suggest any kind of wrongdoing and instead, offer an option for improving the overall mood of the office. This would improve the efficiency of my own department as well as the work of the other departments. It would help build better working relationships with coworkers as well. I would try to anticipate any objections to this plan. For example, the company’s policy does not allow the usage of office time for personal projects. I would try to engage the company policy maker and discuss my concern for the well-being of the developers while also keeping the best interests of the company in mind.
3. A detailed response
The telecommunication company that I work for has a policy that explicitly states personal projects cannot be done during office hours. If I were to recommend that this policy change

: Tyzzer’s disease; January 11, 2011
- Posted on: January 11 2011
- Leave a response: Click here.
In a post back in 2009 I noted a case of Pendred syndrome that I had seen in our practice that very day.
In a way it seems to be a case of “Man bites dog”.
I have seen a “lot” of Pendred syndrome cases. To my knowledge, I have seen 8 or so cases that were younger than the couple of months old that were seen when I was writing that post, so they add to the “lot” I have seen.
But still, as of my writing this, it stands as “a single case of Tyzzer’s disease” with Pendred syndrome on the MD side of the pedigree.
While I haven’t had a similar thing happen on the DS side yet, I am seeing more patients that have had a GI stent placed and an endoscopy or colonoscopy done at or around the time of the stent placement. Out of the three patients that come to mind (I can think of 3 more that did not go to one of the same medical groups… they have to have been medically and financially well enough to take time off to be in an outpatient Endo suite, so no loss of access to care with that, I figure) the first had a parasite on microscopy that I’d have had trouble identifying on a 1,000x oil immersion picture and the second patient had the most bizarre intestinal sample I’ve ever seen. We had to get a zee rod to help with the diagnosis, and I do not know what it was the diagnosis was at this point. The third just had clear (non-group) conjunctivitis. Which is a pretty commonplace presentation in those patients. The first one was at a local Out Patient (O.P.) clinic doing the endoscopy and when I came to do the first consultation with him, he was still pretty much asleep on the table. Second, I did consult with the GI team that was doing the endoscopy and am I sort of interested in knowing what they found. Third, I did know it was going to happen before it did.
This is nothing more than a bit of medical trivia about potential microscopy specimens. But again, I have not done what would be a truely large study, so I do not know how common an infection/parasite with

​When I think about what makes a great chef, it's not just about cooking. In my mind, it's about storytelling and character. Who you are and how you live your life-- both those things play a huge role in how you cook. And how you cook-- whether or not you create a deeply personal restaurant or pop-up or cart-- is also an expression of your character.
When we worked together to rebrand myself and my culinary work, I knew that my mission statement and unique value proposition needed to come from the heart. I put in a few long days on the computer, helping myself get out of my own head and into the flow of coming up with my own language. Then, one night as my boyfriend and I were getting ready to leave the house, he asked me a question that helped my define my brand's "point of view". ​"What's your aim with your food? To take you on a journey?" he asked. And suddenly, everything fell into place. Here are four elements of a brand that, as the founder of Stories by the Slice, I have taken seriously to craft a unique point of view: Authentic storytelling, Real audience connection, Delighting guests through custom experiences and Personal investment in helping to write their story. ​I'll save the whole backstory for another post, but this is the moment where I realized that the mission of "Stories by the Slice" was, and continues to be, clear and close to my heart. Here's why. When you are hired by a client, you want to know that there is a common ground. And for a chef in a chef-driven business, that means knowing what you care about, and what your business stands for. It's never more clear to the client who you are and why you do what you do more than during the initial discovery phase. During discovery, your instinct is always to get the most detailed information you can from the potential client so that you can get a feel for them, the position they are hiring for and the culture they're trying to create. As a freelance brand strategist, I do this for myself, too. But when a client tells you their vision for the future and you get to hear, more often than not, what drives them, what makes them come alive, and what they feel like they're good at, that takes the work to the next level. For me, it's what helps me get to know them, not only as a business owner or designer, but as a

Earlier research has demonstrated how the symbiotic relationship between mammalian gut microbiota and the brain profoundly affects health (Foster et al., 2013). Recently, there has been a very exciting shift in thinking that lays claim to neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease being driven by a gradual alteration in gut microbial composition which can lead to microbiota-driven systemic inflammation and disruption to the body’s metabolic and immune systems (Keenan et al., 2013; Najmanovich et al., 2013). It is certainly the case that once these meningo-cerebral events occur at an advanced state in the disease process, this leads to the generation of neurotoxic metabolites that can be detected in biological samples of brain tissue, cerebrospinal fluid and/or blood samples of patients affected (Brundel et al., 2014; Wesseling et al., 2013).
In order to truly answer whether these microbiome derived toxins can influence progression of disease, we need to rule out potential contaminants, so most recent studies have employed the use of CDI free bacteria, carried in a trans-triplicate of gDNA-free falcon tubes (sample tubes in which bacterial cells have been fully disrupted by a DNAse treatment) to accurately account for the isolation of endotoxin instead of DNA from any bacterial or archaeal species present. Indeed, our latest work in collaboration with Chelsie Campbell from the University of Edinburgh, in attempting to identify markers of disease states from whole blood samples has confirmed the presence of endotoxin from the transference of whole bacterial cells into the white blood cell preparation used in this assay (Power et al., 2014). This study successfully isolated markers of the disease states from the control group and those individuals in the late stages of Parkinson’s disease, which indicated the presence of circulating endotoxin originating from the gut microbial populations and translocated across the blood brain barrier and into the brain. This new work is suggesting endotoxins may be the beginning of the disease pathway for disease progression of neurological diseases. Furthermore, when taken together, the interrelationship between the gut microbiota, the gut-liver-brain axis may provide an opportunity to apply positive modulatory treatment to stimulate the innate immune system and kick-start neuroprotection in Parkinson’s disease patients.

in simple terms Physics is the study of matter, energy, and the interactions between them. It involves understanding how things move, how they interact, and how they change over time. It includes topics such as mechanics, electricity and magnetism, thermodynamics, and quantum mechanics. Physics helps us to understand the world around us and to make predictions about future events. It has a wide range of applications in many fields, including engineering, medicine, and technology.

1960-2017
In the early 1960s, meteorologists were among a group of scientists in the USA being persecuted by US Senator Joseph McCarthy and his HUAC (House Un-American Activities Committee). Prof. Arnold Schierhuber, head of the Austrian Meteorological Institute, even went as far as resigning and seeking asylum in Sweden. Science established itself as a counterforce to the so-called ‘McCarthy hysteria’, much like in 2017, with the attack of Donald Trump on climate scientists like Michael Mann. As scientists have consistently proven, it is not beneficial for humanity to follow this US leader down a path of destruction. In 1962, meteorologist Robert Matthews, called scientists who favoured man-made climate change ‘propagandists’, while some German politicians wanted scientists to stop naming weather phenomena, for fear that international treaty negotiations with Germany, could be jeopardised.
In this talk, climate scientists Stuart Browning and Steve Easterbrook aim to dispel the notion that the role of scientists is to predict the weather for an ‘industry of fools’, simply to make them more fearful of hurricanes and tornadoes. They demonstrate that meteorologists’ other, more ethically-loaded, work, is to communicate more effectively to the public, to justify and inform policy-making, in order to accelerate global solutions. They seek to deliver good communications and explain complex science as they perform their research, whether they be presenting scientific results at conferences, giving public lectures, writing reports, advising policy-makers or participating in the media. Their most important responsibility is to engage in the communication of science, making the world better able to tackle the problems it faces, primarily including the climate crisis.
***
Bringing scholarly papers to the public is a significant aspect of Science Communication Online’s work. Readers may download a copy of the transcript here. Please be aware that some of these articles have been published before on SCoPE, such as:
- Online discussions of the ethics of climate scientists in 2016
- Facing real science to make better policy choices

in the style of William Shakespeare Certainly, I shall endeavor to weave a tale of meditation in the style of Shakespeare. In the court of King Henry VIII, a young and ambitious squire named Thomas sought to learn the art of meditation. His heart was set on attaining a peaceful mind and a calm disposition, which would serve him well in his future endeavors.

He first approached the queen herself, who was renowned for her serene presence and quiet contemplation. She took him under her wing and showed him the art of sitting quietly and focusing on the breath, without any distractions. Thomas struggled at first, for his mind would often wander and he would become agitated. But with the queen's guidance, he learned to still his thoughts and let his breath guide him.

He also sought the counsel of a wise old monk, who lived in a secluded monastery in the countryside. The monk taught him the ancient art of mindfulness, which involved paying attention to the present moment and acknowledging one's thoughts without judgment. Thomas found this practice difficult at first, for he was used to suppressing his emotions and thoughts. But with time, he learned to accept his emotions and thoughts as they were, and to let them pass without becoming attached to them.

Finally, Thomas turned to the words of Shakespeare, who was a great believer in the power of meditation. He delved into the bard's works, studying the meditative themes of his plays and sonnets. He found that Shakespeare's poetry was a form of meditation in itself, a way to quiet the mind and enter into a deeper state of awareness.

And so, Thomas continued to practice the art of meditation, combining the teachings of the queen, the monk, and the bard. He found that his mind became clearer, his emotions more stable, and his thoughts more peaceful. He became known as a man of great wisdom and serenity, and was soon appointed as a councilor to the king himself.

In the end, Thomas realized that meditation was not just a means to an end, but a way of life. It taught him to live in the present moment, to appreciate the beauty of nature, and to love and be loved. And so he passed on the teachings of meditation to the next generation, ensuring that the art would endure for generations to come.

1. Meditation is easy and can be done without any preparation or guidance: While it's true that some people may find meditation

is rooted in human history. This chapter sets out to understand what robotics means and how it fits into the human quest for self-discovery in an increasingly advanced and complex world. From ancient mythology to the present day, robotics has been used in many cultures to represent certain features of human nature: its religious meanings are well documented, but it is also used as an expression of philosophical systems, social ideals, and cultural values. It is an instrument in society to shape and inform human experiences and perceptions of the world, and even of its own role in the world. This chapter examines robots as symbols of human nature, treating robotic representations as if they were “human in robot suits.” It begins with the earliest known references to robots in Chinese mythology and moves on to more recent research that also sets out to restore the missing explanatory context in the forms of poems and historical accounts that describe the use of robots in Japan at the height of its centuries-long cultural influence and power. It then considers robots in other cultures and gives special attention to the myths of various Asian cultures, treating the robot not as a fantasy but as a cultural resource and a social phenomenon that has played a historically influential role in shaping how people think, believe, and experience reality. The chapter finally traces how robots have become dehumanized as a product of the global modernization and technological challenges that humans have faced today.

Review Article Article

Robotics is a rapidly growing area of technology and science with strong potential for the betterment of human life (Cassidy & Lee, 2017). It is a booming research field with a global market of over $125 billion per year and is set to grow to over$230 billion by 2025 (Burgess & Zohar, 2017; Kaller, 2016). Despite these huge projections and ever-increasing investment in robotics research and development, the anthropological and sociological studies of robots remain relatively rare. Dutton (2017) found 109 studies published in 2017 alone and many more in 2018. Yet, these studies tend to be dominated by design and engineering perspectives and rarely take account of the full range of cultural meanings that robots have had. The main problem that has been identified is the lack of understanding of the “the meaning of the machine in itself and the meaning of the machine as a mediator between the natural world and human activities” (Housley & Owston, 20

, and gleaning insights about the nature of art from artistic endeavors, has been central to my role as a teacher and a writer for the last five years. Ever since I read "My Sentence Was a Thousand Years of Joy" in high school, poetry has been part of my education. I gained in my understanding of the imagination and human experience, particularly through the subjects and themes of its most prestigious authors. In the process of composing and analyzing poetry of all sorts, I also came to appreciate creativity and human expression in novel ways.
Through these lessons, I've come to believe that poetry was, and is, my main source of sustenance and my vehicle of growth. I discovered that at the personal, emotional, and artistic level, this literary form is most elemental and profound. I pursued English literature courses in college and honed my analytical and critical eye, and I received a BA from Hunter College, and an MA from Columbia's School of the Arts. Under the guidance of Grace Schulman, I participated in the Graves House Workshop, an innovative MFA program. I did a total of four years in workshops with June Joyner, Sam Hamill, and Elizabeth Alexander, three of the foremost minds and poets in the NYC community. These artists were an extraordinary influence on my creative development as an amateur writer.
I also started writing professionally in my sophomore year in high school, and have since continued to serve as a literary contributor in literary magazines, and performed in venues all over the country as a singer-songwriter for over 15 years. My poems have been recognized at the National Scholastic Writers' Awards, and I am currently working on my debut novel about girls and music, which might be the subject of my second major creative project in my adult life. In the meantime, I've had the opportunity to teach students of all ages, including at Columbia University. It is a joyous and meditative task to bring the truth and beauty of art into my students' work in order to inspire new life in their text.
About Sam: Sam Stevens holds a BA from Columbia University in history, and an MA in creative writing from Columbia's School of the Arts. In addition to being a writer, musician, and teacher, Sam is also a visual artist who creates drawings and paintings in a gestural, abstract, and metaphorical style.

: The first artificial Earth satellite 'Sputnik' was launched by the USSR (Russia) on 4 October 1957. It was the height of the space race between the USSR and the USA.
The Russian name for Sputnik is Commeleon.
It took the satellite about 98 minutes to complete a full orbit.
Sputnik 2 carried the first animal in space, a dog named Laika, but Laika died within two days of entering space due to overheating in the capsule.
The moon has dark and light areas. The dark areas are caused by dust and ice. The light areas are made up of mountains and hills, and they are brighter because they are made of volcanic rock.
The moon is tidally locked with the earth, which means that the same side of the moon always points in the same direction in relation to the sun.
The solar system consists of the Sun, planets, moons, asteroids, comets and other heavenly bodies.
There are eight planets in our solar system: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. The eight planets make up about 99.8 percent of the mass of the solar system.
Every planet in our solar system has a ring around it. The rings are usually made of ice and dust.
If you look at a planet in a telescope, you will not be able to see any stars around it because the planet is in front of the stars and they are too faint to see.
NASA space agency launched a mission to Moon called Artemis. The mission's main goal is to pave the way for human exploration of Mars.
Astronauts have gone to the moon more than 15 times and have landed on it 10 times. The last time was in December 1972.
Explore your horizons:
Prepare to explore: space stations are also on the moon, we can live there.
Become a planetary biologist: to grow and protect a planet, we need to learn more about it.
Become a geologist: study the moon, uncover the answers about the formation of the Earth and the stars.
Become a navigator: space and astronomical objects are vast. Learn how to find your way.
Become an archeologist: study the composition of space debris from space missions.
Become an engineer: study the materials used by the space industry, develop them or substitute them for new materials and find new applications for them.
Join a space company: find out what scientists do everyday to make a difference

and artificial intelligence (AI) systems have led to large increases in the availability of data for use in data mining and pattern recognition algorithms. Knowledge extraction from datasets is a critical, sometimes critically hard, problem. The data are typically plentiful, but frequently noisy, incoherent, or improperly labeled. Proper knowledge extraction from data is a challenging but important task. This dissertation research attempts to automatically extract meaningful knowledge from noisy big data sets and apply the concepts to practical needs.
State-of-the-art unsupervised learning for such big data requires two issues to be addressed: First, huge amount of data and computation can be prohibitive and, second, massive amounts of datasets need to be processed in order to discover useful, but elusive, patterns. In this dissertation, we address the problem using an integrated technique: we combine and extend semisupervised pattern extraction algorithms, such as Neural Probabilistic Models (NPMs), which improve data distributions based on labeled data to deal with noise and a larger amount of datasets; and fully supervised knowledge extraction algorithms, such as deep neural networks (DNNs), which can propagate the wrong information to assist models in finding the hidden patterns, to improve the overall results.
To make DNNs better at extracting knowledge, we also propose a data distillation method, which uses synthetic data to obtain a more accurate DNN model, by introducing pseudo-labeled data. For knowledge extraction from open data, such as Web and social networks, we also propose a sampling method to extract datasets with minimal information.
For data distillation, we introduced an inductive and transductive phase. In the inductive phase, we extract high-level features, which are then used to extract a dense mapping model from unlabeled datasets. In the transductive phase, we use the dense mapping model to explore all relationships between data points, which are hidden inside unlabeled datasets. In the sampling phase, we create a long-tailed distribution based on the results from data distillation, which generates synthetic datasets with varying proportions. For finding common relationships among data, we introduce a novel hybrid learning method, which combines ideas from NPMs and the deep representation framework. The results from NPMs are combined with the DNN to create a DNN-NPM hybrid model, which is trained on multiple sub-datasets (hypervectors) and combined to learn the relationships hidden inside every sub-dataset.

technology have made things more convenient for people all over the world to become healthy and fit. We can now track our activity, monitor our energy expenditure and calorie intake, or even check our body composition.
If you are used to calculating your calorie intake using a nutritionist or online calculator, or you do it by hand, know that tracking the calories in the foods you eat is more complicated than you think. If you would like to stay on track with your diet, you need to keep track of the total calories, a balance of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. Not to mention, you need to understand the difference between absolute calories and relative calories. This article will explain what exactly a calorie is, why it's important, and how you can monitor your calorie intake.
A calorie is the unit of measurement of energy. When someone's activity requires the use of energy, it is measured in calories. You can measure calories by food or any other thing that requires energy to function. The basic purpose of a calorie is to measure the energy that is required to burn 1 gram of fat.
Your daily diet is your main source of energy. During the day, your body is constantly using energy and working. Since there are numerous energy sources in your diet, your calorie requirements may vary. Also, not all of your calories are usable. Some of them come from fats and proteins and those calories are used to supply energy for all of your organs. The energy that is not consumed is stored in your body in various ways.
When you are on a diet, it is important to eat a well-balanced diet, especially when it comes to calories. You can not only eat foods that are high in energy, but also foods that are low in calories. You can find your ideal calorie level by either calculating or measuring the amount of calories you are consuming on a daily basis. Knowing your ideal calorie level can help you make adjustments to your diet.
There are two types of calories: absolute and relative calories. The difference is that the absolute calorie is based on the total amount of food you consume, while the relative calorie is based on the amount of food you actually eat.
The nutritional value of the food you eat is important when it comes to maintaining your health and wellbeing. People who want to lose weight should not only pay attention to the calories in their diet, but also the nutritional value of the food they consume.
The nutritional value of the food you eat is important, especially when you want to lose weight. A diet that has a high nutritional value will not only

, as the most science that can adopt known approaches to understand brain mechanisms, has gathered considerable momentum in the recent decades. The interdisciplinary field consists of two fields. One is the biomedical and clinical neuroscience, and the other is the cognitive and behavioral neuroscience. The former tries to understand the origin of syndromes, diseases, and behavior through neurobiological causes of the brain. The latter studies brain mechanism in the same way but focuses on understanding and interpreting complex cognitive and behavioral characteristics, including emotions, intentions, creativity, motivation, reasoning, language, and mental pictures.
To study these intriguing features of neuroscience, a range of behavioral and brain science methodologies is routinely and successfully used: behavioral tests, fine and coarse-grained electrophysiology, neuroimaging, single neuron recordings, as well as a variety of sophisticated animal models. The analysis and interpretation of these data sets is usually undertaken through a set of theoretical tools: computational neuroscience, data mining, cognitive modeling, machine learning, and, more recently, complex networks analysis (Cellai, Mazzocchi, Pizzamiglio, 2009; Kurzban, 2006).
We try to understand the fundamental mechanisms by which data are produced in the sciences of brain. To this purpose, we make an active use of tools and theories from diverse disciplinary fields such as mathematics, biology, medicine, computer science, physics, chemistry, and psychology. In this day and age, the abundant amount of research data in such interdisciplinary fields as neuroscience makes the study of the mechanisms by which data are produced an urgent task for any one.
ComPNeS is also interested in exploring what kind of approaches and methods could be efficiently applied to extract theoretical knowledge from data through an appropriate combination of quantitative methods from the above disciplines.
We welcome collaboration on any subject of interest in neuroscience and beyond.
Morgan J., Zekanowski M., Fontanini P. and Molesini G.

If you’ve been considering creating your own music but are unsure of where to start, fear not. All you need is an internet connection, and some smart tactics. Here are some top tips for those of you making your musical debut.
It’s vital that you get your computer set up for sound editing and music production. Your best bet is to get yourself a powerful desktop or laptop computer and some decently expensive headphones. Recording music requires a strong computer and loud headphones to really blow your potential fans away.
You can spend thousands on state of the art, and very expensive, audio software and equipment, but at the end of the day, you don’t need all that in order to start mixing your own tracks and releasing music. In fact, the more you do it, the better you become, and the less you’ll rely on fancy programmes and expensive equipment.
Take a crash course on producing and the internet is full of content that can get you started without burning a hole in your pocket.
Pay attention to what the experts are talking about. Join a forum, or two or three. Listen to popular trends, and dive in. That’s what will get you heard. Going at it alone is not going to do it for you, so pay attention and make your mark.
Getting your music heard is as simple as taking the next step to listening to and making music. Get your ears opened up to what’s out there, your eyes on what’s possible, and trust us, you’ll be able to do it too.

is inescapable, and both industries are struggling to work out where they are going. It is obvious that travellers are using their phones for travel planning more and more as a means of cutting through the clutter and simply finding the information they need.
A recent survey by Jounce of 1,000 US travellers found that more than 40 per cent claimed to be using smartphones or tablets on mobile. The list of the most visited websites includes route planners such as Moovit, Google Maps, Rome2Rio, Rser, TripAdvisor, Foursquare, Avis, CarteBlanche, METRO and SkyScanner, Google Tickets. The National Weather Service (NWS) ranks first in the list of most used apps among travellers, followed by TMC booking apps Expedia and Kayak and then TrackMate, Google Events, Facebook Local and Foodcritic.
The National Parks Service’s Redwood app is a great example of how technology is used to engage travellers, providing them with the tools to plan and experience the parks. The app is full of information for visitors, including an interactive trail map, tips and essential information, and self-guided audio tours of select sites. It also enables visitors to interact with the actual park in real time, without leaving home. Also included in the app are suggestions for activities, such as hiking, and amenities such as water, barbecue, restrooms and parking. There is also the opportunity to contribute your own photos.
NPS officials said the aim of the app is to foster visitor engagement, explain how conservation works and increase attendance to the parks. The app has more than 500,000 downloads.
Another great example of smartphone innovations in parks is the Yellowstone app, which features the park’s brochures and multiple webcams, including an active fire camera feed from a hike on the back side of the park. The best part? It’s available for free.
No doubt many of you are familiar with apps such as those mentioned above, but what are the most significant features in apps available for travellers?
Detailed information is important, and Jounce’s research found that 60 per cent of US travellers ranked detailed information as very important, while 53 per cent said safety was most important. Another study from FirstFreeSoft found 60 per cent of travellers cited the availability of accurate and timely travel information as most important.

Once upon a time, in a small town in the heart of Europe, there was a man named Max. Max had always been fascinated by cinema, and had dreamed of opening his own movie theater. He spent years saving up, and finally, one day, he opened his own cinema.

At first, Max had only a handful of customers, but he worked tirelessly to make his cinema a success. He hired the best projectionists, and carefully selected each film that was shown. Max loved nothing more than seeing people coming to his cinema, laughing and crying together, and experiencing the magic of the movies.

Over the years, Max's cinema became a beloved institution in the town. People from all over came to watch the latest films, and Max was always there to welcome them and share in their joy. He even started a movie club, where regular customers could share their favorite films and discuss them together.

Max's cinema was not just a place to watch movies, but a place to connect with others. The people of the town came together to share their love of cinema, and Max was right there to help them do so.

As Max got older, he began to worry about what would happen to his cinema when he was gone. He didn't want to leave it in the hands of someone who wouldn't understand the importance of cinema to the town. So, he came up with a plan. He would find a young person who loved cinema as much as he did, and hand over the reins of his cinema to them.

Max spent months looking for the right person, and finally, he found him. His name was Lucas, and he was a young film student who had just moved to town. Max knew that Lucas was the right person to take over his cinema, and he passed on the keys to him, along with all of his knowledge and love of cinema.

Lucas was overjoyed when Max handed over the keys to him, and he spent the next few months renovating the cinema. He added new seating, a state-of-the-art sound system, and even started showing some of the older movies that Max had loved in his younger years.

Today, Lucas's cinema is more successful than ever. People from all over the world come to see the movies that Lucas has chosen, and they leave feeling uplifted and inspired. And every time Max looks up at his old cinema, he knows that he did the right thing in passing it on to Lucas.

Working in an agency you have to come up with great ideas, campaigns, concepts. Your ideas or campaigns will get in the mind of consumers and influence them to do something. Either to buy the product or to think differently. Engineers on the other hand, like us, think of how to make things work better. They come up with something that is logically working. One uses logic to become great, the other one uses ideas.
Here are 3 elements to a great campaign. For me, these are the basics and most important.
It is bad business when the promotion you start is not aligned with what you are currently doing. There is nothing worse then looking like you are ‘inside a loop’. If something does not work there is no point to keep doing it. Stay honest about it and let the consumer know you worked out the flaw and changed it. The person behind this is smart, but for sure not all the people that are consuming.
Through all our branding, funnily enough often the important logo and name of the organisation are not on a beautiful design or concept. If you would like to influence the consumer, then it is important to let your DNA shine. All examples in the reports below show they have one clear logo, have a nice colour scheme and that are very consistent with this.
A strong brand and campaign help you identify the most important parts of it and strengthen these parts. If you’ve been at the top for a while you have to remind the customers of the unique attributes that make you tick, or you will become just another face in the crowd.
For now, we’ll focus on broadcast media. Broadcasting media costs have increased dramatically over the years. And what seems to be the most important now for advertisers is volume and less competition.
If you are wanting to buy TV in Australia, then you are most likely coming across the FOXTEL Digital TV Network. This huge network consists of 16 channels. There is a huge difference between channels on the FOXTEL channel. Some have a product or name that is so big that everyone in your market is familiar with it. It is of your advantage to promote your product on one of these channels.

Fitness training works because it helps to improve fitness levels through various exercises. Here is the reasoning:

1. Fitness is about overall health and well-being, which includes cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, flexibility, and body composition.
2. By engaging in regular fitness training, you can improve these elements of fitness.
3. Fitness exercises typically involve cardio (cardiovascular) activities that increase your heart rate and breathing, such as running, cycling, or swimming.
4. Strength training helps to build muscle, increase bone density, and improve your body's ability to perform everyday activities.
5. Flexibility exercises like stretching or yoga can improve range of motion and prevent injury.
6. Depending on your fitness goals, you may also incorporate certain types of training like high-intensity interval training (HIIT) or Pilates to further challenge and improve your fitness levels.
7. By regularly participating in these activities, your body adapts to the exercises, making them easier to perform over time.

Overall, fitness training works by gradually improving your fitness levels through regular exercise, which helps you maintain or improve your overall health and well-being.

can often lead to misconceptions about psychology-related careers. Below is a list of questions frequently asked by people interested in studying psychology or in pursuing one of the related fields.
What are some misconceptions about psychology?
What kinds of jobs are available in psychology?
There are a wide variety of jobs available in psychology. The World Health Organization estimates there are more than 60,000 professional psychologists in the United States. It is believed that many of these psychologists work with the approximately 100 million people that suffer from mental, emotional, or behavioral disorders. There are also therapists who practice in a wide variety of settings, such as hospitals, senior citizen centers, schools, and corporations. Medical doctors, lawyers, and social workers regularly consult psychologists as members of an interdisciplinary team when dealing with severe emotional or behavioral problems, or as part of a team addressing issues within their practice or law.
What kinds of training are needed to become a professional psychologist?
There is no single, direct path to become a professional psychologist. The majority of psychologists need a doctoral degree from an accredited university and the requisite experience through internships and residencies. There are several doctoral-level degrees from which to choose, including the Ph.D. (Doctor of Philosophy), Psy.D. (Doctor of Psychology), and Ed.D. (Doctor of Education), among others. Whatever degree you choose, it is recommended that you go to a university in the top 25th percentile for psychology that has an APA-accredited doctoral program, because those schools are best prepared to provide the training and experiences that will best prepare you for a career as a psychologist.
What kinds of undergraduate majors are appropriate for psychology?
Psychology majors can find a wide variety of careers that focus on pursuing social justice, providing psychological support, and working to increase quality of life. Because psychology majors need to prepare for a rigorous graduate program, they should enroll in mathematics and statistics courses. Many students opt to take courses in philosophy, sociology, anthropology, and other social sciences.
Those students who wish to study a more applied area of psychology may want to combine their psychology major with an education in communication (including speech, language and hearing sciences), and/or social work. Others who want to study a very specific area of psychology can find specialized graduate programs. For example, those who wish to become forensic psychologists should be sure to combine their major in psychology with a minor in criminal justice, criminology, or a related field. Students who plan to become family therapists should find a school that has a dual major or minor

Chris Brown embodies cultural perception with his voice, his movements, and his very being. Chris, or "C. B." as his friends call him, moves between different roles, incorporating different dimensions of his personality with each of them. He seamlessly jumps between acting, poetry, singing, breakdancing, and running (remember his half-marathon?)--not only in that order--but actually does them all simultaneously. Catching up with C. B. was an absolute pleasure, and we look forward to see what he achieves next.
Welcome to the first five questions from our Q&A with C. B. Smith. For a few more questions and his thoughts on Socratic adaptation, check out the remainder of the interview!
Q: Chris, you're a Southern boy who is now making it big in the big city. How do you adapt to society? What kinds of situations keep you on your toes, and what allows you to flourish?
CB: I think it's all about adaptation. I find it really easy to adapt to situations because I feel that I can go with the flow a lot easier than most people. Though, I'm nowhere near perfect at adapting, I always seem to get around whatever situation I get myself into. A lot of the time, I try not to change who I am for the better or worse, but, adapt to the situation to make the people around me comfortable. I'm so socially awkward that if I were to act like the thing I think I should be, I would almost get laughed off stage or go home crying.
Q: Who have you studied to inspire you?
CB: I've been reading about a bunch of different philosophers such as Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Plato, Friedrich Nietzsche, Alain de Botton, Niccolò Machiavelli, Roberta Rute, Emerson, and Søren Kierkegaard.
Q: Do you find it difficult to use your cultural perspective in your art?
CB: I don't necessarily find it difficult to use my cultural perspective to create art because I'm taught that the different perspectives can enrich my art. I've been taught to use my perspective to show what life is like here in Southern life and the challenges I face and how I get through them. I think using my perspective comes from teaching kids something and talking about my mind.
Q: Do you find your in an actual discussion in the sense of discourse or just simply engaged in a debate?
CB: When I'm debating, I'm always engaged and having a discussion

Scientific research is the core element of the department. The courses are about research at the interfaces between geosciences and environmental sciences.
We conduct research with a view to both basic and applied questions. Our research programme consists of three main themes: “Earth systems”, “Geo and environmental change” and “Human resource evolution”.
Within the Earth system discipline, we are researching Earth processes in the past, present, and future to deepen our understanding of geo-environmental systems and human interactions with nature.
The discipline of Geo and Environmental Change focuses on how human and nature have interacted, and how interaction has developed. This is a multi-disciplinary field that draws on historical, societal, political and technological perspectives.
In this research domain, we focus on the major changes to Earth systems in the Anthropocene era and human society over the last tens of thousands of years. We also look ahead to future scenarios for human-nature interactions. Research includes topics such as current land use (forestry, agriculture, construction), climate change, and natural hazards such as landslides, river flooding, and drought. A key research focus concerns the effects of human activities on the ‘natural’ system. We also conduct research into societal and political issues, for example, how the effects of climate change are being communicated, how the concept of ‘nature’ should be defined and how the future of natural resource management should be conceptualised.
We investigate how natural resources, such as water and minerals have been and are being exploited throughout human history. The resource age includes resource conservation issues such as waste, recycling and resource recycling, as well as issues concerning energy and climate change (energy and materials in the context of climate change and how human activities affect the carbon cycle). In line with our research theme “human resource evolution”, research focuses on “how resources are used and exploited” from past to present.
What courses does the Department of Geosciences offer?
All Geosciences courses listed below are taught in English.
Which University of Copenhagen faculties offer classes in geosciences?
The Department of Geosciences courses are taught in the Natural Sciences section of Faculty of Science and the Department of Geosciences is part of the Graduate School of Natural Sciences (GSNS).
How to declare your major?
Students with specific interests are welcome to inform the teaching staff at their bachelor’s degree programme, although, when all courses are listed, it is usually clear whether a student will be admitted to the Earth sciences research programme.
In general, students should ensure that they declare a primary major.

Are you interested in the global economy? Do you think about how the price of gas would affect you if it rose? How about how the food you buy is taxed? Learn more about global economics with the fun facts on this page.
Fun facts
• The Olympic marathon was held in the U.S. for the first time in 1908 in Boston. The winner, John Flanagan, a servant at a local New England military academy, ran 44 miles and 110 yards from Ashland to Boston.
• Before sweatshops were banned, children of China worked 21 hours a day. Their wages were 10 cents.
• The 1908 Summer Olympics opened in London a year late because the Royal Marines and the Royal Navy were involved in the Boxer Rebellion.
• Today, Pakistan has the world’s highest rate of inflation at about 20 percent per year.
• By the year 2050, the United States is predicted to spend 30 percent of its gross domestic product on health care.
• Between 1990 and 2003, China increased its GDP (gross domestic product) by 7 percent every year. This means it increased by more than four times, making it one of the fastest growing economies in the world.

The Monaco Sustainable Finance Forum returns to Monaco September 27th through 28th, for an expanded 360-degree, action-oriented approach to sustainable investment.

In most books it is presented like a mystery novel: the reader wants to know how it all works, but will have to read a lot to find out.

# Back cover

This book is about making the reader to be able to explain why science is possible at all (in the book it is described as being in a position to be able to debunk mythological claims, including ones that are found in modern times, such as “the hard problem of consciousness”). The key elements are:

• Scientific method. A great chapter here on this topic, I always wanted to read a thorough treatment about the methodology of science.
• Natural philosophy: Here you will find a justification for science. Science seeks to understand the workings of nature, we know that it is possible to do so given that nature has been studied intensively for centuries and yet even now our understanding of it keeps getting better.

Science can continue to do so since it claims that God is not involved in our universe. What drives science is the basic assumption of physicalism: if something can be created or eliminated, it is a physical entity. Furthermore, whatever is not physical, is not real, and cannot be studied.
That is, we distinguish what can be touched, it is physical. If it cannot, it is not physical, and therefore we cannot study it, including claims about “not-me” (which we touched earlier). This is a new logical argument that I have not seen before (the original one is presented by Arthur Danto). If one can measure something, then it is physical, and if one cannot measure it, then it is not physical.

# Table of Contents

Preface

• Scientific method of observation
• Scientific realism vs. positivism, not what either of them were and are
• Kuhn’s model of revolutions of science and Kuhn’s criticism of the history of science in physics
• Platonism is part of the dark age of natural science
• The objections to scientism
• Accepting scientism is the easy way out

Part Three: Natural philosophy, the hard problem of consciousness and free

Machine learning algorithms and their applications in various industries have become an integral part of our lives in the modern world. In this post, we will discuss the cultural significance of machine learning.

Machine learning has revolutionized the way we approach problems and has provided new tools for individuals and societies to solve complex problems. It has had a significant impact on society, politics, economics, and culture. Below are some of the cultural significance of machine learning:

1. Social Impact:

Machine learning has a significant impact on society and has the potential to shape social change. For example, machine learning algorithms can be used to identify and address social issues such as poverty, crime, and inequality. It has the ability to identify patterns in large datasets and can help policymakers make informed decisions to address these issues.

2. Entertainment:

Machine learning has also impacted the entertainment industry. It has become an essential tool in creating personalized content for audiences. Streaming services like Netflix and Spotify use machine learning algorithms to recommend movies and music to users based on their preferences.

3. Politics:

Machine learning algorithms have also been used to influence political outcomes. For example, deepfakes, which are deep-learning-based manipulations of images and videos, have been used to create fake news and influence public opinion. It can also be used to detect fake news and misinformation on social media.

4. Business:

Machine learning has revolutionized the way businesses operate. Companies like Amazon and Netflix use machine learning algorithms to personalize their services and improve their customer experience. It has also helped to improve customer satisfaction and increase revenue for businesses.

In conclusion, machine learning has had a profound cultural impact on society. It has influenced the way we approach problems, entertainment, politics, and business. It has the potential to shape our future and create a more informed and connected world.

How do machine learning algorithms work?

Machine learning algorithms are a subset of artificial intelligence (AI) that enable machines to learn and improve without being explicitly programmed. They work by analyzing data and identifying patterns that can be used to make predictions or decisions. Here's a general overview of how they work:

1. Data Collection:

The first step in machine learning is data collection. This involves gathering relevant data from various sources, such as databases, documents, or sensors. The data must be labeled, which means that each data point is assigned a label or category.

2. Data Preprocessing:

Whew, ML practicals are finally done for the semester, but as always I felt a bit more of my machine learning background refreshed during the last week. Machine learning seems to be making a splash at 1U this semester and I'm thrilled to see more and more co-requisites popping up in my classes.

A lot of the skills that undergraduates use in academia (that may or may not translate in industry) are not going to be the ones employers will want to see for graduate jobs and it looks like machine learning will definitely be a major skill by 2020, right alongside working with data (see Cathy O'Neil's Weapons of Math Destruction). This is definitely a career move for me that I'm planning for and while it's still a bit too early to dig into it, I figured a neat little guide was in order. I'll probably keep this updated to help whenever I'm in the market and you can also find it on GitHub

What is machine learning?

For a high level overview of machine learning (and what I didn't necessarily learn about when I took AI), I've found how hard it is to get an apt definition of what it is but I found this short guide to be quite helpful:

So basically, machine learning is just a way to measure uncertainty using statistics. We use this method in everything:

ML helps us answer questions that will follow any data we put in. As the famous saying goes: if you can't measure it, you can't optimize it. It is this statistical nature that allows us to make predictions, which in turn allows us to improve the world around us (e.g. self-driving cars).

As the name suggests, machine learning is a computer based model that allows the computer to adapt to the world with data. And that's the magic part. But behind this simple name, machine learning is truly an interdisciplinary field that merges statistics, algebra, and programming.

You see the acronym ML everywhere, but is it worth your time?

It is almost necessary if you want to succeed in tech and the number of jobs is increasing! This is the analysis from Stack Overflow:

Source

Though you don't have to major in machine learning, it is not a bad idea to take courses with a subset of ML. If you are looking for another class to take, Google recommends this one (take both of these and you are a machine learning master).

helps us to understand the influence of waves on the surface of the water, tides, currents, and sedimentation. Our knowledge about how water behaves is intimately connected to our knowledge of weather, climate, and how sediments are transported (or moved).
Our study of waves in the course of oceanography is a part of dynamics, which includes sub-disciplines such as fluid dynamics, meteorology, and geophysics. Dynamicists look into the physical processes, such as winds and forces exerted by water, which are the driving forces behind water movement and sediment movement. Waves are an integral part of that physical science and they may be modelled in combination with heat and moisture transfer as fluids move around. Ocean waves may be modelled and analysed to predict currents and water movement that may occur if the weather should change.
The phenomena that occur on the surface of water are especially complex, involving physical, chemical, and biological phenomena as well as changes due to time (cyclical). The science of oceanography includes research into such features of ocean waves as their stability, the relationship between wave frequency and wind speed, and the directional swell that results from wind.
It is possible to study the movement of waves, winds, currents, and sedimentation separately, or to attempt to integrate their motion. Forecasts are made to allow people to safely venture out to sea, and to manage the effects of waves on infrastructure. The shape of seashores, lighthouses, and harbours depend on the variety of ocean waves.
Modern oceanography includes understanding of waves from the surface down to the continental shelf. The research is carried out in laboratories as well as in natural settings. It encompasses observations and measurements of water samples, water column studies, laboratory models of ocean behaviour, and modern instruments.

Sure, I'd be happy to help explain the concept of architecture in software development.

Architecture is the overall design of a software system. It defines how the different components of the system will interact with each other and how they will be organized to accomplish the system's goals. The architecture is the foundation of a software system, and it sets the stage for the development process.

In software development, architecture refers to the high-level design of the system, including the overall structure, the interactions between the different components, and the principles and rules that govern the development process. It includes the software's structure, interfaces, dataflows, hardware and network components, and other elements that affect the system's operation.

The architecture of a software system is typically created early in the development process and is refined as development progresses. It is an essential step in the software development process because it sets the stage for the system's implementation and helps ensure that the system is scalable, maintainable, and flexible.

When creating an architecture, it is important to consider factors such as performance, scalability, reliability, and security. The architecture should also take into account the system's intended users and the environment in which the system will operate.

Overall, architecture is an essential part of software development. It sets the stage for the development process and helps ensure that the final system is scalable, maintainable, and flexible.

uses the physical and chemical properties of matter to unravel the mysteries of the world around us. Our chemistry curriculum offers students a broad and flexible foundation, from organic chemistry to analytical techniques and physical science. Students choose between two areas of emphasis: Analytical Chemistry and Chemistry and Biochemistry.
Chemistry is the study of the composition and structure of matter. It is one of the basic sciences, and all sciences, from biology and environmental science to physics and nanoscience, can be traced to chemical processes. Chemistry, therefore, is not only of intrinsic scientific interest, but is a course of study with applications in the world around us. Students will learn the essential concepts of organic and inorganic chemistry and will be exposed to the various methods used to investigate chemical phenomena. A second-year course in inorganic chemistry further builds on knowledge of molecular structure, chemical bonding, and the roles of electron configurations and configurations of radiation emitted by atoms during chemical reactions. The accompanying computer laboratory (Chromatography and Spectroscopy Lab) gives students the opportunity to develop the skills required to operate these instruments.
Our three faculty members bring a broad array of research interests to our chemistry program, resulting in a wide variety of courses and program options for undergraduate students. All three faculty work closely with members of the Department of Biochemistry and also with other faculty across the Faculty of Science. Three examples of their research interests follow: catalysis for chemical synthesis, nanomaterials and magnetism. Find out more about their research here.
Molecular Spectroscopy Lab provides students with hands-on experience in light spectroscopy, ultraviolet-visible absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy, infrared and circular dichroism spectroscopy, with applications in biophysical chemistry and organic synthesis. The second-year Practical Organic Chemistry laboratory is the starting point for a program in the modern organic chemistry laboratory. It provides the fundamentals in chromatography and spectroscopy, with applications to quantitative analysis, synthesis, reaction mechanisms, qualitative analysis, and the preparation and analysis of various samples. The laboratory sets up students for upper-level organic chemistry laboratory courses.

as the yogi sees it is basically this: Meditation is to not be ego-focused, but to be rather focused on the outer world and environment. It is said that by doing this the yogi gains immortality and achieves great power and enlightenment.
His focus on developing his meditation techniques came from many years of personal observations, experimentation and great reward from his devotees. He was so enamoured of meditation that he gave up his very loving wife, who later became his devotee.
He developed the technique of meditation from two branches. One was seeking the elimination of the delusion in man, by using the "science of sensation". This second branch of practice he coined "mantra-samhara" or "mantra practice".
The mantra was taught as a technique to focus his mind's attention on the Omkrishna mantra to bring about the change in his mind that he desired. Thereby, he would attain greater awareness of himself.
There are different types of mantras and the yogi would use different ones depending on his thoughts or beliefs. He would also change his mantra as his thoughts and feelings changed.
His mantra practice and techniques are very similar to what many modern scientists have come up with. The main idea is that our mind is like a machine and its actions are like the operations of the machine. If we want to change the way our mind thinks, we need to learn how to change the program that drives our mind. We must learn to change the thoughts.
There is no difference between a mantra and a mantra practice. A mantra practice is the practice of focusing our attention on an object of meditation, not necessarily on the mantra itself.
Our focus is focused on an object and the mental representation of the object. If you think about a flower, you have to focus your attention on it before it can actually become a part of you.
The very act of visualizing an object in your mind's eye and training yourself to notice and be aware of the movement and changes in the mental imagery itself is called the "meditation."
The same goes for a mantra. If we visualize a mantra and focus on it until it becomes part of our subconscious mind, we can use it to change our beliefs or attitudes. By doing this, we can find better ways to control our own actions and emotions.
In order to meditate on a mantra, one must understand that they cannot be "enlightened" just by memorizing the mantra. However, we are very capable of becoming enlightened by simply visualizing our mantra and focusing on it

based deep learning models. ## Data We use BBT data from OpenBabel (https://github.com/openbabel/openbabel/blob/master/bbt.data) for our experiments. ## Training ### Layer wise training This approach involves assigning one task to each layer of a neural network. The input is a matrix of the input molecules and each column represents a fingerprint. If the matrix has $N$ columns and $D$ is the desired dimension of the feature space, $X$ is an $N \times D$ matrix. The dense layers are initialized to learn the individual feature representations of each fingerprint and the connections between the input and the dense layers are not learned. Reference: [ijcnn 11](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v130/ismail11.pdf) or [nips 16](https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.03509) ### Alignment based layer wise training This method has the same idea as the previous one. However, it also allows us to learn the connections between dense layers. The most prominent usage of the learned representation and the subsequent aligned representation across layers would be what BDE uses here (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jcim.0c00535) which involves finding the alignment that will "complete the graph" and learn the connections. References: [ijcnn 13](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v130/ismail13.pdf) and [access](https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jcim.0c00535) ### Fast conformational sampling Petr Sokolov wrote an extension to OpenBabel which uses accelerated conformational sampling when using this method (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jcim.7b00146) The idea is simple, we simply add a sampled data set at the same time as the input data and have the model learning from that as well. ## DeepSearch The idea here is to incorporate the deep learning model directly into a literature search so that a model is used to direct users to relevant articles. ## BioBERT Recently, there has been renewed interest in deep learning in the NLP field. Question: The geometry of quantum mechanics

Quantum geometry is the geometry of quantum mechanics, involving the use of the geometry in which quantum physics describes the internal structure and interactions of all physical objects[2]. The science behind quantum mechanics has allowed us to get a detailed understanding of how our universe works[1]. In quantum geometry, we know which quanta to expect, and when and where they should be found[3]. The wavelike nature of quantum objects means that their positions are spread out over an interval called their momentum[3]. The relationship between geometry and quantum mechanics is also summarized in the Bohr–Sommerfeld quantization rules[5].

has been great and the ripples of stargazing are still being felt. Unlike many other branches of science and technology, astronomy has made itself more useful to humans than what the science initially shows.
Astronomers have several practical interests like improving positional navigation, which helped us understand the geography, longitude, and time. They were the first to discover the magnetic property of iron and how to accurately produce magnetic compasses. Astronomers were also the first to construct accurate maps of stars on the ground. The scientific discoveries made by astronomy was among the principle causes for exploration, travel and transportation, specifically ships. Most measurements of distance, size, shape and volume used everyday on land are either based on or derived from astronomical principles, and the earth itself is also an astronomical body. Astronomers have also performed complete (albeit incomplete) assessments of the history and development of the earth and solar system. The information obtained by the science of astronomy has formed the foundation for the science of geology.
Astronomy has influenced human interaction with weather. The atmospheric pressure, the types of winds, and the temperature variations in various parts of the world were described and explained by means of astronomy. Astronomy also influenced the storm warning system, allowing ship captains and residents to predict and prepare for extreme weather and storm events. Today, we understand the mechanism of winds, tornadoes, hurricanes, hurricanes, and typhoons that are related to astronomic changes.
The timing of all events on earth has been determined by the ancient astronomers. This American, who moved to Philadelphia to attend university, had been a writer of cookbooks and culinary blogs for years, but always dreamed of having her own food brand. It was the time when all the Mums' cookbooks were hitting the market and the trend of canning food had just started.
After finally quitting her job as a web developer, she published the book and started Marisa McClellan Photography. Today, she offers workshops and travels around the US, spreading her message and trying to convince as many people as possible to support local markets and get in touch with their local produce. She is a true inspiration and her story gives hope to every non-English speaker wanting to get some foodie credentials, like me!
