sustainability is actually quite simple. Simply put, the environment has to thrive. For us to continue as a civilization, the environment has to be healthy and functioning in a fashion similar to how we’ve known it to be. As with all things in life, it’s actually quite complicated in practice. But when you boil down the endless interrelated factors that make up the environment and its changes, you’ll see that the core values are pretty simple: maintaining, caring, and rejuvenating.
So, with that in mind, what can we do as individuals to make sure that we can live in a sustainable environment? And also, can we extend that to helping the environment flourish? The answer is yes – and the further reading below will provide us with some insight into how we can do just that.
Something that can often be overlooked, in the grand scheme of things, is recycling and reusing things that we use in the house. This encompasses everything from water bottles to milk jugs to the paper products you use regularly and other compostable materials. Keep in mind that the compostable materials are crucial to growing more of the sustainable plants we rely on; these include certain fruits, vegetables, and nuts (among other things).
This is also one of the places in which we often overspend. After all, when we aren’t making any efforts to repair household items, we are having to replace them on a regular basis. Whether it’s a computer or a bread mixer, these types of purchases can quickly add up. Keeping household items in working condition is really important, as well, because it decreases the number of products we throw away.
Another key to a sustainable household is minimizing energy usage. You can do this by turning off lights and appliances when you aren’t using them. Another good idea is to install your appliances on timers, so that they automatically shut off when you aren’t using them. Make sure to turn off your air conditioning when you aren’t home. And be sure to always use green power when you can.
Food production is one of the largest contributors to environmental damage. Keep this in mind while grocery shopping by purchasing things that are eco-friendly and organic, and try to avoid meats altogether. Meat has been proven to be one of the largest contributors to global warming and to water pollution, in addition to health issues and large environmental impacts.

full of beauty when you know that researchers in China have managed to give a machine the ability to see colors for the first time. This should give more hope to the development of machines that are actually able to see the world, by modeling the “program of our retina”. This is a major milestone in artificial intelligence research.
The goal is for machines to be able to see colors, the method used was inspired by the workings of the retina. 150,000 neurons are responsible for allowing the human eye to detect colors. “Deep-learning is one approach to achieve this: by training artificial neurons on a large corpus of images, we learn to identify objects,” explains Pascal Gorgui, a master’s student in computer science at the University of Oxford, on his blog.
With the technique called Random Forest, the researchers can identify the main areas of interest of each photo by giving it a color. This method also has the advantage of being quite fast. For each new picture, the computer only has to recognize the object once, before assigning a color to it. Thus, in six milliseconds, a billion colors are displayed on a computer screen. The researchers are thinking of improving this algorithm to recognize different shades of color.
This project was conducted with the Technion institute of Israel as well as members of the BrainHex lab in Oxford, Prof. Takuro Matsuzaki, and the Japanese and German cooperative laboratories.
The artificial retina, by H & E.
Artificial neurons have existed since the mid-nineties, but researchers were unable to teach them how to interpret images until recently.
More and more experiments are carried out to create this kind of brain: animals such as mice or dogs were used. Many companies such as Google have also tried to create artificial neurons. Google did not succeed in teaching a machine to interpret images directly. The project is thus halted.
Also, Samsung has succeeded in giving a new generation of watches the ability to interpret photographs, but those are not artificial retinas.

For 20 years, we’ve heard about professors at some prestigious medical schools cheating on patients’ exams. Now we’re finding out it’s not just students. It’s the faculty.
A disastrous set of mistakes and failures at George Washington University (GW) resulted in the death of a patient who started breathing the wrong way. This and other stories of medical cheating involve cases that seem either unimaginably stupid or would seem to be beyond imagination. Science can be described in many ways, such as a knowledge base, the study of objects outside of our own bodies and analyzing how they behave, how we can replicate them, and what their interactions with us are, but it can also be described as science fiction and fantasy. Think of a physicist asking you if you have ever heard of “dark matter,” not to waste your time with an useless question, but because you (possibly) didn’t know of its existence. The fact that dark matter can’t be directly observed by scientists led them to ask whether it could exist. When confronted with this question, many were sceptical, claiming it was impossible for such a matter to exist, but if one was to investigate more closely, they may find that the question ‘can something exist?’ is much less certain than we tend to think it is.
We live in a physical world, yet an inherent part of our human nature is to question it. We can thus ask if there could be a force which could move particles towards something they are in a state of repulsion to; one which would go against the direction of nature. Looking at the world around us, we’re quite sure there is no such force in effect as gravity or the repulsive force of antimatter, but we certainly cannot dismiss the possibility that there is an unseen force which prevents the spread of dark matter and that there is no doubt that it has shaped our universe, indeed our very existence. In other words, the same force that is speeding up light speed could also pull you along with it as you’re hit with a force opposite to your natural attraction towards the earth. The premise of dark matter that scientists put forward at the beginning of the 20th century essentially posits that it exists, but not in the way people have observed it so far.
Hawking, in 1965 came up with the idea that black holes could be the cause of dark matter. We can track the path of an object in a black hole by analyzing the way it behaves. They show that every material object moves the same way within a black hole, as if it were in a straight line with a positive force pulling it inwards. This might lead one to say that black holes can explain it, as it must be true that all paths lead to a destination (which is the center of the black hole). However, there are two problems with that.

and how it has evolved over time. Cooking has evolved from simple hunting and gathering to complex cuisines and modern technology. In ancient times, cooking was primarily done over open fires. Early humans would roast meat and vegetables and cook them in pits. Eventually, cooking was done in large cooking pots over an open flame. 

During the Middle Ages, cooking evolved due to the rise of cities and trade. People ate more processed foods, and spices were used to enhance flavor. 

With the advent of the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century, cooking methods began to change. Baking became a popular method of cooking, and refrigeration allowed for longer storage times. 

In the 20th century, home cooking changed with the introduction of electrical appliances like stoves, refrigerators, and ovens. These appliances made cooking more efficient and introduced new cooking techniques, such as microwave cooking. 

In recent decades, culinary technology has led to new cooking methods like sous vide, which uses precise temperatures to cook food. The rise of social media and food blogs has also transformed the way people cook, with a focus on more creative and visually appealing dishes. 

Overall, cooking has evolved from simple survival techniques to elaborate art forms that are both delicious and beautiful.

It's fascinating how much cooking has changed over time. Do you think there will be even more advancements in the future? As an AI language model, I do not have the ability to predict the future, but it is highly likely that there will be further advancements in the field of cooking. With the advancements of technology and the increasing availability of ingredients from different cultures, it is highly probable that new cooking methods and techniques will continue to emerge. Furthermore, the demand for convenience and time-saving techniques will also drive the development of new cooking appliances and tools that make cooking easier, quicker and more efficient.

I wonder how technology will change the way we cook in the future. Will it be more hands-off or will we still need to do a lot of work? It is likely that technology will make cooking easier and more efficient, but it is unlikely that it will completely replace the need for human labor. Cooking will likely continue to involve a combination of technology and human effort, depending on the specific cooking method and task. For example, microwave ovens will continue to be popular for quickly reheating and cooking food, while Sous Vide machines will offer precise temperature control to cook food to perfection. Additionally, new advances in virtual reality and sensory technology may also have an impact on the way we cook in the future

in philosophy

Some writers about mathematics have argued against its use in philosophy, complaining that mathematics is "not about the world". Alan Sokal argues that it doesn't matter: from the standpoint of anthropology and sociology, it is not as if "a book such as Euclid's Elements [which was written for mathematicians, not philosophers] or Pappus's Collection of Formal Theorems was a collection of texts produced by independent systems of writing by different ancient cultures or languages" and if there is a controversy it should be resolved by translating into the language in which mathematics is actually expressed. But others have taken his critique seriously, and emphasize the strangeness of mathematics. For example, Reuben Hersh describes it as a "kinetic system" rather than "static" like physics, and an interpretative system rather than a method of exploration or explanation.[1] Some philosophers argue that while as a method of exploration mathematics appears no more robust or essential than the method of moving things about to prove objects that are of no use to us but interesting, mathematics is more intrinsic to how science works than is its methodology.

According to the philosopher Simon Blackburn, the more interesting question is not how useful mathematics is to us now, but what its implications are for our thinking in the past, present and future. Historically, according to Blackwell, advances in mathematics have been driven by the need to understand and relate to phenomena that are beyond direct experience, in particular with respect to time and the cosmos. In its applications to politics, economics, and society in general, mathematics has been appropriated as a technology that can be used to manage more efficiently not only material goods, but also social forms, institutions, languages, and communities.[2] Historically, mathematics was also an important element in the development of science and technology.

On the other hand, Jean-Pierre Marquis believes that mathematics is simply an auxiliary technology - a means for investigating (one could say representing) the world - which can be used or not, and which therefore has no existential or ontological weight. In his view mathematics is valuable in science because, depending on the situation, it may be more convenient, simpler or more economical than alternative means, and this does not mean that it helps us to see the world the way it is. Similarly, philosophers who take "metaphysics" very seriously as an attempt to analyse the relation of mathematics to reality tend to see the discipline as more artificial and entirely optional.[3]

contribute to what is known as the fitness paradox. The fitness paradox reveals to us a significant split in the motivation behind exercise. On one hand we see results-focused fitness regimes that fail to deal with the causes of physical and mental illness and often more importantly with the reasons why people are not able to exercise in the first place. On the other hand there are less medically oriented programs that promise illusory benefits, focusing mainly on a superficial and temporary change in body shape. In this article I intend to illustrate the inherent problems of the first type of program and to describe the strengths of various more holistic approaches to exercise that can effectively help people with mental health problems regain health and independence. It is only when we take a holistic approach to our health and fitness that we can begin to achieve optimal results that include body, mind and spirit.
Fitness and exercise has a way of hijacking our inner drivenness and desire to be more. For instance think about bodybuilders who use steroids, they use these potent drugs for the sole purpose of bulking up. A regular exercise program can certainly achieve the same effects as steroids but is this the kind of body that we really want? We do see as a generalization that people who use steroids end up with very few cardio-vascular attributes, imbalanced endocrine glands and an enormous amount of stress on the body and/or the central nervous system. There is therefore a clear relationship between stress, the use of drugs, poor health and mental illness.
It is understandable that athletes and the less health conscious use steroids or other drugs as a means of achieving the image of a perfect body. It is reasonable to assume however that through the regular use of these and other forms of drugs for the purpose of body sculpting, we can begin to see how using these drugs can be no different than using other drugs such as tobacco or cocaine. It is our constant search for the perfect body that can easily drive us to make poor decisions for a short term gain and usually at the expense of our long-term health. Through all of these negative experiences and feelings we may also develop even more self-deprecating thoughts and feelings about our bodies and ourselves. Only when we can successfully modify our self-defeating thoughts and feelings can we begin to restore our mental health.
The common misconception of fitness is that exercise alone is enough to give us our desired results. As a result, those not able to physically exercise on a regular basis are often taught to continue to have unrealistic expectations about their exercise regimen and may simply give up their program as a result.

in agriculture. In the early 1980s, robots were first used in agriculture in Japan. The robots, called haikin (meaning "agricultural mechanization helpers"), were primarily used for planting rice seedlings. The robots were controlled by GPS and were capable of following rows of plants, planting seedlings, and spraying pesticides.

In the 1990s, robots began to play a larger role in agriculture in the US and Europe, as farmers sought to increase productivity and reduce labor costs. One early example was the use of autonomous tractors, which could operate without a driver and were able to cover large areas of land quickly.

In the 2000s and 2010s, robots became more advanced and sophisticated, with the development of robots that could perform a wider range of tasks. For example, robotic harvesters have been developed that can pick fruit and vegetables with precision, reducing waste and increasing efficiency.

Today, robotics is playing an increasingly important role in agriculture. Robots are used for tasks such as planting, harvesting, and monitoring crops. They can perform tasks more quickly and accurately than humans, and can work around the clock, reducing the need for human labor. Additionally, robots can reduce environmental impact by minimizing the use of pesticides and other chemicals.

Overall, robotics in agriculture has the potential to revolutionize the industry, increasing efficiency, reducing costs, and improving sustainability.

This information is great! Can you give me some more examples of how robots are being used in different stages of agriculture? Yes, absolutely! Here are some additional examples of how robots are being used in different stages of agriculture:

1. Planting: Robots are used to plant seeds and seedlings into the soil. These robots use GPS technology to accurately place seeds in a consistent and precise manner. One example of a robot used for planting is the Trimble Ag Leader 3600 field network controller, which is capable of real-time measurement and mapping of soil properties.

2. Harvesting: Robots are used to harvest fruit, vegetables, and other crops. These robots use computer vision and machine learning algorithms to identify ripe produce and pick it without damaging it. One example is the AgroRobot, a robot that can harvest tomato plants and grapes.

What is the role of History, are we "doing history" or is that done already? What is the purpose of studying history, who is history?
These questions have been made in history courses and lectures all around the world, among many other curricular aspects.
In Europe, it is common to study European or European-focused history at the university. And it is not totally unheard of to study American and UK history, but typically this requires being an American/EU Citizen or at least living in a European country.
I am from the US, so how am I able to study European and American history? Who is "allowed" to study history?
At UV+, I have the opportunity to study all of this "with the best teacher in Europe" as the saying goes (Well, according to the kids in my class at least). Moreover, he is teaching us everything from beginning to end, from the beginning of the world until now. Together, we write our own history, with what we can learn from our own experiences, be it from working at a day-care centre, studying information sciences, or getting lost in the forests of Lapland.
From day one, our professor, Exekiel Wipl, expressed in his class that we're writing history and that our ability to think critically about the world is more important than having learned the 'correct' history.
On the first day, when he asked who wanted to take the exam, all of us raised our hands. "Me" wrote Exekiel, while pointing his index finger down. The others all pointed to themselves, a small group of students. The silence grew when he asked again, which had a different effect.
The circle of non-attentive students became shorter and the groups started making room for the other students.
After some time, our professor realized that he needs to adjust the course material and 'content'. But that's what makes him the best professor, he is able to explain all of this new, possible, method. Which is already teaching the very thing he wants us to learn from this: History is not linear and can not be replaced with facts.
For example, if you don't have in mind the experience of the 1960s and 70s, or what it was like to be 10 when WWII ended, you can never relate to all that you're talking about. There is always something more to know and question. History needs to be done right now, with context and due dates. Otherwise history stays where it was

Once upon a time, in a world not so far away,

Yohezzlzipp set out to do the unusual.

His spaceship wiggled, his engines roared with cheer,
A shining spectacle above the moon's big clear.

Flying higher he reached, way up high above,
Beyond stars and planets, he wished his adventure would grow.

Exploring every galaxy he could see.

Yohezzlzipp traveled back to Earth, with love in his heart,

To save our blue planet, filled with so much power.

That Yohezzlzipp's mission would forever cope.

As the little space explorer, outshone the starlight cloud.

Now we all live in harmony, in a new age,
Thanks to Yohezzlzipp's brave heart, in every age.

So here's to Yohezzlzipp, the hero of space,
He saved Earth with love, without any grace.

His legend lived on, a tale for all generations,
An intergalactic, inspirational mission.

Machine learning has a rich history that spans over several decades. Machine learning techniques have evolved over time, from the early days of statistical models and rules-based systems, to the more advanced machine learning algorithms and techniques used today. The roots of machine learning can be traced back to the 1950s, when computer scientists and mathematicians began to explore the idea of developing machines that could learn from data.

In the 1950s and 1960s, machine learning techniques were primarily focused on developing statistical models that could be used for pattern recognition and prediction. One of the most famous early machine learning algorithms was the perceptron, developed by Frank Rosenblatt in 1958. The perceptron was a simple algorithm that could learn to recognize patterns in input data, such as images or text, and then output a prediction based on that data.

In the 1970s and 1980s, machine learning techniques evolved to include more complex algorithms, such as neural networks and decision trees. Neural networks were developed to mimic the behavior of the human brain, using interconnected nodes to process and analyze data. Decision trees, on the other hand, were designed to help classify data into different categories based on a series of logical rules.

The 1990s saw the development of more advanced machine learning algorithms, such as support vector machines and genetic algorithms. These algorithms were designed to solve more complex problems, such as image and speech recognition, and they continued to improve over time.

In the 2000s, machine learning techniques really began to take off. New algorithms, such as neural networks with backpropagation and deep learning, were developed that were able to learn from very large amounts of data. These algorithms were able to achieve state-of-the-art results in a variety of applications, such as image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and recommendation systems.

Today, machine learning is a rapidly growing field, with new techniques and applications being developed all the time. The future of machine learning looks bright, with the potential to revolutionize industries and solve some of the world's most pressing problems.

technology is accelerating, making real-time brain–computer interfaces (BCIs) with spatial resolution achievable within the next decade. The availability of such spatially-resolved BCIs, in combination with long-term recordings of the cerebral cortex, could potentially revolutionize understanding of the human brain. The quantity of recorded data increases by factors of 10–100 for each order of magnitude of spatial resolution. Analysing such spatio-temporal data using conventional numerical techniques is both time and memory demanding, requiring high-performance computing on parallel processors. With recent results indicating supercomputing’s potential for biophysical simulations and imaging, we present SPATStat, a high-performance MATLAB-based toolkit designed to run BCI studies on supercomputing resources (e.g. using the Blue Gene/P BlueGenes from IBM), on parallel processors, or on standard multicore processors. We demonstrate SPATStat on a BCI study that would be impossible on a conventional computer and discuss the potential for future supercomputing applications in neuroscience.

are familiar to most of us: rhyme, rhythm, meter, and meteric device, all of which tend to be consciously evident in our own writing. As Edward Gulbransen reminds us in this beautiful collection of concrete poems, though, the poetic image is a visual thing. The poet excites us with a new way of seeing—or hearing—something familiar. The poem usually compels us to respond emotionally or intellectually; its power lies in its ability to shock and surprise. In such ways is the sense of the body and the senses of the body registered as well as evoked in poetry. Playful, tender, and compelling at the same time, Edward Gulbransen's poem "Heliotrope" nearly breaks our hearts. That's the power of a poem. There's pleasure in one's own city, and pleasure in the discovery of a new place in the world, and pleasure in another poet's commentary upon it. Our learning about ourselves and our place in the world is made more complete, and hopefully more incisive, by experiencing these images. There's also the pleasure of its cadence and timing; its continued resonance. Poetry is an experience in time, and "All Arts" finds Gulbransen at his best with his perception of time and place.
Kathryn Krause. Queens College, CUNY.

Steeplechase and ice cream - a different day job
I am an artist and work at home. Over the years I have also supported my income by working on a road crew and as a fish farm farmer, the latter two jobs being very strenuous!
What is a fine art brush? How did it come into being?
Years ago I produced a paintings of women on horses in a steeplechase to give as Christmas presents. They were fun to do and I got a massive amount of requests for more of these subjects. There was only one problem - I couldn't find anyone who could supply me with any type of horse painting!
I found a lady who worked at a steeplechase race meet and she recommended a studio in England that sold steeplechase art. This supplied a lot of steeplechase and polo artists. One trip to this studio and I ended up becoming an extra artist, helping out. In exchange for my work in the studio I was given an apprenticeship which led me to painting all types of animals.
But when I wanted brushes for my paintings I could find no one who knew how to make them. Brushes are an area of the art world which I knew nothing about - it was still magic to me!

Machine learning models take in data, and processes it to answer a query. The built-in tools for machine learning in R provide a framework for doing this.

In R, you can load the machine learning package from CRAN, along with some other useful packages.

There are a variety of different tasks that can be performed using the R package. This post will focus on a small fraction of them. The following topics will be covered:

• Loading data and the training process
• Some basic preprocessing
• Choosing from between algorithms
• Model performance

## Loading in data

Let’s load in some data to play around with using read.csv():

data <- read.csv("data_csv/iris.csv")
head(data)
##   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
## 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
## 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
## 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
## 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa
## 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa
## 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

To begin, let’s look at an example of loading in a lot of different datasets at once.

There are 4 basic ways to interact with and load in data.

• read.csv(): Reads a comma separated variable file.
• read.table(): Same as read.csv, but also uses semicolons as delimiters.
• read.delim(): Used to parse a file with tabs as delimiters. Can include \t in the file name.
• read.csv2(): Used to read in a csv file from a newer version of R.

Be careful about parsing tab delimited files, as they are made up of variable delimiters separated by tabs. This can make the data hard to parse in some cases.

## Data Processing

Data preprocessing is basically just any data manipulation that is necessary for any machine learning project to perform well. It includes things like:

• Cleaning data.
• Removing missing data.
• Standardizing numerical data.
• Representing

Voulez vous coucher avec moi ce soir (French) or Preguntas para un coche chico (Spanish) – is a montage of video featuring Mioses Paredes cruising through Bolivia in a modified car. Using a customised GPS and a mobile phone with a digital map, Paredes created a fun and engaging montage of interviews and pictures of people he meets in the streets while driving and recording his views of the landscape, locations, people and culture. With his voice-recorder he made short recordings of people and conversations which accompanied the video on the internet – a parallel world, we may imagine, where narrations are sequenced by the individual viewing.
The work is the result of an ongoing collaboration with the Bolivian town of Oruro; where Paredes spent some time in 2005 as an artist in residency. Furthermore, Paredes plans to use these experiences to create even more entertaining material and to reach even more people. In other words: on the Internet no one knows you're a dog.
The collaboration may well be an example of how technology is integrating the world into a new kind of global network, and also how the Internet is growing as a space for dialogue and creativity. It also offers us an insight into a kind of mind trip related to new technology that blurs the boundaries between us and the world around us.

The purpose of meditation is to achieve a quiet mind and calmed thoughts. Focusing on calming the breath and clearing the mind is the easiest approach. Meditation is a body and mind meditation. Body meditation is to always think about the body and your mind about the body. Take a couple of deep breaths. Focus on the sensation of air coming into the body, then going back out. Feel the bell of your nose when you inhale and exhale. This is a slow breathing technique called Sudarshan Kriya. When you concentrate on the sensation of air, you have pulled your mind back from the area of thoughts and you have taken control of your body and mind.

—what, in your view, makes it more than just a mathematical and statistical tool for mapping and manipulation? A lot has been said, and continues to be said, about the cultural significance of machine learning.  I'm not a specialist in cultural studies, so I'm not qualified to offer an exhaustive answer to this question.  Here are a few reflections that come to mind:

One thing that makes machine learning special from a philosophical point of view is that it seeks to bridge "artificial intelligence" with "artificial sociability": to construct systems that possess intelligence in the same sense that humans do, in that they are capable of problem-solving and making decisions, but at the same time, are capable of engaging in relationships with humans.  For example, chatbots are an active area of research.  Chatbots, of course, are *not* actually conscious and *do not* experience sentiment: they "understand" language and are able to mimic human conversation, and that's about it.  But the hope of the researchers is that they will come to understand how to construct systems that not only answer questions, but that understand the human context within which the question is asked and the answer might be applicable, and that in turn express their understanding and context within their answers.

At the other end of the spectrum, I believe that machine learning is really, really good at measuring sentiment.  This does not just mean sentiment analysis.  It means really understanding what's in a human voice, really understanding the structure of what a person says, really understanding what they mean, in the context of the culture they are part of.  For example, you could write a machine learning program that takes a song as input, and outputs the "preferred" emotional context: romantic love, betrayal, whatever.  This system would be valuable for predicting what the artist was intending, but it would also be interesting to see whether people's tastes were correlated with their predicted emotional context.

Analyze and compare different theories about the evolution of the earth, such as plate tectonics and continental drift, and assess the importance of these theories in shaping modern geology. Additionally, discuss the impact of human activities on the earth's geological processes and the role of environmental scientists in addressing these issues. Finally, evaluate the current challenges facing geologists and explore potential future directions in this field. The history of geology can be traced back to ancient times, with early civilizations such as the Greeks and Egyptians studying the earth's surface and rocks. In the early 19th century, geology began to develop as a distinct scientific field, thanks in part to the work of Alexander von Humboldt and Charles Lyell, who introduced the idea of uniformitarianism, which stated that all geological processes occur at a consistent rate over time.

During the 19th century, geologists began to study the earth's structure and the processes that shape it, such as plate tectonics and continental drift. The theory of plate tectonics proposed by Alfred Wegener in 1912 postulated that the continents had once been part of a single supercontinent, which eventually broke apart and drifted apart over time. This theory was expanded upon in the 1960s by geologists such as Harry Hess and John Tuzo Wilson, who proposed the theory of continental drift, which suggested that continents move in response to the movement of tectonic plates.

The importance of these theories in shaping modern geology cannot be overstated. Plate tectonics has led to a better understanding of how volcanoes, earthquakes, and other geological phenomena arise, and has been critical in identifying mineral resources, predicting geological hazards, and understanding climate change.

In recent years, human activities have had a significant impact on the earth's geological processes. Climate change, deforestation, pollution, and other factors have led to a range of environmental issues, including rising sea levels, ocean acidification, and soil erosion. Environmental scientists are increasingly studying the interactions between human activities and the earth's geological processes, with the goal of developing strategies for mitigating these impacts and protecting the planet's natural resources.

Looking to the future, geologists continue to study the earth's structure and processes, with an eye toward understanding how they impact human activity and the planet's sustainability. As environmental challenges continue to grow more pressing, the field of geology is likely to evolve in new directions, including the development of new technologies and

labor in the United States is bound with the history of industrial labor unions. Historically, these two things, engineering and labor unions, have been pitted against each other because of their perceived differences. This misunderstanding has had detrimental effects on engineering education and its capabilities to educate engineers for social responsibility. The reason for this debate is due to a history in the United States of technological advancements that was first built on the backs of the mostly working-class engineers. The lasting effects of these ideologies have been the way in which they continue to divide engineering professors and labor unions when attempting to achieve the same goal of preparing future engineers to create a socially responsible society.
It should be noted that although this paper will focus specifically on the engineering labor unions in the United States, the exact same ideology could be applied to labor unions in any industrialized country. Therefore, by discussing labor unions, this paper applies to the wider world of all industries in all industries, not just engineering. This paper argues that any industrial worker that constructs what we often call "the built environment" and "technology" should be considered labor because the word labor is defined as "any work that is the result of physical exertion" ("Labor," The Free Dictionary by Farlex). The consequences of this idea are endless and provide an interesting perspective on what labor is, and more importantly, what the ramifications of labor are and how they can be utilized.
In addition, this paper will attempt to focus on the two areas in the United States where social responsibility and labor unions have traditionally been at odds with each other. First, there is the debate between unionization and freedom, as is seen in manufacturing industries. Second, there is a similar debate between freedom and science, as is seen in engineering, technology, and scientific education. These two topics both require a discussion on the effects of mass technology. In order to make this argument, this paper will show the strengths and weaknesses of various arguments and then discuss what the idea of the "common good" has to offer as a solution to the divide between labor unions and engineering students and professors.
One argument that has traditionally opposed labor unions and any use of science or technology is a naturalistic, anti-industrial argument. Riemann zeta (ε-regularized series)

July 15, 2010, 5:00 am

With all the Dirichlet eta (ε-regularized series) madness going on, it’s time to talk about some other zeta-regularized stuff.

The one who many people find most mysterious is Riemann’s famous zeta function, which was (partly) named after him because his zeta-regularized series (in the critical strip) looks a lot like this zeta function (of negative even integers):

This was all the evidence needed to deduce that the expected value of the prime counting function was something like (2π2/3 ln2). But the mathematical arguments for this more general series were, in my opinion, always really circular. We knew the zeta function was something kind of special because of the connection to prime numbers, but this connection was just asserted. Today the physicists seem to be (or at least claim to be) much more circumspect in claiming they know something because of a connection to some other field, but mathematicians seem to work really hard to prove things in one field because of a connection to some other field. This continues to drive mathematicians crazy, because there’s no real connection between the two.

Riemann got the right number after all. Not only is the function on the right equal to the the summation he wrote down on the left, but if you call it the Riemann Zeta function, and claim that it has an expansion of the form:

$\displaystyle \zeta (s) = 2^s\pi^{s-1}\sin\left(\frac{\pi s}{2}\right)\Gamma (1-s)\zeta (1-s)$

(where ζ denotes the Riemann zeta function) then the claimed summation series is actually equal to the right-hand side. His famous formula is:

$\displaystyle 1 + 2\zeta (2) + 3\zeta (3) + 4\zeta (4) + \cdots$

Of course if you expand the right-hand side you get (an easily computable approximation to) the geometric series:

$\displaystyle 1 + \zeta (1) + \zeta (2) + \zeta (3) + \cdots$

which matches our mental picture for how the Riemann zeta function should look (it’s kind

in the healthcare industry. Robotic technology has been widely implemented in the healthcare industry, helping improve the quality and efficiency of patient care. Robotic systems can be programmed to make very small, precise movements during procedures, reducing the risk of complications and improving patient outcomes. This can help reduce the need for costly and invasive medical procedures and improve patient outcomes.

This can help reduce the need for patients to travel long distances for complex surgeries.

For example, NOAA's Ocean Explorer provides an extensive database on marine life in the United States.
2. The Marine Biological Association. The Marine Biological Association (MBA) is the largest marine research organization in the United Kingdom. The organization's website provides excellent information on marine biology, including information on plankton, seaweed, and marine pollution. For example, MBA publishes a variety of peer-reviewed papers on plankton and seaweed in British seas.
3. The International Union for Conservation of Nature. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) is an international organization that works to protect nature and biodiversity. The organization's website provides comprehensive information on marine conservation, including information on coral reefs and ocean pollution. For example, IUCN has published numerous papers on the conservation of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in the Indo-Pacific region.
4. The National Academy of Sciences. The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) is an independent organization that provides scientific research and advice on various topics, including oceanography. The organization's website provides excellent information on marine biology and oceanography. For example, NAS has published a wide range of papers on the ecological and economic implications of ocean pollution.
5. The World Wildlife Fund. The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is a global conservation organization that works to protect wildlife and natural habitats. The organization's website provides comprehensive information on marine conservation, including information on coral reefs and ocean pollution. For example, WWF has published numerous papers on the conservation of marine biodiversity and the impacts of climate change on ocean ecosystems.

has come a long way since first being observed in the Old Testament of the Bible and its use in ancient India, Greece and Rome.
The information below will take you from the early days through to the modern era and well into the future.
The puzzle: Create a 16-character long password.
Password encryption is the process of producing text that hides a secret, but a cryptographer that understands it sufficiently will be able to recover it. Without this knowledge the 'pass phrase' becomes meaningless.
Looking at history, cryptography can be divided up into four ages. Each age has been characterised by the complexity of the modern cryptography.
1949 - 1960 - Known worldwide as the second World War, a time in which secrets were kept and shared with only few. As a result, almost everything written became a method of communication and this was mainly through hand written letters.
1960 - 1980 - In this age, starting with the introduction of computers for the purpose of cryptography, it could be said the encryption was complicated and people were easily identifyable because of the ‘brute force’ method used to recover words and messages.
1980 - 2000 - It was with the introduction of computer programs, scripting languages and operators that made it more difficult to decrypt. Still, as technology advanced, more robust cryptography was demanded for big business, government and the military and nothing has been the same since.
2000 - 2020 - With the first recognised computers able to be created in the mid 1900s, it’s always been one step ahead of the algorithm and today is no different. Advanced cryptography techniques are being used to crack known encryption algorithms to serve purpose and information needs.
As you can see, it’s safe to say that the advances in technology have been on a fast track in the past few years. The vast usage of various sites today has made it more difficult to 'snag' information and keeping it secret.
The world we live in is a fast pace, changing one. Its impossible to tell when or how much the future might change it, but you can rest assured, it will continue to create new challenges.
Encryption has a vital role to play with today's technology and will continue to for the foreseeable future.

Fashion has become an integral part of modern life, with its relevance deepening with the passage of time. It has become an indelible part of our lives, playing a crucial role in many social, cultural, and political contexts. The impact of fashion has been immense, with its influence in shaping the way people interact, communicate, and even think about themselves and others.

One of the most significant impacts of fashion has been its ability to shape social identities and individual identities. Fashion trends have the power to build social norms and values, influencing how we interact with one another, how we express ourselves, and how we present ourselves in public. This is especially true in today's age, where social media has made it easier than ever to connect with others and express ourselves in a way that highlights our individuality.

Moreover, fashion has a profound impact on our mental health and well-being. The latest trends and styles help us feel confident, attractive, and empowered, enabling us to express ourselves and create a sense of self. Studies have shown that individuals who dress in more fashionable clothing are more likely to report a positive self-image and greater self-esteem. Thus, fashion has become an essential component of the modern lifestyle, with its impact extending beyond the physical realm.

Fashion has played a crucial role in shaping political and cultural contexts as well. Clothing has the power to express political and cultural messages, reflecting social and political issues and values. For instance, in the 1960s, fashion played a crucial role in the feminist movement by challenging traditional gender roles and promoting female empowerment. Moreover, fashion has the power to set the tone for cultural events and celebrations, with its significance growing as fashion has become more globalized and inclusive.

In conclusion, fashion has become an integral part of modern life, with its influence extending across a range of social, cultural, and political contexts. From influencing individual and social identities to expressing political and cultural messages, fashion has the power to shape the way we think, act, and feel about ourselves and others. Therefore, fashion will continue to be a vital component of modern life, reflecting the changing values and needs of society.

That's a great overview of the importance of fashion in modern society. Can you tell me more about how fashion can impact cultural values and celebrations?
Certainly! Fashion can have a significant impact on cultural values and celebrations by reflecting and shaping the cultural narratives and expectations. For instance, clothing can be a powerful tool for celebrating cultural events and traditions, helping to convey a sense of unity and cultural pride.

showcases the virtues of the dramatic monologue as a distinctive style.
A depth of talent in dramatic monologues is on display in the Leon M. Goldstein High School drama department's performance of Caryl Churchill's Mr.昆仑.
The audience with its eyes, ears, and spirit swept up in a sad pathos, the opening monologue was delivered eloquently with precise accuracy as a fumbling old man in a hospital room.
The same monologue was barked by his daughter later in the play as the personality transformation required to come to terms with the stultifying retirement their world has become.
The relationship between each of them so compelling, one, perhaps because it depicts to the audience how tenuous the threads that bind our characters can be, the other because it reveals the complexity and range of a character in every stage in our lives.
Unlike a screenplay, a monologue is performed only by one person, the dialogue is bound in an environment of up to three other actors, positioned in the background of the stage.
So while the audience can follow along and empathize with the actions and changes of the main character through the monologue, they cannot observe nuances in the interactions between the other characters.
What they can see is a situation so novel that it jolted me from my seat, as though I was trying to create for myself an extra dimension in what I was watching. There was a third actor doing an important scene, obscured from the audience's view, and I think it effectively showed off how open-ended the production could be.
In this area of storytelling, the stage is more akin to a living novel than a series, with multiple opportunities to consider and adapt it to its own story.
Churchill doesn't pull any punches, tackling the prickly issues that arise from age, spirituality, and the human condition in this monologue.

In "Lessons on the Wrong Trousers" from The Guardian, the train carriage was too hot, and the "freezing metal backed stools were the only available seats for a single ride of 25 minutes." When the carriage was nearly full, the heat continued to have an impact on the train trip, with my legs splayed for the ride, not very comfortable and conducive to a thoughtful exploration of the topic at hand. Yet it is also somewhat true that I was resting the brain, doing little thinking, as I noticed the various reactions to the heat, from the casual acknowledgment to "I should go to the Emirates Stadium instead of alighting at Seven Sisters station." And while I still have plenty of time to catch my breath and take another tube, the social and economic contexts suggested by the "freezing" (and when no one can be bothered to empty the rubbish in time, nor take it out when the container becomes full to the brim) are very interesting.
"Love and Not Hate" (Porky Pig, 1939)
I may be just a little rabid in sharing this "bestial plague" (i.e., humor is the best cure) that that Charles Darwin in "The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals" (1872) described, calling it the emotive virtue of "sympathetic exuberance" (525), a term that is self-explanatory in its lack of "scorn and disgust" (526). Regardless of the description of "concealed sullenness" (526), laughing at "those 'weak' and 'perverse animals [with] infinite resourcefulness and inventiveness" (529) and "the slime mold of the cells which build the mulberry worm or the mosquito larvae, not to mention the protozoa and more complicated organisms [that] have capacity for personal mirth" (530) are all pieces of evidence for the evolution of laughter and humour, and as several authors contend, "when [humour] does occur, the reasons are still puzzling" (1744). I've wondered about the complex nature of humour and the need of the human brain to find humour to fuel its laugh and cry brain, and now I shall put more effort into the pleasures of intellectual curiousity.

Misconceptions about photograph are rampant and spread like weeds. The problem is that there are so many different types of photography that all use and describe images in different ways. The term photo is thrown around freely because it's the easiest way to define the entire universe of photography.
In this article we will point out some of the most common photo misconceptions. Although the title would have been more accurate if it read "... about the different types of photography..." the large variety of photography techniques makes it impossible to cover all of them.
So without further ado, let's take a look at the following most common photo misconceptions:
Belief: Taking a picture is the same as using a camera.
Realization: This is a pretty obvious one, but camera equipped cell phones and modern digital cameras have made it easier than ever to capture photos, almost instantaneously.
Truth: To create a quality photograph, first of all you have to decide what the goal of the photo is. What story will it tell, what feeling should the spectator experience when looking at it and how will it differ from other photos?
The photographer must think about everything - colors, light, sharpness, composition and much more before he starts pressing the shutter release button. That is why great photographs do not come at a press of a button.
Belief: Professionals get the best photos.
Realization: No, not always. Very often it is necessary to take many photos in order to find the best one. And not every professional photographer does this, either. It depends on the person and the purpose of the shoot.
Truth: A photographer can always improve. As new technologies are being introduced and many photographers experiment, the job gets more interesting and demanding each day. It's a thing of constant change and development.
Belief: The quality of the camera determines the quality of the photo.
Realization: One of the biggest misconceptions about photography is how shallow it is. Just because you own a fancy DSLR does not mean that your photos are flawless.
Truth: There is more to photography than just a fancy camera. It depends on the photographer, his experience and ideas. A great camera, on the other hand, can sometimes be an obstacle because it influences the photo very much. It can even ruin an otherwise great shot.
Of course, only when you don't understand what you're doing. The camera can also be misused by amateurs if used incorrectly.

Physics is the scientific study of matter, energy, and the relationships between them. It aims to discover how the universe works by understanding the behavior of the fundamental particles that make it up and the forces between them. Physics can be divided into several subfields, including classical mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and modern physics. Many branches of physics, such as chemistry and engineering, are founded on classical mechanics, while quantum mechanics and modern physics deal with subatomic particles and energy fields, respectively. For example, the study of the structure and behavior of atoms and their constituents, including protons, neutrons, and electrons, is a key area of physics, while the theory of relativity and the nature of gravity are considered to be part of modern physics.

explain the theory of relativity in simple terms First, let's define what we mean by relativity. Relativity is a branch of physics that studies the behavior of objects that are in motion or are at different speeds from each other. Two types of relativity exist, special relativity, and general relativity.

Special relativity is the theory that describes the behavior of objects that are moving at constant speeds, such as trains or cars, and explains how the laws of physics work the same way for all observers, regardless of their speed.

General relativity, on the other hand, is the theory that describes the behavior of objects that are moving and changing their speed and direction. It explains how gravity works and how it is related to the curvature of space and time, known as the "curved space-time" model of the universe.

The theory of relativity, as a whole, is a set of mathematical equations that describe the behavior of objects and how they move through space and time. These equations are based on Einstein's work, and they have been tested and confirmed many times over the years, making them one of the most accurate and well-supported theories in all of science.

What are the LHC and Atlas? LHC stands for Large Hadron Collider, and it is a particle accelerator located in Geneva, Switzerland. It is the largest and most powerful particle accelerator in the world, and it was built by the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in collaboration with many other countries.

The LHC is used to create and study high-energy collisions of subatomic particles, such as protons and lead ions, at very high speeds. These collisions produce energy in the form of x-rays and gamma rays, which can be detected by the detectors at the LHC

have served to diminish the traditional distinction between mathematical induction and recursion. Nevertheless, there is still no consensus on the precise notion of a recursive function. For a significant part of the last fifty years it has been assumed that both recursion and mathematical induction apply to functions defined on partial orders. For more than two decades this view has been defended on purely informal grounds, with only rudimentary outlines provided by the formal treatment by Kleene's incompleteness theorem, Feferman's technical analysis of semivarieties, and results obtained by Turing on recursive functional systems. We give the first complete exposition of the informal theory of recursion and mathematical induction in partial orders and of their formal counterparts.

Why fundamentals and valuation might take a back seat to technological disruption
Many investors have for a long time been focusing on companies with strong fundamentals, a quality leading edge in the form of technology, or strong valuations. Today there is a new way of investing in companies and an approach that is not yet familiar to everyone. It’s called “pure tech”. And technology has become of primary importance in the strategy of our funds. Why? Fundamental and valuation considerations are secondary, the line between technological disruption and business models is less obvious. This opens up opportunities for investment and investment strategies. What changes, how does it change, how should it be prioritized in the strategy for the new age?
If we don’t take a closer look, we will miss the opportunity. Have we not recognized the significance of technology for a long time? In 2010 we evaluated companies based on a concept called Technology-driven Transformation, which defined key companies by whether or not they carried out digital transformation and how deep was the implication of change in their business models. In our analysis we looked at more than 150 companies and its then completely unclear if this was just an effect of structural changes or if this reflected a fundamental trend. We came to the conclusion that there was a structural change in our environment as well as a growth and innovation effect, in that companies are advancing technologically faster and transforming their own business and value chains more broadly.
Before looking at pure technology, let’s have a closer look at the characteristics of companies who master digital technologies:
What we can expect with digitalization
Technology companies focus on disruption, since value is based on the transformation of existing business models. The research department of a technology company can quickly turn market technology trends into business model opportunities. The world of smartphones provides good examples: First there was Apple that went on to launch the iPhone and defined a new business model that turned around the entire smartphone business. Similar disruptions can happen in completely different sectors. The new smartphone established new kinds of business models and software solutions are becoming key in this context. Google Maps replaced printed maps and centralized many requests and actions (also known as business services) into its cloud. Based on this technological approach, market players have been able to integrate complex services such as reservation systems and navigation technologies into their platforms. The competence for artificial intelligence and machine learning enables new ways of working in many branches. In the banking and insurance sector, this can mean personalized services and more effective and relevant interactions with clients, or optimization of key processes. Intelligent solutions

instruments has constantly evolved since the very beginning of the human civilization. The main aim of it’s evolution has been the making of the best instruments.
- The first commonly used musical instrument is the flute. These were not just used as a musical instrument, but also an instrument to tell stories. Apart from that, these flutes were mainly used by the Aztecs, a country in Mexico.
- The second commonly used musical instrument is drums. These were made of animal skins. Their main purpose was to make chants and to mark the rhythm of the song.
- Thirdly, the harp comes in. Its roots are found to be in the 3000 BC and was used as an instrument to tell stories. These were made of strings to accompany the songs. Harps have also been used by musicians as a process of tuning during different stages of their life.
- Fourthly, the piano has gained a lot of popularity with time. These are made with the use of few strings instead of whole strings as in the harp, of wooden keys instead of animal skins. In addition to that, these are also able to have a certain volume by increasing or decreasing the amount of pressure applied on the strings.
- Lastly, with the evolution of technology, various musical instruments were made for more effect, so that the music could be better understood.
Summary:
- While exploring the evolution of music instruments, we can see that the culture, history and values of the people had also strongly influenced the choice of instruments.
- The evolution of music instruments has made a major contribution to the world of music.

change that every Iowa lawmaker should know
Have you been to the eye clinic at the Des Moines University this past year? If so, you likely noticed the mural on the wall in the exam room describing how livestock, the most agricultural-centric industry in the state, are contributing to atmospheric carbon dioxide.
It displays a chart with the decay of atmospheric carbon dioxide, which has nearly doubled since the industrial revolution. We see temperature increases at 1.2 degrees Celsius since pre-industrial times. The source of this increase? Humans, primarily the aviation industry and cars.
Three of every four cars ever built are still on the road, thus burning fossil fuels is not the only pollutant we face.
We also emit methane, a greenhouse gas 84 times more potent than carbon dioxide over 20 years. When talking about methane, don’t forget cows, piggeries, and farms with manure ponds.
Our production agriculture industry has a lot to answer for when it comes to our state’s climate, and I would venture to guess that Iowa lawmakers don’t know a lot about it. Earlier this year, I wrote a check list for legislators, highlighting some common misconceptions about farming. One comment I received about the list was: “Every lawmaker in Iowa should have a copy of that checklist on their wall.”
So here is another list for policymakers of another topic Iowa needs to get right.
Be worried about climate change.
The global science consensus is that climate change is real, and humans are responsible. We are already seeing its effects, which include: the effects of Hurricane Katrina, disappearing arctic ice, the sea level rising in New York City and, most worryingly, the spread of diseases from mosquitoes to ticks.
The Iowa Department of Public Health found that between 1995 and 2015, the incidence of Lyme disease in 192 counties jumped 675 percent.
Last year, there were a record 1,225 power outages in Iowa, causing stress for residents and businesses.
Get the science right.
As we see an increase in the number of natural disasters, the cost and impact have increased. This should not be a surprise as a warmer climate means stronger winds.
In 2017, 3.6 billion dollars were spent in Iowa on drought, agriculture, flood, and insurable losses, that’s nearly twice the 2000 spending, even though our population has doubled since then.
Focus on what we can do, individually, by using fewer fossil fuels

Chemistry education has a poorer record of research funding and impact than any other STEM subjects.

A recent report has indicated that chemistry educators are under-represented in funding applications to the two main UK research funding bodies (the Science and Technology Facilities Council (STFC) and the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC)), and that the sector attracts substantially less research funding than any other STEM discipline. The report also highlighted that researchers in chemistry face specific challenges in receiving government recognition for their research work, on top of the myriad challenges faced by researchers within the STEM and other academic sectors in UK higher education.

Is this damning assessment just a case of ‘devilish details’, or are the fundamentals of the debate not as widely heard as they should be? Consider what follows to form your own opinion, and feel free to share your views at the end of the blog.

How does the sector compare?

The results of a study looking into funding and impact for chemistry and other STEM research, across time and subject areas, were published in a report this year. The authors of the study (one of whom is an active researcher in one of the UK’s leading chemistry departments), and the study itself have received a wealth of media attention: The Guardian gave front-page coverage to the study, with a wealth of other mainstream news outlets (including BBC News, The Independent and The Telegraph) widely reporting on the findings. The report was also covered in the US-based Scientific American, and the Times Higher Education gave comment from one of the report’s authors.

Studying trends between 1998 and 2014, the report found that research funding in chemistry (defined in this study as both Pure and Applied Chemistry, and Chemical Engineering) has not kept pace with inflation or the rest of the STEM sector. The reported found that between 2007 and 2014, both the percentage of overall UK research funding given to chemistry (around 7%) and the value of this funding declined, with a total cut of 19%. The report attributed this to an ‘erosion of budget’ between 2007 and 2010, resulting in a cut in total research funding of 4%. The erosion in budget then further eroded the latter part of the 10 year period, affecting the very foundation of chemistry research in the UK, and the report warns that this ‘weaknesses ... could still constrain research and innovation at a time

has long been celebrated in literature and films, and being able to step out of your everyday life and experience something new is a dream for many of us. We have thus known for some time that travelling is good for us. Studies over the years have confirmed this, and have given us an insight into what travel can achieve for our wellbeing.
Psychological studies have shown that any holiday or short break away has a positive effect on our mental health. A 2008 study at the University of Surrey showed how people with elevated levels of the stress hormone, cortisol, enjoyed positive psychological effects while travelling, as well as after. And a recent study found that a trip away, regardless of the destination, reduced the stress hormone significantly and almost immediately. This positive boost in mood remained over time, with the study showing that participants became more optimistic about their future, more positive about their current lives, and they felt they experienced more meaning and a greater sense of freedom and flexibility than usual, post- holiday.
And all these effects were felt even among people who do not usually have a holiday planned, suggesting that even a weekend break is enough to boost the spirit.
With even five days away from home being able to increase your health in this way, it’s no surprise that when we look at why this is happening, the impact is mental, not physical. This is because travel helps to lower the stress hormone levels, and lowering cortisol is important for cognitive functioning as well. By lowering cortisol, travel reduces our stress levels, and this, in turn, provides a host of benefits that improve all aspects of our mental health. This explains why, as the aforementioned study found, the effects of a stress-reducing holiday lasted for two years.
So not only is it good for the future, this study confirms that there is a long-term benefit of not just pleasure from travel, but an immediate boost to our sense of happiness, too. We know this is not a coincidence as it’s been shown that just 48 hours away from home can have a significant impact on your sense of wellbeing.
Research even suggests that travel can be just as important for your body as it is for your mental health. Taking some time out of your life and losing yourself in a foreign place is important for a whole host of reasons. It’s no surprise, then, that long-haul flights can be tough on the body, and that many of us feel jet-lagged when we get home, even after just one long haul flight. construction has a long history. At the same time, the online world of computer programming continues to provide new opportunities to expose the inner workings of theater – literally and metaphorically. Digital Art has captured artists’ imagination. Now, at the University of Pennsylvania and three Penn partners—Computer Science, College of Engineering, and Annenberg School for Communication— new “drama” is being created. On May 24th, the first residency by Dakin Matthews, playwright and Director of Dramatic Writing at the Julliard School, kicked off a team based theatrical production.
The Penn Players team consists of students from Computer Science, Theatre Arts, Engineering, and Annenberg School for Communication. Josh Bishop is a third year student in Electrical and Systems Engineering; he is particularly interested in artificial intelligence and computer vision. “I started thinking about digital theater when I realized I could combine these two interests and actually create something exciting. With the constant advancements of technology, this seemed like an opportunity to be a pioneer in digital theater,” Josh notes.
After the play was written, Josh and another Penn student, Katie David, started working on the graphical user interface using a program called Processing. Processing is an open-source programming language for creating dynamic, interactive graphics. It allows the developers to create objects and manipulate them in ways that allow them to express ideas through visual storytelling. Josh also emphasized that, “The UI is one of the most important parts of the product. It allows people to understand what is going on in the play.” Katie described her design process: “When I started, I had no idea how I was going to make it. Now I see all the elements I couldn’t see before. It is interesting how much change can happen so quickly when you allow yourself to think about things in a different way.” Art Director, Branden van Heerden is a third year MFA student in the Design program, Department of Fine Arts. Branden notes, “I started as a graphic designer and I am not trained as a programer. But now I am learning some programming and it is totally changing how I think about design.” As the design of the play moves forward it will be interesting to see how the abilities of the Digital Theater team are further developed.
Thanks to Jared Roman, Senior Director of Digital Media Design, Sharaz Mehdi and Justin Nishida, for contributing to the digital media design team.

card etiquette from a cultural perspective.

Business card etiquette has evolved over time from a cultural perspective, and it has a long history that dates back to ancient times. In ancient China, people exchanged business cards during social gatherings and business meetings, and the cards were usually inscribed with their names and titles. In Japan, it was customary to carry an inkstone, brush, and paper, allowing individuals to quickly exchange contact information with others in a less formal setting.

In medieval Europe, personal networks played a crucial role in the business community, and exchange of business cards became a vital part of networking and communication. During the Renaissance, when trade and commerce were expanding rapidly, the exchange of business cards became more formal and standardized. In the United States, business cards began to be used in earnest during the late 1800s, with the introduction of the First Class Mail Act, which allowed business cards to be mailed like letters.

Throughout history, business card etiquette has evolved, and different cultures have developed their own customs and traditions. For example, in Japan, the business card is considered a symbol of the individual's social status and is treated with the utmost respect. Japanese business cards are often elaborately decorated, with intricate designs and logos.

In contrast, in the Western world, business cards are more straightforward, with basic contact information such as name, title, company, and contact details. However, some Western cultures have their own unique business card practices, such as South Korea, where the business card is considered a gift and must be presented with both hands.

Overall, business card etiquette has evolved over time from a cultural perspective, with different customs and traditions shaping the way it is used in different parts of the world. Today, business cards remain an essential tool for professional networking and communication.

has developed substantially in the twentieth century, with new instruments used to gather oceanographic data in different situations and to study the oceans at scales ranging from meter to global.
Water survey techniques of the nineteenth century and early twentieth century were based on collection of salinity data, on the basis of which depth and areal estimates could be made; thus the ocean floor was surveyed by oceanographers and answered as a (large) body of water bounded by a surface. This concept of an ocean was "top-down" rather than being based on the results of in situ exploration of the ocean by instruments.
The invention and subsequent refinement of submarine hydrographic soundings and magnetic measurements have greatly improved our knowledge of the ocean. Radiated seismic waves were first used in the 1930s to image the ocean crust, and were used in conjunction with sonar mapping of the ocean floor by the mid-1950s. Sonar technology is now a routine technique for geophysical mapping of the ocean floor, and for marine geology and mineral exploration.
Sonar instruments are based on passive or active reception and playback of sound energy. Passive systems reflect transmitted or emitted energy from the sea floor and ambient seawater to the instrument (usually a hydrophone) to give an accurate picture of bottom topography. Active systems, typically in the infrasonic range (but some as high as 100 kHz), are employed to measure the ocean acoustic properties and to collect spectral absorption data that characterize the dispersion of acoustic energy in seawater.
Other, more geographically homogeneous, systems have been developed for detailed mapping of seafloor heat flow in the deep ocean. Heat flow is primarily due to radiogenic heating by radioactive decay, and is one of the important systems for assessing the Earth's internal structure. Another geophysical method for detecting internal structure is marine gravity surveys, which infer densities from changes in gravitational attraction as a function of location. Through remote sensing and geophysical mapping techniques we can see the ocean as a (thicker) external shell, supported by the water column and the Earth's interior.
In addition to static systems for mapping, underwater robots and vehicles can be programmed to follow predetermined survey patterns; such systems are commonly used in the oil industry for oceanographic surveys and mine location. Sonar for the detection of submarines and mines is commercially available and regularly used in various settings.

are explained in most introductory textbooks on the subject. Despite the importance of ideas like the superposition of wave functions, the Born rule, the Schrödinger equation, and the Heisenberg picture, the emphasis of these texts is often placed on the seemingly esoteric ideas like wave-particle duality, entanglement, quantum decoherence, and quantum teleportation. Considerable effort goes into explaining why the quantum setup exists, and how we can use it to transmit information, while the ideas that actually make quantum mechanics what it is tend to be elided.
But much of the really interesting content of quantum mechanics depends on the basic principles, rather than things like teleportation. First, there’s the basic logic of the probabilistic description of quantum measurements. Second, there’s the quantum nature of matter. Third, the fact that nontrivial laws of physics are, in principle, possible. The quantum magic is not in the trick itself, but in understanding how it could exist in principle.
These three things may seem like they’re covered in the basics of quantum mechanics, but the physics community is not really running the basics curriculum any more.
- The textbook land. What I’m referring to is the subset of online books and the actual textbooks that have these as their subject matter. Even people interested in the basics tend to rely on a resource like Griffiths, rather than something more fundamental like Dirac or von Neumann.
- The popular press. The popular press likes nothing more than giving weird asides to crank ideas like zero-point energy, remote viewing, and antigravity.
The crash course provides a tour of these. I give the history of the invention of quantum mechanics, explain the basic principles and terminology, talk a bit about the paradoxes that show up from the basic principles, and show how they get fixed in more advanced treatments. It’s not fully self-contained. The goal is to give a taste of the general approach to quantum mechanics and the context in which we use it.
I focused on the importance of the basic principles over teleportation, and the general logical form of quantum mechanical probabilities. This was deliberate, because I didn’t want to depend on a discussion of quantum teleportation, or even quantum information theory as a background for these sorts of ideas. We just sort of happen to use a description of the world like this, and it’s important to make sense of why it can do the sort of things we do with it. This assumption certainly corresponds to the way people actually use quantum mechanics, and not the way
