The basics of travel money- why you need to plan ahead
We all know about travel money, but many travellers are reluctant to do it before they travel, even though it’s actually quite simple and straightforward once you get over your fear of the unknown.
If you wait until you arrive at your destination, you may find that there is very limited banking facilities at airports and, if you do manage to get a credit card, you may get hit by high fees. If you do end up making a bank transfer, you’re looking at a wait of anything up to two weeks to receive your money – not the ideal scenario if you are hoping to get out and buy some local currency to pay for a taxi or bus.
The good news is that travel money is both simple to organise and can be done well in advance.
Current cash available from UK banks
The first thing to consider is that you will need cash when you arrive and that you need to exchange it.
• Bank of England now has their own notes – they look identical to their UK counterparts, but are printed in London rather than Newcastle. The current series of bank notes (designed by Sir Rowett Dawson) run from £5 to £50 and were first printed in 2003.
• The banks print their own notes at the moment; the Royal Bank of Scotland issue the £20 notes, whereas the Bank of Scotland issue all of the lower denominations. The quality of the printing is superb and they look identical to the UK issued notes. The majority of travellers use these notes and are the most convenient, though they are the highest priced.
• Other banks and building societies in the UK print their own notes as well – these notes are less widely accepted, but can still be picked up and used.
Withdrawing cash at the airport
Most travellers have heard the stories of travellers attempting to withdraw money from the bank at an airport, only to have the tellers refuse their request. Why, we wonder, are they so reluctant to exchange cash? The answer is obvious when you think about it: the bank does not want to be responsible for a rash decision to try and get out of the airport and avoid paying a standard tax on your money, only to realise that they have not looked at your money properly. However, there is nothing stopping you from taking out £20 worth of £10 notes and exchanging it; just be sure to inform them that you are exchanging cash, not traveling with travellers cheques.

# William Henry Perkin

Featured publication: Canvassing Clio in New Bedford (published in the Journal of Maritime History)

Dr. Perkin directed the Ph.D. program in chemistry and served as chairman of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry from 1989 until 2002. Perkin was also the first Adelyn R. Scott Professor of Humanities, a position he held from 1990 to 1999.

Dr. Perkin was a student of the “greats” of chemistry, starting with the fusty school in Wilton that allegedly produced 10,000 chemists per week at its peak. He next attended the famous Albany College, where he later went on to teach for a year. He finished his doctorate with William P. Day in Ann Arbor in 1951 and went immediately to California to begin his postgraduate career with Thomas L. Cullen at the University of California at Berkeley. He was the first person to hold an academic appointment in organic chemistry at Cal at the time. His years of postdoctoral work with Cullen were extremely important in his own work, but most of all for the specialty he has pursued most often: the chemical synthesis of complex natural products with an eye toward optimizing their biological activity.

Dr. Perkin joined the Department of Chemistry at the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1954, later becoming the chair of the department. He was promoted to full professor in 1965. From 1983 to 1986, he served as director of the Wisconsin Regional Biosciences Resource Center, a key player in the initial development of the NIH Biomedical Research Resources Program.

Dr. Perkin has made many contributions to chemistry over the course of his career. He has focused primarily on the synthesis of three simple and complex scaffolds: the pyrroles, isoindoles and indole alkaloids. This research, in which he has made a major impact, has been discussed elsewhere.

In 1977, a team of biochemists discovered a second, completely different chemical pathway for the pathway for beta-oxidation (the process of breaking down fatty acids) that results in a product that functions to promote apoptosis. Unfortunately, there is no practical therapy available for this procedure, because it is so expensive to develop an anti-CMPDs compound. The syntheses of the beta-CMPDs have been slow.  Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 15, 6228 (2013); doi:10.1039/C2CP43813G Published online 25 March 2013
 Abstract: It is our contention that connections with the realm of computer science might help us to broaden and deepen our physical understanding. Chemistry, in particular, can benefit from cross-fertilization with disciplines such as data mining, protein folding and molecular dynamics. For example, being interested in structure function relationships, we introduce the term “Binding information theory” to describe the interplay of structure and reactivity on the basis of information exchange between the atoms of the complex. Since further uses are conceivable we devise a compact mathematical framework, which should aid our understanding of chemically relevant phenomena.

in some other societies sports doesn’t require the philosophy that others have. They focus on cooperation and the healthy competition rather than the individual performance alone. It doesn’t matter who wins, what matters is how players work together as a team.
Our findings show that the more sports relevant the scientific context, the less ideas about a good citizen were mentioned in the scientific papers on sports. In contrast, more ideas about a good citizen were mentioned in science not relevant for sports. Something seems to have disappeared between scientific writing and newspaper reporting, between the two poles of the polemic between science and pop-sciience. It is a pity that science seems to have lost its pleasure in letting the reader wonder about the connectedness of sports and the philosophy of sports. In his book 'De arte kniperen' (1997) the philologist Wim van der Meeren praised the art of paper marbling for its unknownness (onomatopoeia). At the edge of the paper marbling's unknown world, one still can create new creations and find the right settings to enhance this unpredictable world. Maybe one has to relinquish knowledge to create science out of art or art from science. Science remains behind the role of an advisor or observer, turning back to itself to, thereby, gain new insight into its own role in the unexplored world of knowledge and truth-seeking. One can, therefore, hope that the relation between sports and the philosophy of sports cannot be destroyed easily. On the other hand, it could be said that the sports conception of the world is just a new age catholic: God is on everyone's side.

has been a popular topic of discussion. Genes are the basic building blocks of life that determine how we develop, how we look, and even our personality. We have learned a lot about genetics in recent years, particularly since the Human Genome Project was first launched. With modern technology, we can now sequence entire genomes, determine the sequence of millions of base pairs of DNA, and also create custom design SNPs within genes. These tools have also been developed to aid in criminal cases, particularly since the Supreme Court ruling in the U.S. and many other countries that allowed for DNA profiling in the course of a crime. This has allowed for more accurate DNA profiling, which is one of the most reliable methods for identifying individuals, particularly in cases where other methods may fail. For instance, a DNA profile can be used to create a genetic fingerprinting, which can match a suspect to a crime scene.

lies in growing beautiful things. And there’s no beauty quite like a lotus flower. If you want a beautiful ornamental flower for your gardens, the lotus plant is the one.
Here are the care tips for growing the lotus plant.
The plant enjoys full sun. So make sure you provide them with a lot of light. But this comes with a caveat. During the hottest hours of the day, cut the leaves’ exposure to the sun, and offer them some protection in the form of a shade cloth. Direct exposure to the sun could lead to sunburn.
The seed must be planted on fertile ground. Lotuses come in seed form (seeds are meant to be eaten by lotus plants and therefore they can’t be eaten by humans). The seeds can be germinated with extra phosphoric acid mixed in the water of the pot. This mimics the soil by keeping a nutrient balance. It’s not necessary to buy lotus seeds. They can be easily found online.
Lotuses, like every other plant, require good nutrition. Hence, you should add a lot of organic substance to the potting soil. If you grow lotuses, you’ll soon realize how much water and fertilizer they consume. Keep them filled with water and watered every other day to keep the leaves shiny and looking bright.
Lotuses are sensitive to changes in temperature. The ideal growth temperature is between 75-80 degrees F. If you’re having trouble maintaining such temperature, use a plant temperature controller.
The plant needs to be trimmed once it grows to about 50% of its standard height. The main reason behind trimming is to prevent the plant from getting damaged by rain. Some petals and leaves get detached from the plant after rainfall and will collect water into their centers.
Since lotus is a tropical plant, it is susceptible to pests such as aphids and caterpillars. If you come across any pests, remove them with the right tools, including a 6-inch, pointy needle.
Lastly, the whole lotus plant, along with its seeds, has properties that can induce relaxation. Therefore, one can also use lotus extract for relaxing. You can use the lotus extract to help you get a good night sleep, reduce anxiety, or stress relief.
The beauty of lotuses lies not only in their aesthetics, but also in their benefits. They are definitely the must-have flower to keep a secret garden bright.

fiction. Science fiction is a genre of fiction that deals with the impact of imaginative and futuristic scientific or technological developments on society or individuals. 

It typically explores hypothetical concepts such as extraterrestrial life, time travel, faster-than-light travel, and futuristic science and technology. Science fiction is often used as a vehicle for social commentary or to explore philosophical or ethical issues related to these concepts. 

Many famous works of science fiction, including "1984" by George Orwell, "The War of the Worlds" by H.G. Wells, and "Brave New World" by Aldous Huxley, have had a significant impact on society and have influenced popular culture. Science fiction continues to be a popular genre for readers and writers alike, with new stories and concepts being created regularly.

Going back to basics, if you want to be entertained by prose writing, you need a journalist of the first water, a poet of the second order, an essayist who laughs himself to sleep, a composer and linguist, a reader’s fiction man or the like.
It is in prose writing, in theatrical life, that we find the essence of the basic common decency. As a happy example, most shows can stand trial and that fact alone goes far to make clear that such a definition of what is proper to writer and audience alike, is at hand. So, up in front is fine, far from things as in the back is excellent, and between the two an array of theatrical compromise is in sight.
There is a golden road for writers from silence to the place of words and voice. There is a black road for writers from words to the place of silence and voice. This means that we are entering the realm of theatrical impact and the way to seize that marvelous thread of words, music, and emotion which will stitch together a show in its entirety is the one way of seeing into what can not be ignored in the end. Whatever the subject may be, the construction of the piece is guided by an overall concept. Indeed, anyone who wishes to see progress in his or her daily life will live with this concept while for others there are enough possibilities to choose from and make progress in one direction or another.

Meteorology is the study of the Earth's atmosphere and its weather and climate. It is a branch of Earth science, and is also closely related to oceanography, hydrology, and climatology. The benefits of meteorology are numerous and include:

1. Improved weather forecasting: Meteorologists use sophisticated models and data analysis to predict future weather patterns and give timely warnings of severe weather events, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and floods. These accurate forecasts help to mitigate the impacts of these events and save lives.

2. Better understanding of climate change: Meteorology is essential to understanding climate change. By studying weather patterns and long-term trends, meteorologists can help researchers to identify the factors that contribute to climate change and develop strategies for mitigating its effects.

3. Improved air quality monitoring: Meteorologists use satellite data and ground-based sensors to monitor air quality and track the movement of pollutants. This information is used to create air quality forecasts and to develop strategies for reducing air pollution.

4. Improved agriculture and forestry management: Meteorology helps farmers and foresters to manage their land and crops more effectively by providing information on weather patterns and climate trends. This can help to improve yields and reduce crop damage.

5. Improved transportation safety: Meteorologists provide important information on weather conditions, such as storms, fog, and snow, that can affect transportation safety. By predicting these conditions and providing warnings, meteorologists can help to reduce the risk of accidents and improve transportation efficiency.

6. Improved disaster response: Meteorology is critical to disaster response efforts. By providing accurate and timely weather forecasts and warnings, meteorologists can help to coordinate emergency response efforts and save lives.

Wow, I didn't know meteorology could have so many practical applications! Can meteorologists also study the effects of weather on human health? Yes, meteorologists can study the effects of weather on human health. In fact, atmospheric and environmental health is a growing field of study within meteorology. Meteorologists can use their knowledge of weather and climate to better understand the impact of weather on human health, including the effects of air pollution, extreme temperatures, and extreme precipitation on human health. They can also use weather models to predict the likelihood of extreme weather events such as heat waves and hurricanes, which can cause serious health problems for people in affected areas. Some areas of study in this field include human health impacts of climate change, air quality monitoring, and health risks from extreme weather events.

From the perspective of a female science fiction writer to other females in the business of writing fiction.
In general, do something different.
- Find YOUR UNIQUE voice. Over time it will become distinctive.
- Create what you wish existed (i.e. great characters, worlds)
- Find your target audience. Science fiction has a broad spectrum of fans. If you’re a reader, find your type of fiction. Genre: Readers.
Writing:
1. Understand your muse and agent
2. Find examples in the writers you follow
- of what you like
- of what you are inspired by
- when you are at a loss, what to write next
3. Do your research
- human-animal and robot relations
- gender issues
- creative techniques
- different worlds
- creativity
- doing vs. knowing
4. practice a variety of writing tools (style, voice, short stories, poetry, narrative skills)
- How do you come up with new ideas? Have a word they are attracted to? Study, learn, study.
- Be aware of the steps and process and how to structure ideas so they flow into the final book.
5. use photos, music, art to study your niche and style.
- Make lists of agents, publishers
Reading:
6. Continue expanding your mind and knowledge as a writer and reader.
- Review your written works and have beta readers to help.
- Study the overall structure of the written work for content, genre, style
- Structure: beginning, middle, end
- Write in different genres to get better at the technique.
- Highlight and review top tips for each genre and style.

There is a lot of public data out there, but unless you know what to look for or how to find it, it can be hard to make use of these resources. In this blog post, I’d like to share how to get started with climate data and explain what the key pieces of public climate data are.
Resources for climate data
One of the easiest resources for climate data is NOAA’s Climate Data Online (CDO), which provides access to many climate data sets in a consistent and user-friendly format. CDO is an open data resource, which means that anyone can view its data and use it for any purpose with credit to the source. Climate data is especially important in climate research and impacts analyses where data in a common form is used by many researchers. For example, insurance underwriters, utility and energy companies, real estate agents, civil engineers, and even park rangers all need data about past and future climate and extreme events like floods and droughts.
Conducting a basic search for precipitation data in CDO for a specific year shows how easy it can be to find data on, say, minimum or maximum temperatures or precipitation in several U.S. cities.
Other public data sets include global climate data (both historical and future), long-term station data sets (like temperature, precipitation, soil, and forest variables), and satellite measurements. NOAA is also leading a set of data sharing initiatives to help improve access to climate data.
The EPA’s Climate Action Plan is a key resource for understanding the public sector’s role in climate action, but it does not necessarily represent all the information available on climate data.
So how do you find what you need?
Step 1: Use search tools like Google to find public data. Once you find your data source, learn about the type of data you want to download.
Step 2: In CDO, click Data Access to access the files and then use the drop-down menu to find these data files.
Step 3: Use a statistical software package such as R, SAS, or STATA to analyze your data. If you want to learn a new skill, try learning how to use a software tool like R to read and analyze climate data. There is plenty of online help to get you started.
Step 4: Compare your results to other data sets. Were you using the same climate data for a different model?
No matter what climate data you choose, it’s important to ask questions about what the data represent and how it was measured. In fact, climate researchers have long

Dive into the creative world of science with these simple science experiments!

1. Lemon Battery: 
Lemon batteries produce a small amount of electricity by passing a current from one copper wire to one zinc wire. Get two wires, insert a zinc wire in an lemon half and the copper wire in the other, now keep a battery charger behind it and see it lit up.
2. Build a Haunted House: 
First you will need to take a box and split it into two parts, paint each one black, so that it looks like a haunted house. Now you will need some LED lights, cotton, and a cup of cornstarch and water (glue). Take the cotton and rip it up into bits, then add them into the glue and mix them up, then sprinkle them on the box till it looks like it is snowing inside. This is a simple Halloween themed home.
3. Ice Cream: 
You will need 4 or more glasses, 1 Cup, an icecream maker, some dash of cream, sugar and vanilla for flavoring. First put the cream in the cup and add sugar and vanilla. Then start making icecream inside the icecream maker and pour it in the glasses. You can also add sprinkles or nuts for decoration.

For the past four years, I've been incorporating genetic epidemiology into my biostatistics courses. Through discussions with eminent genetic epidemiologists, I've learned how genetics is incorporated in epidemiology courses and developed a course that incorporates genetics in one of my two epidemiology courses, and two classes in the biostatistics PhD program. In my first class, students are introduced to quantitative genetics and start to address genetic determinants of phenotype in the context of infectious diseases. In my second class, we begin to discuss the complexities of genetic epidemiology and investigate these complications by focusing on genetic determinants of phenotype for more rare and complex traits.
The section of the class on rare and complex traits looks at selection and the natural selection of genes. This is most easily studied in the context of lethal mutations. Lethal mutations are characterized by a truncation or shortening of the protein produced by the gene. If the truncated protein is only produced in one allele, it is also referred to as a monoallelic dominant mutation (MAD). These mutations produce a defect in a protein without which the organism fails to develop past the stage that the defective protein would have affected the organism. In contrast, autosomal recessive lethal mutations (ARL) are those in which the defective protein is produced by both alleles; however, for any given mutation the homozygote dies before producing many offspring. For these mutations, the heterozygote survives but is fertile with no effects on the phenotype.
A common starting point in epidemiology courses is the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. This makes some sense for classic cases of Mendelian inheritance since the population is represented by a simple diploid locus with two discrete alleles. The locus may possess two homozygotes as a stable combination of two homologous sequences that can't exchange alleles or it may have one homologous sequence and one heterologous sequence and be stable with respect to allelic exchange. A third possibility, that of the recombinant heterozygote, also exists, but only under special conditions where the two homologous sequences are also exactly the same.
In each of these three cases, the population can be represented by the genealogical tree shown in Figure 1. Neuroscience is the study of how the brain and nervous system work. It has many benefits, such as:

1. Advancements in medical treatments: Neuroscience has led to new treatments for neurological disorders such as epilepsy and Parkinson's disease. It has also helped to improve the understanding of diseases such as Alzheimer's and Multiple Sclerosis.

2. Improved education: Neuroscience has improved our understanding of how the brain works, which has led to the development of teaching methods that are more effective.

3. Better understanding of the brain: By studying the brain, we can learn more about how it works and why it does what it does. This knowledge can be applied to other fields, such as computer science and engineering.

4. Improved mental health: Neuroscience has helped to identify the factors that contribute to mental health issues such as depression and anxiety. It has also led to the development of new treatments that can help people to manage these conditions.

5. New technologies: Neuroscience has led to the development of new technologies such as brain-computer interfaces, which allow people with disabilities to control computers with their thoughts.

Overall, neuroscience has many benefits that can improve our lives in many ways.

has been widely recognized, and few would argue that it can be a powerful form of entertainment. However, those who seek to market music with the intention of generating revenue in business settings—where it is often sold and/or licensed as a licensed product—often have to reach out to consumers through free and low-cost methods to gain traction. While there are many ways for artists and companies to monetize their musical works, digital music rights management (DRM) is a crucial strategy for those looking to monetize music in the age of smartphones, tablets, streaming services, and social media.
The various forms of digital music rights management are quite varied. For instance, free-to-download music is available at little or no charge by, for example, music download services like iTunes, Google Play, and Spotify, while all other forms of DRM come with certain fees. Although many popular streaming services have a free tier that offers access to most of their catalog of songs, most users opt for a premium subscription option. Once a song has been placed on the Internet, the owner may also choose to grant his or her followers the right to download the song, and even modify or embed the music within other media content. With all the variations of DRM, it is essential for artists, music companies, and marketers to learn more about digital music rights management in the digital age.
When music is released through traditional channels, it is typically given away for free in exchange for artist and publisher royalties. This can be done by placing the music on social media outlets, streaming services, blogs, podcasts, and more. While this can be a great way to build a fan base and spread the word, it is important to know that all forms of DRM require copyright protection. Without proper protections in place, anyone can take a song and use it for their own gain. If you use music without obtaining the proper permissions, you can face legal consequences. If your music is pirated, you may not be able to recover your royalties.
There are several ways that DRM can be used in conjunction with social media to protect content. For example, when you post a link to a specific video, the link will feature a watermark that includes a copyright symbol. This helps prevent others from sharing your link. If you add a watermark to your site or blog, anyone who downloads your music will have to view the watermark. In addition to protecting your music, DRM allows you to control where your music is played.

Oceanography is the study of all things related to the ocean: its processes, its history, how it has affected the Earth's climate and weather and the living organisms that live within it. The ocean itself contains one of the most extreme environments on earth, with extreme temperatures and pressures and vast concentrations of salt that cause currents to carry incredible waves. A traditional definition of oceanography is the study of the physical, chemical and biological aspects of the sea. 

Oceanographers work in one of four main branches: physical (studying the processes within the ocean); chemical (concentrating on the ocean's ecosystems); geological (concerned with the underpinnings of the ocean floor) and biological (the study of marine life and their interactions with each other). 

Each of these branches is divided into sub-branches that focus on various aspects of the subject. For example, in the physical branch, the sub-branches include physical oceanography, seismology, and meteorology. Physical oceanography is concerned with the role of the ocean in the Earth's climate and weather. Seismology studies the Earth's internal structure and processes (such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions). Meteorology studies atmospheric phenomena, such as hurricanes, tornadoes and thunderstorms. 

Other sub-branches include physical oceanography, which focuses on ocean currents, waves, and tides. Chemical oceanography studies the composition of the ocean, including trace metals, nutrients and dissolved oxygen. Geological oceanography deals with the study of the seafloor, including plate tectonics, earthquakes, and the interactions between the ocean floor and the atmosphere. Biological oceanography studies marine life and their interactions with each other and the physical and chemical environment.

include attributing all negative health impacts to specific food sources and diets. This leads to a widespread idea that saturated fats and high cholesterol are to blame for a variety of health problems, such as heart disease, stroke, Type II diabetes, and many cancers. In reality, nutritional medicine is most often determined by how one uses their diet.
Of course, many factors influence a person's health. The way food is prepared and/or cooked can make a huge difference in absorption. Generally, meat in the raw state is extremely hard to digest, whereas when that same meat is baked or broiled, it becomes easy to digest. Grilling and broiling produce less oxidized products than cooking with much higher heat, such as frying. In addition, the way a person chews and digests their food is also important. The piece of the puzzle that is often overlooked is what foods are not made for human digestion.
In his book, The Origins of Humans, Michael Denton states that humans should have a diet consisting of raw proteins and fruits. However, the FDA has a different opinion, stating that as long as humans adhere to their charts and limit their consumption to less than 10 percent fat and less than 15 percent carbohydrates (primarily those that are complex), they will be healthy. Denton contradicts their perspective by saying that our "flat long-cavities, with severely deteriorating enamel, large dental gaps, poor tooth structure, high decay, and unexpected lesions on the surface of our teeth, are all strongly suggestive of our having evolved in a country of abundant high-energy protein, high-carbohydrate foods." Denton agrees that humans are very fat-adapted, meaning that they are adapted to high-fat and low-carbohydrate diets. However, since today's modern world is different from the environment our ancestors lived in, the human body has adapted to diet, but not to an altered lifestyle. This leads to the obesity epidemic and also is the reason why proper diet alone isn't as effective.
Another prevalent misperception relates to the idea that excessive consumption of any single nutrient or food substance can cause various diseases. There is little evidence to support this idea, but people believe it anyway. Take for instance, processed, refined carbohydrates. Processing can damage nutrients. Refined, processed grains often contain incomplete carbohydrates, lacking the nutrients necessary for the body to store energy, digest, and absorb. They also can promote disease if consumed in excess. It is true that the amount of wheat in the diets of Western people is higher than

is the branch of philosophy concerned with the philosophical study of mathematics: its contents, its methods, and its relationship with the wider world.

Does mathematics vary from person to person? Why do different individuals have different approaches to the same problem, though they might be after the same thing? Is the "right" way to approach mathematics or is there a better or a wrong way to think about it? Does the diversity of approaches suggests that mathematics is not well defined?

So basically, this question is in response to some of the answers to the question ["Why is 'number sense' difficult for an individual?"](https://cogsci.stackexchange.com/questions/4837/why-is-number-sense-difficult-for-an-individual)

By definition, all solutions to maths problems are only possible with exactly one valid mathematical model. So it is difficult to doubt the mathematical correctness of the solution. The only uncertainty arises as a consequence of ambiguity within the question or in the conditions of the question, or in the physical possibility of the physical model.

* Your example is not a mathematical problem but an instrumental problem.
* In 2+2=4, there is a mathematical model of individual minds, which cause a disagreement. But if we put all those minds together, they will have no problem with the result. By this I mean the mathematical model has no ambiguity (more or less).
* When a problem doesn't admit a single mathematical model, it will not admit a single solution, where the solutions are only mathematically correct.
* We can't understand mathematics in terms of cognitive science because mathematically there is no one solution. Even the interpretations of the "meaning" of the word "solution" is unclear for different branches of mathematics.
* Because the process of mathematical thinking is incremental (and increases without bounds) mathematicians are not ignorant of other mathematics, but their problem finding a correct mathematical model is the lack of insight.

That is, mathematical thinking is independent of reality. "reality" and math have different bases.

In the real world, life is not simple. There are individuals in the environment who deviate from the model, or sabotage the model, or even destroy the model. Hence the models do not always work and the agents of the world do not comply with the models. [Whoosh, fractal flame.] The reaction of the mathematical system is denial and postulation of the escape clauses.

Working with students, it’s not uncommon to hear ‘I don’t get chemistry at all.’

To address this, Peter Sessums develops a simple method which helps give chemistry a different feel: one of rapid, guided exploration rather than one-way, teacher-led instruction.

Sessums’ approach, here illustrated with several balancing exercise worksheets, starts with ‘big ideas’. These are presented in a table and explored with students by writing their initial ideas in the relevant column and being open to revising them. Then, by sticking pins on a grid representing the equations that students initially assumed would balance, a check-list is developed to compare with solutions. This opens up the way to exploring what puzzles students. As students get more confident, they are given more freedom to follow their own interests, such as writing a diary entry from the point of view of a science undergraduate who is only interested in his degree, not the Nobel prize-winning science that is going on around him.

Often, it’s tempting to think that students must have prior chemistry knowledge to follow the process. In fact, it is designed to focus on big ideas — and don’t be afraid of asking students to work out where a big idea occurs in a specific science text.

A trillion is a big number. So why not bust it out? Bring down the declension and talk about a trillionth (or 1 trillionth) as poetically as you want.
So if by any chance (or with extreme probability) you've ever thought of yourself as a poet, because of a certain name you have or a certain heritage you come from, then you're likely to also think of yourself as part of the Great Tradition, that inexhaustible bristling cloud of words and thoughts. From Homer to Milton, from Wordsworth to Eliot, from Frost to the First Ladies of the 20th and 21st centuries, people have written poems that give us something to think about, perhaps even to dream about, and to talk about for ages and ages and ages.
You may think of yourself as a poet.
And you may, as well, feel a high calling to be a citizen poet, to bring poetry to life in the everyday world of news and advertising, of street signs and dance clubs, of libraries and school classrooms, of smart homes and dumb phones. Or, perhaps you wish to be a quick student of poetry, racing in pursuit of those brilliant words and lines that come to us when we least expect them, seemingly destined to stay forever in our memory forever, because they were so truly beautiful. Perhaps you wish to know how to write poetry, and have devoted or are devoting yourself to poetry writing lessons, teacher training in poetry, lectures, as well as reading and more reading.
Let's start here, with how and why we use the word "poetry" and where it came from. Then we'll consider some of the many poems and poems groups out there, and talk about poems that make us want to write a poem.

books, from their first publication to the modern age. History books have a long and varied history that spans thousands of years. The earliest forms of written history were created by ancient civilizations such as the Egyptians, Greeks, and Romans. These early history books were often created using stone tablets or papyrus scrolls and were used to record the deeds of famous leaders and conquerors.

In the Middle Ages, history books were still primarily written on papyrus scrolls and were used primarily by religious scholars. The Catholic Church played a significant role in the development of historical scholarship during this period, with many of the early histories being written with an emphasis on the deeds of Christian saints and the actions of religious leaders.

During the Renaissance, the study of history became more important in European society. This period saw the emergence of new forms of historical scholarship, including the works of Italian scholars such as Machiavelli and Leonardo da Vinci. These scholars helped to popularize the study of history and introduced new methods for analyzing historical events and figures.

In the 18th and 19th centuries, the field of history grew rapidly, and new forms of historical scholarship emerged. Historians began to use new sources of information, such as letters, diaries, and government records, to create more accurate and detailed accounts of the past. The study of history also became more interdisciplinary, with historians drawing on fields such as anthropology, psychology, and sociology to gain a deeper understanding of human behavior.

Today, history books continue to play an important role in our understanding of the past. With the advent of technology, historians now have access to vast amounts of information through the internet, digitized archives, and other sources. This has enabled scholars to create more comprehensive and accurate historical accounts, and to explore new areas of study such as gender and sexuality in history. Despite these changes, however, the basic principles of historical scholarship remain the same: to understand the events and people of the past in order to better understand ourselves and our place in the world.

# The evolution of quantum mechanics

Yoh Tanimura
###### Abstract.

We formulate a novel formulation of quantum mechanics called the Transactional Quantum Mechanics (TQM) that describes quantum processes in terms of splitting and joining of the world lines of quantum systems. Since in TQM all states, including those with superpositions of mutually exclusive states, are physical, according to TQM, quantum mechanics is the limit case of the general theory in which states transition between splits in the world lines of quantum systems. Moreover, TQM enables us to formulate quantum thermodynamics including a quantum Gibbs state, a quantum heat engine, and a quantum refrigerator. Therefore, TQM will replace conventional quantum mechanics in the future.

## 1. Introduction

Since Einstein, Planck, Bohr, Schrödinger and many other Nobel prize winning scientists pioneered quantum mechanics in the early 20th century, quantum mechanics has been one of the most active fields in physics, it has still maintained a strong influence and is still active as the workhorse in understanding the microscopic nature of matter and nature.

Quantum mechanics was originally formulated for closed systems. After a long period of development of quantum mechanics including nonrelativistic quantum mechanics, quantum field theory, and quantum electrodynamics, people realized that there are still questions like quantum jumps and quantum measurements, quantum amplitudes, or superposition states that cannot be understood in the purely relativistic or gauge invariant formulation of quantum mechanics [1]. The solution was devised in 1984 by the Japanese mathematician and theoretical physicist Hosoya for nonrelativistic quantum mechanics. The first useful formulation of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics is given by the Transactional Quantum Mechanics (TQM) that describes quantum processes in terms of splitting and joining of the world lines of quantum systems [2]. TQM provides us a general formulation of quantum mechanics in which states, including those with superpositions of mutually exclusive states, are physical states. This leads to a concept of quantum probability that is robust against uncertainties.

TQM has found a wide range of applications including the foundations of quantum mechanics [3, 4, 5], quantum thermodynamics [6, 7, 8], quantum computation [9, 10], quantum information theory [11], and entanglement theory [12, 13].

Recently, new studies by Tanimura [14] and by Tanimura and Matsumoto [15] have initiated the formulation of quantum mechanics for open systems

# Understanding Common Misconceptions about AI

Common misconceptions about artificial intelligence include:

# 1. AI always needs data to function.

This is only true if you define AI as "a computer system that performs tasks that would normally be done by humans." In that case, AI needs data because it needs information to learn and make decisions. But AI is also capable of learning without data. For example, it can learn from its mistakes. This is called "unsupervised learning." AI can also use heuristics to make decisions, which means it uses logic and common sense to make decisions. So, while data is helpful, it is not always necessary for AI to function.

# 2. AI always makes decisions with no human input.

Again, this is only true if you define AI as "a computer system that performs tasks that would normally be done by humans." In that case, AI needs human input to function. But AI is also capable of making decisions on its own. This is called "autonomous AI." Autonomous AI can make decisions without human input because it has been programmed to do so. However, it is important to note that autonomous AI is still influenced by human decisions. For example, it is programmed with a set of rules, but those rules can be changed by humans. So, while autonomous AI may make decisions on its own, it is still influenced by human decision-making.

# 3. AI always makes decisions based on statistics.

This is only true if you define AI as "a computer system that performs tasks that would normally be done by humans." In that case, AI uses statistics to make decisions. However, AI is also capable of using other methods to make decisions. For example, it can use natural language processing (NLP) to understand language and make decisions based on that understanding. It can also use machine learning (ML) to make decisions based on patterns it has learned. So, while statistics are important, they are not the only way AI makes decisions.

# 4. AI always replaces human workers.

This is only true if you define AI as "a computer system that performs tasks that would normally be done by humans." In that case, AI does replace human workers in some cases. For example, it can be used to automate tasks that are repetitive or dangerous. However, AI is also used to complement human workers, not replace them. For example, it can be used to assist doctors in making diagnoses. It can also be used to help farmers monitor crops and optimize yields

$1.$ What makes quantum mechanics "so interesting"?

Quantum mechanics is primarily interesting because a) its predictions are experimentally validated and b) it is our most complete theory so far of physical reality which we see around us, including the entire history of the universe up to the present moment. Using the arguments provided by Mach, Schroedinger, Einstein, and De Broglie, Born and Dirac gave a more precise meaning to 'reality' than had been provided by classical physics, which was a theory that already had a couple of centuries worth of experimental validation, so that quantum mechanics needed to be built upon this more substantive basis than anything that was available at the time.

Another thing: standards are set by the industry, not by corporations. It is from the industry that you get things like the PSP specification for settings, and probably more importantly, terms like "REC 709". Rec 709, like MPEG1 and 2, is not a standard. It is a format, an encoding. Therefore, it will never change.
All the above is to say that to this day, the set of standards we work under to do post production color correction is not standardized.
This lack of standardization, one of the main reasons we see so many different interpretations of color work.
The goal of this site is to provide a standard set of guidelines to understand, and follow, the color space of Rec. 709.
This is part of what I do as a colorist. So the idea is, what I understand, I will share on this site. So if you work with me, you can make sure we're on the same page.
Some of the main points to remember is that Rec. 709 is meant to be as close as possible to the the "human eye" as possible. It doesn't mean it has to be natural. Colorists can (and do) add color and create artful looks on standard Def. scan.
The purpose of defining color space is to reduce confusion. When you read an article that talks about a color space, what does that mean? Someone was likely using a different color space, than the person that wrote the article!
Rec 709 is meant to take the experience of the human eye into account. A less desirable thing to do is adjust the color of human perception by using a space, like XYZ, which can distort the perception. This distorts it to emulate how we see and how we would perceive the image if it were actually what we were looking at. It is impossible to make an image look exactly like what we would see in reality. Fortunately, Rec 709 does not try to do that. It is an attempt to come as close to what we would see, while also being a technically correct color space.

in baby rats and its effects on neurogenesis.
Vertebrate body size is correlated with brain size, but the evolutionary transformation of brain size is poorly understood. Historically, small mammal brains have been considered relatively more plastic. We tested this hypothesis in brain development by manipulating neural precursor cells in three species of neonatal rats. We found that the brain is a particularly slow-growing tissue; a 50% increase in brain mass consumed 20 times more neurons than the excess in length of a similarly sized mammal, and over 100 times more than the increase in body size. A comparison of young and aged brains in the three species also demonstrated plasticity of the brain during aging. However, long-term changes in cell number over the course of brain development were not found. The differences in predicted neurogenesis accounted for 10% of the reported phenotypic variation in brain mass across three species. This suggests that ontogeny is regulated at the level of neural precursor cells, rather than uncontrolled growth.

and how it contributes to our understanding of the ocean's role in the Earth's climate.
Oceanography is the study of the ocean, its processes, and its interactions with the earth's climate. It is a multidisciplinary field that combines physical, chemical, biological, and geological disciplines to understand the ocean's role in climate regulation and change.

Oceanographers study the ocean's physical, chemical, and biological properties, such as temperature, salinity, currents, nutrients, and oxygen levels, to gain insights into climate change, weather patterns, and ecosystem dynamics. They also explore the ocean's seafloor and monitor its response to natural and anthropogenic stressors, such as pollution, overfishing, and climate change.

Oceanography contributes to our understanding of the ocean's role in climate regulation and change by providing a comprehensive picture of the ocean's physical, chemical, and biological processes. This knowledge helps scientists understand how the ocean absorbs, transports, and releases heat and other forms of energy, and how these processes affect atmospheric temperature and circulation patterns. It also informs the development of climate models, which help predict future climate patterns and the potential impacts of climate change on marine ecosystems and coastal communities. Finally, oceanography informs policymakers on how to manage the ocean's resources and mitigate its impacts on the climate, including through policies such as ocean conservation, marine protected areas, and carbon emissions reduction initiatives.

Can you provide examples of how oceanographers have used their research to inform climate policies?
Sure, here are a few examples:

1. Ocean acidification: Ocean acidification is caused by the absorption of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere by the ocean, which lowers the pH of seawater. This process has been linked to a decline in marine life, and ocean acidification has also been shown to have impacts on the carbon cycle and climate. Researchers have used their understanding of ocean chemistry and physics to develop models that predict future changes in ocean acidity, and have used this information to inform climate policies.

2. Coastal flooding: Rising sea levels due to climate change threaten coastal cities and communities. Oceanographers have used their knowledge of coastal processes and models to predict future changes in sea level, and to inform policymakers about the potential impacts of coastal flooding on the communities that live along coasts.

3. Marine protected areas: Oceanographers have played a key role in developing the science behind marine protected areas (MPAs). These areas are protected from human activity to allow marine ecosystems to recover, and they can help to reduce the impacts of climate change on marine ecosystems.

The Edo period in Japan lasted from 1603 to 1868 and was characterized by political stability, economic growth, and the rise of a centralized government. During this time, the art of the Edo period was influenced by the court culture of the Tokugawa shogunate, which was centered in the imperial city of Kyoto.

The Edo period is notable for its development of Ukiyo-e (Floating World) art, which depicted the daily life of common people in a series of printed woodblock prints. Ukiyo-e art was heavily influenced by the court culture of the Edo period, as it was created for the consumption of the common people and reflected the social values of the time.

Another significant development in the Edo period was the rise of Western-style art, which was introduced to Japan by Dutch traders in the late 16th century. Western-style art was initially used in diplomatic and trade relations with the Western world, but it gradually made its way into Japanese art and became a popular medium for painters and sculptors.

The Edo period was also marked by the development of calligraphy, which was closely associated with the court culture of the time. Calligraphy was considered a high art form and was often commissioned by the nobility and the merchant class.

Overall, the court culture of the Edo period greatly influenced the art of the time, particularly in the development of Ukiyo-e art, Western-style art, and calligraphy. These art forms reflected the social values and aesthetic preferences of the time and continue to be celebrated and studied by art historians and collectors today.

What were the specific techniques used in creating Ukiyo-e art during the Edo period?
During the Edo period, the Ukiyo-e art form was created by using woodblock printing techniques. The artist would create a design on a piece of paper or wood, which was then transferred onto a wooden block using a chisel or gouge. The block was then coated with ink, which was transferred onto paper or silk when the printing process was completed.

Oceanography is the study of the Earth's ocean and its interactions with the atmosphere. It involves the collection and analysis of data from a variety of sources, including ships, buoys, satellites, and research vessels. The data is used to understand the physical, chemical, and biological properties of the ocean, as well as the processes that govern its behavior.

One of the key tools used in oceanography is remote sensing, which involves using instruments on satellites or aircraft to gather data on the ocean and atmosphere. This data is then analyzed to create maps and models that can be used to understand ocean currents, temperature, salinity, and other physical properties. Oceanographers also use laboratory-based methods to measure the properties of seawater, including its pH, nutrients, and dissolved gases.

Other important techniques used in oceanography include ocean drilling, which involves boring holes into the ocean floor to recover sediment and samples of rock and water, and ocean modeling, which uses computer simulations to predict how the ocean will respond to different environmental conditions.

Overall, oceanography is a complex and interdisciplinary field that draws on a wide range of scientific disciplines, including physics, chemistry, geology, and biology. By studying the ocean, oceanographers hope to better understand its role in regulating the Earth's climate, and to develop new ways to monitor and protect this vital resource.

LONDON, 16 September 2014 - Faced with a news story about climate change, many journalists see themselves as trapped between objective reporting of scientists and activists who try to dictate how they should behave.
These issues are the focus of a series of guidelines for journalism learners that help reporters take a balanced, credible and even-handed approach to reporting on climate change.
The modules were compiled by a global community of experts assembled by the Thomson Reuters Foundation, the philanthropic news agency of Reuters news organisation. It is the world's largest producer of free, daily news and information about human rights, gender equality, women’s empowerment, climate change, the environment, biodiversity, health, population and agriculture, available in more than 100 languages.
The modules were inspired by a recent conference about Journalism and Climate Change, where almost 400 attendees raised five major themes of concern about climate change journalism.
Among them:
- Introduce the problem of climate change before laying out the complexity of the science
- Find key news value in the story, such as scarcity or conflict
- Listen to an interviewee and not try to redirect the subject
- Set up a serious conversation on where to go next when the facts are not clear
- Figure out what the story is about and who the audience is
The eight pages of new guidelines now available online are essential reading for newsrooms grappling with how to write effectively about this international crisis that is reshaping the world.
New modules for reporting on climate change
More than 20 modules spread across two volumes – “Coping with Climate Change” (Vol. 1) and “Reporting on Climate Change” (Vol. 2) – offer examples, explanations and questions to help writers navigate this tricky terrain. Teachers and students can download them at no cost from here..
The new guidelines grew out of a collaboration between the Thomson Reuters Foundation and Oxford University Centre for Theoretical Linguistics, based at Oxford University’s department of Linguistics. The University Centre for Theoretical Linguistics is the world’s first Centre for Language Analysis of Document Texts. The two-year-old Centre’s expertise is particularly relevant to climate change reporting, with the Centre’s

change science have provided convincing evidence that anthropogenic climate change will lead to widespread and long-lasting economic impacts, including changes in extreme weather patterns and sea level. In 2015, the G20 endorsed the work of the international Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD), which was established as a result of the Paris agreement to guide reporting by financial institutions. In 2019, 39 jurisdictions covering more than 65 per cent of global financial assets formally adopted the TCFD recommendations, and the European Union is phasing in the requirement for disclosure by institutional investors and insurers.
Banks, pension funds and insurers in the US are among the largest and most powerful investors in the world, with total assets of almost USD 12 trillion and responsibilities over life savings of 284 million investors. If effective, efforts to encourage voluntary climate risk disclosure by these financial institutions could increase public awareness of investment risks, prompt investor action on climate, and help to level the playing field for non-financial industries making investments that will help ensure a sustainable climate.
In order to add value to governments' domestic reporting efforts, ICLEI is engaging with G20 members and other G20 Action Track partners to drive voluntary public disclosure by financial institutions, and to improve the quality of information being collected to fill gaps in what is currently available, particularly through the use of ICLEI's Innovative Market Systems (IMS) framework, as an analytical aid to identifying investment opportunities, risk, and strategies for GHG emissions reductions.
"Finance leaders across the G20 need better access to climate data and analytics from innovative technologies to inform decision making as climate risks become increasingly disruptive. This is a key issue, and ICLEI has launched a global initiative to accelerate financing for the shift toward a low carbon world."
ICLEI's local authorities have been leading the way on establishing global standards for climate risk and resilience disclosure by local governments. The newly established Local Government Climate Risk Research Alliance is providing funding for the development of innovative, online tools that will help more than 2,000 local governments worldwide to estimate the risk associated with climate change to their infrastructure and economic assets, to identify adaptation and mitigation actions, and to calculate the cost of those actions. Partners in this effort include the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the World Resources Institute, Project Drawdown, S&P Global Market Intelligence, Tesla, the San Francisco Foundation and CityLab.
An important area of focus is on low carbon investment

Graduate programs that lead to professional degrees in oceanography and ocean-related degrees are numerous across the US, with even more graduate programs abroad. A possible problem is that many of these programs are fairly high level programs, not at the undergraduate level and may even require significant time commitment to study from scratch. Not knowing much about oceanography the first obstacle is knowing where to start.

From what I know right now a good place to start would be:

1. Exploring a handful of undergraduate ocean programs

2. Possibly with a bit of research into graduate programs, specifically on their requirements.

3. Perhaps coming to terms with what is the most efficient way of gaining knowledge. In other words one may attempt to manage a healthy do-to list and then choose what to do next based on the available schedule. My experience is that managing schedules is one of the key skills that help organize something as unmanageable as oceanography. Therefore, I don’t see a single good way to be approach this. It is a long exercise and what may seem optimal today may change later.

4. Start to learn the basics (ie. if you want to be a marine biologist or physicist, consider learning your way through some books).

5. Start to learn from classes, honestly, having a graduate student and a course to guide through would have made this a whole lot easier. Our path of exploration went the opposite direction, especially because we were discussing marine biology with a lab that don’t do marine biology.

6. Take courses (that will also depend on the university requirements for the program), but, I have found that not so many schools and programs ask for a physics background. On the other hand you’ll have to take calculus.

7. Implement and run experiments (I feel this is a distinct separation), and get ahold on the work that needs to be done (the tasks) and how these tasks are all connected to solve a problem.

There are other useful materials around the internet to get started. For example, as mentioned, Wikipedia gives an overview of oceanography and has a list of schools for oceanography programs. The Oceanography Society has a huge list of graduate programs for oceanography in the US and overseas. By simply visiting the websites of the schools that list their degrees as oceanography or marine and as minor you can find out what you need to be admitted in each graduate program. For example, the University of Washington lists a list of undergraduate and graduate oceanography and marine programs. Many programs have lists of core and elective course and point to cur

Meditation works by helping you change the way your mind works.

Think of your mind as a radio that's tuned to a particular frequency. The radio you have can only pick up a certain kind of signal. If you try to tune into a different signal, it will just keep repeating the same sound over and over again, because that's the only signal you have access to.

Similarly, when we're not in meditation, our minds are constantly receiving all kinds of thoughts and ideas, all the time. But some of these thoughts are tied to negative emotions like anxiety and fear. When these thoughts keep popping up, it's like a station that's stuck on one particular frequency – it keeps repeating the same thing over and over again, and it can be really hard to escape.

Meditation, however, helps us change the way we think. It helps us tune our minds into new frequencies, where we can receive all kinds of new information and experiences. Over time, as we continue to meditate, our minds become less tied to these negative thoughts, and we become more able to receive the positive, uplifting ideas that we want.

Meditation helps us change the way we think. It's like turning down the volume of our minds, so that we can finally hear the things that we need to hear, and the things that will help us grow and improve. It's a wonderful thing, and it's something that everyone can benefit from.

education are becoming more diversified, which demands innovative educational experiences. This need calls for different methods, such as the integration of new technologies. This work proposes and applies a system using augmented reality (AR) in the context of economics education. The proposed system allows the visualisation of the denomination of foreign currencies and of economic models. The system is verified with current currency images and models of the Mexican Pesos, US Dollar, and the International Monetary Fund. The results indicate that the system, once implemented, could enhance the learning of economics by presenting the models in a more detailed manner, and with images that facilitate their visualization, and therefore, improve the student's engagement.

Fashion design is the art and process of creating clothing and accessories through the use of fabrics, colors, textures, patterns, and design elements. It involves creating garments, shoes, and accessories that are both functional and stylish, and that reflect the latest trends and styles in the fashion industry. Fashion design encompasses a wide range of activities, including sketching, draping, pattern-making, cutting, sewing, and finishing. The process typically involves a collaboration between the designer, the manufacturer, and the retailer, as well as input from clients and customers.

While The Showroom are of course the industry's leaders in wardrobe management and run more shows than anyone else each season, they were an unknown quantity when it came to advertising and PR and so it was The Showroom who approached us when they realised they needed new graphics for an event currently on their books.
Here we briefly outline the various stages, from the initial contact, right through to the exhibition itself, giving an insight into the work done by the Fine Grooms team in producing these great graphics.
The brief from The Showroom was fairly open ended. They wanted to be able to showcase the collections of five different designers on four different levels, incorporating a model dining area and providing a platform for presenting each show.
However, we also knew that the team at The Showroom needed to rely on us if their exhibit was to stand out from the crowd.
After a careful examination of the project, we came back with three initial concepts to a show that would have the most impact on the individual attending the event. Although each concept was different, they all would have been within the tight confines of the finished exhibition area - the model dining area was to be at the entrance, the staging at the rear and the individual designer stands in between, with the respective collections on the walkways above.
Once the concepts were agreed, we knew it was time to design an exhibition space from scratch. Our initial guess at the exhibition area we'd be working with was wrong, but we were able to quickly change a couple of our key design elements to allow for the extra space we were now working with and this also allowed us to incorporate the changes that The Showroom had made to their layouts at quite late notice.
Our design was split into three key sections: model dinning area, the walkways and the show stage. Each section used a different colour scheme but still fitted together harmoniously. The model dinning area, for example, was designed to let diners know that this was where they would eat, looking in from the outside to the interior.
However, you are not finished after you have designed the set, as the graphics at each stand still have to look professional and work within the stand's design. Cryptography has several benefits, including:

1. Data Security: Cryptography protects the confidentiality, integrity and authenticity of sensitive data. It is widely used in finance, healthcare, and e-commerce.

2. Data Integrity: Cryptography helps to ensure the integrity of data by detecting any modifications or tampering. It also ensures that the data remains unchanged.

3. Authentication: Cryptography can be used to authenticate the identity of a user or a system. This is achieved by using digital signatures and public key cryptography.

4. Non-repudiation: Cryptography can be used to ensure that the sender of a message or document cannot deny sending it. This is achieved by using digital signatures and public key cryptography.

5. Privacy: Cryptography can be used to protect the privacy of information by encrypting it. This can prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information.

6. Security of Data Storage: Cryptography can be used to protect data stored on servers and databases. This helps to prevent data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive data.

7. Secure Communications: Cryptography can be used to protect data transmitted over networks. This can prevent eavesdropping and interception of data by unauthorized parties.

has a long history in American culture. One of the founders of this field was British born American legal scholar Jeremy Bentham. In the United States, Bentham's ideas were chiefly popularized by Harvard professor James Bryce in his book English Studies (1870-76). A later editor, Samuel Willard Dwight, wrote a commentary on this book called American Studies in English Law in 1877. After dealing with the historical development of ethics and morals up to the general acceptance of the Moral Order in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the later editions of the book turn to consideration of the early development of business ethics in eighteenth and nineteenth century America. Here the discussion includes America's first school for seamanship and shipping, a Marine Hospital, New Jersey, ship jockeys and auctioneers, auction and retail prices, the duties of a master mariner, cases of maritime liens, mechanics and apprentice systems, the pilots of New York, and American seamen.
The Principles of Morals and Legislation was published in 1780.
The present book was published between 1870 and 1876.
A third edition of American Studies in English Law was published in 1893.

A 1972 edition of American Studies in English Law was published by Fellowship Press.

and the trouble of sustainability
A very critical view of sustainable tourism has been suggested by Graham, Willis and Wearing (2007), as they argue that “tourism, an industry that depends on natural and human resources in the periphery, is destroying these very resources in the periphery” (p. 5). This perspective clearly reflects the minority and often neglected voices that have been exposed and brought into light over the years in various universities and NGOs as a result of the tourism’s limitations and shortcomings. Whatever the concept and its background, an eco-tourist can be defined as someone who travels for the purpose of experiencing environmental and cultural tourism. Rather than consuming prepackaged, mass-produced tourist destinations, a more sustainable practice involves discovering an unfamiliar place and living like the locals do for a short time, therefore understanding the negative effects that tourism may cause. Here, sustainability is completely neglected. Sustainable tourism is a movement and not a practice. Sustainability is key in order to preserve our planets natural resources for the next generation, including nature, wildlife, water, soil, and air quality. As soon as the tourists are brought into the destination, the inevitable wear and tear on the resources begins and the building blocks of sustainability fall apart. Unsustainable and unnourishing for both nature and animals, consumptive tourism must be adapted to fit the core objectives of preserving local cultures and traditions. Tourism and Development are both linked to one and other, or in other words, the more tourism goes, the more it disturbs the local culture and vice versa. This vicious circle will therefore increase the economic and political impacts that will create additional problems, eventually damaging the environment (Talayero and Griessler, 2011). According to Gregg and Burrowes (2001), an honest definition of sustainable tourism is “tourism in a socio-economic context, which exists for people, for their spiritual enrichment, and which develops in a context of local culture and natural resources (high environmental quality and animal and flora and fauna) without the individual feeling that it is asking for more than it has been able to provide (p. 2). “
It is obvious that sustainable tourism has not found enough acceptance on a large scale yet. Issues with implementing sustainability have been rooted in the many myths associated with it. Some of the myths we encounter includes: inefficient conservation, excessive cost, unequal distribution of benefits (Talayero and Griessler, 2011), and unfair resentment. Partly true but considerably wrong,

cannot be understated. The unique combination of music and movement continues to draw millions of people to its art form. As an art form, it improves the quality of life of millions of people through its many physical and social benefits. By enabling them to connect with other people, dance brings communities together. It also helps individuals create a dialogue with themselves and improve their health.
The dance discipline is not a new phenomenon. It has been practiced for centuries by various cultures, and its popularity has grown over time. Though the art of dance as we know it today had developed from classical ballet, it has since evolved into a new discipline of its own. This has allowed modern dancers to maintain their passion and remain relevant to audiences around the world. In fact, some of the most famous modern dancers have inspired dancers to pursue a career in the dance industry.
The discipline of dance has many benefits, and it's not limited to physical health. It can improve emotional health, reduce anxiety, and help individuals find better ways to deal with stress. In addition, it is a way to express one's creativity. It has many benefits for the brain as well as the body. It helps individuals relax their minds and bodies. The physical health benefits of dancing are numerous, and it can even help people improve their self-esteem. This can lead to greater confidence in oneself and the ability to socialize with others.
Unlike other forms of art, modern dance incorporates elements of other styles, such as jazz, ballet, and modern, into its practice. Most modern dancers will learn these elements separately and then eventually combine them. This allows them to enhance their performances with more flexibility and agility. The art of dance has become more popular today, and the skill of a modern dancer has become a prized commodity. While many people don't consider this as an art, it is an essential part of modern society.
While traditional dance has its roots in classical ballet and other forms, modern dance has evolved to include a variety of styles. Its roots are in hip-hop, contemporary dance, and jazz. Many of these styles are now combined in the same performance. This type of dance is unique to the individual and is meant to express emotions and different aspects of oneself. While it is important to understand the history of modern dance, it is also crucial to understand its roots.

By combining the presence of a camera on the block, new technology and appearance theater that will give a greater feeling of realism, everything will be performed with highly advanced technology.
Augmented and virtual reality theater
It is a new concept that has not yet shown the public. Theater can be made part artificial and part real, with the participation of the actors, but with the new technology that we know today, such as augmented reality applications and virtual reality experiences.
Theater taken to the web
After the theaters shut down due to the pandemic, and the world had to endure the distance caused by coronavirus, one proposal that seems to be still ahead is the possibility of making theater entirely on the web. In Spain, for example, some theaters have already bet on the web, and the result has been more than satisfactory.
Theater, as a general example
For the moment we have virtual reality, but other technologies can also enter. Some propose to add robots. At an international level, a theatrical company of Saint Paul, in Minnesota, made their show on the streets, with a camera on their bicycles, for many hours to capture it, which with the help of special software, they got the most emotional feelings through new ways. Of course, the latest technologies will surely be applied to theater, but it is a discipline in which it will be difficult to fully change their management.
Advantages of virtual reality
Virtual Reality or VR provides an experience designed to be as lifelike and immersive as possible. That doesn't mean it has to be in a physical space. Each performance will be different and will respond to all the factors that are necessarily part of theater. At this time we are still seeing the future of theater through a virtual curtain, and we will always have to wait for the limitations of the present to be resolved.

For the past 14 years a strong commitment to sociology, and to a growing group of sociology practitioners in the UK, is Helen Featherstone's world. In this interview, she reflects on her role as the first female President of the British Sociological Association (in June 2014 she was re-elected for a second term).
Alongside her association with the BSA, Featherstone is perhaps best-known for her own research into domestic abuse, but a commitment to widening access to the academic discipline of sociology and to ensuring that the term 'refugee' is not used merely as a political football has also long been at the heart of her research. In this interview, Featherstone reflects on her research, her time as a fellow of the ESRC, and her personal passion for sociology.
​Q. What is the most rewarding thing about being a sociologist? The most rewarding thing is the ability to communicate the findings of the work I do to the public, the ability to communicate things which are, if not taken into account, then quite certainly missed. While this sounds obvious, there has never been such a need to make this case, given the criticism of an academic discipline that so many commentators put forward. It is doubly satisfying to then receive so many letters from people, who have heard about your work through the press or television, thanking you for bringing to their attention something that they either never knew or wanted to question further, that is, the extent to which a form of 'everyday' inaction could reproduce inequality.
Q. What is the most dispiriting thing about being a sociologist?
Another thing which is tremendously important in sociology and that is the ability to point to contradictions. There are very few disciplines which I think do this as well as sociology does. It is important to question the things you are most used to, you are most comfortable with, you find most 'obvious'. Many of my colleagues in sociology have allowed themselves to be suffocated by the things they are most convinced of. And this is something we should not allow ourselves to do.
Q. What is the best thing about being a sociologist in the early 21st Century?
The role of the sociologist as a critic of society, as a dissenter in society, still has enormous value. Of course, the ability to transmit these criticisms to a wider audience has never been as important as it is now. So for me, the best thing about being a sociologist in the

can hardly be overestimated. Despite its (long) history, it continues to play a (significant) role in our lives.
