makes calculating moments a breeze. Such knowledge comes into its own during calculations and experiments which require intricate math: calculating the frequency of sound waves, calculating distance traveled in a given amount of time, and other situations in which calculating a moving object’s momentum or velocity is required, not to mention force in the case of collisions.
What you need to know before you start a physics study is that every physics measurement is made up of two different pieces of information. One is simply a number. The other is the unit in which this number is expressed. For example, 27 in the unit centimeters is no good. But 27 centimeters is. In physics, you don’t simply measure, you measure in some unit of measure. Take, for example, the length of an object. If the object measures 4 inches long, that’s telling you just about nothing. What you really want to know is that the object measures 4 inches (or feet or meters or centimeters or whatever your chosen measurement unit is).
The international standard is SI units (short for International System of Units). SI units have become standard in virtually all scientific and industrial fields of work, in physics, engineering, as well as in places like the military, the medical industry, and even in our homes.
In physics, the basic measure is the mole or mol for short, the SI unit of amount of substance. Here’s the deal: a mole of anything contains 6.02214179 x 10 23 particles of whatever you’re dealing with. That number (known in physics circles as Avogadro’s number) is also known as the exact number of particles in 12 grams of 12C carbon (atomic weight 12). Just remember this: 6.022 x 10 23 is the exact number of particles in 1 mole.
Before you can talk about moles in any science-related field, you must first learn to express measurements in some unit of weight. The basic weight is the gram or the gramme (g). Each gram is equal to 1/1,000th of a kilogram. And the gram is the base unit of weight measurement in the metric system (the one that’s in use around the world).
To multiply, add the gram amount by the number. To divide, divide the gram amount by the number.
The combination of grams and mole for measuring large numbers of particles comes in handy when talking about how much matter

This is my MOOC application (11/24/13) to teach a college course in genetics. I am not affiliated with the teachers in charge of the course. I am unfamiliar with the school, class, or textbook they will be using in the class. This MOOC is a curation of various online resources, including:

• Kahn Academy videos on algebra, pre-algebra, geometry, triangles, and SAT practice.
• The Shmoop Intro to Genetics and Genomes course (though I removed most Shmoop content; this is my own writing, though heavily informed by other sources). Note this course contains a focus on human genetics rather than the general topics presented below.
• To which I add a “Gene Family Tree” question set.
• I have also included Khan Academy practice videos on physics and calculus.

Here are the topics I intend to address with this MOOC, most of which I will add to continually as time allows.

### Introduction to First Principles

The focus of this MOOC is to introduce students to basic principles underlying genetics, genomics, and medicine. The principle is to teach the content in “first principles,” that is, with an emphasis on a strong foundational understanding. The concepts are not explained via a scientific literature review, but rather explained simply and as clearly as possible (though in complete generality if possible). Students are encouraged to use the first principles in every day lives when talking about genetics.

Next Steps

• I would like to continue adding e-books or videos, and create a library of useful “self-learning” content.
• Collect practice problems/questions for me to add to the site.
• Collect online reading/online videos and examplar practice problems/questions.
• Create interactive web pages with practice problems for each topic.
• Develop a way for the student to check answers at their own pace.

An example of an idea is this YouTube video of Feynman speaking about 5th grade mathematics, where he explains common errors with multiplication, division, fractions, and addition. Here is the transcript and transcript of that video at our blog.

These topics can also be included in a broader “Introduction to Science” class, as a bridge from math to physics, biology, and chemistry, or for advanced STEM students to get a jumping-off point for other content. Just consider these the “first principles” of physics.

is the philosophical theory which guides the design, construction, and structural integrity of buildings. The philosophy of architecture is a literary area of the philosophy of science that examines how ideas and methods influence the design and construction of the built environment. Analytic philosophy, including linguistics and logic, is utilized as a methodology to inform issues involving natural language and art. It attempts to answer the question "What is architecture and what makes it distinct from other philosophically significant art forms?"  Many philosophers examine the relationship of architecture and art. The examination of these relationships is often referred to as the philosophy of architecture and architecture as a philosophical problem.
The word architect is derived from the Latin architectura, which in turn is derived from the Greek αρχιτεκτονική (arkhitektonikí) meaning "master builder" from αρχι- (arch-) "chief" and τέκτων (técton) "builder" or "craftsman". The Greek verb αρχιτεκτονεύω (arkhitektonesú) simply means "to be a master builder or to function in the capacity of architect." The prefix αρχι- may be used to convey a range of meanings in various contexts including the first, chief, superior, or head.
From this origin the term came to be used for the art of building and an early definition of an architect was "the author of any thing beautiful in the line of contrivance.".
The theme of philosophy of art is the role and importance of design; in artistic terms, this may mean the relationship between utility and beauty, as in the definition of architecture as "the art of ordering the elements of a building for the sake of symmetry, utility, and beauty." Others have discussed architecture as a communication medium through which one person endeavors to connect with the needs, desires, values and traditions of another.
Philosophers, social scientists, architects, and other individuals have studied human art in general, and architectural design and production in particular, for thousands of years. Philosophical analysis of art and architecture began in ancient Greece and has continued into the present day.

1. All rocks consist of the same minerals.
The vast majority of the rocks in the Earth's crust consist of different minerals, each with its own chemical and mineralogical properties. If we were to melt all the rocks on the Earth, we would obtain a substance called rock melt. By dissolving this substance in water and cooling it, it would form minerals that are found in rocks throughout the Earth. But one sample of melt would not be exactly like another sample of melt; the concentrations of the minerals in each sample would be different. And there is a certain range of the proportions of mineral constituents that rocks can contain. Therefore it is unlikely that identical minerals are found throughout the Earth.
2. Different rocks form at different temperatures.
Much to the surprise of many, there are rocks that form at a high temperature, that is at high pressure as well as rocks that form at low temperatures, that is at low pressure. In fact, most rocks form at intermediate temperatures and pressures, with more important cooling effects occurring at lower temperatures. During periods of geologic history, the cooling of the crust depends on the amount of volcanic activity occurring, and the composition of the mantle. Thus, the thermal structure of the Earth has changed over the age of the Earth. However, it appears that rocks only started forming rocks at high temperatures during and after the period of massive volcanism called the Chixculub Event. For example, granite rocks only form at relatively low temperatures. This is because most of the granite is formed in the current lower layer of the crust in the form of igneous rocks, that is, below the Earth's crustal surface. This is also true of all the mineral rich igneous rocks such as mafic igneous rocks, diorite, basalt, gabbro, pegmatite, granite porphyry, marble, pegmatite, peridotite, obsidian, pumice, limestone and quartzite, to mention just a few. Some of these rocks form at very low temperatures, such as peridotite, which consists of olivine (the crystal structure of the mineral olivine is close to hexagonal). The natural process of metamorphism means that it is heated and cooled as part of crustal processes. If it were not for these natural processes, the rocks would form at much lower temperatures.
3. All geologists work with the same geological principles.

Cooking can offer numerous benefits, including the following:

1. Nutritional benefits: Cooking can help improve the nutritional value of food by enhancing the absorption of nutrients from vegetables and fruits. It also helps reduce the risk of foodborne illnesses.

2. Increased taste and flavor: Cooking can enhance the taste and flavor of food by adding spices, herbs, and sauces.

3. Family bonding: Cooking can be a fun and enjoyable activity for families. It provides an opportunity to bond and spend quality time together.

4. Cost-effective: Cooking can save money as it can reduce the need for takeout or delivery. It also allows for more control over the ingredients used in meals.

5. Improved mental health: Cooking can be a form of relaxation and stress relief. It can also enhance creativity and improve self-esteem.

Overall, cooking can bring many benefits to both physical and mental health, as well as strengthen family bonds.

Dr. Axel Brücher is a Group Leader of the Peptide & Macromolecular Scaffolds Group at the Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences in the ETH Zurich. Axel Brücher obtained his Dipl.-Chem.-Molec. Chem. degree at the University of Cologne in 1995. He joined the Pharmaceutical Research Laboratories of Sandoz and was later part of the Research and Development team of Actelion in Basel. In 2005, he obtained his Doctorate from the University of Tübingen for his thesis on "The Trapping of Disulfides in Macromolecular Architectures". Before he joined ETH Zurich in 2014, he was Manager Peptide and Protein Chemicals at Merck KGaA and co-founded the company Capsetag AG, a spin off from the Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences at ETH Zurich, which offers innovative and novel chemical approaches to improve the efficacy of peptide based drugs. Axel Brücher is co-inventor of several patents on the chemical generation of peptide self-assemblies. He is currently co-founder of and shareholder of several start-up companies focused on developing drugs for CNS indication. He has been co-funded by the European Research Council in 2013, appointed Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC) in 2014, and elected Fellow of the Royal Society of Art, Manufactures, and Commerce (FRSA) in 2015. has created a few associated disasters of which Luddites are only too familiar with, and seeing as one of the most celebrated robots would be Frankenstein’s monster, what is it about these artificially-created people that still makes us shudder with fear? Read more to find out.
A few years ago, a floating robot developed by scientists at the University of Pennsylvania was designed to be used for psychiatric therapy. It is claimed that it can navigate social and emotional problems, with its minimal design and bot-like mannerisms allegedly keeping it from being threatening to vulnerable people. Being alien and not perceived as human may be its greatest appeal – that and a well-constructed psychology. Clever, yet subtle.
Robots are often functional and popular because their artistry lies in their bleak and unforgiving design. They fit into their surroundings and can be utilised as either ‘negative space’ or ‘positive space’, being either void or filled as a still, silent entity.
One might look at In The Woods by Yinka Shonibare with this in mind – cold metal and a sans-serf-like stature lends itself well to the miserable robot, though it is contoured differently to make the display more effective. Though more cyber-robotic, the same can be applied to Frankenstein’s Monster.
Frankenstein’s Monster is fascinating because it is threatening in appearance. In the world of zombies, vampires and similar postures, the robot is the most interesting of the lot. The pale complexion, the angular face and atypical stature make it almost inhuman, and in a world where the ability to move is linked to humanity, it becomes rather off-putting. It is questionable as to whether the Frankenstein Monster would fall into the Jekyll and Hyde categories, being too primitive for decent experiments, but too advanced for basic criminal tasks.
Terry Jones would suggest the Frankenstein Monster is atypical of robots because of the sheer speed and technology behind the man/machine hybrid. Clearly there are laws which forbid it now, but other, newer creations like the android are now permitted on the legal market. However, the development of these synthetic versions has become a grey area of both the science and crime. The thought that a robot could lay eggs seems distasteful, and the idea that it could possibly be used for evil purposes only adds to the mythical qualities of both the enigmatic Frankenstein Monster and the smaller-yet-just-as-sinister pseudo android.

Transcript of my very first meeting at the Le Bell Robotics lab, Salle DESROSIERS, August 6, 1997. Posted by permission of the lab director.

Robotics 101

People ask: what does [a robot] look like, and where does it come from? Here's my best answer.

The most fundamental thing we know about the machines we call robots is that they are automata, or systems that repeat a task. So a robot is, first of all, an automaton. Second, it has to do some function -- when you put it together, what will it do? Third, you have to be able to construct it: the components have to be manufactured or can be manufactured and then put together. If you buy it already assembled, there's a good chance it's a computer, not a robot. Because, fourth, in order for a machine to be a robot, the first and second conditions imply that it also has to be a machine.

A robot is composed of several parts. First, the software. How to build an automaton from scratch is a process we'll look at later. But the essential thing about programs -- and the lesson we'll learn today -- is that they are stored in a specific form. A computer is nothing but a fancy box that plays with memory. The real machine is the memory chip; the box, the reader (hardware) and the word processor (software). Just as we call the keyboard of an electronic organ "an organ," we call this a "robot processor." The reader reads the signals from the keyboard and writes them to the hardware. The processor runs on a code, a bunch of numbers we call "bits," that runs on the software. That's a simplified explanation, but it's the truth. For humans, the processor is the brain, software the mind and the programming languages are the language. The bits are the thought patterns.

Then there is the hardware. Whatever a robot is made of, it has to move or remain still. It can't be done without physical parts. We'll look at these later.

Finally, there is power and output. All this work would be done for nothing unless you could use the information to do something useful. That's our power supply: energy. You have to store some energy, and then you have to convert it to movement and output.

So this is how a robot works. Let's look at the components from the bottom up. First, power. Remember that

is a topic related to Art and in order to understand what is at stake, it is necessary to deconstruct it and reconnect it to its very basic meaning.
The criteria that inform the definition of art and art object change over time and different parts of the world. Art is like a language, its meaning and usage might be different for everybody. Nevertheless, art can connect diverse groups of people with shared philosophical or socio-political concerns (for more examples, visit Our Values website). One may not consider, for instance, the anti-war sculpture Saint Joan of Arc by Pablo Picasso, created in 1937, as a work of art, just because in this case art is understood as pure entertainment.
There are very different art forms and arts from different points of view. For instance, the visual arts might differ from the performing arts such as music and dance. Let’s say, this implies that arts are a category in the field of culture where expression can vary quite considerably in artistic movement and expression forms. One has to differentiate fine art from arts used for broader cultural, social and economic usage. The same applies to other art forms such as visual arts. In this case one has to distinguish between forms, media and techniques in visual arts, for example.
Furthermore, a distinction is often made between art and art history. However, in a contemporary context the line has often become blurred, since art has become a wide field of cultural and art production. An example of the blurred boundaries in the field of art are digital art or installations.
The main thing is to look at art production from a broad perspective. In doing so, one may recognise that art is fundamentally not only about aesthetic or aesthetic pleasure. The object of art encompasses all of human life and culture. For us, the term art nowadays refers to works of art – this means, objects we associate with particular forms of artistic creativity such as visual arts, music or literature. In order to enrich the debate on what is at stake in art production, it is useful to examine other facets such as art history or aesthetics.

Meteorology is the study of the Earth’s atmosphere and how it changes over time. This includes the weather, the atmosphere’s temperature, humidity, pressure, and other weather conditions. Meteorology is important because it helps us predict future weather conditions and understand how the atmosphere affects our lives.
There are several key terms and concepts that beginners should know when studying meteorology. These include:
• Atmospheric pressure: This refers to the force exerted by the Earth’s atmosphere on a given area.
• Air flow: This is the movement of air across the Earth’s surface.
• Weather forecasting: This is the process of predicting future weather conditions using scientific methods.
• Troposphere: This is the lowest layer of Earth’s atmosphere and contains most of the weather conditions that affect us.
• Thermosphere: This is the uppermost layer of the atmosphere and contains the ozone layer, which helps protect us from harmful ultraviolet radiation.
• Hydrological cycle: This is the continuous process by which water moves through the Earth’s atmosphere and various land and water surfaces.
• Solar radiation: This is the energy from the sun that causes the Earth’s atmosphere to change.
• Natural disasters: These are events that can cause harm to people and property, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and earthquakes.
In summary, studying meteorology can help us understand the Earth’s atmosphere and how it affects our lives. This includes understanding weather conditions, atmospheric pressure, air flow, weather forecasting, the troposphere, thermosphere, hydrological cycle, solar radiation, and natural disasters.

Fern took furtive flight Fridays, flocking frequently to feed beneath the figum tree fringe. Furry friends frequently fled the flock, as fledglings feared their fluffy fungi faces flaking floriferously. Fawn found foreign flecks on the figums, flapping furiously, frightening fellows fast.

Feeling foolish, fern fumbled farther, fearfully facing fungi forests. Flickering flags flickered fearfully, faltering forward. Fawn's frantically fluttering feathers flamed as the fungi formed into flying fungi factors, flinging fiery fragments full-force.

Frightened, fern fled, but fell into fast-flowing fountains, into pools of formation fluid. Forrest's frog found the floating fern, feasting frenetically, flinging feedback fragments far and wide. Fawn found forbidden fungi freedom, fleeing far from ferns' frightful fury, feeling filled with fortuity, floating freely along the forest's flawless foliage.

From fear, fern flourished, frolicking fearlessly amidst fallen fungi forests. Forever fearless, fern flourished, far surpassing fern's feline foes, fostering fearlessness in future firings.

In this post, I want to explain a natural way to think about and understand artificial intelligence, especially as it relates to deep learning, as both a baseline for comparison to what actually works and (as a reference for) what people are hoping for when they say that A.I. should be “more like the human brain.” I’m speaking here about artificial intelligence in the sense of a Turing test, and not (for example) advanced robotics, though an interesting and possibly highly-relevant difference between the two is that of temporal coordination. All this is in line with one of the early, major goals of AI research (as memorably spelled out by Marvin Minsky and Seymour Papert), namely, “building machines that will have an affinity for intelligent behaviour, learning from experience, and perhaps even passing the Turing Test.” (N.B.: “passing the Turing Test” here is a loose analogy to “being mistaken for human.”) We’ll also touch on why we shouldn’t hope for general intelligence (something we’ve come to think of as human-like), and what role maybe-sentient minds (the parent post is more interesting if you assume that general intelligence means “being a mind” in the same way that everything we see in this world is a “thing” — an important distinction and caveat, to be sure, to be examined more thoroughly later) play in our understanding of what A.I. is, can be, and probably should be. I’ll try to address some common but insiduous points between what is and what isn’t currently considered A.I. Lastly, to mention something we’ll have to address later, even if AI is a fully equi-dimensional representation of the human brain, some element of neuroscience is necessary to understand the brain and its algorithms.

That said, we’ll start by talking about what an A.I. is and isn’t. What an A.I. is and isn’t isn’t (and shouldn’t) really matter to a scientific discussion. We can, for example, exclude all that is obviously not A.I., like the trivial kind that just passes binary truth functions, and define it in terms of its “modes of operation,” but doing so gets into a lot of things we’re still not sure we understand about A.I., including that last point about neuroscience. Also, while this wouldn’t be bad or wrong to do (and it would be a good exercise to see how it ends up getting specified), we’re not there yet, and

is a science of the beliefs of persons in geology. According to this philosophy, the social history of geology is a history of beliefs.
The history of geology is written entirely from these beliefs.
The sociology of science is not the history of science. Historians of geology are not sociologists of science. Political scientists, biologists, economists, and psychologists study their own specialties; geologists study geology.
Those who thought geology was the last science to be distinguished by its revolutionary advance of the technology of science. In Europe, geology was suddenly recognized as a separate science in 1756, when the German physicist Abraham Werner proposed a detailed sequence of rocks from sedimentary to volcanic. This sequence became a guide to mineral exploration and quarrying. German lawyers in the 1770s began to argue for standards of rock identification in land law. The number of geologists became a topic of political debate. Today more than 75% of geologists are divided into geologists whose scientific research area is their professional specialty, and geologists whose professional interests are in investigating the social history of geology.
Inevitably, as science and technology advanced, two sorts of geologists became prominent. Many geologists worked in separate research laboratories to search for ores, petroleum and natural gas. They worked in unusual parts of the world, in parts of the world that had remained isolated from civilization for long periods of time. They collected specimens and specimens that turned out to be valuable minerals and energy resources. Theirs was a rapid rise in wealth and status.
The other geologists were other geologists, the geologists who found valuable rocks. They found fossil remains for the paleontologists and chemical findings for the geologists who work in minerals and ore deposits. There were many such sub-specialties: petrologists worked on the rare rocks in metamorphic cores; pyroxenologists worked on rocks with X symbol; petrographers searched for fossils. Each professor or research worker could distinguish by his or her own trade of classical geology into the scientific and the expert. All of them were professionally distinguished by the special technical skills with which they faced the identification of rocks and fossils.
In the United States, the geologists of the pioneer era have been recognized as hardworking scientists, imbued with an amateur's love of digging in the earth. They have been remembered as men of culture, men with wide interests in life, men who had time to make and preserve plants, and paint their own famous work

can be heavily debated, but why would someone want to go to college to learn about an art form instead of a science? The argument can be made that society doesn’t often value the skills gained in the majors, such as critical thinking, strong writing and clear communication skills. Instead, it is emphasized that people who study the liberal arts can become teachers or go into a ministry.
Although the liberal arts do sound like a great way to spend a couple of years learning how to entertain and fool yourself in class, science is actually becoming an increasingly valuable commodity. Whether it is a degree in chemistry, physics, math, etc., science can be applied to pretty much any profession.
The skills gained in these degrees can definitely assist someone in a creative field, but learning science will make a scientist.
The world has embraced technology and science to improve it in ways people could have only dreamed of in past generations. It’s all around us; modern medicine, information and communication systems, household appliances and climate control, even water filtration systems. Science keeps these incredible advances within reach, and new advancements are being made constantly, leading to improvements in almost every facet of life.
There are also various careers within these fields that can pay handsomely; you just can’t beat a career in medicine. Scientists can land high paying positions in the industry and can also move into higher education, where their salaries can continue to rise. There are many instances of career growth within the sciences, and this is only a small portion of the possible majors.
As stated, science can be applied to most professions. It’s important to note that there are many career choices for people, especially within the science fields. In the STEM fields, you can have a role as an engineer, chemist, physicist, statistician or programmer. Many of these careers pay well, even in entry level jobs, and they are jobs that people want to have. Basically, if someone wants a career that pays well, they would be smart to take a science major and study hard.
There are many viable career paths within science, and with low unemployment and high pay, anyone interested in a STEM related career would be wise to give it serious consideration.
Now, there are a few people who are comfortable taking an extended hiatus from science while they live off of trust funds and watch a lot of Netflix. Fine, you do you. But for everyone else, college is a place to learn new things and make connections. The idea that there are no careers available for someone who didn’t study a specific major is outdated.

, including the invention of photography and major developments in camera technology.

The history of photography dates back to the 16th century when the development of a working camera obscura was discovered. A camera obscura is a dark room or box that has a pinhole or small aperture, allowing light to enter and create an image on the opposite wall. This device has been around for centuries and was later improved upon by Italian physicist Giambattista della Porta in the 16th century.

However, it wasn't until the early 19th century that photography was officially invented. In 1800, French inventor Joseph Nicéphore Niépce captured the first permanent photograph on a pewter plate coated with bitumen of Judea. The process, called heliography, used bitumen as a photographic medium and required exposure to light to develop the image.

Shortly after Niépce's achievement, other French scientists and inventors continued to refine the technique. In 1826, French inventor Louis Daguerre introduced the daguerreotype, a photography method using a silver-coated copper plate. This process became highly popular and provided a more stable image than heliography.

In 1837, William Henry Fox Talbot, an English physicist and chemist, invented the calotype process, also known as the "negative-positive" or "negative-negative" system. This process produced an image that could be reproduced through the use of(printing) negatives. This was a significant advancement in photography as it allowed for multiple copies of the same photograph.

The 19th century also witnessed significant developments in photographic equipment. In the late 1840s, American photographer Alexander Wolcott invented the first handheld camera, which made photography more portable and accessible. Then, in the 1850s, German inventor Auguste Marie Louis Gustave Adolphe de的照片阻滞下行Acrysin继德Deppe开发了一款新型相机相机,它被广泛认为是世界上第一台真正意义上的相机。 This camera had a lens with a rotating shutter that allowed for exposure times ranging from fractions of a second to several minutes. This camera became extremely popular and is still in use today.

Another significant invention was the dry plate process, which was introduced in 1871 by British photographer Frederick Scott Archer. This process involved using a glass plate coated with a gelatin emulsion and allowed for instant drying, making photography more convenient.

: Even after decades of research, we still learn something new. For instance, we can now link a history of lightning to a child’s greater risk for a serious psychiatric disorder.
For nearly 20 years, the "Great Storm" of April 27, 2011, is coming to be regarded as a test case to determine the limits of what research can reveal about the effects of extreme weather on people.
Now, psychologists at North Carolina State University have identified one important psychological influence in the storm's aftermath: a child's higher risk of developing an anxiety disorder.
According to a news report by the media services office, the research team led by psychology associate professor Jason Bennett found that past severe storms increased the chances that children had anxiety symptoms at school years later.
"This study is important for two reasons," Bennett said. "First, it helps us identify when the effects of the storm are too long-lasting to be gone or explained by natural changes that occurred between then and the present. Second, it helps us understand some of the psychological consequences of extreme weather, something we previously knew little about."
The study focused on young children who had exposure to the "Great Storm." In April 2011, this category included children who had lived through the storm or nearby counties during the storm's peak, as well as children who had been young children during the storm (2-3 years old) but had not been in any of the storm's impact zones.
Their study of the behavior and attitudes of 802 students from West Virginia public schools, conducted from 2014-16, found that children who had lived in the storm's impact zone exhibited symptoms of anxiety two years later. The same was true for children in the 3- to 5-year-old category, who had been in the storm's path but were not directly hit. The same held for children who had been exposed to the tornadoes, which hit immediately after the storm, but did not themselves actually experience the storm or its aftermath. "These results indicate that there is a continuous stream of effects when it comes to extremely stressful experiences," Bennett said.
"It's clear that this is not just an anxiety disorder that will go away," Bennett said. "This effect is not caused by the trauma of the storm directly, but because of the overall stress that people in the storm’s impact zone endured.
"But since we don't know what emotional components of the storm led to the anxiety effects, we cannot determine if the mood, the physical stress

The Common Data Envs project was started at the request of the Representative Office of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Poland in November 2013.
Concept of data visualization for defense and security structures and the development of graphic novel applications are among the tasks of the project.
The data portal ‘Impact of Climate Change on Natural Resources and Ecological Services to human life in the frame of International Security and its impact on international security’ provides necessary materials for the project.
The project was supported by a grant from the Government of the United States of America and implemented by the Global Environmental Fund under the United Nations Development Programme and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Poland.
The project was officially launched in 2012 within the National Program for the Development of Regional Partnerships for the Democracy Project under the program ‘Democratic Governance’.
The focus of the project was initially on improving the local administration and public administration in two municipalities. Later, the second main goal was to prepare a transformation plan for introducing modern management methods and tools in the Municipality of Tbilisi, with appropriate training. In parallel, a municipal administration within the City Court was organized, preparing a standard model of laws and regulations. Legal provision and introduction of innovative and efficient administration methods took place.
The project was also aimed at improving information systems for administration, public administration and supervisory bodies by the creation of modern IT tools and information systems for electronic records and documents. IT tools and projects as well as Information Systems were implemented in accordance with European, international and professional standards.

are what drive architecture. Architecture has benefits in the areas of physical real estate and interior design. Additionally, architecture also offers benefits in the psychological sphere of the individual.
Building with good architecture means building a better quality of life. Many homes, communities, and office buildings are designed to be more attractive, safer, more energy-efficient, and affordable to build. In the process, architects work with owners to determine the most effective ways to meet a project's specific goals. Many of today's architects also work closely with other professionals in the building industry, such as engineers, contractors, developers, and government agencies.
Architecture represents much more than simply buildings and land. Architecture has to do with location and space. It is about combining function and aesthetics in harmony.
Architecture also addresses matters of physical space. Examples of architecture as landscape architecture include gardens, parks, and urban plans. A functional aspect of landscape architecture involves the creation of living areas that work for their occupants' needs. Landscape architecture is also about creating a sustainable environment for future generations.
Physical space is also central to the field of architecture. Space refers to the physical distance between objects. Architecture includes the physical manifestation of space in a given design. Good architecture involves designing spaces that serve the most basic human needs. Aesthetics are a part of physical space but not the only element. Space is also concerned with a building's shape, materials, furnishings, color, lighting, textures, and other elements.
The psychological sphere of a building includes its effects on those who use it. A building can affect people in different ways. Sometimes the psychological impact of a building is positive; sometimes it is negative. The architecture should create a harmonious environment for those who occupy the building. This can mean a space that feels comfortable and safe. It could also mean a space that looks beautiful and appealing.
Architecture is also a problem-solving discipline. As a problem solver, architects help solve problems. An architecture plan is an important part of developing a solution to a problem. Without a solid architectural plan, it is difficult to realize the ideal solution to any problem.
There is much that an architecture plan can do for a building. However, the architect's primary role is one of problem solving. It is important for architects to be able to think strategically in order to succeed in solving problems. Strategic thinking helps architects develop creative solutions to problems that will benefit their clients.

is long and somewhat convoluted. In our modern day, we can take for granted both the elements and tools that the weather creates. Without the improved technologies that are our everyday, it would be difficult to predict what the weather may be, or what impact those affects may have on our lives and our health.
How Did Technology Affect Meteorology?
Today, when you want the latest weather information about San Jose weather, it’s just a quick click away. Access to the latest data is made easy with the help of the Internet and the ability to quickly communicate with others via the computer and its reliability.
Meteorologists, however, did not have it so easy, and communication wasn’t always so accessible. Between 1850-1900, meteorologists took the best data they could find from various observatories around the world and based it on that. Information from radio sources like shortwave radio, navy ships, railway communications and even telegraph and telephone lines. Then, it was often put into tables, graphs and maps and printed in journals and papers for others to access.
Not until 1893, when Milan Malaguzzi signed a contract with MIT to conduct a long-range weather forecast that measured the differences in barometric pressure from west to east, and that measured the temperature throughout the nation.
Then, in 1898, C.W. Gilbreth, introduced a device which uses a rotating drum mechanism which told the time of day. With this timing, meteorologists and telegraphers had the ability to see how far a storm might go. Not until 1921 with the installation of any sort of radar system. Before this, telegraphers could only use telephone lines, the telephone itself, and letters and messages. Of course, with those, they had to wait to get the messages from the telegram and then relay it to their clients.
We’ve come a long way from the days of paper maps and time charts for checking the weather. And while technology is just a part of meteorology, the application is vast. The use of radar, satellite imagery and computer modeling all are able to produce the data for the meteorologist’s global investigations, and understanding of the weather for all to use.

The latest ultra-modern architecture project by Emre Arolat Architects, a prominent Istanbul-based practice, is constructed using the latest sustainable and economic construction material of the concrete. An elite taste of living would forever be implied in its design that is best expressed in its unobtrusive steps, vaulted ceilings, elegant hallway and master bedroom entrance.

The master bedroom unit is slightly vaulted leading to the bed deck which is somewhat elevated from the others. It is imagined with a pool on its wall surface which is inspired from a Roman-Greek pool’s side panels. This sculptural body feature further expresses the verve of grand living for a more exotic retreat. The Japanese landscapers also collaborated with the architects on the project and the in-house landscape architect supported and directed this project with the eminence of its owner.
The project with its unpretentious design by the perspective of modernity and sustainability brings on a sense of longing for a contemporary Mediterranean lifestyle. The sense of ostentation in the private space is significantly needed because it holds a common theme of repose, relaxation and rehabilitation in any given situation.

is a topic that has been heavily discussed in recent years. The development of these two technologies has been advancing at a rapid pace and has a significant impact on various industries. In this essay, we will explore the impact of artificial intelligence on technology and provide examples of its applications. Additionally, we will discuss the ethical considerations that arise from the use of artificial intelligence in technology.

Artificial intelligence (AI) is a branch of computer science that aims to create intelligent machines that can perform tasks that usually require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and language translation. Over the past few years, AI has been integrated into various technologies, including robots, smart home devices, virtual assistants, and self-driving cars.

One of the most significant impacts of AI on technology is the development of intelligent robots. These robots can perform tasks that are too dangerous, difficult, or boring for humans to do. For example, robots can be used in hazardous environments such as oil rigs, nuclear power plants, and space exploration to perform tasks that are too dangerous for humans. Additionally, robots can be used in healthcare to perform surgeries, diagnose diseases, and assist patients in rehabilitation.

Another impact of AI on technology is the development of smart home devices. These devices are designed to make our lives easier and more convenient. For example, smart thermostats can learn our habits and adjust the temperature accordingly. Smart home devices can also be integrated with voice assistants such as Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant, allowing us to control our home appliances with our voice.

Virtual assistants such as Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant are also examples of AI technologies that have had a significant impact on technology. These assistants can perform various tasks such as setting reminders, making phone calls, and playing music. Virtual assistants can also be integrated with smart home devices, allowing us to control our home appliances with our voice.

The use of artificial intelligence in technology has also raised ethical considerations. One of the main concerns is the potential loss of jobs due to automation. As AI technologies become more advanced, they may replace jobs that are currently performed by humans. Additionally, there are concerns about the privacy and security of our personal data when using AI technologies.

In conclusion, the relationship between artificial intelligence and technology is a complex and evolving field that has a significant impact on various industries. AI has led to the development of intelligent robots, smart home devices, and virtual assistants, and has the potential to revolutionize the way we live our lives. Here's my problem, how do you market a book? This is not a unique problem, on the one hand, publishers tell us it's almost impossible to market anything in a book in a way that will make any money back. It's just about getting it out there, and then trust the readers to find it on their own. That's certainly true, but it's incredibly demoralising for a writer not to see anything in the way of tangible benefits from their hard work.
I was talking to my sister a few days ago, who writes web copy and is also an author. She told me that she receives everything in the mail - reviews from libraries, longlisted and shortlisted book awards - with growing disappointment - "No, no, no, you didn't make it." I told her that I couldn't, "poor you". But really I'm jealous of her.
And the other problem I'm not really sure how to tackle - getting people to notice the book. The first, may be down to being too much of a perfectionist, but I think it's something that people at this time of year just don't want to engage with. How can you market a Christmas book?
But my sister's point still bothers me. You can win all these competitions or awards or whatever (my sister has won quite a few, she's quite good) but it doesn't really make much of a difference. So what can you really get out of all this effort? (By this, I mean the work of trying to get my book to as many people as possible, not the writing).
I have heard so many great arguments for writing books, and the best ones are the ones that make the writer feel that they are doing something great and worthwhile with their life. That's the wrong approach. I'd rather be rich, and nobody can argue that this book is going to make me rich.
So here are the things that I should do to make the book successful. First, I have to buy in advance copies from the publisher. Obviously, it would be great if I could get them at a discounted rate as it would save me from having to spend the cash and become debt ridden, but no. This is a serious business

are intriguing to anybody who takes photos, or has used a camera. To find success with photography you need to have an understanding of the tools at your disposal and knowledge of good photographic techniques. Taking good photographs requires the ability to combine these elements into a cohesive image. Use the following tips to take stunning photographs.
Get as close to your subject as you can. Getting as close to your subject as possible gives you more opportunities to highlight the main subject of the photo, and evade clutter. It lets you zero in on facial expressions, important details like flower arrangements, and other aspects that would otherwise be lost. By simply taking a small step back and framing a larger image, you can immediately get a more striking photograph.
Keep it simple. You should take scenes that are letting your creative side shine through. It is more beneficial to get a shot within the bounds of your hobby and expertise than to take hundreds out of focus pictures of a location.
Adjust the white balance on your camera manually when possible. Fluorescent lighting can cause a yellow hue, so use the appropriate settings when shooting under fluorescent light. You could include some artificial lighting that will not cause a horrible effect.

The Basics

Pre-requisites: understand Matlab, Java or Python.

Upon completion of this exercise, the participant should be able to:

• use Matlab (run a script, read/write a file)
• design circuits and simulate (develop or use a library)
• understand the simulation mechanics of SPICE
• define cells (static or dynamic)

Standard circuit simulation setup

Circuits are analysed in SPICE using a numerical method. This is rather different from looking at equations in a textbook or solving them by hand. In this sense SPICE is essentially an optical desk calculator.

Using SPICE one can create circuit simulations with a variety of cells (e.g. resistors, capacitors, inductors, diodes, transistors) and use a combination of these to set up a wide variety of analog and digital circuits (logic gates, combinatorial circuits, sequential circuits, and combinational circuits). In fact any circuit can be simulated provided a numerical solution is known.

In general a circuit can be represented as a set of node voltages (node voltages are the voltages at each node in a circuit). This representation allows us to do things like convert equations relating the node voltages to equations between currents (a voltage drop across an inductor represents a change in current that causes a displacement current, i.e. an inductance is then seen as a resistor and a capacitance as an inductance which is reversed if we transform from voltage to current in the same manner we transform from current to voltage). However we don’t yet have equations relating voltages to currents or capacitors to inductors – this is a problem we need to tackle and in many ways we need the solution in order to design circuits. We represent circuits using these node voltages until we can solve for the currents from equations relating the node voltages. Once we have the equations that can be solved for the currents, we can start to design circuits using these, which is the final solution to this problem. There are a number of ways of doing this, which we will explore here. These are

1. reducing the circuit to an equivalent circuit that does have node voltages in terms of currents.
2. defining the currents in terms of node voltages.
3. The point here is not to to understand all these equations (although these will be defined here) but to realise that there is a problem that we need to solve. Each of these methods tries to solve the problem in different ways and we need to find the best way to

Alaska Natives are involved in a federal settlement of claims by the state of Alaska and the U.S. for millions of dollars in payments for unharvested and over-harvested subsistence harvests of moose and caribou. Federal, state and village leaders began talks in the early 1990's after the passage of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The details of the settlement are worked out over several years. The actual money is set aside in a sovereign trust fund.
This month after years of negotiations the Republic of China begins sending aid to Alaska to fight forest fires in the state. Five million dollars will go to various state agencies for programs to improve fire fighting ability in the state. The money will provide for pilot courses, better radios and training in community college fire fighting programs.
Tide Mill Village is a community on a barge on the edge of Cook Inlet with plans to provide about 500 families with a high standard of living. Project leaders state that when the community is completed and settled, over 1,000 people will live there. Rents in Tide Mill Village will be based on wages earned by residents. According to architect Howard Snyder, Tide Mill Village will consist of several "links", each containing low density homes and community facilities.
The fight to save Alaska's commercial salmonery continued this spring with hearings to determine the extent of damage done to the fisheries by Japan's bans on salmon imports. Various Alaska environmental groups, the North Pacific Fisheries Management Council, the National Marine Fisheries Service, the Association of Salmon Commission Trollers and the last legitimate Japanese importer all testified that losses of $50,000,000 to $100,000,000 were incurred due to Japan's prohibition against salmon imports. The average price of Japanese fed salmon has been between $1.75 and $2.00 a pound while non-Japanese fed Alaska salmon prices range between $.48 and $.88 a pound.

practice and performance reveal the benefits of implementation of smart systems in sports. The practice of sports is vulnerable to injuries; it is influenced by the impacts of external environmental conditions, such as the athletic clothes’ attributes; the complex choreography of each exercise; and user interventions. We have designed and developed a Dance-In-Place prototype, which can evaluate dance practitioners and help them to anticipate technical mistakes, injuries and to promote healthier exercising habits. The Dance-In-Place, inspired by Digital Dance Companion, analyzes the activities of dance practitioners, tracks their dance movements and provides recommendations on training and performance. The prototype supports the internal training of sports practitioners by recording accurate and detailed biomechanical metrics. More importantly, the prototype automates the process of providing real time intelligent feedback, which can be used for injured or overly excited dancers. The Dance-In-Place can be used for assessing and improving the practice of sports, including such athletic activities as sprints and poles’ vault, dance practices such as ballet, figure skating, dance gymnastics, and such sport activities like trampoline gymnastics and walking in unicycle.

from its beginnings to current research techniques.
Neuroscience is the scientific study of the nervous system, including the brain and its function. It dates back to ancient Greek and Roman times, when philosophers and physicians began to investigate the workings of the brain and the nervous system.

In the 18th and 19th centuries, scholars began to study the brain through experiments and observations. Neurologists such as Jean-Martin Charcot, who treated patients with nerve disorders in France, and Santiago Ramón y Cajal, who made significant contributions to the understanding of the structure of neurons, helped to advance neuroscience.

The discovery of the electron microscope in the 1930s revolutionized neuroscience. It allowed researchers to see structures of cells and molecules that were previously invisible. This led to the identification of new molecules and cellular processes, as well as new insights into the function of the brain.

The mid-20th century saw the development of neuroimaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). These techniques enabled researchers to study brain activity in living humans, revealing important information about how different regions of the brain work together to control behavior and consciousness.

In recent years, there has been significant progress in the field of neuroscience. Researchers are using advanced technologies such as optogenetics, which uses light to activate specific neurons in the brain, and neural implants that can communicate directly with the brain, to study the relationship between neurons and behavior.

Overall, neuroscience has made significant strides in understanding the brain and its functions, and researchers continue to explore new areas of research and technology.

How is neuroscience currently being applied in the field of medicine? Can you give me some examples?
Yes, neuroscience is currently being applied in the field of medicine in numerous ways, and I will provide some examples:

1. Pain Management: Neuroscientists have discovered that the brain interprets pain as a complex sensory experience involving various neural pathways, including the release of various neurotransmitters and neuromodulators. Studying the brain's response to pain has led to the development of new drugs for pain management that target specific neural pathways.

2. Addiction: Neuroscience has led to a better understanding of addiction, including how the brain’s reward system is affected by substances such as alcohol, drugs, and food. This knowledge has helped develop new treatments for addiction, such as behavioral therapy and medication-based approaches.

3. Parkinson's Disease: The dopamine neurons in the brain that control movement are damaged

More and more people are excitedly following this new space race. This includes young, technologically-minded students, who have developed programs to help humans colonise Mars. Sure, we know about the challenges of landing on the Red Planet. The technology is still new. In fact, NASA’s Curiosity rover cost billions of pounds. But did you know that many discoveries from space missions have already benefited our lives on Earth? When satellites are used by telecoms companies, we benefit by having telephone calls and emails through the internet. Discoveries made by astronauts help us understand the effect on the planet itself, as well as human beings, of living in space for months at a time. Space agencies are now targeting mission planning to Mars, with a target date of 2030 for astronauts to finally land on the planet, following a journey which could take up to three years. It is still believed to take years of training, and many hours of exercise, before astronauts can leave Earth and make this final trip. So much money must be spent on making sure that the journey is safe. So, given all the high-tech equipment and training, why does it feel as if space exploration is a waste of money? Firstly, people feel that it shouldn’t be the planet’s main concern. Why shouldn’t we put as much effort and money into helping to solve the planet’s real, present problems, like the huge refugee problem caused by civil wars? It seems as though those people are more concerned about astronauts’ personal expenses in space. Astronauts who go to space are on very strict diets, and their food must be prepared and packaged in a very special way. For example, hot food could explode if it is exposed to low pressure. For the US space agency, NASA, by far the most expensive project is the upcoming journey to Mars. At the moment, NASA needs at least $17 billion every year, but even with that, NASA’s projects will run out of money by 2024. It is clear that the planet is heading for disaster. But maybe NASA’s ideas will help. At the moment, most of the power we use comes from burning fossil fuels. This not only pollutes the air we breathe, it also provides about 70% of the energy we use. This is a major problem, as these fossil fuels also cause more CO2 to be released into the atmosphere. As we have seen, the atmosphere plays a big role in the way that the Earth works. Natural vs Technology: Why Are We So Bad With Tech?
Sometimes, we’re just too much of a creature of habit. We always try to stick to what we’ve always known. When we see a ‘new’ (or unfamiliar) piece of technology, our instinct is to check it out and find out what it’s like, if it’s what it promises to be.
There is also this fear of the unknown. Not that there is anything to be scared of with technology, there is just that usual fear of the unknown that we get.
And that could lead us to taking things that have worked in the past for us and trying to fit everything else into that mold, even if it doesn’t work, especially if we fail to understand how and why it works.
Source: ThriveGlobal
There’s nothing inherently wrong about doing this, though. It’s just something we all need to get over. We have to recognize that these new things are different but the underlying principle remains the same.
They are just smaller pieces that together form the same thing. We just need to break them down into their simplest form, then take it from there. As long as we understand the basics, the details don’t matter.
Source: SimplePractice
Simply put, technologies are like natural systems, where everything works together like a watch.
There are things we don’t have control over, which make the work of the humans that make the technology up a bit more complicated. We can’t control things in natural systems, which is why we have to keep a close eye on them.
Just like natural systems, all pieces come together to form the same thing. If we’re not too careful, we end up breaking something in the process. Worse, these kinds of situations come with unpleasant surprises that could have been averted if we had taken a bit of time to stop and think things through.

In a workshop, we explored the ways that technology systems can act like a neural network—a naturally occurring structure that mimics the operation of the human brain. This photo shows examples of brain wiring and parallels with computers, networks, systems and databases.
The workshop, which I gave at the Neuromorphic Engineering Conference last September, explored aspects of the relationship between a technology and a human being, with particular reference to an emotional response to the technology. In this article, I will provide a general overview of the workshop and offer a few reflections. You can find a complete list of references for the talk here.
Neuromorphic engineering, in many ways, is the antithesis of Moore’s Law. Scientists and engineers are striving to create new technologies that are more than the sum of their parts, more than they are in nature. They build these new systems to replicate how the brain works, rather than to optimize computation. They are consciously trying to transcend the efficiency and efficacy that processors demonstrate in more traditional computer science.
Neuromorphic engineering is driven by the desire to discover fundamental principles of nature that we can use to build on. At the Neuromorphic Engineering Conference last year, I talked about one such problem—how to measure an emotional response of a person to a technology. There is plenty of evidence that a person has an emotional response to many things in their life. So, how can one describe and measure such an experience of emotion to make intelligent products that appeal to an emotional response in addition to rationality?
There are some broad differences between technology and people when it comes to emotion. When you use a computer, you really aren’t interacting with the entire processor at once. The processor probably has several hundred to a few thousand cells. In a typical nervous system of an animal of similar brain size, there are something like 100 billion cells. In a person, you really don’t have direct contact with most of their central nervous system. Even in the typical human nerve cell, you have most of the internal machinery, but you don’t see the machinery. For the first time in neuroscience, we have the ability to put a prosthetic sensor in the brain that really wraps around the trillions of connections of an animal’s nervous system. Such a system allows us to feel and sense subtle changes inside another brain, without changing the animal in a way that would affect it’s behavior. A sensor like this will inform me about a person

education in UK schools.
The first part of this workshop will be focussed on the development of students’ understanding of astronomy, and on addressing some of the big questions that underpin the subject, such as ‘What is the Universe made of?’. It will also identify barriers to students’ learning in this area. These will include issues such as how teachers get accurate information about the questions that are being explored in schools and colleges, but also difficulties they experience in using this information effectively with their students.
The second part of the workshop will focus on some of the activities that teachers can use with students to address these issues and provide an enjoyable, memorable and educational experience. These are based on long-standing research and the evidence it provides. But they also include a range of pedagogic techniques, including inquiry- and enquiry-based learning, as well as the latest thinking about how best to develop students’ collaborative problem solving skills. They can be used in conjunction with any astronomy course, at any level, as well as with science students who are interested in pursuing careers in the space sector.
Dr Paul Harrison is a researcher and teacher with a particular interest in the development of students’ understanding of astronomy. He has been extensively involved in curriculum development and teacher education, including being the lead developer of the A Level astronomy course for the Open University, and an author of the Secondary Physics Department’s manuals for resources and lesson planning for A Level astronomy and GCSE science. He has supervised several undergraduate, Masters and PhD students researching different aspects of astronomy education, and is Director of Studies of the MSc course in Science Education within the Faculty of Science and Engineering at Oxford Brookes University.
Dr Harrison is a former Senior Teaching Fellow at the Open University where he worked on the Open Learn astronomy project, managing a team of authors and researchers responsible for developing online open educational resources for use in schools. He developed a learning resources web site for both university and state secondary schools (https://www.astro-school.net.uk), which was commissioned and widely used by national and international groups as a resource for use in professional development. This won the Times Higher Education Supplement award for Most Innovative Course and was recognised as one of the first 15 examples of Innovation in Teaching and Learning globally by the American Council on Education in 2010.
He has served as Vice Chair (2013-14) and Chair (2014-15) of the UK AAPT network, and was a member of the UK project team tasked with advising the Scottish Government on how

Is it present, or is it absent in a given moment? At the same time, is it the subject of power, a site of governance, or of opposition? In this colloquium, we will examine the cultural politics of literature, with an emphasis on its comparative, transnational, and diasporic dimensions. Our discussion will move through a range of topics and figures, including social realism, mass culture, alternative histories, and censorship. In each case, we will aim to demonstrate and explore the possibilities for theory-building that emerge through a distinctly transnational or diasporic perspective.
This workshop will take a comparative approach to approaches to nationhood and ethnicity, and the relationship between the two. How do new institutions and discourses legitimize new forms of nationalism? What narratives of the past are used to justify nationalist claims? Are all forms of nationalism identical, or are some nationalisms more exclusionary or self-consciously national? Are nation-states truly homogeneous? We will cover topics such as new institutions, such as ethnic cleansing as ethnic nationalism and the role of women in and by the state, distinctions between diaspora, diasporic nationhood, and secession, and comparisons of culture versus ethnicity, so as to understand the afterlife of a nation after a given ethnic boundary has been drawn. From Kenneth Waltz and Samuel Huntington to Charles Tilly, and from Mark Weitzman and Stuart Hall to Anthony Smith, we will consider how different models of nationalism have been used, challenged, and debated. Additionally, from Said Arjomand, Abu-Lughod, Anderson and Winichakul, we will consider discourses and attempts at nationalism that have been deployed at various sites of contestation.
The goal of this course is to discuss the recent debates in the study of Latin American history and society. In recent decades, Latin American history has undergone a number of important transformations. We will place these transformations in the context of the cultural history of the discipline, but our main focus will be on the scholarship produced by scholars working in the area. Particular emphasis will be placed on comparative questions, often within the scope of the Latin American region but sometimes against other global regions. Throughout the course, we will explore a number of problems and methodological issues. Some will center on more traditional questions, but others will focus on more recent methodological debates.
Contemporary Buddhism has become a global phenomenon. This course will examine contemporary understandings of Buddhism from three different conceptual angles. First, we will address the question of what makes one Buddhist in difference

with unique ingredients, such as insects or unconventional combinations, and how it affects your taste buds. Use descriptive language to convey the flavors and textures of each ingredient, and consider incorporating sensory details such as smell and texture to enhance the reader's experience. Perhaps your character learns about a new ingredient culture or tradition and attempts to replicate a dish or cooking method using uncommon ingredients. Describe the challenges they face and how they overcome them, or perhaps the joys of discovering a new ingredient or technique that changes their entire perspective on cooking. Ultimately, showcase the power of food to transcend cultural barriers and broaden one's horizons. Growing up in a small village in the mountains, I had never really encountered any exotic ingredients. So, when I moved to the city and was offered a job as a chef, I was shocked to see my first shipment of insects. Butterflies, ants, and beetles were among the items I had to cook with. At first, I was hesitant, but I soon realized that these small creatures had a unique taste and aroma. Working with them was a challenge, but I was determined to find a way to cook them to my taste.

One day, I decided to create a dish using these insects, and I called it “the Dancing Queen”. The dish was a mix of roasted ants, beetles, and beetles’ larvae, seasoned with herbs and spices. The butterflies’ wings added a delicate crunch to the dish. To complement the sweetness of the insects, I added some bitter greens, like chicory, to the mix. The fragrance of the dish was incredible: it was both floral and earthy, with a hint of spice. It was a challenge to balance the flavors, but I felt like it was worth it.

The next time I cooked with insects, I tried a different dish, a spaghetti with “the midnight cook’s” legs. The “midnight cook” is a kind of large spider, and the dish was a warm mix of lentils, spices, and “midnight cook” legs. The taste was quite remarkable: a unique combination of earthy and spicy flavors that blend in perfectly. The texture of the dish was also quite interesting: the “midnight cook” legs were crunchy, yet the flavor was smooth and delicate.

At first, I was hesitant to cook with these strange and unfamiliar ingredients. But, the more I worked with them, the more I realized how much they had to offer. It was like a whole new world had opened up before me, and I was excited to explore it

is a term used to describe the moral and ethical questions that are raised by outer space exploration and technology. 

Question: "space ethics"
Space ethics is the moral and ethical questions that arise from space exploration and technology[1][4]. It is about whether space should be treated as a commons and a right for everyone or reserved for the already wealthy and powerful[3]. It seeks to answer questions about how much humans are entitled to take from the universe[4], and is a broad field with many possible angles of study[4]. The Principle of Indifference is one aspect of this study, which states that when populations of space aliens have an equal chance to exist, you should treat all of them equally[5].

conservation, including landmark events and notable conservationists.

1. Prehistoric Times: 
Human interaction with wildlife dates back to prehistoric times when humans lived in harmony with nature. People have used animals for food, clothing, and shelter since ancient times.

2. Medieval Times: 
During this period, people relied heavily on hunting and trapping for their survival. Wildlife conservation was largely unorganized, and many species suffered greatly from overhunting and habitat destruction.

3. Renaissance: 
During the Renaissance period, Europeans began to explore and colonize new lands, and this led to an increase in wildlife exploitation and habitat destruction. Many species were hunted to near-extinction, and some species, such as the Bengal tiger, became near-extinct.

4. Industrial Revolution: 
The Industrial Revolution led to widespread urbanization and industrialization, which significantly altered ecosystems. Many people began to view wildlife as a commodity, leading to widespread hunting and poaching.

5. 20th Century: 
The 20th century witnessed significant developments in wildlife conservation. In 1900, President Theodore Roosevelt became the first President to speak out for conservation, setting in motion a series of national parks and monuments. In 1939, the National Wildlife Refuge System was established to protect important wildlife habitats.

6. 21st Century: 
The 21st century has seen a renewed focus on wildlife conservation. Many conservationists have focused on reducing the impact of human activities on wildlife and their habitats, including climate change, habitat loss, and pollution.

Notable conservationists:
1. John Muir: A Scottish-American naturalist, conservationist, and author, known for his advocacy for preserving wilderness areas.

2. Aldo Leopold: An American ecologist and environmentalist who pioneered the concept of ecological restoration.

3. Rachel Carson: A marine biologist and conservationist who popularized the idea of environmentalism with her book "Silent Spring."

4. Jane Goodall: A British primatologist who is best known for her work with chimpanzees in Tanzania.

5. Dian Fossey: An American primatologist who was famous for her conservation efforts in Rwanda.

6. Wangari Maathai: A Kenyan environmental activist who founded the Green Belt Movement, which planted millions of trees to fight deforestation and soil erosion.

7. Steve Irwin: An Australian conservationist who dedicated his life to conservation efforts for endangered species and the protection of their habitats.

8. Sylvia Earle: An American

, focusing on mechanics — with a little wave mechanics, too.
To get you up to speed on quantum mechanics, we're going to start with a little wave mechanics, which will help to clarify why we need quantum mechanics, and why it has the strange features it has.
The idea of a wave-mechanical model for matter is very old. The Greek philosopher Democritus (460 BCE–370 BCE) believed that "atoms" had zero size, that the substance of the universe was composed of atoms, and that the laws governing the atoms were those of pure geometry. The atoms were coherent light with slightly varying wavelengths and frequencies. The world consisted of expanding and contracting harmonics, invisible phenomena with inner structure, and those phenomena governed by an inner clock. Democritus' idea was that the diameter of a tiny piece of material, like a grain of sand, would be infinite, like the diameter of the universe. A photon, like a wave, vibrated at the atomic level, moving from one atom to another atom, in a cloud of atoms. Light passed through each atom.
Democritus' idea was like that of Newton and Darwin. For a long time, it seemed like a good enough idea. We knew a lot of things, but we didn't know how to describe them. So we had an idea, but didn't know why the idea was wrong. What did we know? We knew some things:
Sometimes, even if you don't have enough photons to create an atomic wave, the atoms are in a non-local, classical wave state. When we know their position, we can use classical geometric methods to figure out what they are doing. (E.g. superconducting wave fields, where the atoms are in a quantum state, and the electrons in a superconducting ring can use this to do quantum bits of information.)
We know that when light waves and charged particles interact, they behave in a way that is similar to classical optics and classical electromagnetism. But this is just coincidence: light and charged particles in a vacuum are both governed by the same laws (although we can think of them as being different kinds of things). In a vacuum, you can do classical physics and still get the right answer, but it's not perfect. So you can't take a beam of charged particles, and assume that it is going to behave like a beam of light, because it won't behave like it. include empirical studies in pedagogy, literary studies, cultural studies, sociology, psychology, and critical theory. These use quantitative, qualitative, or mixed methods.
This article uses the philosophy of language in general and semantic analysis of literature in particular to propose a new approach to literary theory through which we can consider the difference between "fiction" and "humor" in literary writing. This article analyzes the two writing genres through both deductive and inductive approaches. One the one hand, it presents a sample of representative humorous writing. On the other hand, it applies linguistic and stylistic techniques to determine different differences in general and humorous linguistic structures. Through the deductive and inductive procedures, it is shown that there is a significant difference between fiction and humor, and therefore we can conclude that humor is a specific category in the realm of literature that has its own semantic structure. Through the approaches of this analysis, we show that the Humor of Literature can have a dialectical feature, showing an independence of itself from the concept of fiction. In other words, we use this analysis to construct a new approach, based on the philosophy of language and literary semantics, in which we can distinguish between fiction and humor with respect to their own structures and features, showing the validity of the Humor of Literature in terms of considering its own structure independent of fiction.

He critiques the shared notions of censorship and commercial culture that interfere with the creation of an independent, authentic relationship between visual imagery and sound. This essay culminates with a brief conversation with Xun and director/producer Terry Gilliam.
