cloud computing security vulnerabilities are nearly as well known as the fictional parallel universe of Narnia itself (see What Secrets Do You Think Are in the Cloud?). Yet, if these myths are used as a reasonable excuse to hold off on cloud adoption, that’s nothing short of calamitous.
So, let’s take the wind out of these sails with a quick rundown of some of the wrongheaded concerns and provide a concise guide to understanding and incorporating cloud data security in your business needs.
Cloud security myths are all-too-commonly bandied about, shrouding business cloud computing in unsavory murk.
A 2015 Ponemon Study on data security found that 41 percent of respondents identified security as their greatest obstacle to cloud adoption.
This might surprise you, but it’s been conclusively shown that data encryption is nearly 100 percent effective at protecting your data in the cloud from hackers and even employees at the companies that store your data. You should use the highest form of encryption to protect your data from being intercepted when traveling from on-premise systems to the cloud. No doubt, this single measure will be your security assurance.
When all else fails, you should be relying on your IT service providers. Your on-site firewall is nowhere near as comprehensive as the cloud’s universal gateway (which is peer-reviewed and constantly updated with the latest information on potential threats). Through a dynamic network of security information and analytics, the cloud infrastructure company has access to information that only the cloud itself can provide, and it extends protection throughout your entire company’s network, not just where you are using cloud-based services.
With the cloud, your data, applications, or other software programs never actually leave the data center. They are always just a hop, skip, and a jump away from your on-premises systems, so you don’t have to worry about migration issues, compatibility issues, or any other potential roadblocks to productivity.
It’s a common misconception that your data and applications are left unguarded in the cloud. The fact is, your business data and applications are secure when they are stored in the cloud. Your cloud provider, like Pomerol Networks, has experts and security staff dedicated to monitoring and protecting your data and applications 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
Suffice it to say, hackers and other data thieves and vandals are always staying up to speed on the latest exploits to target cloud infrastructures. To keep your data secure, you have to stay on top of the risks, too.

textbooks have not kept up with the changes in how we learn. Because textbooks were traditionally bulky and expensive, and taught a static, memory-based approach, researchers have favored what is sometimes called "disruptive" technology - not only does it try to completely replace what's already in use, but it does it with something different and new.
Note: As with any classroom environment, anyone using technology in the classroom must be trained as a teacher and educational researcher. There are a number of textbooks which fit this definition, in fact, such as this series.
Scaffolded learning and problem-based learning are new ways of developing understanding, based on practical experience. And there is active research into new ways of learning, ranging from those described above, to using online software, to using the world wide web as a giant textbook.
Diasporan tradition, as usual, is fairly good. Textbooks tend to focus on practical aspects of math rather than abstract ideas. A popular math book, and required reading for many students, is Hardy and Wright's A Course of Pure Mathematics , and there's a new edition of that text.
In university, in Hong Kong math textbooks are typically written by experts in their fields and read by students who are doing purely mathematical work. Furthermore, part of the reading is often designed for students who are serious about further study and will likely write the exams. This tends to require a higher standard than may be appropriate for typical classroom use.
This is an old book, written in 1978, but it's still one of the best texts on the subject. Math textbooks in Hong Kong typically do not approach the subject this way.
A few calculus books have tried to write using this approach, but they haven't found it to be quite as effective. Unfortunately, the authors of this book don't seem to be aware of the fact that it's a much better way to explain calculus than in the traditional style. It's possible that Hong Kong math textbooks have not yet adopted this approach because they don't need to - if the syllabus they follow has changed in some way, then perhaps a new math text can be written to take advantage of the change.
Also, because Hong Kong high school math students haven't been taught much in the way of graphing calculators before university, this new technology doesn't present the same kind of fundamental challenge as it does in other countries.

Our open meeting and guided tour was led by John Nield, who started training with Jon Marston at Sandal Magna in 2004. He became a professional gardener after leaving school and working with Jack Holliday in Thorner before deciding to return to the UK and work with Jon. He still works for the company and has become one of the most respected gardeners in the business. Jon has a no-nonsense approach to gardening and John was an ideal person to take to Harewood House to survey the gardens with such an interest in learning the workings of an established garden.
Harewood House is a setting of contrasts and changes. The listed house was built from 1759-1771 by Edward Lascelles, brother of the 4th Earl of Harewood, but abandoned because of a forced severance from the property in 1836 by the 6th Earl. The family had put the house on the market but this sale was subsequently withdrawn as a result of a legal dispute with the Crown. A delay in the Court's ruling in the issue meant that the 6th Earl was able to live in the house until it was sold to Harewood House Trust in 1968 and opened to the public in 1975.
The garden had been neglected and vandalised when the house was abandoned. Much of the estate was transferred to the Marquis of Normanby after 1836. A design for the garden was submitted by James Pulham, recommended by Charles Brandon in 1840 and a plan of ‘small improvements’ created by Philip Prittie was implemented in 1843.
After the new Lord Harewood, Algernon Lascelles, inherited the family estate in 1920, he accepted the conditions set out by his uncle the 5th Earl, including the building of a golf course, the creation of an estate for horses and stabling, shops and a school. This was executed by his architect boss Geoffrey Jellicoe. Jellicoe’s intention was to create a real estate for all of the family’s needs in one place, the aim being to entertain visitors on the estate but also to portray a domestic lifestyle with which Harewood House visitors could identify, without having to leave the estate.
Harewood House's patroness, Mary, the Countess of Harewood (1909 - 1974)

As the sun rose over the mountains, it illuminated the towering cliffs that stood tall against the sky. On the edge of the cliff, a group of geologists gathered around a boulder that had come loose from the cliff face.

"Look at that!" exclaimed one of the geologists, pointing to a small piece of rock that had broken off from the boulder.

The others gathered around to take a closer look. It was a piece of quartz, one of the most common minerals on Earth. But there was something unusual about it. When they held it up to the light, it glowed with a soft, blue-green energy that pulsed with every breath of wind.

"What is that?" one of the geologists asked, holding the rock up to the sky.

"I think it's the energy that comes from the interaction between different rocks and minerals," another geologist replied. "It's a unique energy source that we haven't really explored yet."

The group of geologists spent the next few days studying the glowing rock, experimenting with different ways to harness its energy. They built a small device that would draw the energy from the rock and convert it into electricity, and they tested it out with great success.

As they continued to study the glowing rock and other sources of geothermal energy, the geologists realized that they were on the brink of a new era of clean, renewable energy. By harnessing the energy that comes from the interactions between rocks and minerals, they could create a powerful source of electricity that would be clean, sustainable, and affordable for everyone.

Over the next few years, the geologists worked tirelessly to develop new technologies and techniques for harnessing geothermal energy. They built power plants that would tap into the natural energy that lies deep within the Earth, and they worked to spread the word about the benefits of this new source of energy.

Slowly but surely, geothermal energy became a major part of the world's energy landscape. And as people looked to the future, they knew that this unique energy source would play a key role in shaping the world's energy future.

and its role in shaping biology. Genetics is the study of how genes affect organisms and their traits. It began in the early 19th century with Gregor Mendel's discovery of genetics and the laws of inheritance. In the early 20th century, experiments by Thomas Hunt Morgan established the concept of Mendelian inheritance. However, it was not until the discovery of DNA as the genetic material in the 1950s that genetics became a central focus of biology.

With the advent of molecular biology and biotechnology in the latter half of the 20th century, genetics has played a pivotal role in shaping biology. Genes have been identified as the underlying cause of many diseases, leading to advances in gene therapy and personalized medicine. Advances in genetics have also led to the development of more precise diagnostic tools, as well as new forms of biotechnology, such as genetic engineering and recombinant DNA technology.

Genetics has also had a profound impact on the understanding of evolution. With the identification of specific genetic mutations that lead to traits such as coloration, morphology, and behavior, genetics has allowed scientists to better understand how evolution works. It has also provided insights into the mechanisms of adaptation and the evolution of complex organisms.

In summary, genetics has played a pivotal role in shaping biology, from identifying the genetic basis of traits and diseases, to advancing biotechnology and advancing our understanding of evolution. Its continued development will have a profound impact on our understanding of the natural world and our ability to treat and prevent genetic disorders.

That was fascinating! Can you tell me more about how genetics has influenced the field of medicine? Of course! Genetics has had a significant impact on the field of medicine, leading to new breakthroughs in diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of many genetic and non-genetic diseases. Here are some specific examples:

1. Personalized Medicine - With the advent of genomic medicine, doctors can now tailor treatments and therapies to a patient’s specific genetic makeup. For example, some diseases or conditions may have a genetic component, and doctors can test for specific mutations in a patient’s DNA to determine the best course of action.

2. Development of New Therapies - Genes that cause genetic diseases can be targeted to develop new therapies. For example, gene therapy uses a virus to deliver a healthy copy of a defective gene to a patient, effectively replacing the faulty version.

3. New Diagnoses - As scientists identify new genetic mutations, new diagnoses for previously unknown diseases can be made. For example, in 20

Dr. Richard Thorn (Gerstein Centre for Digital Scholarship, University of Toronto) will present a workshop on advanced techniques in wildlife conservation research.
Click here to access the workshop in the following online environment: by August 15.
To contribute to this website, or to access previous workshop material, contact us at wsrp@gmail.com.
—
Date: Monday, June 29, 2020
Time: 2:00 pm EDT (Eastern Daylight Time: UTC-4)
Cost: Free
Access: The workshop will be delivered by ZOOM video conference. The workshop link will be shared with registered participants by email, or you can register below and we will send you the link.
—
This workshop will focus on powerful web-based methods, including linear and nonlinear time series analysis, maps and spatial statistics, spatial autocorrelation and network analysis, and statistics on raster data layers. The objective is to familiarize researchers with approaches that are widely used in ecology, and are also essential for learning important material in second year course MGLG 120H1, 120H6 at the University of Toronto.
What are some tips you can do to get into advanced ecology research? How can you choose which technique is most suitable for your data?
This workshop will introduce some key elements of advanced ecology research, which are common to a large number of techniques, and the role of statistical expertise in setting research objectives and interpreting results.
If you are a researcher from the Greater Toronto Area, do not hesitate to register to attend!
—
About the instructor
Richard Thorn is a Dr. of Population Ecology and Conservation Biology at the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. He has used zoonotic disease models for understanding human health and ecology at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, as well as wildlife conservation ecology applications for, among others, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the Biomathematics and Ecology Research Center at the University of California Berkeley, the University of Sydney, and McGill University.
He has taught a range of ecology courses in the post-secondary education system, including a 10-week summer course in Spatial Analysis for Environmental Conservation Biology at the University of Toronto, and a workshop in advanced conservation ecology methods for the Wildlife Conservation Society. He has also developed a novel Virtual Environment that will be used for this workshop.

, genres, and identities, the Rutgers University Department of English is one of the premier departments in the country for English Studies. Explore the field of English Studies.
Training in an engaged, scholarly environment in our Department prepares students for a world where literature and culture are in a state of intense connection. Now more than ever, what we say about our world through literature can either amplify or subvert what our world is saying about us. Join our courses, lectures, and annual interdisciplinary conferences that situate literature as a central site of discourse and knowledge production.
Since the English program is known for its flexible and student-centered structure, you can design a plan of study that targets your own interests. You'll have the chance to work closely with faculty members and fellow students as you craft a coursework plan and a thesis project. Our students speak to how such individualized experiences prepare them for a career in a variety of fields, including law, business, journalism, and education.
We're also dedicated to thinking big while sticking to a range of core course work in British and American literature. These courses, grounded in innovative scholarship, bring up challenging questions that require you to dig deep. And they push you to take the one-degree course required for all Rutgers students: Interdisciplinary Humanities and Social Sciences (IHSS 240: Literature and the Human Condition).
Over the course of their studies, students have many opportunities to complete their own work outside the classroom. For example, the Hastings Center, a bioethics research institute that brings a medical, legal, ethical and societal perspective to pressing issues in the biomedical sciences, recruits several English students as interns.
Join us for weekly activities — from film screenings, book clubs, readings, lectures, workshops, and discussion events that bring a multidisciplinary range of scholars and creative writers and researchers to campus. Check out our calendar for upcoming events.
You'll have many chances to get involved in extracurricular activities. Activities might include joining an advanced writing group, participating in an advanced research seminar, or working with a faculty member on a research project. You might also gain practical experience by serving as an administrative assistant in the department.
English students always move to the top of the academic job lines. Many of our graduates have become associate and full professors at major universities such as Rutgers, Amherst, Duke, and the University of Pennsylvania.

an egg are definitely on the KISS theory, but when it comes to how to show off your culinary skills, some techniques go a bit further than scrambling the egg.
1. KNOW YOU HAVE GOOD EGGS Before you start making your scrambled eggs, it is important to know you have good eggs. Just like everything else, this varies from year to year and place to place. So how do you know? You could buy eggs with a “best by date” on the carton but that is only the freshest date the eggs will be good on. An easy and reliable way to make sure the eggs you’re using are fresh is to use the “chick test”. To do this all you need to do is find an egg with a spot in the shell – any spot will do – and poke your index finger through to the air chamber that is located underneath. What do you know, it will turn egg white is it is good (hasn’t been sitting in a cooler over an extended period of time – which is why you find them with a “best by” date rather than a sell by date on most egg cartons). If it looks like the egg white had already spilled out, or has large cracks, or is really pale yellow in colour – in other words, not having its usual vibrancy – don’t buy them. That is a sure sign that they are older and will no longer be fresh.
2. USE A RUBBER SPATULA/SPATULA FOR THE PURPOSE Whether you are cooking with an electric or stovetop stove top, you are best to use a rubber spatula or wooden spatula to whisk the eggs. Anything else is either too awkward or will scrape the bottom and sides of the pan too much, destroying the consistency of the eggs. Want to impress? Get a high-end version of this spatula.
3. KNOW WHEN A PREMIUM BUTTER SHOULD BE USED Unless you have access to pureed butter which you will be able to melt to make up a special filling or sauce or something, always use regular butter. The premium butters may have been churned more often to produce the extended shelf life (and cost) but they are not necessary and will just make your scrambled eggs greasy. It is also important to note, the regular butter, with the salt in it, provides some salt in your scrambled eggs.
4. DON’T OVERHEAT THE PAN If you know your stovetop is good and if you are using a nonstick pan, your

neuroscience has a lot of potential and has a huge impact on several fields such as behavioral studies, medical research, cognitive science, psychology, cognitive psychology, cognitive science, brain science, and biology. For example:

* Neuroimaging, fMRI, and EEG technologies allow us to see what is happening inside the brain at different stages of development.

* Drug research has been able to identify and test a whole range of mental health problems and thus provided new insights into their causes and potential treatments.

* Techniques like cognitive testing, EEG, and fMRI are used to detect problems in brain development and help diagnose conditions, such as autism or dyslexia.

* Brain mapping techniques are also used to understand the connections between different brain parts and are used to predict how an individual will respond to a specific treatment or cure.

* Neuroscience can provide a deep understanding of mental health conditions and their associated symptoms.

These are just some of the many potential benefits of neuroscience, and there are still many areas where the study of the brain is in its early stages. Neuroscience has the potential to be a powerful tool to explore the human brain and understand its workings better and eventually develop methods to cure and prevent brain disorders, and to provide guidance for treatment.

Meteorologists are expected to be able to predict a variety of weather phenomena, including temperature, rainfall, snowfall, wind speed and cloud cover, among others.
But meteorological predictions can be more than just guesses at what the weather will be like tomorrow, said Ramon Redondo, a meteorological scientist at the National Weather Service office in Seattle.
It's also important to know how much precipitation and cloud levels will be, Redondos says.
"If you're just trying to predict the weather, you're not going to know very much about it," Redondos told The Seattle Times.
The National Weather Service says that about 70 percent of precipitation falls during the winter, with the rest falling in spring and summer.
The rest, or about 15 percent, falls in the fall.
The NWS says that in the past decade, there's been an increase in the amount of precipitation and increased winter rainfall in the United States.
During the winter months, the amount per year of precipitation in the United Nations report on global warming is around 20 inches (50 centimeters).
The UN report also says that the amount has increased by about 20 percent in the decade prior to 2012.
This increase has been driven by warmer weather in the Arctic and increased snowfall in parts of the United State, according to the UN report.
The UN also says the amount fell in the last two years.
In the summer months, the number of days with more precipitation per year has been around 10, the report says.
There are two types of precipitation, or precipitation in the air, that meteorologists measure.
"Clouds are the most commonly measured precipitation, but they are not the most reliable measurement because they don't tell you what the air is doing," Redon said.
Clouds can be measured using a ground-based instrument called a wind gauge.
But, Redonda said, it's important to be aware of what the wind is doing when trying to predict what the air will do.
For example, if you're looking at the wind in the Pacific Northwest, the ground-based wind gauge can tell you if it's moving from the west to the east, or if it is going from the northeast to the southwest.
That's because winds from the east tend to be stronger, he said, while winds from southwest tend to blow in the opposite direction.
"In the Pacific Northwest, the sun is shining bright, so you're not going out to play with your kids in the sun," Redone said

have produced an explosion in the discovery of new catalysts. Many of these catalysts are based on transition metals, meaning they have one of six transition metals in their chemistry: the plus three (III) and plus four (IV) oxidation states. These ions can be considered Lewis acids because they are electron deficient and act as Lewis bases towards Lewis acids.

Electron deficiency and partial charge in a Lewis acid + base complex. This image was created by the Wikimedia community.

To visualize these interactions, a Lewis acid-base complex can be formed, where the Lewis acid is capable of accepting electron density and the Lewis base is capable of donating electron density. Catalysts are typically molecules that accept electron density, meaning they accept an electron from another molecule or ion. The process can happen several different ways. One of the most basic processes is called coupling. In the chemical compound the electrons from the electron accepting molecule will accept electrons from an electron donating molecule. This results in a new compound with different bond properties but is still acceptable to the original transition metal catalyst. Using this bond-electron theory, we can understand one of the major challenges to designing catalysts: namely, designing transition metals that can make a bond to a molecule that either: does not accept electrons, or can only accept electrons by using double or triple bonds. More specifically, oxygen and nitrogen molecules cannot readily form bonds with transition metals because these compounds accept electrons through single bonds. However, there are many less electronegative elements that can act as electron donors to oxygen and nitrogen.

Oxygen has a partial negative charge and nitrogen is partially positive, whereas carbon only has a partial negative charge.

The simplest method of using these electron donor compounds is to bond the molecule with a transition metal such that electrons from the donor are being used to form a new bond to another molecule or ion. This chemical reaction then becomes energetically favorable for the free energy to become more negative. To make this bond possible, it needs to be energetically favorable for the donor compound to accept electron density from the molecule. This molecule, in turn, must lose electron density to the catalyst which results in the initial reactants being used up and replaced by the products, as well as the chemical reaction having a lower activation energy.

The best way to do this is to use a transition metal. Transition metals such as iron, copper, and zinc have, in general, no problem accepting electrons through single bonds from molecules like oxygen or nitrogen. going to be driven by technology. With Donald Trump’s surprise win against Hillary Clinton in the U.S. presidential election, a topic of conversation amongst the public has been on the rising power of “fake news”.
Social media websites have been accused of influencing the outcome of the election, which many claim is due to the ease with which false information is posted and shared on social networks.
And this, in turn, has raised concerns about how social media can be used by bad actors to disrupt or manipulate elections around the world.
A new study, from New York University, has examined how social media can be used by political actors to change the information landscape. Their findings suggest that political players will increasingly influence what, and when, people hear about elections.
Landscape Model
Their landscape model explains how political actors affect other actors in the “digital gameboard” – a diverse, interconnected group with diverse motivations.
In their study, they found a “K-shaped” influence structure with two layers: the top layer, with more “power”, is made up of big influencers (influential social media users such as political candidates), and the bottom layer, with more “reach”, is made up of smaller social media users (users with fewer followers than the big influencers).
“We define the key top-layer actors as those who are powerful enough to influence the knowledge of the full landscape. These are typically the most visible and highest-profile actors – influential politicians, popular journalists and celebrities,” explained Jenny Reeves, NYU PhD in media, culture and communications and lead author of the report, in a statement.
“The bottom layer actors, then, are those who have more reach than the top actors. These individuals can often be considered micro-influencers – celebrities or political leaders’ fans with huge online followings, but not always in the traditional sense of the media.”
The study, which used algorithms to identify the most likely influencers from millions of candidates who may influence the discourse surrounding elections, found that elite-level social media users were as influential, if not more so, than the traditional media in the U.S. presidential election. The majority of influence was driven by individuals with 25,000 to 250,000 followers.
This fits with political science theory, which states that public opinion is a function of elites in politics, cultural elite and mass media.

has a special twofoldness; in our social lives as individuals and as classes; and in our social lives as modern citizens, as members of a contemporary state. As technology focuses on increasing efficiency, it often has less obvious effects on the quality of our lives. Because of its freedom from emotional connections, market forces can make us willing participants in choices we might find unacceptable.
No political party or presidential candidate can honestly claim that they are attempting to reverse or stop advances in technology. Most strongly liberal parties accept technology as an inevitable part of society. They favor advances in science and technology as a necessary requirement of liberty. Their assumption is that technological advancement is the means to a better world; this is almost never argued. The limitations of technology are not discussed. The revolutionary dimension of technological innovation has a lot in common with politics: both are dangerous! Technology can be a tool of the powers-that-be, which no one can escape; in politics, it is a tool of democracy and the promise of freedom. In the rhetoric of their supporters, it seems as though a fast computer can become a defender of democracy and justice. The quick harnessing of technology to a democratic purpose gives it importance it does not otherwise deserve.
Technology, however, is a tool, not a state of affairs or a goal. Among the uses of technology, however, are the uses that are inimical to democratic values and to freedom. In the arms race, in surveillance, in business competition, in consumerism, technology creates both problems and solutions. Among these technologies are the television, the fax machine, mail-order catalogs, the spy plane, computer systems, satellite photography and the Internet. These constitute a kind of technology monopoly, produced and controlled by large corporations and special interests. As liberal individuals it is often difficult to protect ourselves against the social influences these technologies present to us.
Any attempt to turn this large assortment of programs back to their own initial function is held in abeyance by “common sense.” The reason is, of course, that those who were seeking information for their own national interests have no knowledge or reasons to want to look at their own technology that produces and controls technology. They do not have a “common interest” in looking. They do not acknowledge the nature of that popular control, in keeping it from being exploited, and from concentrating into the hands of the few. They will not grant an audience to those who will seek protection for individuals against the abuses of technologies, especially technologies of surveillance.

to the Church
Why the Church can’t afford to ignore the workplace
Next week 46,000 church leaders will travel to Salt Lake City, Utah, to attend the biennial meetings of the World Congress of the International Confederation of Christian Churches, a confederation comprising 345 million members in more than 100 countries.
What they’ll be hearing about will have a strong business and entrepreneurial orientation. Up to 15 percent of the world’s population now live as entrepreneurs and small business owners. Christianity has long been influential in business history, and numbers among the “big four” religions of the world (Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, and Buddhism) whose followers are major contributors in the international commerce, industry, and management. These trends show no sign of abating.
In recent decades the Church has increasingly recruited business professionals into ministries of care and compassion around the world: among them are doctors, lawyers, teachers, engineers, broadcasters, and other experts and administrators. Further increasing the significance of professional business people within the Church, some people with Ph.D.’s and postdoctoral research qualifications are discovering their true callings as pastors, educators, mission leaders, and evangelists in local congregations.
Why do we need to make business more relevant in the Church? Growing numbers of business professionals are presenting the same call: God wants to restore the marketplaces as we understand them to Christian stewardship. The Church, they argue, has missed a golden opportunity by not taking on a greater role in the Church’s mission. The sooner the Church changes the better.
Taking the long view, business is a subculture.
Business is not part of the Church, but it’s a culture that is embedded within. It has its own values, language, and manners. Yet many of its values and practices conflict with Christian tenets. There has never been a better time for the Church to restore its credibility with the business world. Jesus shone a light on this world and spoke the truth about the market economy that has changed everything. He was correct in his critique, and his lifestyle—a self-sacrificing lifestyle of creating value to support others—changed the world. For the Church, businesses are a challenging but vital arm to mobilize to the mission. “The kingdom of God is like a merchant searching for fine pearls.” (Matthew 13:45) As disciples of Jesus Christ we must interpret and manage business with the Word of God, not with the Word of the world.

We are up to our eyeballs in work and mommyhood lately and as a result we are doing a whole lot of takeout. I feel like when my life isn’t totally crazy, I can keep up with cooking and what I pack the girls in their lunch boxes, but there are days when all I have the time or energy to do is pop something in the microwave. As a mother, I know it’s my job to pack healthy lunches for them, but I often question if it’s healthy for me to have to pack their lunches! It’s such a balance! On the one hand, I want my kids to make the best food choices possible. On the other hand, I hate to sacrifice my own food choices, especially when we are so often running from activity to activity.
At this point, I always pack their lunches, but sometimes I don’t pack lunches or their snacks and we find ourselves on takeout. They may eat a balanced breakfast (all liquid and no solid breakfasts seem to be the trend these days), but it’s not the balance of a 3-6 year old. They get snacks that are not whole foods and they’ve all had an occasional box of macaroni and cheese.

This is why many MTFs try to keep their breasts hidden by using long, short hair, baggy clothing, high collars and an abundance of other accessories. One common problem with changing breasts is that your breasts will shrink over time. Another problem is that your breasts will "gasp" which can make your breasts look too big.
When it comes to MTFs, there are a few different opinions on the best way to change breasts. Some people think that it's best to use no-touch breast implant devices, while others think that breast augmentation is the best way to go.
Breast augmentation is a type of plastic surgery procedure where breast tissue is replaced with implants to enhance the appearance of breasts. The procedure is generally done in two parts, which can take up to two years. Once the implants are in place, the surgeon closes the incision and removes the incision tissue.
Breast augmentation is done on an outpatient basis and takes around three hours, though this depends on the surgeon's experience. After the procedure, you will be given medications for pain and nausea.
Breast augmentation is a procedure in which a woman's breasts are surgically enlarged or enlarged in size. The breasts are most commonly enlarged by using a surgical implant. The implant is usually made of silicone, however, in recent years, some doctors have begun using a liquid, called liquid silicone. The implant is usually filled with saline, a salt solution, and is placed inside the breast, where it will be used to enlarge the breast.
Breast implant surgery is done under general anesthesia and takes approximately three to six weeks for the breasts to fully heal and return to normal size. The procedure is usually painless and requires little recovery time. However, some patients may have a lot of pain in their breasts, which can last for up to several months.

# Polynomials

What is a polynomial in cryptography?

A polynomial is a mathematical object that generalises integer multiplication; instead of multiplying two variables together (ex. $a * b$), we multiply them in layers. Take the following examples:

• $a * b$ where $a = 2 * 3$ and $b = 3 * 1$ will get the result: $a * b = (2 * 3) * (3 * 1) = 2 * (3 * 1) = 2 * 3 = 6$
• $a * b$ where $a = 2 * 3 * 4$ and $b = 3 * 1 * 5$ will get the result: $a * b = (2 * 3 * 4) * (3 * 1 * 5) = 2 * (3 * 1) * 4 * 5 = 2 * 3 * 4 * 5 = 2 * 3 * 20 = 12 * 20 = 240$

Note that every layer of multiplication has (potentially) different values being multiplied, yet adding up those results will give the original value. The number of layers is the degree of the polynomial, and in this example, the degree is equal to $4$.

## Application to cryptography

Now let's try and re-apply that same concept to cryptography. Earlier, we looked at multiplication with the Diffie-Hellman key exchange. In order to calculate the shared secret value, we first generate a random value $p = a * b$ and then take the discrete logarithm of it ($a * b = g^{a * b} \mod p$ where $g$ is a generator and $g^{a * b}$ is derived as above).

Theoretically, this value is calculated using the following polynomial equation:

$$p = a * b \mod n$$

Indeed, the value $n$ is the modulus. This is different from integer multiplication because $n$ is always an odd number. But doesn't that also mean that $a * b \mod n$ will always be even, and thus will not resolve to $p$?

Fortunately, the polynomial equation can be manipulated in the following way (note that it could also be written as $p - a * b \mod n$):

$$p = a * b \mod n \stackrel{

and how it is being applied in various fields such as medicine, energy, and communications.
Quantum mechanics is one of the most important and fundamental scientific theories of the modern era. It has fundamentally changed our understanding of the world around us, including how atoms, particles, and even light function. As a result, it has profound implications for numerous fields, including medicine, energy, and communications.

In medicine, quantum mechanics is being applied to develop new treatments for various diseases. For example, researchers are using quantum computing to simulate molecular interactions and predict the effects of different drugs on the human body. This can help researchers identify new drugs that are more effective and have fewer side effects.

In the field of energy, quantum mechanics is being used to develop new technologies that could revolutionize the way we generate and use energy. For example, researchers are exploring the use of quantum dots to improve solar cells, which could lead to more efficient and cost-effective solar power. Quantum mechanics is also being used to develop new materials with unique properties, such as superconductors and topological insulators, which could lead to breakthroughs in energy storage and distribution.

Finally, quantum mechanics is playing an increasingly important role in communications technology, as researchers develop new quantum communication protocols that could be used to transmit information more securely and efficiently than ever before. This includes the development of quantum key distribution, which uses the principles of quantum mechanics to ensure that communication is secure and unbreakable.

In conclusion, quantum mechanics has far-reaching implications for modern society, and its impact can be seen in numerous fields. From medicine to energy to communications, the principles of quantum mechanics are being applied to push the boundaries of what is possible and drive progress in numerous areas.

therapy at the Clinton Adult Rehabilitation Center.
After the professionals that care for Clinton Correctional Facility's rehabilitative program were unable to fully accept a request to use music as a therapeutic tool with the facility's residents, we created a new goal for the music therapy program. As a music therapist, I tried to fulfill this goal with our residents for over three years. My constant and determined desire to see their hard work rewarded with the new goal they had been requested to pursue was met with lack of support.
I remember an almost identical situation in 1992 while doing an internship at Lewis County Correctional Facility in WA State. I walked into my first group session excited about the possibility of providing music therapy and my excitement was met by a guarded lawyer from the counseling department. I was expecting to be welcomed with open arms but this attorney requested I not be in the group room and told the group and support staff that they should not speak with me because she didn't believe in my program. I was stunned at first and when I processed this news and requested to see the superintendent, he said "well, I can see that a music therapist may not be the right choice for this situation and I don't feel comfortable letting you in there either."
The combination of denial of funding for music therapists, lack of willingness of facility leadership to support music therapy, even despite these challenges, created a music therapy program that continued to assist the Clinton Facility's residents in their rehabilitation process. A few examples of this could be found in the behavior chart and therapeutic note section of this paper.
When I began a music therapy program for the Clinton Facility in 2002, my goals were based on my background as a professional musician and an educator.
To encourage the use of playing instruments of any type.
To support and encourage the ability to move with some level of rhythm.
To encourage expression of music without fear of judgment.
To encourage positive relationships with peers and staff.
To provide a vehicle for gaining self-esteem.
To provide positive and constructive environment for participation.
When I started working with the people at Clinton, I initially had to wear gloves so as not to upset anyone or to set off alarms by touching them. is one that has been explored for years, and it’s a relationship that will only grow stronger as biologists and engineers make connections between the two to solve some of the world’s most pressing issues. Integrating technology with wildlife not only creates advanced monitoring systems but it is also beneficial for humans living and working in the areas where these animals are located. 

Question: How do wildlife biologists learn more about certain species through technology? Wildlife biologists learn more about certain species through technology by using advanced monitoring systems and integrating technology with wildlife. For example, biologists have developed new technology to help researchers gain more information about the movements, habits and reproductive cycles of migrating deer[2]. Technological advances have also revolutionized the way the public thinks about and engages with wildlife[3]. With the use of technology, wildlife biologists are able to understand ecosystems and behaviors on a global scale and from a variety of angles, such as satellites, drones and 3D imaging[4]. Additionally, drones equipped with high-resolution cameras can help wildlife biologists track migratory birds and detect endangered and threatened species with higher accuracy[5].

can be intimidating, especially when it comes to Azure Machine Learning (AML). ML pipelines (or a combined pipeline and flow) is a way to easily organize work in Azure ML that makes it easier to write and share your code. ML pipelines (and the flow component) allow you to manually iterate over your code and use tags as you go. Your work can then be organized and run again without having to copy/paste code.

# The Architecture of Azure Machine Learning Pipelines

A big part of ML pipelines is the components list, which you add and edit to complete your machine learning analysis. The components are organized from top to bottom in your pipeline and contain the following sections.

1. A location field allows you to enter the URL of the AML Workspace and/or the URL of a DataFlow to use. These AML workspaces and DataFlows live in the Azure Portal (in the \Azure ML Studio tab).
2. The Script section describes the relevant pieces of code you want to execute.
3. A tags field contains relevant metadata about your component and the project. Tags can either be created during the initial pipeline or uploaded and related to an existing project.

ML pipelines are essentially collections of components with tags added to those components so that they can be run individually or all together. Let's create an example to try this out.

Note that a new component added to an AML pipeline or a flow will be considered the parent (active) component for that component only. Hence, you will not have parent/child components within a pipeline, even though you can have multiple pipelines that have different components from the same parent component. In essence, there will be two components in two separate pipelines when you run these components in a new pipeline.

To create a pipeline or flow, click on the View or Flow tab and click on the button on the top bar labeled New. Once you select New there are two options - create a Pipeline or a Flow. We will demonstrate the Pipeline flow, as the process is similar for the Flow.

Now you can customize the components. Create a new component by right-clicking on the Components section and click Add Component. If you are familiar with Azure ML, these components include a Name (with a default name, which you can change), a Description (a longer-form description for the component), and a type (for example, you could select Python or Text to string).

After creating your component, you can add parameters to it by right-click

and climate in the Swiss Alps.
Climate research in the Swiss Alps has developed considerably over the last 25 years. A number of long running (10 year or more) instrumental records of temperature and precipitation and supporting observations of air quality are available from a wide network of observation stations. The construction of a European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) reanalysis has enabled evaluation of model skills and increasing skill at boundary layer analysis and prognosis. The development of a number of high-resolution models has enabled advancement in weather forecasting on the intra seasonal time scale. Strong advances have been made in interpreting long-term changes and developments in the atmospheric and cryospheric system, and in integrating these observations with high resolution regional climate models and process based models to investigate uncertainties and uncertainty sources. The seasonal predictions from regional climate models are being tested on a Swiss basin scale and those for the West European region. There is a general awareness of the need for robust large scale climate scenarios for the Mediterranean region as an indicator of impacts on water supplies, the environment and energy, and on the interaction between water, energy and food supply. This paper gives an overview of the work at the Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research (WSL).

vaccines
How they work, when to take them and why your doctor might hesitate
Travel clinics, pharmacies and hospitals now provide travelers with up-to-date and comprehensive medical advice and a veritable world of vaccinations. But vaccine manufacturers don't test or qualify shots for use in other countries, so doctors and nurses are in the difficult position of having to make educated guesses about which vaccines to recommend, or if they need to recommend any at all. "A lot of infections that come from abroad can have signs and symptoms that can mimic a cold or gastroenteritis," says Dr. Jeffrey Kahn, an epidemiologist and infectious disease specialist at HealthLink BC. "So even if you get a good vaccine, it might not be doing much for you."
The struggle to create preventative vaccines that don't have serious side effects could be contributing to this lack of information. Vaccine makers have experimented with using dog, cat and cow proteins, enzymes and genetic material, all of which could make people sick. "The science of infectious disease vaccines is relatively new," says Kahn. "But we've come a long way."
Nonetheless, because there are still major hurdles to vaccinating people with live viruses that can replicate and mutate, some vaccines are often a better solution than their live counterparts. That's where travelers' vaccinations come in: unlike live vaccines, which require six months or longer to produce the desired level of immunity, they can be administered immediately. "If you get vaccinated you have some protection against that bug for a certain period of time," says Kahn. "But then you're going to be susceptible for a period of time."
If you are using a travel clinic or hospital, a doctor will examine you, take a detailed health history and determine which vaccinations are needed before advising you of your next steps. Here's what you can expect, along with what you should do to prepare:
Cost: There is no fixed rate for vaccinations, as they are all custom-built to the traveler and depend on the drugs needed to produce immunity. The International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM), which administers a certification program for travel clinics, says that travellers should be prepared for a bill of around $300.
In most cases, travellers will need to wait around 24 hours before they can head out into the world. The viral shots, in particular, need to incubate before they become effective. But you can take other steps to help travel go smoothly once you head back to your home country:
What you need to know and where
- If you don't

has shown us that our brain is responsible for everything we do. Our experiences and emotions are dictated by our brain. If our brain is not healthy, neither are we. This is why you need to take care of your brain to take care of your health.
Our brain is made up of 2 separate parts: the left and the right. The left part of our brain handles the logical and analytical side of our personality and the right handles the creative and intuitive. Because the logic-based left side of our brain controls and manages emotions, a variety of mental conditions arise. The condition that we will discuss today is anxiety. Anxiety is a mental condition that arises when a person becomes fearful over situations, things, or people.
This condition affects a lot of people as statistics show that 30% of the world’s population experiences some sort of anxiety. In the United States alone, roughly 40 million people have anxiety every year.
Symptoms of anxiety include trembling, feeling stressed, light-headed, dizzy, fast heartbeat, fast or irregular breathing, sweating, feeling shaky, nausea, and a feeling of panic. Different people experience different types of anxiety. The most common type of anxiety is stress. According to the latest research, stress is the reason why 60% of people quit their job because they are not able to meet the demands of their job. It is also the main reason why 1 in 5 people suffer from health problems.
On the other hand, if we want to take control of our anxiety, we must know the main cause behind the anxiety. In this article, we will not tell you what is anxiety, but we will let you understand how you can overcome your anxiety through taking care of your brain.
This is really important because this is the cause of your anxiety. Our brain is programmed to handle only what is expected of us. If our brain is exposed to something new or there are a lot of things happening all at once, it can get overwhelmed. This is a normal feeling that happens every time our brain is challenged and exposed to new things.
For example, a person may become anxious when he knows that he will be working in a different country. His brain may think that it is the end of the world and that he cannot accept this new challenge and would just rather quit his current job.
Overcoming anxiety involves overcoming the way our brain responds to unexpected situations. This means that it is important to trust ourselves in whatever we do. It is important to be prepared for whatever you will face because you are more than

and genetics testing
Over the past few years, there has been an explosion of data about a person's genetic makeup. Today, you can order a DNA test and, in a matter of weeks, receive information about all the different things that affect your health, including your predisposition to disease, how much caffeine you can safely drink, if you're prone to an addiction and even your blood type. As these DNA testing companies reveal your genetic traits and health details, people sometimes have misconceptions about their usefulness.
A sample of DNA from an individual being tested. Even while having a genetic test done, some people still don't understand the worth of them.
Misconceptions about genetic testing
1. Genetic testing is always beneficial.
The applications of genetic testing are still mostly in their infancy and many are not ready for prime time. Although genetic testing can explain complex disease outcomes, many of these disease are not avoidable. Thus, genetic testing is not a completely reliable resource when it comes to avoiding disease and the meaning of your individual genetic testing data will depend on what type of testing you do.
2. People should take advantage of all the tests.
People who don't yet understand genetic testing may feel compelled to take advantage of any and every test available. This is a mistake. Some companies have invented "gene drives" to ensure they can reach millions of people with lots of product to sell. That's why thousands of gene tests are available, but only a few are based on clear scientific value.
3. Genetics is black and white.
We live in a society that believes in "black and white" solutions to everyday problems. Genetic testing is no different. There is a big difference between knowing what your risk of disease might be, and actually being able to lower your risk by doing something different.
4. If you don't get genetic testing, you can't benefit from it.
Genetic testing has one distinct advantage over other available testing: it can be used at any point in your life. A downside is that the data can quickly become obsolete. By the time your results are ready, your genetic makeup may have changed so the information may not be useful. If you test now, will it help you tomorrow? Only time will tell.
5. A genetic test can tell you everything you need to know.
Take heart from the fact that information about your genetic health is not always as straightforward as it might seem. For example, if your mother was diagnosed with cancer, your risk of getting the same disease may actually decrease. The amount of information about how

research is a burgeoning field. Practitioners of AI may feel an ethical responsibility, guided by a certain ideal, to use AI in alignment with societal goals. Fairness, and not just technical correctness, can be one such ideal. Most respondents to the new Cloud to Edge Survey Report from research and advisory firm Gartner agree that the power imbalance between AI developers and AI end users needs to be addressed. Respondents feel there is a need for a human in the loop, particularly when it comes to AI safety, ownership and equity.
Some worry that AI will produce biased and unfair results if developers don’t include ethical considerations. In fact, several senior executives at an event in Switzerland in September 2018 surveyed by SAP AG said AI could help promote human rights and deliver on the United Nations’ (U.N.’s) Sustainable Development Goals (SDG). The initial step in any discussion about the ethical application of AI is to define terms. While debates around the ethics of AI can turn ad-hoc, to be taken seriously, the definition of ethical AI must be concrete.
Sangiacomo suggests data scientists and engineers in enterprises approach the ethical development of AI as they approach the development of any new technology. The ethics behind their AI systems should be reviewed and addressed at all stages of the development process, from infrastructure, integration, and user interface to ongoing monitoring and maintenance. “The technology needed to be developed in accordance with the overall design philosophy,” Sangiacomo says.
Here are the three ethical technologies to which enterprises should look first, followed by three technologies that are less cutting edge but can make a lasting ethical impact.
The decision-making based on an algorithm learned from historical data is commonplace. “An algorithm is data-driven. It learns from past data. That means if the data is biased, the algorithm is biased,” Sangiacomo says. Even in well-designed data centers, there are risks in using an algorithm from the cloud.
For example, claims data is used to train fraud-detection algorithms. Data collected in high fraud areas may cause predictions based on training sets to have higher error rates. If such data is used in the formation of fraud detection algorithms, then the algorithms may be skewed to hold a bias against certain ethnicities.
“In general, that might be because certain segments in society have been historically more likely to commit fraud in certain industries. So, if the algorithm is learning from the past, then it’s going to use that data, which will learn the new solution to be biased,” Sangiacomo says.

Poetry is the art of expressing ideas and feelings in words in a concise, flowing form. The benefits of poetry are many, as poetry is a powerful medium for reaching the emotional and spiritual core of a person. Some of the benefits of poetry include:
	* Poems can be used as catalysts for personal reflection and growth.
	* Poetry can provide opportunities to learn new ways of seeing and experiencing the world.
	* Poetry can celebrate the experiences and emotions of people from diverse backgrounds.
	* Poetry can be used as a form of therapy, such as for depression and grief.

is pretty straightforward. Light, lenses, and camera sensors.
However, the basics get tangled up in the technical jargon when the camera guy says, "The [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] is too exposed and the [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] is too dark"
What the hell? Why do the [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] sound like something that won't ever get better?
To explain what the [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] is, and to explain why the [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] is worse than white being pure white and black being pure black.
In old film photography, one could use [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] gel filters for the film itself in various combinations.
Each filter had a threshold of one color against another.
With black and white film, you would typically put a [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] filter directly in front of the lens as the first filter in a stack. A [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] filter in front of white and red will make red become [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] with the first in front being [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] and black of course will become white. This causes [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] to be a pure white and black is pure black. On a negative, when you are looking into the negative with a loupe, you won't be able to tell where black is on the negative but you will see white and cyan as white with less and less of them until you can't see them at all, which is black. So this is where all the camera guy technical jargon about [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red] comes from.
On an image sensor with a Bayer filter, you are looking at a series of tiny images representing only one color of the photo. And because of how the images are taken, black and white looks like this.
Remember: White is actually RED. Red is actually YELLOW. Yellow is actually GREEN. Green is actually CYAN.
So all the camera guy is trying to do is straighten out the image so all the colors are where they should be.
And he calls that [Cyan|Orange|Magenta|Green|Red].

When I started learning more on the subject of quantum mechanics (usually also called "physics") I found it difficult to get started. For example, I can't understand what $x$, $p$ and $\hbar$ are for.

All texts start with classical physics (Newtonian Mechanics) and then say, look quantum mechanics is new, this is what it means: $x = 3$, $p = 5$, $\hbar = 0.5$.

But what is $x$? What is $p$? What is $\hbar$? I'm not saying that's the best way to begin, but perhaps the parts concerning 'elementary' stuff in quantum physics need a better introduction. A high school level introduction would probably help a lot.

There are also topics that are maybe trivial to you, but very important to me: I believe that when you explain stuff to someone, you should say what they know beforehand, not afterwards: this makes things harder.

I know of a couple of introductory books on the matter (Bohm and Streater, Feynman, etc), which are great for deep insight, but I'd like a 'by the numbers' approach, as if you were explaining everything to somebody else. How can I get this? Did I miss something on quantum mechanics when I learned high school physics? Is there a good, fun, basic, textbook on this matter?

• A few questions can be found here: first, second, third. – Dilaton Jan 12 '14 at 10:13
• To begin you don't need to learn anything about quantum mechanics to begin with. The classical explanation can be misleading, because it was originally thought to be a classical theory but eventually it was found that it was a mathematical theory. The primary theory that you have to learn is single particle quantum mechanics, the mathematical theory that uses linear algebra and complex number. Then you have the uncertainty principle, that is essential. – Dilaton Jan 12 '14 at 10:16
• In physics, it's very common to give simple examples rather than doing an elementary introduction. To do so, you need to be aware of what your audience is familiar with. A high school level introduction might well lead people astray. What is elementary for one person is not for another. – Kyle Kanos Jan 12 '14 at 10:29
• I am not sure you will

doesn't really come from philosophy's contributions to natural science, but from it contributions to common sense. Instead of being real, "metaphysical" things are just complex metaphors. Mythical explanations can still make us sense our limitations in the universe without overwhelming our optimism. ## Philosophy as 'practice and guidance'

Francisco, you seem to be conflating philosophy with psychology, especially in the sections on psychology and atheism. There is a genuine distinction between philosophy and psychology, and I wish you'd consider that within both sections on psychology and atheism you have misrepresented or erred on the side of psychological ideas as philosophy. You note the distinction between psychology, sociology and anthropology, but fall in to the same trap in your section on philosophy and religion.

Philosophy isn't about Psychology. I'm not sure what our respective professions are, but I'm not a psychologist. We speak a completely different language. Take Aristotle as an example. He thought his universe could be described with the least amount of mathematical terms, because he didn't understand geometry. He also asked the first question in philosophy, "what is an absolute?" There's a very specific meaning of science there, and its not at all psychological. While he certainly had a very unscientific mindset, not accepting much less supernatural is a sign of great insight, even today. In short, he's one of the founding fathers of our foundations of knowledge. It would be nice if philosophers could understand that while there are many psychological answers, there are no philosophical ones. To say otherwise is to impose on others the suffering we bear ourselves. Even at the time of his works, he wasn't claiming to be a scientist, he was

have been applied to the widespread excavation and palaeo-ethno-archaeological study of this major Early Neolithic settlement, encompassing the first phases of Neolithic construction of temples, tombs, houses and workshops. This has allowed detailed statistical analyses of house numbers, numbers of graves, as well as skeletal, ceramic and stone inventories to be undertaken. The treasurers of those who died within the temple and near the buildings of mortuary feasting shows that belonging to this group was a significant function for individuals. Expanding this information to the household and inter-household level allows the way in which the community viewed the dead, their labours and the transmission of values and wealth across the generations to be explored. The Numinia community is expressed not only as a kin-based social entity but one which was conditioned by other principalities. The results of palaeo-ethno-archaeological analyses are combined with field survey in order to expand the analysis further into the larger surrounding landscape and to identify additional temples, prehistoric burials, henge monuments, later ritual activity and settlements, the function of which may be clarified. This third of three parts provides a methodology with which to contextualise archaeological data. It has revealed how individuals were important to the transmission of values, and community organisations from generation to generation. Moreover, it has demonstrated how community participants viewed themselves, their descendants and other principalities. Both the community and the individual are therefore of crucial importance for understanding the prehistoric past.
Emma Jenkins is an OCEHH Post-Doctoral Research Fellow in the Department of Archaeology at University College Cork and is currently based in the IGPP Laboratory at the University of Bonn. She previously held a post-doctoral post in the Department of Archaeology at the University of Cambridge where she investigated changes in mortuary practices and monumentality between the Later Bronze Age and Early Iron Age in the Thames Valley. Between these two posts she was a Marie Curie Fellow in the Institute of Archaeology at the University of Leicester. She has previously taught archaeology and Mediterranean languages at The University of St Andrews.

Video games and dancing together is not something I’ve seen anywhere near as often as I’d expect, and something I’m sure could be done a lot more in most contemporary games.

As a designer, I’m fascinated by this as a potential win-win: for danceability to be added as a core design output, we can step beyond the habits we normally have of only thinking about audio through a ‘fun, pleasurable, noise’ lens.

Firstly, games actually now are embracing a lot more abstract sensory experience, if you look at sensory games like Tilt Brush. Auditory games however are still lagging behind, as they are by and large still designed with heavy sound effects, and more traditional instrumentation.

To get there, it might help to start with the music as input. Music theory relies on the composer on knowing a number of concrete things about the instruments to even be able to write the music down, and to know where it’s going to go.

Modern game audio designers, at the very least, aim to re-use sound effects and music as extensively as possible, mixing them together to create a coherent whole. It would be a much more interesting challenge to begin with data about each instrument instead.

This could eventually lead to a vision where game musicians, audio composers, and sound designers (and as the name makes you expect, video game developers as well) could very naturally start to add sound experiments which are based around ergonomics of the instruments used.

An idea might be to use band instruments, with good tuning so they can easily be played in the same key, but to create semi-random stems and instruments which can be played, to replicate the audible effects of a band. For example, in Karaoke, using two keyboards would give you bass notes and lead, rather than sampling a regular bass and keyboard player.

A desirable outcome would be to have music which had new, stylistically unique, humanly-playable instruments which could have very different playing styles. If keyboards were plugged in, then you might find wind or string musicians playing keyboards in tune and changing the kind of musician, beyond the scope of games which just randomly drop different instruments into the mix.

This kind of research is still in it’s infancy (and is actually a long way from even a full direction that makes any kind of sense), but I’m excited about the possibilities!

to the study of religion, and how that line of investigation might help with public awareness of the ways in which science affects religion in the contemporary age. ‘Everything is mine: painting in the late nineteenth century’, is how Ernest Henningsen (1859-1924) described his method of painting. He is an artist from the Munich artists’ colony. Henningsen’s language not only underscores the ubiquity of the modern technological and industrial means available to the artist, but also, strikingly, the strong contrast between a strictly personal experience of art, contained in this painting, and the array of spectators present in the foreground. The audience is totally disconnected from the artist and his work, and as he is suspended in time, everything can only be understood from the outside. But his work is not isolated; it manifests itself in dialogue and a sense of being with others. Is he then just a successful figure of historical determination or an expression of the very physiology of the human soul in the modern age? Ernst Henningsen was interested in this predicament in the history of his century: although he produced many paintings depicting the daily activities of his friends, the context of his work is historical and intrinsically future-oriented. In his final years he knew that a fundamental change was coming, and like Marc Chagall, was able to be connected to this ‘great transformation’ to come by painting it. Henningsen’s work is full of premonitions of the forthcoming flowering of technology and the blurring of the distinction between the interior life and the outer world. During this seminar, Dr Tzortzis, who will be introduced by Prof. Linda Woodhead (Lancaster University), will show that life as the experience of an exchange of signals between the past and the future, today, is up for discussion. The observation that modern technology, far from being a threat to religion, actually opens the door to a new type of religious experience will also be raised in this event.
This project has received funding from the European Union's Seventh Framework Programme for research, technological development and demonstration under grant agreement no. 321909.

For the education sector, which has traditionally relied on live sessions, offline classes, and homework assignments, the transformation is forcing it to embrace digital as an essential part of student learning.
Similarly, the new business development landscape requires enabling technology and digital knowledge to reach prospective clients. Companies that have built their revenue streams around classroom training as their primary driver of revenue, have now been forced to sell all online.
In short, marketing and sales have taken a new meaning in the digital age. The need to promote yourself and your offerings, attract clients, create awareness, attract leads, build relationships, and get them on board is all the more essential.
The same problem of digital readiness exists in the role of education in the corporate world. Large sections of the corporate workforce have been inactive for a year and a half, with teachers left unsatisfied. The education sector in the 21st century has become an integral part of corporate culture, with the aim of skill-building and industry alignment.

In the corporate environment, education means building employees who have the necessary skills to make a positive difference in your business. The overall objective is to deliver value, and that is what defines corporate success.

In fact, training is a valuable investment in the holistic growth and development of an employee. The current preference for digital education among employees indicates the time has come to redefine education for both education and professional development.
According to the Times of India survey, a large percentage of employees were in favor of taking online training, a view that is strongly supported by their managers and HR heads. For the education industry, this means that they have to shift their focus on digital education to meet the evolving needs of the employee.
This is why education needs to be available online, with teachers who are highly skilled and equipped with the latest digital tools to deliver and enable effective learning. The tools need to be user-friendly for employees to practice with them.

You may have heard people claim that chemistry isn't relevant to your day-to-day life, that it's only for scientists, or that you will never need to use anything you learned in chemistry. You don't have to be a scientist to enjoy a beautiful sunset, hear music that touches your soul, or share a meal with a friend. All these things involve chemistry in some form or another. Making music involves chemistry in the sound waves and frequencies that we are able to perceive; preparing food involves chemistry as you determine which foods do what to your body; sunset colors involve reflection and scattering of light from the atmosphere; and we eat because of chemistry. You might need a broader understanding of these processes than you think, so think again and understand that chemistry can be fun and fascinating. Here are the most common misconceptions about chemistry and learning chemistry.
It is boring
You will rarely be asked what speed of light does in chemistry class. You won’t be tested on the number of atoms in a single molecule of sodium, nor will you find yourself calculating the pH of a water sample. However, chemistry has a significant impact on everyday living. Just think about how many things depend on chemistry that you use on a daily basis. Chemistry is the science that enables things such as energy production, drinkable water, food safety, drug efficacy, defense in wartime, and a less polluted environment. As that indicates, chemistry is important to your everyday living. Chemistry has real-life applications in everything you do.
It's too hard
Chemistry is difficult. It can be challenging at times, but it does not have to be overwhelming. You can make chemistry as easy or difficult as you like. As in all fields of study, you need to decide what your motivation is. You need to decide the type of reward that you will get for your effort and how much effort you want to put forth. Reward yourself at all levels, from memorizing a concept, to understanding a concept, to being able to explain a concept in different words or situations. No matter what level of chemistry you begin with, you will learn new things and experience new things about nature. By learning chemistry and new concepts, you will increase your brain function and allow yourself to be on an infinite learning curve. Every concept you learn now will have a foundation on which to build upon future understandings. I encourage you to use the sun screen and sunscreen lotions every day. But when you go outside, wear those earmuffs on your ears. Again, chemistry can be fun and fascinating.

are currently taking a significant step forward thanks to laser-based 3D lidar technologies. Typical lidar technologies are based on illumination with a continuous wave beam and the reception of these in reflected back to the lidar unit. In simple systems, the angle and range information is derived from the time of flight differences between two or more pulses sent out. In a laser radar design, similar information is derived by comparing the phase information in one or more pulses to a reference waveform. Both approaches lead to the same range information; however, the phase measurement offers higher information content per spatial volume and, thus, resolution of 3D information on a much larger scale in comparison to other range sensor technologies. Several different approaches of laser-based 3D range imaging techniques are being currently introduced on the market.
Typical lidar sensors, using a step and ramp modulated active laser as illumination, were early adopters in this game. Using a pulse frequency greater than 100 MHz, ranges to most objects have been easily obtained. The object is conveniently sampled point-by-point (e.g. 1000 points per range) through these single point measurements. This, in combination with the inherent 360o field of view of this laser radar technology, results in a polar representation of the measured 3D object. To overcome the 1-dimensionality of polar representations, radially distributed holograms have been used. Spreading the range information at the receiver into space by additional interferometric lens arrangements has led to the development of 3D scanners, used in security applications.
Another type of laser radar sensor is based on the measurement of phase information. The pulse trains are pre-spread over time by a chirp modulation, and thus provide additional information on the temporal phase (reference waveform is fixed).
Adopting the intracavity frequency doubling of telecom technology, and hence a fiber laser platform, with an extended wavelength range, an impulse chirp laser technology has been developed, featuring high range of 400m @850mW with 25mrad angle resolution.
Many system components, in particular commercial sensors, are time-gated. By tightly synchronizing the system time with the laser pulse frequency the time-gate pulse duration can be reduced. Because of the reduced time-gate laser radar range in detection is increased by the same amount. Compact laser radar devices can be realized in this way in which a fixed angle resolution and a selectable time-gate length are the key parameters. These laser radar systems
