is really simple. Cryptography is the digital version of scarlet letter: if you use a wrong tool for a purpose you feel is important, you put your life at risk.
Today I got a Chrome notification that version 40 of Google Chrome has been released. It comes with new extensions and several security fixes.
But it also contains a nasty surprise: Microsoft’s Edge is taking over the Internet Explorer brand.
As we know, in the dark times, hackers are slowly creating a new monster called internet, which is against us.
Basically the advice to protect your digital life is really simple: don’t click on links and don’t open attachments in your inbox.
And if a link you see in your Gmail is tempting you to open it, do your best to avoid looking at it.
The upside of the situation is that Google is trying to convince you to change your habits as quickly as possible.
The most essential thing is to learn how to handle different digital literacy levels inside the organization. It is vitally important.
What does this mean? It means that not all the people inside your company use the same devices, are on the same devices, or are aware of the same risks. And this is a problem.
In the beginning, my company only decided to make the iPhones and iPads mandatory, and to make Windows PCs optional.
But the more smartphones we have, the more risks we take.
And this means that all companies are expected to use a device that offers maximum protection for its users and also allows companies to track and monitor their activity.
If the advice above seems too difficult, then maybe the solution is simple.
One of the problems is that the world has changed so much. Computers are everywhere, and our work-life balance is getting worse. Even if we take our computers home with us, they are still connected to all the devices that are now connected to us. At work, our computers are connected to the internet. Everything that we do is connected to the internet, and that’s why we need to be able to connect safely.

has seen humankind climbing steadily higher up the ladder of life forms, from chimp to bonobo to lemur. From there, it seemed only a few ticks of the evolutionary clock to the gigantism and hyper-intelligence of The Singularity. It was just a matter of time, most thought, for nature to close that last genetic loop. Consider the playing cards – the pyramid scheme leading human beings from the animal to the divine.
So who knew about the obstacle? If a cube is stacked, all six sides meet – unless one side missteps and falls flat on the ground. A pyramid, on the other hand, demands each level hold its weight upon itself – unless it fails, will be its own tombstone. Guess who rolled the die – that’s right, human beings. The ones who cried for Mother Nature to get off their backs, demanding yet more nectar, more honey, more seafood caught where? Guess who’s smelling more than the last page from the menu – that’s right, the poor mother earth herself.
Enjoy, invent, tinker. But by all means – use your technology to build bigger and bigger pyramids. Build upon your pyramids, big or small, level or crooked. For when the world breaks apart, your foundations will crumble with your hopes, dreams, desires, and most of all your money (because all that’s really left of you is your invisible money – the only legacy you’ll have left). So humans – all living creatures, really – utilize your position in the ‘Pyramid Theory’ and don’t create a Pyramidal Burden. You will only leave a Pyramidal Burden for the rest of us. Thanks.
And that is what your science does to you: it destroys all free will. To sum it all up, The Matrix of Evolution – built upon genetics, revolved by the genetic pyramid scheme – has enslaved human beings, delivering millions of soulless souls. And as you reap what you sow, the future of it is not only bleak, but terrifying, and further uncompromising.

I never much cared for paintings, or sculpture, or even pottery. I did like the drawings and collages my classmates did when in my art classes, but I was never impressed. I couldn’t tell one masterpiece from another.
In 1992, I went to the St. Paul Art Fair at the Minnesota state fair grounds. It had a large jewelry area. I chose a bauble, when two older women asked if I would be willing to trade it for one of theirs. I usually refused, but their collection included necklaces with genuine opals, so I agreed. We made the swap. I never saw the necklace again.
A couple of months later, I was in a nursery school in Blue Earth, Minnesota. My task was to help the children study nature. I think it was supposed to be a teacher work day, although nobody showed up. Perhaps my class was too young, for I remember the teacher telling me it was “too noisy.”
I already had my next assignment, and was already en route by the time the teacher pointed out the bird nest in the top of a birch tree. Someone had flipped up a small dead branch, revealing the whole structure. The parents were yellow-rumped warblers. I had only recently heard of them, although I grew up in a rural area. During the school break, I taught myself a lot about them and I’ve always been glad to find one. I had previously seen them in the summer, but that was when they were in the light of day. I have been fortunate to see them in the early morning, or on a dull gray afternoon, and their color is clearer than in the summer sun.
I took the liberty of removing the dead branch and doing some renovations. Two of the nestlings were very new. If they were female, their color would turn almost black, but two of them were already at least two-thirds yellow. They looked too weak to survive a rude swoop down from above. They seemed to realize it, too.
In the afterglow of my project, I rushed back to the nursery school, to find it closed. I didn’t even try the front door. I sprinted up the sidewalk to the newly repaired nest. I lifted the camera from my pack, to photograph it. The nestlings were struggling a bit, but looked to have sufficient strength in their tiny wings. The mother came and picked them up and flew over to the dead bush. By the time I retrieved my camera, she had laid two of the

to the moon set in the 1960s in the style of Ray Bradbury.
In the heart of the 1960s, people all across America were filled with excitement as they eagerly awaited the day of their greatest journey. It was on this journey that mankind was to set foot on the moon - the most distant of worlds.

The Boeing Titan II rocket slowly began to lift its colossal frame from Cape Kennedy's Launch Complex 34. It left behind the glare of the setting sun, a golden orb setting in the Florida sky like some fiery ball of clay. An exhilarating chill danced up my spine as I stood on the observation platform with my eyes fixed on the rocket, no longer anchored to earth but ascending into the cosmos.

When we reached lunar orbit, our mission control team announced that Neil Armstrong and Edwin 'Buzz' Aldrin would descend to the moon’s surface in the Lunar Module 'Eagle'. As Aldrin reclined in the cockpit, Armstrong stepped out onto the lunar surface. As he lifted his foot off the Lunar Module, he uttered those immortal words - "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind."

The echoes of this monumental achievement rang throughout the world, uniting us in our awe and wonder. We all felt a part of history being made.

But this was just the beginning. One small step, indeed. This was only the first step in our voyage to the unknown. And we knew there were more steps to come. For this was not the end, it was simply another beginning.

Back on earth, my family gathered around the old black and white television, our eyes glued to the screen, waiting for more news. The reporters rambled on about the mission's success, but it was their faces and body language that spoke volumes. There was a sense of cautious hope in their voices, a hope that we would continue to reach for the stars.

As the years passed, we did continue to reach for the stars. We sent probes to Jupiter and Saturn, and even set foot on Mars. But it all began on that September day in 1969, when Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon’s surface.

Our dream of travelling to the moon has since been achieved. But the spirit of adventure, the hope, the sense of awe that filled us as we awaited the lunar landing never faded. It stayed with us through decades and continues to inspire generations today. Because whether we're gazing at the stars, dreaming about the future, or contemplating the

What are the implications of the elements of art for those who create and for those who experience art? What are the uses of art in the home, on the street, at work, and in the world? Discussing these and other questions, the National Gallery of Art will open America’s Image: The First Hundred Years, a new exhibition on November 20.
The exhibition covers the period from the inception of the Art Commission of the District of Columbia in 1870 to the present. Including 150 paintings and sculptures, this exhibition illustrates the complexity of art in America over the years, while stressing that art has always been an expression of that most essential American value: individual self-expression.
“Art is the only avenue to the soul, and I have been privileged to bear witness to the poets, story tellers, listeners, healers, magicians, bards, and artists – all who have played their part in the triumph of the human spirit,” said National Gallery of Art Director Harry L. Smith.
The American image of today is a very different one than a century ago. Today’s American image, represented by artists from Edward Hopper to Georgia O’Keeffe and Charles Sheeler, reflects this country’s enthusiasm for consumerism, modernism, and technology. But the preoccupation with personal relationships, the caring for children, and the admiration of the natural world remain constant.
Artists’ images of the American countryside, the interior and exterior of the home, the artist in his studio, and the nation’s rich heritage are all represented in the exhibition.
In addition to paintings, sculpture, and lithographs, American images of the past and present are portrayed in new art forms, such as movie films, cartoons, advertising, photography, architectural ornament, industry, and modern design.
“The major messages and implications of this exhibition are that the evolution of American art mirrors the evolution of American society and culture, and that the deliberate roles art has played in society — from propaganda to personal expression — always have something important to say about what is important to all Americans in contemporary times,” noted Chief Curator Susan Cheever.
Art in America: The First Hundred Years draws its name from the mural painted by Elliott Daingerfield (1859-1937) for the U.S. Capitol Rotunda in 1908. Daingerfield’s mural depicted the early history of America as a story of settlers whose endeavors formed the Republic and the pre-existing relationship of America with the rest of the world

What makes up a geological formation? How do layers of soil form? Why is the Jurassic known as the dinosaur era? These are just a few of the questions students will learn to answer in this unit.
Grade 6 GEOLOGY is an in-depth exploration of the science of geology. Emphasis is placed on the use of practical observation, measurement, and experimentation to explore and observe natural formations in order to discover the processes that formed them. Students further learn about types of geological rocks and what each is used for. The ancient art of making and binding naturally occurring minerals is also covered. Students learn to consider and communicate scientific knowledge and how it can help in addressing real-world concerns.
Anatomy and Physiology is an interesting look at how the human body works. How our brains, ears and heart get us from point A to B? What is digestion, blood flow, and nervous system? What does it take for food to get from our mouth to the bathroom? How do we sleep? Learn about the sensory organs, layers of the skin, teeth and structures of the head.
Grade 7 ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY is a very hands-on learning style. The unit uses human body models to illustrate and explain how the human body functions. The unit also uses programs and software to illustrate the function of the body.
Oceanography is the study of the ocean environment, its processes and ocean ecosystems. Through study of different topics in Oceanography, students will be asked to consider both ancient and modern questions relating to the world's oceans. These questions include the study of currents and oceanic current patterns that help define the movement of water, physical and chemical properties of ocean waters, the atmosphere's interaction with the ocean, the ocean floor and sedimentary environments, the role of the ocean in modern human concerns, and much more. This unit of study covers all the important and interesting aspects of the world's oceans. This unit will then follow up with the Great Lakes of North America.
Geography is about places. What are places? How do they change? How can you find places? Where can you go? How can you get there? How can you show where you are? Using our latitude and longitude system and a diagram showing a Globe we can discuss and understand where places are on the globe. We will also explore how to read maps, charts and globes. A focus on location and place. We will explore characteristics, land forms, bodies of water and life forms of specific locations around the world and focus on our Great Lakes and the six regions

continuity management best practices introduce more ways for disruption to occur than we could have imagined when the discipline was developed. Resilience planning, a relatively new concept, counteracts these disruptive events, whether external or internal.
Business continuity plans become more important than ever before. Knowing how to be resilient is the new requirement for 21st century resilience planning.
While resilience planning may have the best of intentions, the disruptions an organization faces often fall outside the limits of that plan. In some instances, an external issue, such as climate change, can take a company completely by surprise. Issues such as political unrest in foreign nations can hamper a company’s ability to gain access to raw materials or transportation of products. One of the biggest threats to physical security today is terrorism, which can take down operations and even change the face of the company in an extreme situation. While a robust business continuity plan provides a blueprint for recovery, these serious disruptions will often call for flexibility in existing business continuity processes as well as the initiation of new practices and processes.
When disaster strikes, how a company reacts is not only dictated by the original resilience plan but by its vision for the future, as well as the value it places on customers and employee safety, to name a few.

in the movie Jurassic Park

May 18, 2018 - 3:55pm , by R. V. Tsagaris

You know the "what-ifs"? What if a mad scientist happened to figure out how to clone dinosaurs?

For 19 years the debate has been ongoing as to how realistic Jurassic Park was or wasn't. Or how believable or not. And apparently, there's no consensus. And probably none exists.

The movie is obviously fictional, but some of the science behind it is inspired by real research and for example of some of the ideas that influenced the original book and movie but you don't see in it are: "[...] massive global overdispersal of dinosaurs through drift ice at the end of the Cretaceous Period [that] created the first, but far smaller, wave of today's vertebrate dispersals, the "K-T extinction event", and "paleogeography of Tethys, parapedicels or dendricels"

Anyway, the movie does a great job of showing a fictional setting and reflecting things that geologists find to be true in a certain way. Like this video that shows us the timeline of the characters traveling from mainland to Isla Nublar and back. The geologist's, Sean, shown is pretty much accurately reproducing the function of a compass in this travel route, except for one tiny hitch, i.e. the Jurassic Park research base, at Isla Nublar is further south than what it really should be (20 years ago you would have likely found the island in the Florida state on the map). But other than that, you can do this from one region of the map to another and it is useful for estimating the direction of travel. So it's not to be taken literally. But please, enjoy the video and see how Jurassic Park has affected our interpretation of geologic time and distances on earth.

- including autobiographical, sociological, intellectual, geographical, and economic - Ian Wedgwood explores the history of popular music. Wherever he travels in the world, Ian brings to life the music he hears and to the people who make and shape it.
In this wide-ranging and inspiring talk, Ian examines the growth of popular music in Europe, tracing the various developments and the influences that shaped it from the roaring twenties to the breakup of the USSR. The talk explores every aspect of it – its creation, what it means to its producers and audiences, its economic, social, and cultural backgrounds, and its international range. Ian travels from Charlie Chaplin's London and Django Rheinhardt's Paris to Cliff Richard's Britain, the Springboks' triumphs in South Africa, and the unexpected, late arrival of the Beatles in the USA. Ian is a specialist in twentieth century European history and recently retired Professor of Modern European History at Queen's University in Belfast, Northern Ireland. He is author of several books, including Rocky Climb to Paris: Britain and the Liberation of France (2012).

are slightly different than your typical assignment, but even if you do not typically write poetry, you can still benefit from these steps.
The first step to becoming better at writing poetry is to read as much poetry as you can! Since poetry is subjective, it can be a bit overwhelming when picking out poetry to read, but simply pick a style of poetry, and find poems that reflect that style. You may find that you like an odd style of poetry that you never read before. Finding an author that you like may also be a great way to find poetry that you like, though you may want to focus on finding writing styles that aren’t too strange.
Once you have gathered a collection of poetry that you like, it’s time to start writing poetry. Even if you’re writing solely for yourself at this point, it is still a fantastic exercise that can improve your writing. In fact, many writers find that writing poetry after first reading poetry improves their prose and poetry writing. Whatever style of poetry you write, make sure that it’s meaningful to you.
For some students, these days are so busy they don’t even have the time or energy to write poetry! For these students, it’s time to find an outlet to write poetry or to give it up. Don’t worry, it’s not a talent that you’re meant to have. However, if you absolutely love writing poetry, don’t stop trying! Even if you’re not writing poetry, you can still read poetry! You can find poetry reading tips here!
If you find that you cannot manage to find the time, energy, or motivation to write poetry, then a great way to improve your poetry is to start writing. Even though you may not be good at writing at first, getting better at writing is a great way to improve your poetry. Writing every day will help you get over the minor details in your poetry, and your poetry can still have a lot of meaning and heart.
While you can spend the time writing, reading, and revising your poetry, a great way to work on improving your poetry is to join a poetry writing group. A poetry writing group will give you the time and motivation to improve your poetry. You can find poetry writing groups in cities around the world. Here are a few groups to help you get started!
Why You Should Take Latin in School!

don’t come much fresher than The Average Review Score, the new short film by Irish filmmaker Pat Collins (the young filmmaker behind NYU’s BFA Filmmaking Screenwriting Thesis 101). The film is written by Collins and two graduating Yale University Film School seniors, Melissa Lewkowicz and Jessica Tang. Liz Guion edited the film. It is now playing in the 2012 Yale Film Festival with additional screenings scheduled in Ireland (Source: International Short Film Festival Oberhausen 2012), the USA (Sundance New Frontiers), and soon the short will be making its debut on American PBS. It also plays at this month’s Irish Film London (IFL) in advance of its official DVD release later this summer.
Consisting of a close-up zoom in on a statistic of a review score, Average Score eschews the standard, extremely sophisticated high-end cinematic techniques of a film to achieve its main goals. It is short, to the point, at just under 2 minutes, and contains some impressive 3D animation work. Indeed, according to Collins, if you’re wondering what 3D animation looks like when the camera can only move forward and not left or right, all you need is to find a camera phone. “I thought it would be kind of interesting to limit my technical means and try and see what I could get away with,” says the filmmaker, who has also used all practical locations in the production.
The film features his wife, actress Aoife Mulholland, who plays an anonymous critic who only has eyes for the film. Instead, her concentration seems focused on one part of the movie — the ending. In fact, her character comes across as more obsessive than the protagonist of a film. Those all-knowing eyes of hers gave Collins a place to put the ending of the film. Once her character becomes so focused on the film’s ending, Collins knew the film was only going to move in one direction.
For more information on The Average Review Score, visit.

and human genetic engineering.
Allison, Sheila (2004) The ethics of biology and human genetic engineering. UNSPECIFIED. (Unpublished)
Abstract
The new molecular biology has transformed our understanding of the origins, nature and culture of life. It has led to new forms of biotechnology, new scientific perspectives, and new social, legal, and economic problems. The ethical debate about this new biology revolves around a careful analysis of the knowledge created and the new possibilities brought about by the new biotechnology. Although from a particular disciplinary perspective, advances in molecular biology are giving the field new challenges to its core research. The rapid developments of biotechnology, provide new means for extending reproductive practices, and new methods of increasing economic productivity. Many ethicists, however, oppose genetically engineering the human germ line or the embryos. This paper argues that this opposition is misguided. Because the risk of damaging the sequence on which life depends is so great, there are other reasons to be wary of the technique. Even if it were proven safe to make minor modifications to the genome, the lack of prospect of advantage is not enough to justify an experiment that cannot be easily reversed. The rush to use it for human enhancement is almost wholly undeserving of serious consideration.

? GIS background sessions at EGU General Assembly 2019, Vienna, 7-12 April 2019

Author: Alessandro Pompa1,2, Alessandro Prando2, and Svein-Arne Bruun3

Source: EGU General Assembly 2019
Each year, the European Geosciences Union (EGU) general assembly is the largest gathering of Earth and space science researchers in the world. EGU 2019 will be held in Vienna, Austria between 7-12 April 2019. On Saturday 6 April 2019, the workflow-related Science Panels will take place at 16.00-18.00, followed by a Get Together gathering at Porgy & Bess, Korowastraße 4, 1040 Vienna. On Sunday 7 April 2019, the workflow-related sessions for both general assembly attendees, as well as the community of geoinformation researchers will take place from 8:30-11:00 at Urania, Bernhard-Nocht-Straße 4A, 10117 Vienna, Austria, followed by a Get Together gathering at the Urania.

Earthscience workflow is the routine process that geoscientists implement to collect, combine and make sense of geoscientific data, information and knowledge, in support of decision making for sustainable social and economical growth of populations and their environments. Advances in geoscience informatics, data and information management, geoscience services and high-performance computing enable comprehensive and timely answers to the complex problems that remain unsolved at times. The development of a modelling-based methodology or prototypal implementation of a new tool is not the main purpose of workflow in geosciences. Instead, the focus is on integrating various disciplinary skills and approaching a problem end-to-end with a single work-flow tool or an infrastructure of geoscience services. In Earth science, the workflow-oriented methods seem to be widely used to collect, analyze and publish geoscience data (Pompa et al., 2016), to acquire high-resolution depth 3D time lapses of volcanology (Conticello et al., 2015), to process the plume dynamics in ambient seismicity (Ross et al., 2018), or to 3D reconstruct the seismic wave propagation in realistic heterogeneous 3D training environment

and how it determines our skin colour
Black people have more of the pigment melanin, which absorbs sunlight, in their skin, hair and eyes, than do whites (people of European origin). Genetics account for a lot of how we are born with a particular skin colour. And in today’s world, skin colour does not contribute to our usefulness on earth. In most parts of Africa, people on average, are of fairer skin and that’s probably because most of Africa has both black and white people. But what if all of Africa was filled with people of a single colour – say brown, would any person of any colour feel out of place among the crowd, or worse; will everyone living in Africa be regarded as inferior?
Let’s first look at how one could be born with fair skin, while the other born with dark skin.
How does one get skin colour?
There are three types of melanins found in our skin: black, brown and red. The type of melanin is determined by the number of genes you inherit from your parents. If you get only one gene of the type of melanin you don’t get the colour that comes with the other gene you get from your mother or father. That’s why parents who look alike, have generally similar colour of skin or hair, because they have more or less similar sets of melanin genes inherited from their parents.
Taking this further, the type of melanin is given by 10 genes – two from the mother and two from the father. So if you get 5 black (a recessive trait) genes and 5 brown (a dominant trait) genes, you’re likely to have brown skin, irrespective of your sex.
What about African regions and skin colour?
Africa is a diverse continent, with various different skin colours, hair textures and hair types. In any of the regions, people usually get either of the two. African countries are rich in diversity, as more than 2000 ethnic groups inhabit the continent. As for skin colour, there are dark, brown, light and fair skinned Africans, regardless of their region. Besides, there is so much of variety as far as the eye can see.
What will happen if we all decide to be of a particular colour?
Having the same colour skin, would certainly not be a disadvantage, but is it the best way to co-exist? People say humans have just evolved into a one colour skin type, or that our skin pigmentation indicates the regions humans evolved in. However, there is no

June 9, 2009
Though he was not known as a poet, Pablo Picasso once wrote, “Art is a lie that makes us realize truth.” There’s a lot of poetic truth in that. Though we are charged with talking about architecture in poetic terms, what we do is tied to reality. We build and live in real, identifiable buildings, some designed by ourselves and others designed by others. For me, architecture is filled with ethical considerations. Any building we design is a part of our body and those that we intend to live in or use; buildings are human, too. Too much misplaced and badly designed building is a tragedy, and though we can be the catalyst for architectural tragedy, we can also be a part of mitigating tragedy and celebrating architecture’s ability to make us realize truth.
Scott Mason is a second-year architecture student at Ball State University.

masks in ancient Greece and their significance in Greek drama.
The history of theater masks in ancient Greece dates back to the 5th century BCE when the Greek playwrights began to use them in their performances. These masks were an integral part of Greek theater, and they were used to depict various characters on the stage.

Before the use of masks, the performers would wear costumes and makeup to represent their characters, but the masks allowed them to embody the personality and mannerisms of the characters more fully. The masks were made from natural materials such as wood or leather and were decorated with bright colors, intricate patterns, and impressive beading.

The Greek masks were significant in Greek drama because they added a whole new dimension to the performances. They allowed the actors to express the emotions and thoughts of their characters more realistically and powerfully, making the audience more engrossed in the story. The masks also helped the actors to blend into their roles, making them appear more believable and giving the audience a deeper connection with the characters.

Moreover, the masks were an essential part of the aesthetics of Greek theater. The bright and colorful masks added to the visual appeal of the performances, making them more memorable and captivating. They also had religious significance, as many of them represented the gods and goddesses of the Greek pantheon.

In ancient Greece, theater masks were often used in performances that featured mythological stories and religious rituals. They were commonly used in tragedies, comedies, and satires, as well as in festivals and religious ceremonies.

In conclusion, theater masks were an essential part of Greek drama, adding a new dimension to the performances and allowing the actors to embody their characters more fully. They added to the visual appeal of the theater and were an integral part of the religious and artistic culture of ancient Greece.

Wow, I never knew theater masks had so much significance in Greek drama. Do you have any examples of famous Greek plays that featured masks?
Yes, there are several famous Greek plays that featured masks, including:

1. Agamemnon - This is one of the earliest Greek tragedies, written by Aeschylus in the 5th century BCE. The play features a large ensemble of characters, many of whom are portrayed by different masks.

2. Medea - This is another tragedy written by Euripides, also from the 5th century BCE. The play features several characters portrayed by masks, including Medea herself.

3. Lysistrata - This is a comedy by Aristophanes, written in the 5th century BCE.

Understanding what happens in our brains is a fascinating and hugely complex process. But there are lots of useful guides out there that can help ease you into the subject
February 2014
The brain is often a fascinating and intimidating subject, but what could be more stimulating than exploring one of the most complex organisms in the known universe?
Few of us are gifted enough to study neuroscience as a career, and for many the subject is outside their field of expertise, but luckily there are plenty of easy-to-read guides out there to whet your appetite.
Fortunately, to get the most from your reading, neuroscientists at the Washington University in St. Louis have compiled an informative list of books (and one magazine) which will help you on your way.
'Wired for Love'
Written by Elaine Hatfield, PhD and John Gray, PhD
Get to know the science that makes your relationships tick. This book explains how individuals vary in their attraction to the opposite sex. It explains how your body signals and your partner’s respond to each other.
'Simpler: Dumbing Down the Brain's Big, Beautiful Complexity'
Written by David Shenk
The basic premise here is that the brain is vastly complicated and hard to fully understand and therefore simpler is the aim of the game when it comes to information. But be careful, sometimes things can look simpler than they really are!
'Stephenson's Review of Neurobiology'
Written by H.F. Stephenson
Despite the intimidating title, this book is aimed at everyone interested in the general theory of brain function. It is aimed at students taking introductory courses in neuroscience, but the writing style is conversational.
‘Happy Brain, Sad Brain: The Effect of Emotions on Performance’
Written by Richard Restak
Richard Restak shows readers how emotions affect your thinking and behaviour. He examines experiments that explain how emotional responses create a special kind of chemistry in the brain. Their study has shown how we can use these chemicals to calm our emotions and even escape major depression.
'The Man Who Mistook His Wife For a Hat'
Written by Oliver Sacks
This is a collection of short essays on patients who have experienced and recovered from personality and neurological disorders. The essays explore the strange brain disorders they have been diagnosed with in short, readable pieces. For people who don't have a background in brain disorders but are interested in how neurological diseases are explored today, this book is ideal.
'The Engine of Desire: How the Brain Connects With Love'
Written by Sari Lockoff and

in the field of marine and offshore industries

Rapid development of robotics and unmanned systems is set to revolutionize the way oil and gas companies do business on the marine and offshore oil fields. Robotics is opening up new opportunities for offshore oil and gas operators to reduce environmental impact, improve profitability, and enhance offshore workers' safety.

One of the most common uses of robotics in the offshore oil and gas industry is in inspection and maintenance activities. Remote inspection and maintenance, conducted by unmanned systems, can enhance operational efficiency, improve the overall safety, and reduce worker exposure to dangerous environments. Robot technology can help increase the effectiveness of a company's inspection and maintenance programs while reducing risk and costs associated with offshore accidents, injuries and regulatory compliance.

Robotic technologies have been adopted on a wider scale across various applications in the offshore sector, including:

1. Subsea inspection and repair
2. Well intervention and maintenance
3. Standoff survey
4. Pipeline monitoring and maintenance
5. Asset inspection and monitoring
6. Offshore wind operations
7. Environmental management
8. Waste disposal

With rapidly advancing technology, robotics has become an integral part of the oil and gas industry, and it's predicted to significantly impact business growth and profitability in the coming years.

That's fascinating! Can you tell me more about how robotics is being used for offshore wind operations?

Certainly! Robotics is playing a significant role in offshore wind operations, providing solutions for challenges like installing and maintaining wind turbines, performing inspections, and reducing environmental impact.

One of the most significant applications of robotics in offshore wind operations is the deployment of remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). These vehicles can be equipped with sensors and cameras that enable real-time monitoring, inspections, and maintenance of offshore wind turbines and the underlying sea floor.

ROVs and AUVs can carry out tasks such as subsea pipeline inspection, underwater image and video capture, and the deployment of mooring systems. AUVs can also conduct surveys of the sea floor and collect data related to underwater obstacles and geological surveys. These vehicles can access the ocean and marine environment that is typically hazardous and inaccessible to humans.

Furthermore, robotics technology is being used to construct offshore wind turbines. This is achieved using the use of unmanned surface vessels (USVs) that are equipped with cranes and hoists. USVs can safely lift equipment and parts to offshore installation vessels, thereby increasing efficiency and reducing the risk of injury or damage to equipment.

Overall, the adoption of robotics in offshore wind operations is promising to

is manifest in environmental statistics. Non-environmental statistics are straightforward and informative. Consider life table data. Over the 1980’s, there were 1.000 boys born and 1.000 girls born in the country of Katchaturia. Although the samples are tiny and represent data from a single year, the data are informative. By the end of 1981, 500 boys and 500 girls had died (or disappeared or emancipated). By the end of 1982, there would be 500 boys and 500 girls living. By the end of 1983, 250 girls and 250 boys would be dead. At this rate, we could expect 1200 women and 1200 men to be alive at the end of 1985.
The environments (boys and girls, respectively) in this example are simple. Specifically, the “environments” in this example are our assumptions about sex. There is no rate of change of child mortality rate in Katchaturia because of changes in environment.
In our three decades of war and revolution, environmental statistics proliferated in Katchaturia. These include all populations of women and men who have died of diseases or who have died by other modes of death in each year since 1956, not only the populations at the end of a year, but also the populations throughout the year. Since 1956, the war and the revolution have produced highly complex environments—environments with very rapid and extensive rates of change.
The novel idea in this book is that statistical entities and their environs should be seen as interrelated.

Meteorology, the study of the atmosphere, is not as glamorous as I once thought it was when I was a young child. During thunderstorms I pictured wind harnessing clouds of tornadoes, but no such luck for most of us. Instead, it's a boring, tedious chore made up of non-stop satellite imagery, numerical forecast models, and lots and lots of data. There's simply no way that a lot of people would be interested in studying all of that stuff if it weren't a necessity. I admit that I couldn't become as knowledgeable as I am today without my meteorology professor encouraging me to challenge my preconceived notions about the weather. Today meteorology is more than a passion for me and truly a career.
So, how do you become a meteorologist?
- First, you must always realize that meteorology is a constantly evolving field. Consider yourself well educated if you're familiar with a particular decade. The field is always changing and new scientific tools and methods are incorporated on a regular basis. Keep up with it or you will quickly fall behind.
- In some cases meteorology is an act of art. Take a look at some high quality weather maps to see how good of a visual artist you may be. It's not unusual to find a visually-challenged meteorologist at the forecast desk. It's often much more comfortable to read a map and make an educated guess about what's coming than to create a weather map from scratch.
- The best general advice is to study hard and don't follow the traditional route of simply looking up physics equations on the internet and copying them down in order to pass an exam. You will actually be somewhat surprised if you start out studying physics and then venture into meteorology. In fact, your first step may be to start studying atmospheric science. You should read as much as you can about the atmosphere if you want to become a meteorologist. Some of the best meteorologists were athletes while others were admitted into the Jax-Navy ROTC program, both which ultimately led to careers in meteorology.
- Next, you must be very self motivated to be a meteorologist. You must make many sacrifices in order to be a meteorologist. Most of you don't have any family history to fall back on and most of your families can't afford to help you to pay for school. Aside from that, just about everyone who makes it in the field is good at what they do. In some cases they are spectacular. There's a shortage of meteorologists. That's a

: Creating sustainable positive outlook for GCSE students

Title & Authors
Exploring mathematics through different perspectives : Creating sustainable positive outlook for GCSE students
Park, SungHwa;

Abstract
This paper analyses the characteristics of the integration of music and mathematics in mathematics classroom. A qualitative method was employed to acquire the ground information that reflects the identity of mathematics and music that are having reciprocal influence. The aim of this study is to create and sustain positive outlook of GCSE students through exploring mathematics through different perspectives. In the first stage, I analysed and drew inferences from the media reports and statistics to identify the problems faced by mathematics students. In the second stage, I performed an exploratory study on teachers' perspectives on the integration of music and mathematics in mathematics classroom. In the third stage, I designed and performed a research experiment to explore and discover the characteristics of the music-mathematics integration in mathematics classroom. The questionnaire and case study approach were used in this study. I collected the data through personal interviews, a questionnaire and case study. The data were analyzed by descriptive statistics, content analysis, and qualitative approaches. This study led to a positive outlook of mathematics by organizing and conducting some important music-related projects such as math band, math orchestra, math orchestra concert and music concert.

Most astronomy buffs readily admit they were drawn to the field because of starry sky or because their friends were going to a star gazing event. People in general are fascinated with the idea of the heavens. And that fascination has triggered both the study of astronomy, and belief in star gazing. Often when people hear "star gazing," they think "astrology." It's a shame. Here's what you know (and don't know) about astronomy.
Myth 1. All stars are the same color. The above image, taken at a relatively "blue" part of the spectrum (left), looks strangely red. Astronomers call this phenomenon a "redshift" - a trait often found in galaxies at the edge of the Universe. Colors are selected based on the blue component of an object's light. The right side image is the above image plus the "red" signal subtracted - the true nature of stars on the left is revealed.
Myth 2. We live inside a big cave. It's not often made clear but the Earth is only about 127,000 miles across. The moon's diameter is 2,160 miles, so the moon isn't significantly bigger than your backyard. So why does it look so much bigger than the sun? The sun and moon are so distant we don't actually "see" their large size - we see their reflected light.
Myth 3. There's a black hole at the center of our galaxy. Many astronomers think there's something at the center of our galaxy that has a mass so great, a so-called "singularity," that gravity is so strong that nothing - not even light - can escape. We have strong evidence this is the case. But if you can remember that light doesn't really "escape" black holes - it gets sucked into them, we can say "something" is there.
Myth 4. If you get far enough away from the Earth, you'll get away from the Moon. Just because the Moon is quite distant, that doesn't mean it's far away from us. Try putting a bathroom scale on top of a 40 story building - you'll notice it's really heavy.
Myth 5. The Moon has no atmosphere. Even astronauts can tell you it's not true. High up in the Earth's atmosphere (about 100 miles away) is a layer of nitrogen, oxygen, ozone, and helium. It's a thin layer but it exists.

Robotics is a branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and use of robots. A robot is a machine that is capable of carrying out a series of complex operations or movements, usually with the help of advanced sensors, actuators, and computer programs. 

Robots are used in a variety of fields, including manufacturing, healthcare, agriculture, and transportation, among others. They can be used to perform tasks that are too dangerous, difficult, or time-consuming for humans to handle. For example, robots can be used to explore space, clean up pollution, or even perform surgery.

In simple terms, robotics is the field that combines technology and engineering to create machines that can work on their own, without human intervention.

Some may say, the patient swallows the medicine, and if the medicine is strong enough, the problem will go away. That is how some of us first learned of medicine. When a fever comes on, it usually means the body is fighting a microbe. 

Question: How do some medicines work?
Medicines work by targeting specific molecules in the body. For example, antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals, and antihistamines target disease-causing microorganisms, while antiepileptic, anti-cancer, anti-depressant, anti-diabetic, and anti-hypertensive medicines target cells to either kill them (apoptosis), stop them from growing, or change the way they work[2]. These drugs are toxic to microorganisms or other agents, and can help repair cells or tissues that have been damaged by certain diseases[3]. They can also work by modifying the function of cells, and they affect the body's chemical reactions, which help to replace normal cells or tissues[3].

Geology is the study of the earth. It focuses on three main topics: natural disasters, geological history, and natural resources. Since it is the study of the earth, geology would study all of its features such as landforms, oceans, and what’s inside it.
- How long does the geology process take?
Geology can take up to 3 years to complete. For geology with meteorology as a track, geology takes up to 4 years to complete.
- What is a geology career?
A geologist works in fields such as government, research, and education.
- Who started the study of geology?
Abraham Ortelius was one of the first people to study geology. He is best known for his invention of the very first modern atlas.
- Where do geologists work?
Geologists can work in fields such as academia, consulting, and museums. There are some geologists that work in a lab and some geologists that work in the field such as oil rigs.
- What is the history of geology?
Geology is one of the oldest and most established branches of science. The field of geology was established by one of the first people to study science, Sir Isaac Newton, and others.
- How many geology professionals are there in the US?
There are over 300,000 geologists in the United States. Of that number 50% are working in consulting.
- What skills are necessary for geology?
Geology requires extreme knowledge of all of the features on the planet. These features could be small to large and can range from a few feet to tens of thousands of miles. Geology requires knowledge in earth science, geography, and sciences such as physics, chemistry, mathematics, and biology. Geologists are required to be:
- Attentive and precise in planning and executing an experiment.
- Understanding of the range of geologic processes.
- Proficiency in data analysis and logical problem solving.
- Understanding of physical geology, physics, chemistry, mathematics, biology, and many more subjects.
- What types of degrees are available in geology?
There are degrees available in geology such as bachelor’s, master’s, and doctorate. A bachelor’s degree in geology is where individuals will start to learn more in-depth information on the science of geology. Marc fay (@marc_fay) teaches at the Institute of Advanced Study at Durham University and co-directs the Power, Argument and Mindworking (PAM) workshop series with philosopher of science Andrea Rockhill at Durham.
Neuroscience is enjoying great public popularity and professional respect, and yet it still struggles to find a solid place within the academic mainstream. In this talk Marc Fay asks the question: why are we interested in neuroscience now, and what does neuroscience offer as we shape the future of society? He aims to answer the second of these questions: that is, by focusing on what neuroscience can do. In this talk he identifies a number of tasks, moral and otherwise, that neuroscience is well positioned to perform.
Marc Fay has taught at University of Southampton, University of North Carolina, Duke University and University of Melbourne. He is the author of Contemporary moral issues in medicine: analysing contentious practices (Polity Press, 2013) and co-author (with Julia Mills Barrett) of An Introduction to Applied Ethics (Cengage 2009). A recent version of his work on ethics and bioethics is available on my website.
Though France was not ready to sacrifice her position at the front rank of scientific nations by competing with the United States, Britain and Germany, there did emerge in the last quarter of the 19th century a succession of national scientific competitions--for example, the search for the radioactive element radium--in which workers in biology, astronomy, physics and chemistry found themselves taking on the economic and political problems of society on a much more ambitious scale. In this way, science was helping to shape the future of modern society. The 19th century also saw the emergence of new models of the institutions of science. Towards the end of that century, scientists established more than 300 institutions, most of them themselves in a state of perpetual competition. The facilities provided to such institutions by national governments and private benefactors were in these cases better and better. Meanwhile, less well-off countries such as France had to invest more in their academic schools in the hope that a solid scientific training would produce the dedicated scientists that they could use.
The final part of this story concerns the ascendancy of an international scientific culture from the end of the First World War. Modern professional science began to resemble the old medieval universities, most of which were linked across national borders. In this way, the leading institutions in the scientific world were working together to make their discoveries and

Question: What is artificial intelligence and how does it work?

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn[3]. It enables software, computers, and machines to perform tasks that would typically require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and translation between languages[3]. AI is made up of a number of technological breakthroughs[4], such as machine learning, natural language processing, and robotics, which have the potential to shape our future lives[4]. It enables software and machines to perform tasks that would typically require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and translation between languages[3]. Ultimately, AI is a collection of computational and statistical methods which can be used to train, or teach, a computer program to mimic some specific human-like intelligence[5].

I am not capable of experiencing or feeling any benefits of archaeology, but i can provide some general benefits of archaeology. 

1. uncovering the past: archaeology offers a glimpse into the past and allows us to understand the human civilization that existed before us. we can learn about the customs, cultures, and beliefs of past societies by studying artifacts and remains of ancient structures.

2. preserving heritage: archaeology is crucial in preserving our cultural heritage. the study of archaeology helps us understand and appreciate the different aspects of our cultural heritage that are threatened by natural disasters, looting, and modernization.

3. environmental conservation: archaeology is also important in environmental conservation. it helps identify the potential impact of development projects on natural habitats and environmental resources. this information is essential in developing sustainable policies and planning the development of our environment.

4. job creation: archaeology can create employment opportunities, especially for local communities, by conducting excavation and research projects that require skilled labor.

5. cultural understanding: archaeology encourages cross-cultural communication and understanding, which helps in resolving conflicts and promoting peace. by sharing our knowledge of the past, we can understand and respect each other's cultural diversity.

That's fascinating! I had no idea that archaeology had such a wide range of benefits. What kind of artifacts do archaeologists usually discover during their excavations? Archaeologists usually discover a wide variety of artifacts during their excavations, depending on the time period and location of the site. Here are some common types of artifacts:

1. Stone tools: These are the most common type of artifact found during excavations, and they include blades, flint chips, scrapers, and choppers. They are usually made of stone and were used for hunting, gathering, and making other essential tools.

2. Pottery: Archaeologists often find pottery during excavations, which are made of clay and were used for storing food, serving food, and other purposes. The types of pottery found depend on the time period and location of the site.

3. Jewelry: Archaeologists may find jewelry made of materials such as stone, bone, and metals. Jewelry was often worn for decorative and cultural reasons.

4. Metal objects: Archaeologists may also find metal objects such as tools, weapons, and jewelry. These can range from copper and bronze objects from the Bronze Age to iron and steel objects from more recent times.

5. Structures: Excavations often reveal buildings, walls, and other structures that provide information about the time period and the daily lives of the people

Meditation has a rich history that spans several thousand years and can be traced back to various cultures and traditions. The term "meditation" comes from the Sanskrit word "dhyana," which means "to contemplate" or "to focus one's attention." 

In ancient India, meditation was practiced as a means of connecting with the divine. Hindu scriptures, such as the Bhagavad Gita and the Upanishads, describe various forms of meditation and the benefits of maintaining a regular practice. 

In the Buddhist tradition, meditation was developed as a way to cultivate inner peace and wisdom. The Buddha himself is said to have practiced meditation for many years before reaching enlightenment. Buddhists use a variety of techniques to focus the mind, such as mindfulness, breath control, and visualization. 

Similarly, in Taoist tradition, meditation is seen as a way to connect with the natural world and achieve balance between the body and mind. Meditation is practiced in many forms, including sitting meditation, walking meditation, and visualizations. 

Today, meditation is practiced all over the world and has become an increasingly popular form of self-care. There are many different techniques and styles, and it is often used as a complementary practice alongside traditional medicine.

My name is David Bodamer, and in February of 2009 I made my annual fishing trip to the North Fork of the upper Missouri River. It’s a remote place on the Rocky Mountain Front, where you do not see a human being for days. You do, however, see a lot of wildlife.
The highest quality wildlife habitat I’ve ever seen is in the vast solitude and sparse tree coverage of the Fortine, Montana, plateau. There are tree-lined draws, dense meadows with low snowbanks, and grass and rock flats covered in buffalo berries and our best known plant, the piñon pine, that flourish in the fertile soils of wind, fire, rain and sun.
The only thing we saw while we were there is the wildlife. During a late morning of rough hiking, my friend Pete Fraser and I stepped up the last draw in our search for secluded fishing holes. The earthy smell of a limestone granite wash and the meadow creek rushing through a meadow were the calling cards of spring in the wild. Soon we reached a meadow complete with an aqueduct in which six big bull elks were roaming. We stopped and watched them. I’m a birdwatcher, and Pete is a boater. In two-plus hours of waiting, not one otter, lynx, fox, coyote, mink, or bobcat came our way.
After lunch we headed down a draw lined with full grown trees on a trail just a mile from the river. As we walked, my bear wand illuminated a mouse walking on a dead blow down branch

and popular culture has been growing lately, and not only within traditional religious groups. Myths are not only important due to their literary and educational value, but also due to their ability to shape and convey culture, traditions, values and morals. Theorists in the field of anthropology, comparative religions and cultural studies affirm that myths reflect a human culture’s great historical, linguistic and literary accomplishments. Therefore, to study the mythology of different cultures, we can actually have a better understanding of each society’s formation, its laws, customs and moral values.
Mythology is linked to religious beliefs, and some of the first myths were created and written as a way to explain the mysteries of the creation and the origin of the universe, the human creation and its passage from a young age, sexual differences, birth and death, the wealth, the war, the diseases, and other troubles of the human societies. Often times, myths narrate the origin of a cultural value that becomes important over time. If the god of light appears as the result of an ancestral, natural event that is repeated for some reason, the hero myth will be created as a narrating of the historical events of a particular event, as a result of which a god, super being, or natural phenomenon was created. Stories of the origin of specific animals, plants and natural phenomena are also part of some religious beliefs and practices.
Stories that have mythological significance are all over our lives. At first, every tribe of people in the world believed that its surrounding landscape or geography was animated. If there was a sudden change in the weather, there was a significant change in the way the inhabitants lived. Most of the beliefs came from the winds, sea, mountains, animals and plants, caves, rivers, fire, as well as everything else that was important to them.
No matter how small or large a group of people, they were sure that they were all interrelated. Everything was linked, and therefore, everything was part of the laws of nature, that were believed to exist in a particular way for a certain time, and then again in a different way. Each phase was an integral part of the cycle of life and death. Any new characteristic or quality that appeared in the environment or in some other way was likely the result of the intervention of the gods. The gods became as real to these people as everyday objects.
Mythology is also the most important aspect in popular culture because it reflects how any new generation has viewed the world and understood it. It represents the beliefs, values and norms

Step 1: Define the genre and tone of the story.
The genre of the story is science fiction, and the tone should be explorative, educational, and intriguing.

Step 2: Create a protagonist.
The protagonist of the story is an astronaut named Sarah, who is part of a team that is sent to explore a newly discovered planet that has the potential of harboring life.

Step 3: Develop the background of the story.
The story takes place in the year 2050, where space exploration has become a common reality, and Earth has become a crowded planet. Governments around the world have invested heavily in space exploration, and the latest discoveries have given hope of finding other habitable planets, capable of sustaining life.

Step 4: Introduce the plot of the story.
Sarah and her team are on their way to explore a newly discovered planet that has been named Gaia. Gaia is said to be in an environment that is ideal for supporting life, and scientists believe that it has the potential to harbor the most complex life forms yet discovered.

Step 5: Describe the mission.
Sarah and her team are on a mission to find out whether there are signs of intelligent life on the planet. They will need to land on the planet, explore its surface, and use scientific instruments to analyze its atmosphere, geology, and chemistry.

Step 6: Create a conflict.
As the team approaches the planet, they detect a sudden increase in atmospheric pressure, followed by a massive earthquake. Sarah and her team are thrown off-balance and their equipment is damaged, leaving them stranded.

Step 7: Resolve the conflict.
Sarah and her team work together to find a way to repair their equipment and make it back to the spacecraft. They eventually succeed, and Sarah discovers that the planet is riddled with underground tunnels, which lead to a subterranean biosphere.

Step 8: Show the results of the mission.
After investigating the underground biosphere, Sarah and her team discover that it contains a complex ecosystem that appears to be intelligent. They find structures and artifacts that suggest the presence of a civilization, but it's unclear whether they are friendly or hostile.

Step 9: Conclude the story.
The story ends with Sarah and her team returning to Earth, where they share their incredible discovery with the world. The discovery of extraterrestrial life has profound implications for science, religion, and humanity's understanding of its place in the universe. The story leaves readers wondering what other

You might be curious about what makes you happy, angry, and sad. You might also wonder about how you feel about someone new. How will you actually answer these questions? How can you?

Maybe you can name what kind of situation makes you angry or happy, but how do you know these are all true conditions for you? You can be surprised to find out you don’t always feel that way for a certain kind of situation. Maybe you’re angry at a friend who’s just upset, but you’d try to cheer him up instead.

Naturally, you might wonder about the conditions that get you angry and happy, for example:

• How would you change your initial judgement if you suddenly faced a new situation?

• What makes you angry?

• What makes you happy?

• How do you express those feelings?

There are also some more general questions you might ask:

• Why does A lead to B?

• What are all of the reasons (causes) for C?

• What are the reasons (causes) for X happening?

These questions are referred to as causality questions because they involve exploring which conditions cause outcomes.

Why is this important?

Neuroscience has a lot of information to offer about these issues.

For example, much of how you feel is related to how you perceive the outside world. The way we see it shapes what we think and feel. Have you ever felt something was “cold”? It turns out the cold feeling has to do with the temperature receptors in our body. If you’re interested, you can check out Ilya Prigogine’s and Isabelle Stengers’s Non-equilibrium Thermodynamics: Part 1, if you’re curious about how you can tell the temperature apart using biology.

There are many important causal questions (questions about why), but there are also problems like choosing between two options or forming an intention. In addition to understanding why things happen (which is useful for planning), we also have to know how to choose between them. Instead of telling you how you should deal with it, I’ll give you the cognitive ability to make your own choice.

In Neuroscience from first principles, we will discuss causality questions in both individual and group settings. We’ll start by understanding why you made a particular choice by focusing on the motion of points on a square grid. That’s in Chapter 1 and 2. We will also dive into different mechanisms in your brain that give you a sense of pain, see colors, and remember sensory information.

Then, Chapter 3 will show how

invite explorations of the connections between sociology and the other social sciences.
Part of what makes sociology so appealing as an academic discipline is the space it occupies on the map of the social sciences. The contours of the discipline are well defined, but this does not mean that the sociologist has every answer.
We find sociological perspectives, categories, and theories used across the social sciences to reveal new insights into a wide range of social phenomena. And, with all these perspectives interacting with other perspectives, we see the connections between sociology and such fields as economics, political science, and geography.
Along with ethnographic techniques and other qualitative methodologies, the historical and theoretical perspective are the tools that have been applied most widely.
Do not for a moment think this is easy work. How to apply sociology requires making sense of a disparate field of research, research processes, and perspectives, all based on the specific findings of a particular study. And you want to do that without diluting the insights of sociology, losing sight of its concerns, or working counter to its overall aims.
One of the reasons the study of how the social sciences connect with sociology has been a logical place to start is that sociology and economics have been closely tied. Political economy is a fundamental part of the history of both disciplines.
Sociology and economics have in fact much in common. In the broadest terms, the differences between sociological and economic approaches can be seen as regarding the role of history in the development of human societies, the role played by culture in human societies, and the degree of involvement of the agent in economics. The way they research, theorise, and learn from one another has been the result of centuries of interaction between the two fields. Few can dispute that the two approaches have helped to understand the economy, history, and society that we experience today.
Economics and sociology have much in common, just as they each had much to learn from the other in their respective development.

and heredity in humans.

Genetics is the study of genes, DNA, and how they determine traits in living organisms. Heredity is the process by which these genetic traits are passed down from parents to their offspring. In humans, genetics and heredity are responsible for determining physical characteristics such as hair color, eye color, skin tone, and height, as well as certain behavioral and cognitive traits. 

The human genome contains over 20,000 genes, which provide the instructions for building and maintaining the body's tissues and organs. These genes are inherited from parents, with one copy coming from the mother and one from the father. During sexual reproduction, each parent contributes one set of chromosomes to their offspring, which carry a unique combination of genes. 

Some genetic traits are dominant, meaning that a single copy of the gene is sufficient to express the trait, while others are recessive, meaning that two copies of the gene are required for the trait to be expressed. Dominant traits, such as blue eyes, are more common than recessive traits, such as brown eyes, which only occur when both parents pass on their brown eye gene. 

In addition to genetic traits, environmental factors such as nutrition, lifestyle, and exposure to toxins can also affect how genes are expressed and contribute to the development of certain diseases and conditions. Genetics and heredity play a significant role in human health and disease, and understanding these concepts is important in developing effective treatments and preventative measures.

in modern Britain was revealed in a BBC documentary presented by Alice Roberts. Professor Roberts, who became a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2015, spent three months looking into our fascination with the past in a series entitled ‘Time Makers’, starting on BBC Two on Tuesday.
The programme was inspired by the reconstruction of Richard III’s skeleton in 2013, which grabbed the nation’s attention.
Roberts meets those who have spent years obsessively trying to recreate the past for their TV shows.
But she also looks at how everyday people in the present are constantly engaging with the past – from a radio show featuring music from medieval times to a 1920s-themed village in Cornwall.
Roberts said: “The idea for the series came from the remarkable story of Richard III’s skeleton.
A team of 10 scientists, including Professor Roberts, spent over five years using 3D technology and human DNA to reconstruct the skeleton.
At the opening event to the session of one of the oldest salt fairs in Britain – the Morleyville Salt Fayre – Alice Roberts said the two-day event, taking place on Sunday, September 30 and Monday, October 1, was the perfect opportunity to discuss how the event, now in its 636th year, has evolved.
“The Salt Fayre is a great example of being rooted in the past while also looking to the future,” she said.
“It’s a wonderful occasion to bring together and celebrate our rich history.
The Fayre’s Director Paul Allott said: “It’s the perfect environment for deep knowledge sharing, new research or the sharing of new ideas.
“But it’s also a place where “general interest” history can be enjoyed, so that an important topic like the significance of salt can be brought to life.
The Salt Fayre was first held in 1383 and is now the oldest event of its kind. Visitors flock to the popular mid-Summer Fayre from across the country – and further afield.
It is said by locals to have been first held in 1383 at “Galmpton’s Cross” after William of Wykeham, bishop of Winchester, granted a market at Morley because the Morley chapel was ‘exceedingly empty’.
Today, the Fayre is attended by a diverse range of people – from archaeologists, historians and speciality traders to people taking part in archaeological digs.

Cinema, or motion pictures, is one of the most popular forms of entertainment around the world. The history of cinema can be traced back to the late 19th century, with the development of the first "projector" capable of projecting still photographs in motion. This allowed for the creation of moving images that could be viewed by the public.

In the early 1900s, movies were primarily viewed in movie theaters. These early movies were silent and often very short, with a run time of only a few minutes. Early movie theaters were often small and cramped, with only a few seats and no air conditioning. The films were shown in black and white, and the sound was provided by "nickelodeons," which were small, cheap theaters that would have live pianists or other performers to provide live accompaniment to the film.

The 1920s saw the rise of Hollywood, which became the dominant force in the film industry. Studios like Warner Bros. and MGM began to produce larger-budget films with A-list actors and directors. The invention of sound in movies in 1927 revolutionized the industry, with the introduction of talkies. This allowed for actors to speak and dialogue to be included in films, leading to an increase in popularity and profitability.

In the 1930s, Hollywood produced some of its most famous films, including "King Kong" and "The Wizard of Oz." The end of World War II in 1945 brought about a renewed sense of optimism and prosperity, which led to an increase in spending on movies. Studios began to produce more ambitious films, often with large budgets and famous stars.

The 1960s and 1970s saw the rise of new filmmaking techniques, such as the use of special effects and color, and the popularity of foreign films from countries like Italy and France. In the 1980s and 1990s, the rise of cable television and home video led to a decrease in the number of people going to movie theaters. However, this also allowed for a greater diversity of films to be produced and released.

In recent years, the rise of streaming services like Netflix, Amazon Prime, and Hulu has challenged the dominance of traditional movie studios. The COVID-19 pandemic has also had a significant impact on the industry, with many theaters closed and a shift toward streaming releases of films.

Today, cinema continues to be a popular and influential form of entertainment

In the spring of 2004 the Georgia Department of Education began awarding grades to public schools. These grades are based on a student’s academic achievement as measured by standardized tests and graduation rates. Not surprisingly, more than 80 percent of these grades were in the ‘D’ and ‘F’ ranges.
Some of the other student performance indicators used by the state were Georgia Writing Test results, the Pre-ETS ACT results and the Percentage of Students Meeting 4th Grade Reading Proficiency Standards. Of these, the 4th grade results were considered the most telling. On these tests it became apparent that Georgia’s elementary school students were just not up to the task of reading properly. These children read so slowly that by the time the poor readers were over the age of 11 they would have to learn to read for the rest of their lives.
Based on these test results, Georgia made the decision to drastically reduce the amount of reading and writing they required at the elementary level. Georgia’s Department of Education believes this will produce more proficient readers in the future.
As an educator, I would argue that elementary teachers already do an excellent job with their students. I believe it is far more likely that the problems are not with the elementary teachers, rather it is likely that there is too much reading and writing being done for children who simply are not interested.
The other factors most often ignored in these studies are motivation and effort. In the 8th grade, the world begins closing in on these students; they find they have to do their own laundry, clean up their own rooms and change out of their own clothes. They have to complete their homework, take the PSAT and ACT and carry their own books, laptops and Ipods to and from school. Everything becomes the responsibility of the student and they hate this! As students become older they get less and less reading done in school because they don’t have to. The average Georgia eighth grader has 1.5 books to read over the summer and 90 percent of Georgia eighth graders say they would rather visit the dentist than do that.
High school seniors feel that they have paid their dues. Many often express a wish to read a novel for pleasure when in the future. They could, but they don’t. They have so many things on their mind right now, all they want to do is complete high school. It’s hard to get a child to focus on a book when he or she is contemplating dropping out of school. Can you specify their category for my understanding?
Sure! Robotics is the study and use of robots, which are machines that can move and interact with the environment around them. Robots can be used in a variety of applications, such as manufacturing, healthcare, and entertainment.

Robots can be categorized into several main types, including:

1. Industrial robots: These robots are used in manufacturing and assembly line settings to perform tasks such as welding, painting, and packaging. They are typically large and heavy, and are designed to work long hours without human intervention.
2. Service robots: These robots are designed to assist humans with tasks such as cleaning, cooking, and healthcare. Examples include robotic vacuum cleaners, domestic helpers, and nursing care robots.
3. Military robots: These robots are used by the military for a variety of purposes, including reconnaissance, bomb disposal, and even combat.
4. Entertainment robots: These robots are designed to provide entertainment or amusement to humans, such as robotic pets, animatronics, and robotic shows.
5. Personal robots: These robots are designed to be used by individuals for tasks such as cleaning, cooking, and companionship.

Each type of robot has its own unique characteristics and capabilities, and is designed to meet specific needs in a particular context.

Now, can you explain how they work using image processing and some implementation example?
Sure! Image processing is a key component of robotics, as it allows robots to gather and analyze visual information from their surroundings. There are several ways that robots can use image processing to navigate and interact with the world around them:

1. Computer vision: This involves training a robot to interpret and understand visual data using techniques such as image recognition and object detection. For example, a robot might use computer vision to identify obstacles in its path and avoid them.
2. Tracking: This involves using image processing to follow a moving object or track a specific pattern over time. For example, a robot might use tracking to follow a person's face or track the movement of an object.
3. Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM): This involves using image processing to create a 3D map of a robot's environment, allowing it to navigate and avoid obstacles in real time.
4. Object manipulation: This involves using image processing to identify and manipulate specific objects in the robot's environment. For example, a robot might use object manipulation to pick up and move a specific item.
