, along with our broader understanding of human psychology and mental health, has brought about some much needed changes to the way mental health conditions are identified, monitored and treated. A new kind of care that relies on science to show why people experience the conditions they do is now prevalent in healthcare systems around the world, offering individuals the option of a personalized treatment path to get better.
This kind of care is not something new, it was actually a common practice in the past, especially in Native American societies. As William Felix writes in Native American Medicine: The Art of Vitality, “A personal oral consultation was considered most effective. The principle was that the patient was consulted about his ailments; herbs were administered that corresponded with the nature of the illness; and the recovered illness was channeled into a healing ritual.” How did we lose that understanding in the West?
Apparently, that way of healing took a hard hit in the 16th century with the enforcement of mercantilism and imperialistic practices. Native American communities were displaced, and it became illegal to practice their healing traditions, sending a message to anyone thinking of acting in unison with their instinct that the consequences for challenging authority were grave. It was a cruel, dark period in time that was only more difficult for those with conditions that, at the time, were considered incurable: Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder and Insomnia are just a few examples.
Worse still, medical practitioners were not readily equipped with the knowledge needed to understand the above conditions, treating the symptoms rather than addressing the cause. In 1796, insomnia became the most common condition treated by British doctors, and a cursory look at today’s medical landscape reveals that many of the same methods are still in use, such as drug therapy and sleep patterns. Additionally, patients received little to no social support to help them cope with the condition as a whole, something that is of paramount importance for recovery.
The following is a brief look at how changing attitudes and understanding of mental health over the last 100 years have contributed to and in some cases caused the rise in mental health care and pharmaceuticals.
The Second World War, and specifically the murder of six million Jewish people, at the hands of Hitler and the Nazi party, opened the door to everyone to realize mental health was a problem that needed to be addressed.
This helped to quell the fear mongering media by changing “mentally insane” with “personality disturbances” and helping to drive the delineation between mental health and mental illness

can help you start down a road to poem writing. I myself didn’t start out writing seriously, I started writing for escape. Eventually it became a way of self expression and a way to communicate ideas. Here is some advice to get you going if you are ready for poetry, or want to increase your own poem writing skills.
Writing poetry, or any kind of composition requires perspective. This means you have to know what is going on around you at all times in your life, the places you have been and are going, the people you meet, the events that occur, etc. To write a poem, you need to be open to the world around you and let ideas come to you. Don’t worry about writing something brilliant, the more poetry you write, the better you get. Write like you would speak, let it flow, don’t analyze too much right away, just let it happen.
More than ever you need to have a goal or theme for your poem. What are you trying to say? This is important so you don’t end up with non-sequitors or other random thoughts throughout your poem. Aim your poem for a particular topic, event, person, or whatever you want to say. For example, I just wrote a poem about my relationship with my mother, I was able to flesh out certain aspects and communicate them through my poetry. Write and write and write until you are satisfied with the poem you have.
After you have written your poem don’t leave it alone, work it over again to perfect it. This doesn’t mean you should change the meaning or completely rewrite the whole thing, it’s just fine tuning. Make the words flow better, fix grammar problems, etc. I do a final read through before I show anyone to make sure my meaning is clear, all the syntax is correct, etc.
That is about all there is to writing poetry, if you follow these steps you should be well on your way. The important thing to remember is to have fun with it, allow yourself to be creative and look at things from a different perspective. Like I said before, to start you should write to write and get better as you go. Poetry can also be a very effective means of communication, find a topic or emotion you wish to express and write about it. Don’t expect it to be successful the first time, everyone starts somewhere, keep on writing.

## An ant's perspective on the world

There are many different ways that one can learn about physics, ranging from

• self-instructional learning, such as reading introductory university textbooks on physics,
• taking introductory physics classes at your local community college, or
• learning about physics from older students who may not have the background to teach.

In many cases, these different forms of instruction will teach the same physics and end up in the same place, but may use different conceptual (intuitive) and mathematical tools. Further, it is not always the case that these different paths lead to the same understanding. Often, even if the physics presented is equivalent, the approaches may not lead to identical knowledge, and some students may even think the physics presented is equivalent but have had a different understanding. In the end, it is the students and not their teachers that must determine what is equivalent.

Today's activity illustrates an example of this phenomenon in which two students, both of whom are told about the same phenomena and told about the same experiments, but who use different approaches, end up having very different understandings of it.

• George students at the University of San Diego has developed a high-tech parking meter for his bicycle. He tells us about it here. One of the lessons he learned was that understanding the physics of bicycles and the way wheels rotate is crucial in this process. Watch the video and learn more about George's parking meter.

• Jacob loves bikes, and builds bicycle-powered crazy contraptions like the one in the picture to the right. He's been working on his bike-powered generator lately and talks about the basics of how it all works. You can read more about his generator on the right.

Are George and Jacob talking about the same thing, and if so, what exactly are they talking about?

- including the simple logic of growing!
Many veg, herbs and flowers had moved into pots on the deck and onto lawn, which I didn’t water every day, and then one day my daughter came home and mowed the lawn and got watered up pots!
Imagine my disappointment to see this:
D’oh! Yes, I did spray the vinegar on the tea-bags to help them stick to the pots. But these pots and herbs weren’t quick-drying, and also I had treated the tomato pots with a copper spray last year and I didn’t think vinegar would be compatible.
Thankfully, I did have a good big top up of seaweed and fish fertilizer to help the garden to bounce back.
You can see the pots have recovered, but what I wonder is, would they have survived this without a daily watering regime on the lawn? Does a day of dryness knock back the garden or not?
If you have any thoughts or experience that you feel could help a beginner like me, I’d love to hear about it. I’m starting to collect ideas about how gardening really works! I’ve read lots of articles by people who are much more knowledgeable, but most of them are really deep thinking and so advanced you need a PhD to understand them. My desire here is to share ideas in a simple language, so we can share our thoughts about gardening from all sorts of different aspects.
Thanks everyone! I hope this is useful to you too.
Ps. Readers of my herb blog - if you’re looking for a few more ideas to stimulate your gardening in the spring and summer, you might be interested in the herb magazine I made this summer.

Machine Learning in Cutting Tool Design

Cutting tools play a crucial role in the manufacturing process, and their performance has a significant impact on the final product quality. However, designing and manufacturing high-performance cutting tools is a complex and challenging task due to various constraints and uncertainties. Machine learning techniques offer an attractive alternative to traditional methods for cutting tool design, and they are gaining increasing attention in the cutting tool industry. In this article, we will explore some of the latest machine learning techniques used in cutting tool design.

Machine Learning Techniques for Cutting Tool Design

Machine learning techniques have many applications in cutting tool design, including cutting tool geometry optimization, cutting tool performance prediction, and cutting tool failure diagnosis. Here, we will briefly discuss some of the latest machine learning techniques used in cutting tool design.

Convolutional Neural Networks for Cutting Tool Geometry Optimization

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are a class of neural networks that are commonly used for image recognition tasks. However, they have also shown promising results in other applications, such as feature extraction and pattern recognition. In cutting tool design, CNNs can be used to optimize the geometry of a cutting tool based on design variables such as cutting edge radius, rake angle, and chip thickness.

CNNs are trained using a dataset of cutting tool geometry and performance data. The training process involves two stages: feature extraction and classification. During feature extraction, the CNN learns to extract relevant features from the cutting tool geometry data. During classification, the CNN learns to classify the cutting tool geometry data into different categories based on their performance characteristics. The performance characteristics of a cutting tool include cutting force, cutting temperature, and cutting power.

Once the CNN is trained, it can be used to optimize the cutting tool geometry based on different design variables. The optimization process involves finding the design variables that maximize the performance of the cutting tool. The CNN-based optimization process can significantly reduce the computational effort required to design high-performance cutting tools.

Support Vector Machines for Cutting Tool Performance Prediction

Support vector machines (SVMs) are a popular machine learning technique used for pattern recognition and classification tasks. In cutting tool design, SVMs can be used to predict the performance characteristics of a cutting tool based on its geometry and material properties.

SVMs are trained using a dataset of cutting tool performance data and cutting tool geometry data. The training process involves finding the hyperplane that best separates the data into different categories based on their performance characteristics. # All poetry is emergent

I’ve often heard it said that all poetry is emergent. As in the sentence

There is no such thing as poetry; all writing is emergent.

But that is wrong. We can see it when it comes to using the English language to write. Reading a newspaper or other written text is far more difficult that listening to somebody talk.

This might come as a surprise to many, but that difficulty is due to the emergence of sentence structure. As Dan Sperber and Shaun Nichols put it:

There is no such thing as language; all communication is communication through [pragmatics] and [literary texts] are not language use; they are literature use. Poetry is not language; all poetry is literature.

“Communication through pragmatics” means that words (and their meanings) can depend on an embedded context, which often not what a reader or writer would normally expect. “Literature” is the single word we use to describe all creative writing, including poetry, short stories, novels, plays, and any other creative writing form.

If all writing is literature, then there is no poetry.

I’ll come to that in a minute.

But first I’d like to put a question to you. Look at the sentence:

“You sure got that fiver?”

Can you imagine anybody repeating the order that we can read in this question?

“You sure got that fiver, sure?”

(If so, please tell me in the comments.)

My hypothesis is that all reading depends on the ability of the reader to create embedded questions in their mind. This happens far too frequently for any reader to consciously notice; it’s more like something you do without thinking.

I think people do this all the time when reading, but with embedded questions, in the following sentence:

The report said that things were not so bad and that there was hope for the future.

I remember hearing about this one for the first time. A friend of mine was having a deep philosophical discussion with a priest. “Do you believe in heaven and hell?” my friend asked, and received the answer, “Yes, I do, but I don’t believe in earth and god!”

We normally don’t even notice that we create questions like that.

This got me thinking about the question whether or not all poetry is also literature.

I don’t think I can prove that all literature is poetry, but here are my arguments in favour of this point of view:

• when it comes to writing, the meaning of words, phrasing

The sun appears as a simple splash of color in the midst of natural beauty to the masses, a metaphorical reflection of the voids and contradictions within human beings. It is a path to rapture of freedom of contemplation.
